Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Nevada ballots “don’t even have to be postmarked to be counted” after the election.
Justification: Nevada requires mail ballots to be postmarked on or before Election Day and received by 5 p.m. on the fourth day after the election to be counted. It is not unusual for states to count ballots after Election Day. Results aren’t official until states certify their elections.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Montana Democratic operative was caught tampering with a ballot box.
Justification: The Glacier County sheriff's office investigated an incident in which a Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee employee was videotaped appearing to tug at a ballot box. It found the incident "does not constitute a legitimate attempt to tamper with the ballot box."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Melania Trump declares that she wants a divorce.”
Justification: This claim is "totally false," according to the Trump campaign.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk urges a boycott of ABC Network: ‘Let’s take them down!’”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site. X owner Elon Musk didn’t urge people to boycott ABC.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The government gave $3,500 debit cards to immigrants while giving only $750 to Hurricane Helene victims.
Justification: During an Oct. 2 speech, Vice President Kamala Harris said the Federal Emergency Management Agency is providing $750 in immediate aid to people affected by Hurricane Helene. In the same speech, she also said that FEMA is providing "tens of thousands more dollars" for home repairs and hotel costs. A New York City program gives prepaid debit cards to migrant families sheltering in city  hotels to spend on food and baby supplies for four weeks. The amount of money varies by family size, but is much less than $3,500 per person. For example, a family of four with two 10-year-olds would receive $1,267 for 28 days.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Taylor Swift blames Instagram for losing millions of followers after Harris endorsement: ‘It must be a glitch!”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Michael Jackson discovered alive at age 65” and will testify against Sean “Diddy” Combs.
Justification: A Facebook claiming singer Michael Jackson is alive and planning to testify at Sean "Diddy" Combs’ sex trafficking trial originated on a satire website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Videos show President-elect Donald Trump promised to help Pakistan’s former prime minister Imran Khan get out of prison and retake power.
Justification: The videos dub audio generated with artificial intelligence over 2017 interview footage. President-elect Donald Trump has neither called for Pakistan’s former prime minister Imran Khan’s release nor pledged to return him to power in Pakistan.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In Fordyce, Arkansas, voting machines changed votes from Republican to Democrat.
Justification: Voting machines in Fordyce, Arkansas, are not flipping votes from Republican to Democrat. Election workers examined the voting machine in Fordyce after a complaint was made and found no problems with it. Chris Madison, director of the Arkansas State Board of Election Commissioners, told PolitiFact such complaints often result from voter mistakes. In such instances, poll workers are notified, the ballots are spoiled and the voters are allowed to vote again.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Taylor Swift’s manager confirms: ‘Ticket sales are dead after Harris endorsement backlash.”
Justification: This didn’t happen. The purported quote originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk takes over Taylor Swift’s X account, causing her to lose 7 million followers and $100 million in brand deals.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Breaking: Voters in Tarrant County, Texas are reporting that the voting machines are flipping their votes from Trump to Kamala Harris."
Justification: Only one person out of more than 100,000 voters in Tarrant County has reported having a vote for former President Donald Trump changed to Vice President Kamala Harris when the ballot was printed. Local election officials said the voting machines are not flipping candidates and suggested the voter made a mistake when selecting preferred candidates. That ballot was destroyed and the voter was allowed to vote again.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Gwinnett County, Georgia, sheriff's office said white supremacists “are planning to attack” Black people “from now until the Inauguration.”
Justification: N/A

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “They create hurricanes via cloud seeding” and “direct them where they want the Hurricane to go!”
Justification: Cloud seeding, used to increase rain or snow in drought-stricken areas by injecting silver iodide into clouds, is the most common weather modification program in use in the U.S. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration once used cloud seeding in a decadeslong project to try to lessen the intensity of hurricanes, but the project was ended in 1983 after mixed results. There are no weather modification projects that can create or modify hurricanes, weather officials and experts said.
Sources: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Donald Trump statement condemning the Peanut the squirrel’s euthanasia
Justification: Peanut, an internet famous squirrel, was put down after New York state officials said it bit someone. A viral statement attributed to former President Donald Trump is fake. We found no evidence of the statement on Trump’s website or social media accounts. A Trump campaign spokesperson told the New York Post the statement is fake.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Ballots are not supposed to have fold lines or creases in the candidates name area” or it could invalidate your vote.
Justification: Mark Lindeman, the policy and strategy director for Verified Voting, said a crease through a candidate’s name would have no impact on tabulating machines’ ability to read a ballot. If a crease goes through the spot where voters mark their choice, multiple backup procedures ensure the vote is counted. New Hampshire conducted a recount on some 2020 ballots that were creased where the vote is recorded. But the state passed bipartisan legislation to change the scanner settings so the problem wouldn’t happen again.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Data shows some voters cast multiple votes, meaning "at least 164,568 illegal votes have been cast” in Michigan.
Justification: Michigan’s Qualified Voter File keeps registered voters’ previous addresses attached to their voter IDs, but only the most recent registered address is active. Michigan’s secretary of state said a formatting error in an early voting report from the file generated a line for each voter’s associated address, showing multiple addresses associated with the same voter ID for some. There were not multiple ballots cast and counted from the same voter ID. Only one vote can be counted with each ID, officials said. The error has been fixed.
Sources: Michigan Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson
Michigan secretary of state spokesperson Angela Benander
State of Michigan Election Fact Center

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There was an Oct. 17, 2024, hospital update about the health of Kate Middleton, Princess of Wales.
Justification: Kate Middleton, the Princess of Wales, said in a Sept. 9 video message that she finished chemotherapy for her cancer diagnosis and is cancer-free. The social media posts link to a story with previous news that Middleton had a successful abdominal surgery in January. Images in the posts are either years old or artificially generated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Taylor Swift “admits to having done immoral things with Diddy in the past to gain fame.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. We found no credible evidence, such as news reporting, public statements or interview footage to corroborate the claim that Taylor Swift confessed to something "immoral" with Sean "Diddy" Combs.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Breaking news: Elon Musk endorses Caitlin Clark, will soon donate $10 million: ‘You are the pride of America, I support you.’”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In Glynn County, Georgia, it was 'voter fraud' when poll workers found no record of a person who already voted.
Justification: A system lag in Glynn County, Georgia, meant that a person who had already cast a ballot at a different early voting site hadn’t been marked off yet, an election official told PolitiFact. The voter had not tried to vote more than once, but was at a voting site to assist a disabled person who was voting. If the person had voted twice, the system would have detected it once the system update was complete.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show that Disney World was “destroyed by Hurricane Milton.”
Justification: The photos originated from a satirical website. Walt Disney World announced Oct. 10 that its theme parks would reopen and resume normal operations Oct. 11.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk launches new pregnancy robot.”
Justification: Tesla CEO Elon Musk recently talked about the potential of the company’s Optimus robots, but we found no evidence to support the claim that he’s working on a surrogate android.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: If a ballot has a small dot in the box for Vice President Kamala Harris, “any other box filled in, will be void.”
Justification: Kentucky election officials said they had received no reports as of Nov. 4 of a premarked ballot. A small dot does not constitute a voter’s selection under state rules, and it would not invalidate a proper marking in another candidate’s selection area, election officials said. Voters can circle their preferred candidate if they accidentally mark too many boxes, and in-person voters will be notified if they try to vote for more than one candidate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Kamala Harris posing beside Sean “Diddy” Combs.
Justification: The photo was altered. The original photo was taken in 2001 and Kamala Harris was standing beside talk show host Montel Williams, whom she dated briefly at the time.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Alexa’s answers to questions about Hurricane Helene prove the storm was “artificially created” or the result of “cloud seeding”
Justification: Experts told PolitiFact Hurricane Helene was a natural disaster. It was not formed through weather modification, and there are no projects that can modify or create hurricanes. When we asked Amazon about the responses seen in the social media posts, a spokesperson responded by saying, "These answers are clearly incorrect and we are working to resolve this issue." We did not get the same responses from Alexa and when asked the same questions, Alexa replied with, "Sorry, I don’t have an answer for that," or, "I don’t know that one," or ""Hmmm, I don’t know that."
Sources: Email interview with an Amazon spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Serena Williams reportedly passes away following tragic car crash in Texas.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. Tennis star Serena Williams is alive and wasn’t involved in a purported Texas car crash.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows missing couple Raymond Peterson and his wife, Sophie.
Justification: This photo shows a couple whose remains were discovered in September in California. viral Facebook posts are misusing the image,  claiming it shows another couple supposedly missing from states around the country.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Country Music Television (CMT) has announced a permanent boycott of Taylor Swift.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Taylor Swift unexpectedly lost a $125 million brand contract after a massive advertising campaign” endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris.
Justification: Taylor Swift did not lose a $125 million brand contract after endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris' presidential campaign. The claim originated on a satirical website. PolitiFact found no credible news stories or public statements from or about Swift saying she lost millions of dollars in a brand contract by endorsing Harris.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Taylor Swift’s concert attendance drops after Harris endorsement: ‘No Fans, just empty seats and echoes.’”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site. Taylor Swift hasn’t performed on her Eras Tour since Sept. 10, when she endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris, the 2024 Democratic presidential nominee.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk silences Taylor Swift: Shocking ban wipes out 1 million followers and costs her a staggering $72 million!”
Justification: Elon Musk didn’t ban Taylor Swift from X. Her account is active.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Olympic boxer Imane Khelif fails gender test, stripped of all titles, lifetime ban and $25 million prize money revoked!”
Justification: PolitiFact reviewed Nexis news archives and Google and found no credible news reports that boxer Imane Khelif has recently failed a gender test, been stripped of her titles, been banned from boxing, or had prize money revoked. Claims that Imane Khelif is transgender are unsubstantiated. She has stated that she is female. International Olympic Committee spokesperson Mark Adams said Aug. 2 that Khelif "was born female, was registered female, lived her life as a female, boxed as a female, has a female passport."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Colin Kaepernick said he “will go to Russia if not properly respected in the United States.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Taylor Swift faces a 10-game NFL ban following controversial political involvement.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Shows video of damage from Hurricane Helene.
Justification: The clips are from previous storms in different states and different years, contained artificial intelligence-altered clips and were shared online before Hurricane Helene.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Chiefs' Coach Andy Reid criticizes Taylor Swift: ‘You’re not a good role model.’”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Elon Musk Declares: ‘Pride flags should be banned from classrooms, forever!’"
Justification: This claim originated on a satire website. There is no evidence Musk called for pride flags in classrooms to be banned.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show a toddler “saved” by Deputy Tyler Cooper.
Justification: This post isn’t authentic.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump posted “0-2” Sept. 15 on Truth Social.
Justification: We found no evidence former President Donald Trump posted "0-2" Sept. 15 on Truth Social.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Kansas City Chiefs CEO bans Taylor Swift from attending games, calling her the team’s ‘biggest distraction.’”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Breaking: Kansas City Chiefs refuse to host a Pride Night, ‘It’s woke agenda’”
Justification: This claim originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Taylor Swift forced to cancel Eras Tour dates following endorsement backlash.”
Justification: The article was originally published as satire. News reports did not say that Taylor Swift canceled any shows in her Eras Tour after endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris for president in September.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Taylor Swift’s concert tickets” fell to $75 after she endorsed Kamala Harris
Justification: Ticket prices for Taylor Swift’s remaining Eras Tour dates are more than $800, with many in the $1,000-plus range. The post links to a satire website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Federal Emergency Management Agency “is confiscating supplies and donations!”
Justification: Federal Emergency Management Agency officials and state and local leaders in Tennessee and North Carolina have rebutted claims that FEMA is "confiscating" donations or supplies meant for Hurricane Helene survivors. FEMA delivers supplies and donations to states; the states and state-designated groups distribute the supplies, including volunteer agencies that specialize in managing donated items. Officials warn that spreading baseless rumors can cause confusion, hinder emergency response and put emergency management staff at risk.
Sources: North Carolina Department of Public Safety

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Vice President Kamala Harris’ college professors disparaged her as their “worst student.”
Justification: Viral social media posts used supposed photos and quotes from Kamala Harris’ college professors that were made up. The claims originated from satire websites. The Facebook post used a photo of Bradford Grant, a Howard University architecture professor who joined the faculty in 2007. Harris studied political science and economics and graduated from Howard in 1986. The Instagram post used a photo of Jerry Sandusky, a convicted sex offender and former football coach.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos that show lists of school names are “school shooting lists.”
Justification: The lists included in social media posts show schools that receive federal Title I funding for academic programs. Authorities who have investigated these claims in communities across the U.S., including Alabama, Missouri and Nebraska have said they found the lists did not represent a credible threat. Bernalillo County Sheriff’s Department in Albuquerque investigated the list featuring New Mexico schools and found the threat was not credible.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Georgia coach Kirby Smart's family ends relationship with Taylor Swift: ‘We do not support her endorsement.’”
Justification: This claim is baseless.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Leo Ferreira, a cancer researcher shown in a video clip, was on the plane that crashed in Brazil on Aug. 9.
Justification: A Facebook reel claimed that "Dr. Leo Ferreira," a cancer researcher shown in a video clip, was on the plane that crashed Aug. 9 in Brazil, killing everyone onboard. The video showed Leonardo Ferreira, an immunologist at the Medical University of South Carolina in the Hollings Cancer Center. Ferreira did not die in the plane crash and dismissed such claims in an Aug. 12 X post. Dr. José Roberto Leonel Ferreira, a professor and radiologist who owned an imaging center in Brazil, died in the crash, according to news reports.
Sources: Emailed statement from the Brazilian College of Radiology and Imaging Diagnosis
MUSC Hollings Cancer Center’s YouTube channel
Unioeste: Universidade Estadual do Oeste do Paraná

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Patron, Don Julio and Pink Whitney tequila recalled because they contained fecal matter.
Justification: There’s no evidence that Patron, Don Julio and Pink Whitney tequila products were recalled because they contained fecal matter. A spokesperson for Don Julio’s parent company said the claim is false.
Sources: Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
Searches of Google News and Nexis news database

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows a child “saved” by Deputy Ryan Braidley in Elko County, Nevada.
Justification: This post isn’t authentic.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Jason Aldean rejected a $500 million music collaboration with Taylor Swift.
Justification: The headline was originally published as satire.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Gordon Ramsay calls Tim Walz a ‘woke creep,’ throws him out of Hell’s Kitchen.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris’ “plan to tax unrecognized Capital Gains mean(s) if your house goes up in value you will have to pay that Tax Even if you don’t sell your House!”
Justification: Currently, unrealized capital gains, or unsold assets that have appreciated in value, are not subject to federal taxes. Vice President Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign said she supports President Joe Biden’s 2025 budget proposal, which called for a 25% minimum tax rate on unrealized capital gains for taxpayers with more than $100 million in wealth. Most Americans would not be subject to such a tax. There are fewer than 10,000 people in the U.S. with a net worth of at least $100 million.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Jordan Peterson making disparaging remarks about Chinese food
Justification: A video that appears to show Canadian psychologist Jordan Peterson making disparaging remarks about Chinese cuisine and promoting a herbal tablet book was altered. The footage is from a July 25 interview with podcaster Joe Rogan and the pair did not talk about Chinese food.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There’s no such thing as menopause.”
Justification: Menopause exists. Numerous clinics, groups of health care professionals and medical research entities confirm this and generally define menopause the point at which a woman has naturally gone 12 months without a menstrual period. Menopause occurs naturally when ovaries stop making reproductive hormones such as estrogen and stop releasing eggs for fertilization. It takes time to reach menopause, and most people experience symptoms during that transition. The period is clinically known as menopausal transition or perimenopause but it’s often popularly described as "going through menopause." Symptoms include irregular periods, hot flashes, vaginal dryness, insomnia, night sweats and mood changes.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Somi Javaid
The American College of Obstetrics and Gynecologists

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Caitlin Clark declines $1 million offer from ABC to appear on ‘The View.’”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows Fox Business graphic titled  “Tim Walz’s Communist Agenda.”
Justification: This image was altered. A graphic that Fox Business aired Aug. 7 was titled, "Tim Walz’s economic scorecard" and did not include any information about a "communist agenda." A Fox Business spokesperson told PolitiFact this image did not air on its network.
Sources: Email exchange with Fox Business spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Vice President Kamala Harris was fired from McDonald’s for stealing.
Justification: This claim originated from a satirical website.
Sources: Email exchange with Kamala Harris presidential campaign spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A 15-year-old named “Graci Mae Thompson” is missing.
Justification: PolitiFact found no evidence that a 15-year-old named "Graci Mae Thompson" was reported missing. Users posted this information and photos in Facebook groups for buying and selling items in different locations. Some of these users had a history of posting about supposed "abducted children" only to edit the posts to advertise properties for sale.
Sources: National Center for Missing & Exploited Children
National Center for Missing and Exploited Children
Search through FBI Kidnappings & Missing Persons
Search through National Center for Missing and Exploited Children’s database

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Minnesota Vikings have denounced Tim Walz: “We don’t suppᴏrt his values.”
Justification: The NFL’s Minnesota Vikings did not denounce Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz. The claim originated on a satire website, but other users shared it without clarifying that it was fictitious.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Colin Kaepernick 'screams' as Coach Kyle Shanahan denies his return request: 'The kneeling symbol has no chance of coming back.’”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A plane crashed into the Milad Tower, July 31, 2024.
Justification: This video doesn’t show a plane crashing into a tower July 31. The tower shown in the video is the Milad Tower, a communications tower in Tehran, Iran. The video is from a social media user who defines himself as a video creator. The creator confirmed the post doesn’t show a real video, he said it was computer-generated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: ABC News fired presidential debate moderators David Muir and Linsey Davis.
Justification: We found no credible news stories or ABC News statements saying that presidential debate moderators David Muir and Linsey Davis were fired. The article making the claim originated on a satire news website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Beyoncé and Taylor Swift announced a “big endorsement concert” and said, “No more silence, before it’s too late, our voice must be heard now!”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “All students who knelt during the national anthem were rounded up and removed from scholarships” at the University of Texas.
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Actor Mel Gibson told talk show host Oprah Winfrey, “You sell children!”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. Mel Gibson’s publicist has said that "none of this is true."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Nike announces termination of contract with Brittney Griner after ‘strong backlash’ from online community.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk has announced his first robot girlfriend, with artificial intelligence.”
Justification: A parody account posted the image in July on X. PolitiFact didn’t find credible reports or Musk statements about a robot girlfriend. An AI image detector estimated a 99.9% probability that it was AI-generated.
Sources: Other sources included in the fact-check. Spanish

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “ESPN has fired Shannon Sharpe.”
Justification: ESPN commentator and former National Football League player Shannon Sharpe apologized Sept. 11 after a sexually explicit Instagram livestream from his account. ESPN told PolitiFact on Sept. 13 that Sharpe would continue to appear on the network.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Candace Owens will host an ABC morning show that will replace “The View.”
Justification: The story originated on a satirical news website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Simone Biles “announces retirement” and “reveals she is ‘expecting a baby.’”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. American gymnast Simone Biles didn’t announce her retirement or pregnancy.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Michael Jordan rejects $400 million Disney offer, stating, ‘I do not collaborate with companies aligned with woke ideologies.’”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows a Secret Service sniper at the July 13 Trump rally wearing a red string bracelet tied to Kabbalah Judaism.
Justification: Although the photo is authentic, it doesn’t depict the sniper wearing a red string bracelet. The zoomed-in photo shows the sniper wearing two bracelets on his left wrist: a black band with red letters and a black string with red and black beads. Those bracelets bear little resemblance to the red string followers of mystical Judaism, or Kabbalah, wear.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Thomas Crooks “was a registered Democrat who voted for Clinton and Biden.”
Justification: The FBI confirmed that the individual who fired shots at Trump’s Pennsylvania rally was 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks. Crooks would have been too young to vote in the 2016 or 2020 elections. Pennsylvania voting records show that Crooks was a registered Republican.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows “Roman tidal baths in Malta, still at sea level after thousands of years!”
Justification: Pools in Sliema, Malta, are referred to as Roman baths but were constructed in Victorian times, according to the Maltese government.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Disney and Google bought the rights to the first King James Bible.”
Justification: This story originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows proof of a bullet hole in Trump’s jacket.
Justification: Although the photo is authentic, it doesn’t show proof of a bullet in former President Donald Trump’s chest. The apparent hole is a crease in a Secret Service agent’s jacket. The crease was also captured in a video of the shooting’s aftermath, which shows it disappearing as the agent moves. Neither Trump, the FBI investigators, nor any major news outlets have mentioned a bullet hitting Trump’s chest.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images show FBI assistant director Janeen DiGuiseppi seated behind former President Donald Trump during his assassination attempt.
Justification: In 2023, Janeen DiGuiseppi was promoted to the role of FBI assistant director of the agency’s Insider Threat Office. An FBI spokesperson said a woman shown in viral social media posts is not DiGuiseppi. DiGuiseppi did not attend former President Donald Trump’s rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, an FBI statement to PolitiFact said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Butler Police confirm the shooter’s name is Mark Violets. He is a known Antifa extremist.”
Justification: On July 14, the FBI identified 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks of Bethel Park, Pennsylvania, as the shooting suspect at former President Donald Trump’s rall in Butler, Pennsylvania. Italian sports blogger Marco Violi posted on Instagram denying any involvement in the shooting.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Israeli swimmers protesting Olympic rules by spelling out “bring them home.”
Justification: This photo was shared online in November, months before the Paris Olympics.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Starbucks was an “official sponsor of the RNC.”
Justification: Starbucks Corp. was not an official sponsor of the Republican National Convention. The company worked with the Milwaukee 2024 Host Committee, a liaison between the city and the Republican National Committee, to give coffee to first responders including EMTs and firefighters.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Netflix stock tumbles almost 40%” after the company donated to Kamala Harris’ campaign.
Justification: The post originated from a satire website, which alluded to a real $7 million donation made by Reed Hastings, Netflix co-founder and executive chairman, to a super PAC supporting Vice President Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign. Netflix itself did not donate to Harris’ campaign; corporations are barred from donating to federal elections.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows tornado caused by Hurricane Beryl in July 2024.
Justification: Video footage showing a large tornado towering over a strip mall and other buildings was shared online before Hurricane Beryl formed as a tropical depression in June 2024. We found footage filmed in Florida during Hurricane Matthew in 2016 that largely matched the footage being shared, but the Hurricane Matthew footage did not include a tornado.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Every single McDonald’s french fry comes exclusively from potatoes grown on Bill Gates-owned farmland.”
Justification: One farm that supplies potatoes to McDonald’s is owned by Bill Gates, the philanthropist and Microsoft Corp. co-founder, but it is not the sole supplier. The company’s websites in the U.S. and elsewhere list other potato suppliers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Netflix loses 6 million subscribers within hours of donation announcement.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Samsung drops out of $1 billion advertising campaign with Olympics."
Justification: An International Olympic Committee spokesperson told PolitiFact Samsung Electronics Co. has not withdrawn its sponsorship. Samsung has continued to share posts and articles about the 2024 Paris Olympics. This claim was first shared by websites that publish what they describe as "satire."
Sources: Email exchange with with International Olympic Committee

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Thomas Matthew Crooks worked for BlackRock "in the past" and BlackRock owned the building Crooks stood on when he shot at the Trump campaign rally.
Justification: Thomas Matthew Crooks appeared briefly in a 2022 BlackRock Inc., ad about teachers’ retirement plans. He and other students in the background were not paid, BlackRock said. County records show American Glass Research Inc. owns the building from which Crooks fired the shots that killed one person and injured three, including former President Donald Trump. A BlackRock spokesperson said the company neither owns nor has real estate funds invested in the building.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Official Navy photographs show an unidentified flying object in the Arctic Ocean in 1971.
Justification: The U.S. Navy could not verify whether the photographs were official. The former commanding officer of the USS Trepang II said he did not witness an unidentified flying object while aboard the ship in 1971.
Sources: Telephone interview with Rear Admiral Dean Sackett Jr.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk backs Caitlin Clark, offers $10 million endorsement.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk calls for ban on ‘The View,’ ‘I’d rather walk barefoot on hot asphalt than watch ‘The View.’”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Mount Etna erupting in Sicily in July 2024.
Justification: The photo shows Mount Etna erupting in February 2021, not July 2024. Mount Etna did erupt in July 2024, and the Catania Airport suspended operations only for a few hours. It reopened July 5.
Sources: X post by Aeroporto di Catania

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Riley Gaines won $10 million against Whoopi Goldberg for defaming her reputation.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Gordon Ramsay kicks Lia Thomas out of his restaurant, 'Dine in some woke place.'"
Justification: This claim originated as satire.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Lia Thomas ordered to compete with men.”
Justification: Transgender swimmer Lia Thomas was unsuccessful in her legal bid to overturn rules barring her from elite women’s swimming races. But she wasn’t ordered to "compete with men."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Chiefs' Coach Andy Reid "fires 3 top players for anthem kneeling."
Justification: This story originated on a self-described satire website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Candace Owens vows to have Taylor Swift banned from next NFL season.”
Justification: This story originated on a self-described satire page.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows a pink dolphin spotted off the North Carolina coast.
Justification: The North Carolina Division of Marine Fisheries said there have been no verified sightings of pink dolphins in North Carolina waters. We also found no credible news reports of pink dolphin sightings. Although these images appear digitally altered, there are types of dolphins that can be pink, such as the Amazon river dolphin and the Taiwanese humpback dolphin. Albino dolphins can also have a pinkish hue.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo was the only European soccer captain who did not wear a rainbow armband at Euro 2020.
Justification: There is evidence that three team captains — from Germany, England, and Denmark — wore rainbow or pro-LGBTQ+ armbands during this tournament, which included 24 teams. Germany’s captain, Manuel Neuer, was briefly investigated by the Union of European Football Associations for his rainbow armband. Cristiano Ronaldo was among many other captains who wore normal armbands.
Sources: ESPN. " Why FIFA banned LGBTQ OneLove armband at the World Cup

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows a Houston woman baking bread in her mailbox.
Justification: In 2023, Roberta Wright of Houston shared on social media a photo of her pulling freshly baked bread out of her mailbox. The image went viral. She told a local news station that she shared it to inspire kids to use their imagination. She did not actually cook the loaf in the mailbox.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The U.S. House “has authorized a new $1,000 stimulus card program to support those in need.”
Justification: The U.S. House of Representatives has not approved a $1,000 stimulus card for Americans to use on everyday expenses.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows Disney+ poster for new “Vader” show.
Justification: This poster appears to be fabricated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Actor and comedian Tim Allen died suddenly” in a “fatal car accident.”
Justification: There is no credible reporting of Tim Allen’s death. He has an event scheduled for June 29 that had not been canceled as of this publication.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Caitlin Clark rejects $400 million deal from Nike” saying “not with that Kaepernick clown.’”
Justification: This claim originated on a satire site. In April, it was widely reported that Indiana Fever rookie Caitlin Clark was expected to enter a lucrative contract with Nike.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Saudi Arabia will stop using the US dollar for oil sales and will not renew the 50-year petro-dollar agreement with the U.S.”
Justification: Experts in the global oil market told PolitiFact they knew of no evidence that Saudi Arabia plans to stop using the U.S. dollar for oil sales. Geopolitical shifts mean that more oil sales are happening using other currencies. The U.S. and Saudi Arabia have a long history of economic and political cooperation, and experts said they expect sales of oil in U.S. dollars will continue. In 1974, the U.S. and Saudi Arabia established a Joint Commission on Economic Cooperation. It encouraged stronger political ties between the countries via economic cooperation; it didn’t mean Saudi Arabia formally agreed to exclusively sell oil for U.S. dollars.
Sources: Email interview with David M. Wight
Email interview with Patrick De Haan
Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “WNBA organizers have officially announced an investigation into the referees in all of Caitlin Clark's games for ignoring all dirty actions by her opponents against her.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A jury “ordered Disney and Lucasfilm to pay” actor Gina Carano $115 million.
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire website. "The Mandalorian" actor Gina Carano has sued Disney for wrongful termination, but the lawsuit continues.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Photo shows Egyptian pyramids being constructed in 2549 BC”
Justification: Photo technology was first invented about 200 years ago and not 4,500 years ago.
Sources: International Photography Hall of Fame and Museum

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 returns after 10-year mystery"
Justification: March 8, 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappeared off air traffic control radar. Later evidence signaled it likely crashed into the Indian Ocean. Despite an extensive three-year search, the plane has still not been recovered, but debris confirmed to be part of the plane has been found. The flight has not returned.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Starting from June 2024, the United States will provide a six-month free CDL course.”
Justification: Spokespeople for the State Department and the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration said their agencies were not offering free commercial driver’s license courses. The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration sets testing standards, but state governments issue commercial driver’s licenses.
Sources: Statement from the U.S. Department of State

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows a missing child in Pike County, Missouri.
Justification: The girl in this photo isn’t missing from Pike County, Missouri. She was briefly missing from a North Carolina community but has since been located.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “two electric vehicles in a crash in Canada.”
Justification: Satellite imagery shows that this video was taken in Moscow, not Canada. Media reports of the explosion said it was caused by a truck containing gas cylinders colliding with a bus.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Footage “shows a completely flat horizon proving the flat Earth and completely destroying the globe theory.”
Justification: Photos from space show that the Earth is round.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Burger King is “closing its doors for good.”
Justification: Burger King did not say the company will close all its stores. The company had said it would close up to 400 stores in 2023. Burger King is investing more than $1 billion into updating its restaurants.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The government is offering a $5,800 subsidy, and “every American qualifies for it.”
Justification: The government is not offering a $5,800 subsidy to all Americans. The linked website is not affiliated with the government.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: NFL referees “flex their authority, eject five players” for kneeling during the national anthem.
Justification: This story originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: HarperCollins “removed 64,575 words from the Bible.”
Justification: Since 1978, the New International Version of the Bible has been revised twice, most recently in 2011, "reflecting new archaeological findings, current biblical scholarship and changes to the English language," according to HarperCollins, which owns the Bible’s publisher Zondervan. Some passages and verses were relocated to footnotes in the New International Version to better reflect older and more reliable biblical manuscripts, the publisher said.
Sources: Updating the New International Version of the Bible: Notes from the Committee on Bible Translation

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk fires entire cast of 'The View' after acquiring ABC.”
Justification: We searched Google and reviewed "The View" hosts’ social media posts for evidence that the hosts had recently been fired from the show and came up empty. We contacted spokespeople for "The View" and The Walt Disney Co. and received no response. (The Walt Disney Co. owns ABC.) We also found no reputable news organizations reporting that entrepreneur Elon Musk had acquired ABC.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. Olympic committee says Lia Thomas is welcome to try out for the men’s team.”
Justification: This story originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Walmart has announced starting June 3rd all locations in the U.S. will go back to 24hrs.”
Justification: This rumor is unfounded. Walmart isn’t resuming 24-hour operations.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Dr. Sebi’s daughter was sentenced to 155 years in prison for revealing top secret health hacks.”
Justification: We found no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Prince William announces heartbreak: ‘My wife, it’s over.’”
Justification: In May, Prince William told members of the public who asked about his wife’s health that she is "doing well." We found no news reports that William said, "My wife, it’s over." One image shared in Facebook posts spreading this claim was from two years ago. Another image that accompanied the claim was generated using artificial intelligence.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Denzel Washington rejects $100 million Disney offer to work with ‘woke’ Robert De Niro.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site. We found no evidence this is true.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk sues The View and Whoopi Goldberg for $60 million.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Breaking News: The Grand Ole Opry Bans Beyoncé For Life, ‘Go Play Dress-Up, You’re Not Country.’”
Justification: This story originated on a self-described satire site. Beyoncé hasn’t been banned from Nashville venue the Grand Ole Opry.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “James Woods leaves Hollywood to join Mel Gibson’s new non-woke film studio.”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire page.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows a replica of the Statue of Liberty built from the ruins of a Syrian artist’s house.
Justification: Tammam Azzam, the artist, told media outlets he created the photomontage on a computer.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Every American over 25 is now entitled to get a prepaid reward card up to $500 to use for groceries and everyday expenses.”
Justification: We found no evidence of a program to give Americans 25 and older $500 reward cards.
Sources: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Colin Kaepernick was fired from his new high school coaching job after just one season” because "the kids couldn't stand him."
Justification: Former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick never accepted a high school coaching job. This claim originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Starbucks lattes contain semen.
Justification: This claim appears to have originated on a satirical website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Pittsburgh Steelers coach “directs team to not participate in pride month” calling it "woke crap"
Justification: The story originated on a satire site. A Pittsburgh Steelers spokesperson confirmed that coach Mike Tomlin did not make such statements. A social media page associated with the Pittsburgh Steelers posted an image showing team staff gathered after participating in a pride parade. As of June 13, we saw no other messages from the team regarding about Pride Month.
Sources: Email interview with Pittsburgh Steelers spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “They are hiding the fact that Barbara O’Neill’s cousin was sentenced to life in prison for revealing these gatekept health secrets.”
Justification: We found no reports that the unnamed cousin of Barbara O’Neill, a naturopath banned from practicing in Australia, received a lifetime prison sentence for revealing purported health secrets. The image in the video was artificially generated.
Sources: New South Wales Health Care Complaints Commission

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Kansas City Chiefs said they refuse to participate in Pride Month because ‘it’s extremely woke.’
Justification: As of June 10, the Kansas City Chiefs have not released any statements on social media or its website news page about Pride Month in June. The team’s online shop sells Pride-themed merchandise. The website with the article making the claim contains numerous fake headlines. The story originated on a self-described satire site.
Sources: Kansas City Chiefs team pro shop

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Beyoncé offered Kid Rock millions to join him on stage at a few of his shows.”
Justification: This claim originated from a self-described satire account.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows the scene of a fatal crash that killed a Filipino artist.
Justification: Filipino artist Andrei Sison died in 2023 in the Philippines. A photo online since 2017 shows a car crash in Romania, not Sison’s fatal accident in the Philippines.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Viral images show Lady Gaga at the 2024 Met Gala.
Justification: Singer Lady Gaga did not attend the 2024 Met Gala. These photos were generated by artificial intelligence.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Dr. Sebi’s cousin was sent to life in prison for revealing these gatekept health secrets.”
Justification: No news reports, documents, or public statements from Bowman’s daughter, addressed or supported this claim. Experts say the post’s photo of "Dr. Sebi’s cousin" is likely AI-generated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows dolphins saving a mother whale and newborn from sharks.
Justification: A video posted in 2021 showed dolphins and whales off South Africa’s coast during a feeding frenzy, according to local news reports.
Sources: Cape Town Etc. WATCH: dolphins and whale feeding at Fish Hoek

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Aurora borealis sightings a “fabricated light show” created by a HAARP experiment.
Justification: A powerful geomagnetic storm hit Earth over several days beginning May 10, causing some disruptions to GPS services and other problems. It also allowed the aurora borealis — known as the northern lights — to be viewed much further south than usual. The timing coincided with research conducted at the High-frequency Active Auroral Research Program. That research involved detecting orbital debris in space and was not related to the geomagnetic storm. HAARP can create an artificial aurora, but not one strong enough to create the display seen worldwide.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a Fox News report about a fight featuring Dr. Mehmet Oz.
Justification: This video was doctored. The fight happened on the set of a Polish TV show in 2017 and didn’t include Dr. Mehmet Oz.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows “clearest image ever taken of Venus.”
Justification: This is not a genuine photo of the planet Venus. A U.S.-based researcher created the image by editing original panoramic photos taken by a Soviet Union space probe with the programming language C++ and photo-editing software Adobe Photoshop. The researcher’s edited image shows details not seen in the original space probe images, including distant hills on Venus. Other people further edited the researcher’s black-and-white image to color it yellow.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images show Beyoncé at the 2024 Met Gala.
Justification: Beyoncé did not attend the 2024 Met Gala. These images were generated by artificial intelligence.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Second Boeing Whistleblower Killed In 2 Months!
Justification: Two Boeing Co.-linked whistleblowers recently died within two months of each other. Joshua Dean died following a MRSA bacterial infection; John Barnett died of what a coroner’s office said appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound, though police are still investigating his death.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Brad Pitt promoting a hair loss product.
Justification: This video was altered.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Voter fraud investigations are being banned by Michigan lawmakers!”
Justification: Michigan election officials, a Michigan state senator, a Michigan attorney general’s office spokesperson and a voting rights group executive director all told PolitiFact that they know of no proposed legislation that would ban "voter fraud investigations." If it becomes law, Michigan Senate Bill 603 will amend the state’s procedures for election recounts. It would also put in statute that a recount "is not an investigation or an audit of the conduct of an election," aiming to end frivolous recounts. The bill’s sponsor and county clerks who helped draft the legislation said it aims to clarify and improve recount procedures and will not prevent investigation of voter fraud allegations. The bill’s critics argue it would remove one method of investigating potential fraud.
Sources: Email statement from a spokesperson for Sen. Ruth Johnson’s office
Interview with Michigan State Senator Stephanie Chang

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An executive order proves President Joe Biden “isn’t real and isn’t president.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.
Sources: Executive Order 13823—Protecting America Through Lawful Detention of Terrorists

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hacker Hamza Bendelladj was executed.
Justification: Hamza Bendelladj wasn’t executed. As of May 3, he was still serving his federal prison sentence in California with a projected  July 6 release date.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jay-Z paid more than $20 million to country radio stations to play Beyoncé songs so she’d top the Billboard country charts.”
Justification: This claim originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. News & World Report reported that actor Keanu Reeves rejected a “‘woke’ movie offer.”
Justification: This story originated on a satire site. The Facebook account sharing it used U.S. News & World Report’s logo but is unaffiliated with the publication.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: This video shows BBC News reporting on the “tragic end of Elon Musk.”
Justification: This video was altered. Original footage of a BBC News broadcast and Elon Musk was edited to make it appear as though he and the news host were saying something they didn’t.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk confirms — ’The rapture is going to happen VERY soon.’”
Justification: We found no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows Rihanna at the 2024 Met Gala.
Justification: Rihanna did not attend the 2024 Met Gala because she had the flu, People magazine reported.
Sources: Reverse-image searches using Google Images and TinEye

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The US Women's team has made it clear that they will resign immediately if the Olympic Committee allows Lia Thomas to try out.”
Justification: This story appears to have originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images show Katy Perry at the 2024 Met Gala.
Justification: Singer Katy Perry did not attend the 2024 Met Gala. On Instagram, she said she "couldn’t make it" because she "had to work." Artificial intelligence-generated images of the singer supposedly at the gala went viral, convincing many internet users, including Perry’s mother, that Perry attended wearing a floral gown with an expansive skirt.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There is no campaigning going on, none whatsoever.”
Justification: It’s not accurate that there’s no campaigning happening for the 2024 election. Both President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump have raised millions in their efforts to lead the nation, and traveled to rally voters to their causes.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Democrats are calling to redesign the American Flag to make it more inclusive” by featuring rainbow colored stripes.
Justification: PolitiFact found no evidence — in news reports and Nexis news archives — that Democrats are calling for the American flag to be redesigned. The photo included in the post is from a 2015 protest for the legalization of gay marriage. It is not a proposed new flag.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a mother encouraging her son “who identifies as a cat to use the litter box at school.”
Justification: The video originated from a satirical TikTok account.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “In an interview with People magazine,” Kelly Clarkson “said she will file a lawsuit over keto ads on Facebook.”
Justification: This post about singer Kelly Clarkson suing over weight loss product scams on Facebook is another weight loss scam.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Dr. Mehmet Oz promoting his “exclusive pills” to lose weight.
Justification: Altered footage of Dr. Mehmet Oz appears to show him hawking diet pills. In the original footage, posted on his TikTok account, he discusses mental health and urges people suffering from depression to get help.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows orangutan “stretching out his hand to help a geologist who fell into a mud pool.”
Justification: The man pictured was a maintenance worker who was clearing the area of sediments and grass. He did not fall into the water. The orangutan could have been reaching out for food, according to the nonprofit that runs the orangutan rehabilitation center where the photo was taken. Orangutans at the site are held in captivity until they are ready to be released into the wild.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said the United States and Ukraine won World War II.
Justification: The video’s audio was edited. There were no mentions of World War II, Adolf Hitler or Joseph Stalin during the White House press briefing that’s shown. During World War II, the United States was allied with the Soviet Union against Nazi Germany. Ukraine was occupied by German forces during most of the war.
Sources: U.S. State Department’s Office of the Historian

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There are no real pictures of satellites on Google Images because outer space is not real.
Justification: There are many photographs of real satellites and outer space on Google Images.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Mehmet Oz promoted a weight loss supplement that can be added to coffee.
Justification: In the original video on his Instagram, Mehmet Oz, a celebrity doctor and former Senate candidate, says he supports drinking coffee, but does not tell his viewers to buy any weight loss products.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Morton Salt and other plain and iodized table salts contain 25% sand and 25% glass that cut up “your arterial and venous network and that’s how you get high blood pressure.”
Justification: Morton Salt and other plain and iodized table salts do not contain sand and glass. Excessive consumption of salt can cause hypertension because of the sodium it contains — not because of glass in the salt. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.
Sources: McGill University Office for Science and Society
The Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: John Mellencamp was “booed off stage for praising Joe Biden.”
Justification: John Mellencamp was heckled while talking about his late grandmother at a show in Toledo, Ohio. After another heckling incident, the singer left the stage. He returned to finish the show. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Reba McEntire faces serious charges.”
Justification: This is an unfounded claim on a clickbait post aimed at purportedly promoting CBD gummies.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show the scene of an accident that left an unidentified woman in a coma after a “hit and run incident.”
Justification: These posts aren’t authentic. The photos used in them were taken from unrelated news stories.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Michelle Obama announced she is "running for President in 2024 as a man."
Justification: There are no credible reports that former first lady Michelle Obama has announced she is running for president. Michelle Obama is not a man. The original claim was shared on April Fools’ Day.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Kelly Clarkson is promoting weight loss gummies or other diet products.
Justification: Kelly Clarkson hasn’t endorsed any diet products.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Mehmet Oz said singer Adele used a “coffee trick” to lose weight.
Justification: In the original video, Mehmet Oz, a celebrity doctor and former U.S. Senate candidate, says Adele used "sirtfoods" to lose weight. Oz does not mention a "coffee trick".

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The administration (has) passed a new bill to help Americans with $15,000+ in credit card debt to write off their balance by 50%."
Justification: Congress has not passed a bill during President Joe Biden’s administration that helps consumers cut their credit card debt in half. A Facebook post making that claim links to a private United Kingdom-based company that matches consumers with debt-relief services.
Sources: Federal Reserve Bank of New York

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hunter Biden, “BLM rioters” and “COVID criminals” have “0 indictments”
Justification: Hunter Biden has been indicted twice on 12 criminal counts. People have also faced criminal charges for violent or destructive acts during the protests that followed George Floyd’s 2020 murder by a white police officer.
Sources: U.S. Department of Justice’s Office of Public Affairs

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Megyn Kelly promoted the “exotic coffee method” for weight loss on “Megyn Kelly Today.”
Justification: In the original 2018 video, a "Megyn Kelly Today" show guest tells  Kelly about a weight-loss program called Optavia. She does not mention an "exotic coffee method". Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “protesters at Harvard replace American flag with Palestinian flag.”
Justification: Student protesters raised a Palestinian flag in Harvard Yard on April 27, a Saturday. Harvard University’s media relations department said the American flag was not flying on that day and therefore was not replaced. According to Harvard’s procedures, the American flag is raised in front of University Hall only on weekdays. The Harvard Crimson, the college’s student newspaper, also reported that the American flag was not flying then.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows former President Barack Obama wearing an anti-Donald Trump T-shirt.
Justification: PolitiFact and other news outlets have fact-checked fake photos of well-known people wearing the same anti-Trump T-shirt.
Sources: Searches Searches for Barack Obama wearing an anti-Trump T-shirt in Google and Nexis
Searches for Barack Obama wearing an anti-Trump T-shirt in Getty Images’ and The Associated Press’ photo databases

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Iranian drone sent to Israel stuck in a power line in Iraq.
Justification: A widely shared social media video shows a drone that got stuck in wires in Syria in February. It has no connection to Iran’s April 13 launch of 300 drones and missiles to Israel, as some posts claimed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Tucker Carlson discussing a diabetes cure created with Pfizer and certified by the FDA.
Justification: A Facebook video showing Tucker Carlson and a health educator discussing a diabetes remedy is a deepfake. The speakers’ mouth movements do not align with the audio. The dietary supplement pitched on a website the post links to has no connection to Pfizer, the company said. Nor was it certified by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, which does not approve dietary supplements. There is no known cure for diabetes, a disease affecting 38 million Americans.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Hillary Clinton holding an anti-Donald Trump T-shirt.
Justification: The photo was altered. In the original photo, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton held a T-shirt that said "nasty woman." PolitiFact and other news outlets have fact-checked fake photos of well-known people wearing the same anti-Donald Trump T-shirt.
Sources: Reverse-image searches using Google Images and TinEye

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dollar Tree, Walgreens, Macy’s, Foot Locker, Gap, Burger King, Regal Cinemas and Kroger have had mass store closures during Joe Biden’s presidency.
Justification: Walgreens and Kroger haven’t announced any closures. Regal Cinemas said in 2023 it would close about three dozen movie theaters. Gap Inc. announced its store closures in 2020, when Donald Trump was president. Macy’s Inc. announced store closures during both Trump’s and Biden’s presidencies. Foot Locker announced mall store closures, but plans to open almost as many stand-alone stores. Dollar Tree and Burger King announced plans to close 1,000 stores and 400 stores, respectively.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The government owes you $8,832 and a $2,000 spending card.
Justification: The website linked in this Facebook post is not affiliated with the government. Affordable Care Act marketplace plans offer subsidies, but not in cash. Tax credits vary by income level and payments go to insurers, not consumers. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Filmmaker Mike deGruy died for "exposing the truth."
Justification: Mike deGruy, a nature filmmaker, died in a 2012 helicopter crash in Australia. He did not discover deep-sea brine lakes, nor did he die because he filmed one. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: As of April 24, “there was active military in 360 U.S. cities awaiting a Supreme Court announcement ‘that will rock the world’ and trigger cabal deep state planned protests.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. The Pentagon told PolitiFact in a statement that it is false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Trump takes out a loan and pays it back with interest, it is a crime."
Justification: The case referenced in this Facebook post centered on whether former President Donald Trump inflated his assets to get favorable bank loans. A New York judge found Trump, two of his sons and other co-defendants liable for civil fraud in the financial statements they used to obtain loans. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: World Health Organization pandemic accord “would take away American sovereignty and give the WHO power to put in legally binding policies in America in the case of another pandemic."
Justification: World Health Organization member states are negotiating a new pandemic agreement to help prevent and prepare for future pandemics. The draft text does not authorize the WHO to dictate pandemic responses to the U.S. or any country. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: NASA is “shooting three rockets at three moons” on the day of the solar eclipse.
Justification: NASA is launching three sounding rockets at a maximum altitude of 260 miles April 8. It is not shooting the rockets "at three moons." Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Joe Rogan talking about “mythical sea beasts,” gold in the Grand Canyon, and aliens in the Bermuda triangle.
Justification: PolitiFact found no evidence that these clips were authentic or come from the Joe Rogan Experience podcast. Podcaster Rogan has become a frequent target of artificial intelligence-generated audio and video clips. Digital forensic expert analysis of the audio classified this video as AI-generated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Notice from a New Jersey doctor’s office proves that COVID-19 vaccines are dangerous for athletes.
Justification: The mRNA COVID-19 vaccines can cause rare and mostly mild cases of myocarditis and pericarditis mostly in young male teens and adults, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said. Scientific studies have found no link between COVID-19 vaccines and sudden cardiac deaths in youth athletes. An April CDC study showed there is no association between cardiac death in previously healthy young people and the vaccines. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The solar eclipse path was “full of chemtraiIs.”
Justification: Chemtrails are not real, multiple government agencies and scientists say. They are a conspiracy theory that alleges condensation trails behind aircraft are part of a secret program to poison the atmosphere. There was increased air traffic the week of the solar eclipse because of spring break travel and tourists headed to the path of totality. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: It’s a sign of war that the U.S. Navy is assisting the U.S. Coast Guard in cleaning up Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge site.
Justification: The U.S. Navy is assisting a U.S. Coast Guard-led effort to remove debris from the water after Baltimore's Francis Scott Key Bridge collapsed in March. Military branches often work alongside federal, state and local agencies to respond to U.S. disasters as part of what officials call a "whole of government response." No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: World Economic Forum founder and chairman Klaus Schwab hospitalized in critical condition on April 15.
Justification: World Economic Forum founder Klaus Schwab has not been hospitalized, a spokesperson said April 17. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: CERN’s activation of its Large Hadron Collider is connected to the April 8 eclipse.
Justification: CERN, or the European Organization for Nuclear Research, restarted its Large Hadron Collider after a regular winter stop for maintenance. CERN is not reactivating the accelerator in connection with the April 8 eclipse. CERN houses the Large Hadron Collider, the world’s most powerful particle accelerator, which facilitates experiments to understand matter’s fundamental structure. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donald Trump “pays off mortgage of killed NYPD officer’s family.”
Justification: A spokesperson for Tunnel to Towers, the foundation paying off the mortgage for the home of Jonathan Diller, a New York Police Department officer killed in the line of duty, told a news outlet that it had not been in touch with former President Donald Trump about the mortgage. A Real America’s Voice host who reported that Trump paid off Diller’s mortgage through Tunnel to Towers later retracted his report. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos of Pennsylvania vote tallies on CNN prove the 2020 election was stolen.
Justification: Joe Biden won Pennsylvania in the 2020 election by more than 80,000 votes. Vote counts shown on television change as more information is received from the field in the hours and days after polls close. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “You’ve probably heard that Taylor Swift is endorsing Joe B."
Justification: Singer-songwriter Taylor Swift endorsed Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election but has not issued a public endorsement in 2024. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Venus Williams forfeits match against trans woman,” saying, “I’m not playing a man.”
Justification: PolitiFact reviewed news on Google and in Nexis news archives and found no evidence that tennis player Venus Williams ever forfeited a match against a transgender athlete. The photo in the post does not show Venus Williams. It’s her sister, Serena Williams. The story appears to have originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Taylor Swift is doing satanic rituals during her shows.”
Justification: Taylor Swift’s songs mention neither Satan nor Satanic rituals. Swift has publicly described herself as a Christian. The leader of The Satanic Temple, a religious organization, dismissed the allegations about Swift as conspiracy theories. Experts told PolitiFact that musicians have been accused of performing satanic rituals for decades. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: IRS Satanic Temple tax exempt organization search

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Social Security Administration database shows “how many people each of the 43 states are registering to vote who DO NOT HAVE IDs.”
Justification: The Social Security Administration’s website does not have a table of data that shows how many people in 43 states have registered to vote without IDs. The Social Security Administration’s table shows the overall number of times states have requested verification of the last four digits of a potential voter’s Social Security number. States can also repeatedly run verification requests on the same person’s Social Security number. ​Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement
Maricopa County Recorder Stephen Richer’s X post
New York State Board of Elections

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The day after the total solar eclipse, 85-foot waves traveled from Antarctica to South Africa.
Justification: Ventusky, a weather forecast data website, said on X that its map visualizations had forecast large waves as part of a "model error." This video footage of large waves crashing in South Africa is from 2023. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Nancy Pelosi busted, Speaker (Mike) Johnson just released it for everyone to see.”
Justification: The article linked in the post mentions no wrongdoing by Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif. The article’s only mention of Pelosi is a December 2023 MSNBC interview in which she criticized House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La.’s decision to hold a vote on the impeachment inquiry into President Joe Biden. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Mark Zuckerberg said ‘posting the Lord's Prayer violated’ Meta’s policies.
Justification: A Meta spokesperson told PolitiFact that posting the Lord's Prayer does not violate Meta policies. We found no information in Meta’s community standards and policies that would prohibit posting the Lord's Prayer or religious content. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Snoop Dogg recommending “gummies for quitting smoking.”
Justification: We found no reputable reports that rapper Snoop Dogg is advocating the use of gummies to quit smoking. The footage appears to be from Snoop Dogg’s January appearance on "Jimmy Kimmel Live," but the audio has been manipulated. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: COVID-19 “vaccine injuries exposed in newly uncovered data.”
Justification: V-safe participants self-report adverse health impacts after COVID-19 vaccination, but v-safe data does not show whether COVID-19 vaccination caused those symptoms. The self-reported data has not been verified by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Document shows “Stormy Daniels exonerated Trump herself!”
Justification: Adult film actor Stormy Daniels’ statement denying she had an affair with former President Donald Trump was released Jan. 30, 2018, and widely covered at the time. Daniels has since recanted that statement, saying the affair did happen. Soon after its release, Daniels said in an interview that she denied the affair because of a nondisclosure agreement, and that she felt pressured to sign the statement. Trump on April 15 went to trial in New York on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records for his alleged role covering up a payment to Daniels. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Tennessee has become the first state in the U.S. to ban Bill Gates’ mRNA from being pumped into the food supply.
Justification: Tennessee House Bill 1984 would require food that contains vaccines to be classified as drugs by the Tennessee Department of Agriculture. It does not ban vaccines from food. Edible vaccines, which are administered through food, have been in development since the 1990s but are not approved for use anywhere in the world. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Tennessee General Assembly Fiscal Review Committee

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The Earth is warming because of the sun's changing distance from the Earth, not because of carbon emissions."
Justification: The sun-Earth distance does not factor in the modern trend of global warming. Carbon dioxide and methane emissions, caused by human activity, are the driving force behind global warming No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.
Sources: Retracted: Paper claiming climate change caused by distance from Sun
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There was an “attempt on the life” of Dr. Oz after he shared a blood pressure treatment.
Justification: This video of a man being attacked is from a 2017 Polish television show when a Russian journalist punched a Polish journalist for calling his grandparents "red fascists." Audio of Mehmet Oz, a celebrity doctor and 2022 U.S. Senate candidate, has been edited from a 2014 Senate hearing to make it appear as though he is promoting a blood pressure treatment. Fox News did not report about Oz being attacked for sharing a blood pressure remedy. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Transgender female athletes complained that their uniforms were ill-fitting.
Justification: This originated from a 2019 satire article. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.
Sources: IAAF World Relays Yokohama 2019 biographical summaries

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Las Vegas Sphere displayed a derogatory message directed at former President Donald Trump.
Justification: Sphere Entertainment Co. told PolitiFact this image of the Las Vegas Sphere is not real. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Email interview with Sphere Entertainment Co.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The ship that struck the Baltimore bridge was controlled by a Chinese company.
Justification: News reports and company statements about the incident show that the people who operated the ship Dali were not Chinese. It is owned by Singapore-based company Grace Ocean Private Ltd., managed by Synergy Marine Group and chartered by Danish shipping company Maersk. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donald Trump won Pennsylvania in the 2020 presidential election.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump led Pennsylvania's 2020 election before losing to Joe Biden. Trump’s initial lead was because Pennsylvania most of the in-person ballots were for Trump. However, Biden won a majority of the mail-in ballots, which take longer to count. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “BREAKING: Top CNN host is out as ratings collapse.”
Justification: CNN anchor Christine Romans said in July that she was leaving the network.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show President Joe Biden touching his granddaughter inappropriately.
