Justification: News photos and video show President Joe Biden placing an "I voted" sticker on his granddaughter, Natalie Biden’s, shirt after they voted Oct. 29, 2022, in Delaware, then kissing her on the cheek. The moment marked Natalie Biden’s first time voting. People watching on applauded as she stepped out of the voting booth. The original footage shows no evidence of inappropriate contact. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Emergency officials warn to “stock up on food, water, and fuel ahead of the eclipse.”
Justification: Some state and local officials are encouraging people who live in communities along the April solar eclipse’s path of totality to brace for complications such as traffic jams and overtaxed cell phone networks caused by crowds of out-of-town eclipse viewers. We did not find emergency management officials advising people who live outside the eclipse’s path to stock up on food, water or fuel ahead of the rare astronomical event. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Oklahoma National Guard’s assistance for the April 8 eclipse signals something “bigger.”
Justification: Anticipating large crowds of eclipse viewers, emergency management officials in Oklahoma’s McCurtain County requested support from the Oklahoma National Guard. National Guard troops often support local and state authorities. Oklahoma National Guard troops have supported responses to floods, wildfires, tornadoes and, yes, large gatherings. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Email interview with Lt. Col. LeeAnn Tumblson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Nickelodeon's splat logo design is based on the shape of Epstein Island.
Justification: Nickelodeon’s logo was designed in the network’s 2023 rebranding. It was created to create a sense of nostalgia for the network’s early branding, which included a "splat" logo. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Valid IDs are not required for voting.
Justification: In 36 states, voters are required or requested to present some form of identification at the polls. Some state laws are stricter, requiring photo IDs; other states are laxer, accepting bank statements or utility bills as proof of identity. Fourteen states and Washington, D.C., require no identification to vote at the polls. These states use other methods, such as signature matching, to verify voters’ identities. Federal law requires first-time voters to show ID when requesting mail ballots. Some states have additional ID requirements for voters mailing in ballots. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donald Trump paid off the mortgage of a man who helped him fix a flat tire.
Justification: There are multiple stories with inconsistent details of former President Donald Trump paying off the mortgage of a man who fixed his flat tire. In 1997, an assistant at Trump’s New York office told The Globe and Mail, a Canadian newspaper, that the story was false. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows “a black figure on the bridge before it collapsed.”
Justification: The bridge in this photo doesn’t resemble the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, and it’s been online for at least more than a decade.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump calls for Prince Harry to leave U.S.”
Justification: Asked by a reporter about Prince Harry’s visa application, former President Donald Trump said Harry could face "appropriate action" if he lied on his American visa application. Trump didn’t call for Harry to leave the country.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Georgia district attorney Fani Willis was disbarred.
Justification: Fulton County, Georgia, District Attorney Fani Willis hasn’t been disbarred, though U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., recently requested that the state bar association do so.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video of the ship colliding with the Baltimore bridge proves the bridge collapse wasn’t “an accident.”
Justification: Federal and Maryland officials have said there is no credible evidence the Dali ship’s collision with the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore was intentional. Officials have called it "an accident." Preliminary reports show the ship’s crew made efforts to slow the vessel and prevent contact with the bridge. The pilot also issued a mayday call to stop traffic on the bridge. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Francis Scott Key bridge is the same bridge that was shown in the Netflix movie ‘Leave the World Behind.’”
Justification: "Leave the World Behind" was filmed on location in Long Island, New York. The Francis Scott Key Bridge is in Baltimore. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: FEMA is giving applicants $1,000 checks “next week.”
Justification: This is false, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden signs an executive order to terminate Social Security, SSI, bans side hustle.”
Justification: President Biden has not signed any order to end Social Security or government disability payments. He has also not banned moonlighting. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Dr. Ben Carson discovered 3 completely natural ingredients that resulted in headaches disappearing, blood cholesterol levels lowering, and elevated blood pressure disappearing.”
Justification: This claim is fabricated. "Completely fake," Dr. Ben Carson’s spokesperson said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Albert Einstein was a transgender.”
Justification: This claim is baseless. Albert Einstein’s birth certificate identifies him as a "child of the male sex."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Nancy Pelosi is responsible for Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol.
Justification: Fact-checkers have debunked many claims about former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. There is ample evidence that Pelosi was a target of the attack and none that she was responsible for the event. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: As of March 13, they “really just banned TikTok … we got 6 months left to use it.”
Justification: A potential TikTok ban passed the U.S. House of Representatives, but the legislation’s future is uncertain.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Texas petition to outlaw “aerosolized spraying” is evidence of chemtrails.
Justification: "Chemtrails" are a conspiracy theory that claims that the condensation trails behind aircraft are part of a secret, large-scale program to poison the atmosphere with toxic chemicals. Chemtrails are not real, scientists and the U.S. Air Force say. A group called Clean Texas Skies is circulating a petition asking Texas state lawmakers to pass legislation to prohibit "aerosolized spraying," which appears to be part of the chemtrails conspiracy theory. The petition doesn’t prove chemtrails are real. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Contrails Facts from the U.S. Air Force

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Russian company secured Trump’s bond in E. Jean Carroll case.
Justification: The U.S.-based Federal Insurance Co., a subsidiary of global insurance giant Chubb, secured former President Donald Trump’s $91.6 million bond to cover the amount he owes writer E. Jean Carroll after a verdict in her defamation lawsuit. Chubb is based in Zurich and operates in 54 countries and territories. About 59% of the company’s revenue comes from its U.S. business. Chubb has businesses in Russia, which accounted for a small portion of its revenue. Chubb decoupled from these businesses after Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, a spokesperson said. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: United States Securities and Exchange Commission

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows the Smokehouse Creek fire in Texas.
Justification: The photo was uploaded in 2017, in a feature about a fire in Gray County, Texas. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: X Post by Texas A&M Forest Service

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Beyoncé faces nearly $10 billion loss following ‘Black national anthem’ performance at NFL.”
Justification: This performance never happened. This claim stemmed from a satirical piece published in September 2023. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Martin Luther King Jr. is “rallying around President Trump!”
Justification: Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968, when Trump was 21 years old and still attending the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Rothschilds were behind the Federal Reserve, and they now control the global financial system.”
Justification: Jacob Rothschild, an heir to the Rothschild banking fortune, died Feb. 26, prompting old conspiracy theories about the family to recirculate. The Rothschild family neither controls global financial systems nor is "behind" the Federal Reserve. The antisemitic conspiracy theory has been repeatedly debunked over centuries. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: PolitiFact: "Meme way off in claim that the Rothschild family holds '80 percent of the world's"
Time "The History of Antisemitic Conspiracy Theories

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “7.2 million illegals entered the U.S. under Biden administration,” showing that “the ‘Great Replacement’ is not a theory, it’s a reality."
Justification: The "great replacement theory" claims there is a conspiracy to replace white people of European descent with nonwhite people. The 7.2 million figure represents the number ofencountersU.S. border officials had with immigrants at the Southwest border from October 2021 through September 2024. It doesn’t show how many migrants entered and remained in the country. Millions of encounters led to removals, federal data shows. ​Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Jan. 6 committee “suppressed testimony” from former Deputy Chief of Staff Anthony Ornato that proves former President Donald Trump pushed for 10,000 National Guard troops at the Capitol.
Justification: The House select committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol didn’t publicly release a transcript from its January 2022 interview with former President Donald Trump’s deputy chief of staff, Anthony Ornato, because the Department of Homeland Security was reviewing it for potential security concerns, a letter between the committee and DHS shows. In the transcript, Ornato said he recalled other White House officials saying Trump suggested having 10,000 National Guard troops on Jan. 6, 2021. But he didn’t say Trump gave an order for that many troops. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Committee on House Administration’s Subcommittee on Oversight
Email interview with Rep. Jamie Raskin
Email interview with Rep. Zoe Lofgren
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "NYC to give ILLEGALS $53 Million in Prepaid Credit Cards."
Justification: New York City will give 500 migrant families prepaid debit cards to buy food and baby supplies as part of a pilot program. The city has earmarked $53 million to expand the program if it’s successful. There is a subtle, but crucial, difference between a credit card and a prepaid debit card. With credit cards, you are borrowing money — spending now and paying later. With prepaid debit cards, you spend what’s already loaded. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Texas tractors defend border.”
Justification: No, Texas tractors are not lining up on the southern border. A Facebook video claiming to show that is of a tractor protest in Germany. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden or Donald Trump dropped out of the 2024 presidential race as of Feb 15.
Justification: Neither President Joe Biden nor former President Donald Trump had dropped out of the 2024 presidential race as of Feb. 15, when the claim was posted. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Wearing this bracelet aids in weight loss.
Justification: Health experts say there’s no evidence that wearing magnetic jewelry or bracelets will prompt significant weight loss. Drinking water, eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly can promote a healthy lifestyle. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Poland's foreign minister said the U.S. is "dysfunctional and unreliable" because it has not sent more aid to Ukraine.
Justification: In a Bloomberg News interview, Poland’s foreign minister expressed concern about U.S. not sending more military aid to Ukraine but did not call the U.S. dysfunctional and unreliable. This quote was lifted from an X poster’s summary  of the foreign minister’s interview.ut We find no evidence it is a direct quote. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Setting on Apple’s new Journal app “lets anyone near you know your FULL NAME and EXACTLY where you’re geo-located.”
Justification: Journal, a new Apple journaling app, prompts users to write entries, based on user-enabled information. One feature, if enabled, uses iPhone location data to prioritize prompts — for example, encouraging entry writing if many other iPhone users are nearby. But that feature doesn’t share personal information, such as names and exact locations, with Journal users. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows Donald Trump on a street lined with American flags and a crowd behind him.
Justification: This image is not authentic and was generated by artificial intelligence. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Stanley cups tested positive for lead “inside of the cup where the drink is.”
Justification: Stanley cups’ base contain a sealing material with lead, used to vacuum seal the cups. The lead is covered by stainless steel and doesn’t come into contact with areas consumers touch or drink from, the company said. The Consumer Product Safety Commission has not recalled Stanley cups and said lead home-testing kits are unreliable. A lead expert who tested the cups told PolitiFact he detected no lead on the cup’s exterior or lid and that it would be impossible for lead in the base to reach the cup’s interior. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donald Trump called his wife "Mercedes" instead of Melania.
Justification: Former President Trump was talking to Mercedes Schlapp, his former White House director of strategic communications and wife of Conservative Political Action Conference chair Matt Schlapp, who was sitting to Trump’s left in the audience. Trump was not referring to his wife, Melania. Trump looked to his left, where Mercedes was sitting in the front row, each of the three times he mentioned her name during the speech. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar and Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison posing at “Defund the Police” event.
Justification: This photo was altered. The original photo, from a 2022 election event, does not show "defund the police" signs. Neither Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., nor Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison has supported efforts to defund the police. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Republican Cindy McCain endorses Joe Biden” in 2024.
Justification: Cindy McCain, widow of the late Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., has not endorsed President Joe Biden in the 2024 election. A Facebook quoting Cindy McCain endorsing Biden was taken from two 2020 tweets. A review of news clips and her social media accounts does not show she has not yet issued any endorsement in the 2024 presidential election. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Taylor Swift wearing an anti-Donald Trump T-shirt.
Justification: The photo was altered. In the original 2019 photo Swift wore a pink and yellow dress. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A portable heater invented by a Vietnam War-era veteran can heat a whole home and slash heating bills.
Justification: No, a Vietnam veteran did not invent a portable heater that can quickly heat a whole house on the cheap. It’s a scam product with bogus links. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: KQED via YouTube: KQED Interview with disabled Latino Vietnam War veteran: David Gonzalez
Toasty Heater "This is how thousands of Americans are heating up their homes and slashing electric bills"

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a convicted terrorist, Movsum Samadov, coming to the U.S. through the southern border.
Justification: PolitiFact found no official reports from news outlets or governmental agencies that claim Movsum Samadov, the head of the Islamic Party of Azerbaijan, entered the U.S southern border. Samadov told Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty Jan. 24 that he is not the man in the posts. He said he is banned from leaving Azerbaijan following his prison release a year ago. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.
Sources: Email interview with spokesperson from DHS
United States Commission on International Religious Freedom
United States Commission on International Religious Freedom search

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Donald Trump advertising $6,400 spending cards.
Justification: This video was altered. That is not former President Donald Trump promoting free $6,400 spending cards.
Sources: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Federal food assistance recipients and their children can get “a free passport” by using a specific waiver form.
Justification: The State Department, which issues U.S. passports, says on its website that fee waiver Form I-912 is for immigration services and does not apply to U.S. passports.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Elon Musk developed “Cosmo Heater,” a product that would cut heating costs “to basically $0.”
Justification: A heating device developed by Musk, who runs companies including SpaceX and Tesla, may sound legitimate. But this product is not linked to Musk at all.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: During a speech former President Donald Trump said, “Even the lemonade is killing people” under President Joe Biden.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump did not make these comments. The captions were fabricated on screenshots of Trump delivering a Dec. 13 speech in Coralville, Iowa. The images appear to have originated on a comedian’s social media account.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The U.S. is sending everyone (a) free $16,800 right now.”
Justification: The U.S. government has not announced it’s sending out $16,800 payments. Another sign of a scam: The link included in the social media post is not affiliated with the federal government.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Elon Musk invented an energy-saving device that could “cut electricity bills by 80%.”
Justification: A post claiming Elon Musk has invented an energy-saving device to reduce power bills is an example of a popular tactic online scammers use. Although Musk is involved in the electricity generation business through his company Tesla that sells solar panels, he has not made an energy-saving device that would cut users’ electricity bills.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The government will send a $2,400 check monthly to people earning less than $30 an hour.
Justification: There is no government program giving out $2,400 checks a month. The claim is the latest scam fact-checked by PolitiFact that targets vulnerable people and offers subsidies from nonexistent government programs. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: CNN reported that Dr. Ben Carson has discovered a natural cure for headaches, cholesterol levels and blood pressure symptoms.
Justification: This screenshot is altered. CNN did not report this, Dr. Ben Carson did not say it and medical experts say there is no cure for high blood pressure.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A juice of carrots, cucumbers and garlic will "restore perfect vision in seven days.”
Justification: Good nutrition can contribute to healthy eyesight in some circumstances, for some people, but experts at the National Eye Institute say its effects are limited and won’t restore perfect vision. Most eye problems stem from vision-impairment caused by genetics, aging or diabetes, one expert said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Any type of ground or processed meats have human flesh in them.”
Justification: There is no human flesh in processed, ground meat. The U.S. Department of Agriculture inspects all meat products and allows only other farm animal products as additives, according to its website. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Kelly Clarkson endorsing a natural weight loss product.
Justification: The video was altered using clips from Kelly Clarkson’s Instagram account.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows President Joe Biden promoting a $6,400 government subsidy.
Justification: President Joe Biden has not announced a $6,400 government subsidy. The video’s audio was edited to sound like Biden. The link included with the post is not affiliated with the federal government. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Congress has passed a $6,400 subsidy for low-income Americans.
Justification: Congress has passed no legislation giving $6,400 to low-income families. The claim is the latest scam fact-checked by PolitiFact that targets vulnerable families and offers enticing, nonexistent government programs. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Ben Carson endorsed CBD gummies to treat high blood pressure.
Justification: A spokesperson for Dr. Ben Carson said the retired neurosurgeon and former Housing and Urban Development secretary, has neither endorsed nor heard of the CBD product advertised in social media posts. The screenshot of a CNN article appearing to show Carson endorsing the product was edited. No such CNN article exists.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Nikki Haley is ineligible to be president or vice president.
Justification: The U.S. Constitution requires that a president be a natural-born citizen. It also says a person born in the U.S. is a citizen. Nikki Haley, a Republican candidate for president, meets eligibility requirements, experts said, because she was born in South Carolina. The citizenship status of Haley’s parents, who became citizens after her birth, don’t affect Haley’s eligibility for the job, experts said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Oz endorsed gummies to “clean blood vessels” and treat high blood pressure.
Justification: This video’s audio was edited. Dr. Mehmet Oz didn’t endorse gummies to treat high blood pressure. For years, Oz has warned people not to fall for scams that use his name and likeness to sell health products.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hunter Biden’s “prison term announced.”
Justification: Hunter Biden is facing two indictments, but he has not been convicted of any charges.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Trump has selected his pick for running mate (and the) news stuns Republican Party.”
Justification: Former President Donald Trump has not announced a running mate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows that “Troy Nehls FORCES Pete Buttigieg to admit that Biden is unfit to serve.”
Justification: The video does not show that. During the exchange with Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg called President Joe Biden a "vigorous" boss.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Audio shows former President Donald Trump warned “300 million Americans” will die from a catastrophe “in a matter of weeks.”
Justification: We could not identify the source for the audio contained in these videos, which also appeared as paid ads on Meta. Former President Donald Trump is not on record endorsing the Teddy Daniels documentary that is promoted in these videos. Nor do we find any published evidence that he issued these warnings. While the audio is reminiscent of Trump’s voice, it does not match the cadence of his natural speaking voice. Experts told us AI-detection analysis was not conclusive as to whether the audio was electronically generated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows woman embracing and kissing “a doll,” evidence of “Hamas street theater propaganda exposed.”
Justification: A journalist who photographed this scene identified the infant as 5-month-old Muhammad Hani Al-Zahar, who had been killed. The Jerusalem Post published an article Dec.1 headlined, "Al Jazeera posts blurred doll, claims it to be a dead Palestinian baby," before deleting the article and issuing a statement a day later that it shared an article with "faulty sourcing."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Suggests homeless people mysteriously went missing in San Francisco.
Justification: The Department of Homeland Security designated the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in San Francisco, attended by President Joe Biden and President Xi Jinping of China, as a special security event, which restricted access for some geographic areas of the city. San Francisco officials moved some of the city’s homeless population into shelters before the summit. Other homeless people moved to alleys and under a freeway, advocates for homeless people said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. manual for courts-martial has been recently amended to include civilians.
Justification: Courts-martial is the judicial system for adjudicating offenses committed by military personnel. Ordinary civilians are not subject to U.S. courts-martial. However, civilians working for military branches in the field during wartime can be tried under military law. The 2023 U.S. Manual for Courts-Martial sets out how the Uniform Code for Military Justice, a law passed by Congress, is to be implemented. Congress has not made any changes to the code since 2007.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows teacher teaching gender pronouns and being confronted by students
Justification: This clip shows a skit created by Jibrizy, an online video creator who says he makes videos to "start discussion." The original clip has a disclaimer at the end that it is scripted, but that is edited out from the version being shared. Jibrizy’s videos depicting fake confrontations over LGBTQ+ issues havegone viralbefore without context.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows the aftermath of a school prank in which students drank lemonade containing “horse laxatives.”
Justification: The video does not show real high school students. It’s from the true crime satire show "American Vandal."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: John D. Rockefeller wrote a secret covenant about controlling the world’s population.
Justification: This "secret covenant" emerged online in 2002 on a financial website written by an anonymous author. We found no credible information linking this statement to John D. Rockefeller. Rockefeller, one of the world’s first billionaires, and his family are frequent targets of conspiracy theories.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Tyson Foods may put insect protein in your chicken nuggets.
Justification: Tyson Foods partnered with Protix, a Netherlands-based company that produces insect ingredients. Tyson bought a minority stake in the company and will build an insect-ingredient factory in the U.S. The products produced there will not be for human food consumption, a Tyson spokesperson said. The insects will be used for animal or plant feed.
Sources: U.S. Food and Drug Administration spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Elon Musk announcing he’s giving away free gold bars.
Justification: A Facebook post took a video of Elon Musk talking out of context and edited the audio. Musk isn’t giving away free gold bars.
Sources: Elon Musk Says a World Government Could Lead to Civilization Collapse
Email exchange with X press email

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The new Inflation Reduction Act has just been updated to give Americans making less than $50,000 per year up to $6,400 in subsidies every single month.”
Justification: The U.S. government has not updated the Inflation Reduction Act, a 2022 law, to give Americans $6,400 in monthly subsidies. The link included with the post is not affiliated with the federal government.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Any American who needs $2,000 a month can get it now” thanks to a new government program.
Justification: An IRS spokesperson told PolitiFact that a legitimate government check will never have the IRS as the payer, the way the check shown in the Facebook post does.
Sources: Email interview with IRS spokesperson Octavio O. Saenz

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The U.S. is sending everyone a free $6,400 right now.”
Justification: The U.S. government has not announced it’s sending everyone $6,400. The link included in the post is not affiliated with the federal government.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Magnetic “lymphatic earrings” aid weight loss.
Justification: Health experts say there’s no evidence that wearing magnetic jewelry or earrings that stimulate acupressure points will prompt significant weight loss. Drinking water, eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly can promote a healthy lifestyle.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A river in Russia turned red in a biblical omen or divine “retribution.”
Justification: This video shows Russia’s Iskitimka River in 2020, when local officials said it turned  red because of possible contamination from the city’s drainage system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A “brand new financial relief program available for Americans" provides $5,000 in cash.
Justification: The post links to a website that says it collects personal information to connect users with lenders. The site asks for bank account and Social Security numbers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “8 MINUTES AGO! The largest underwater volcano has SUDDENLY CRACKED OPEN the Earth!”
Justification: The Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai underwater volcano did erupt, but it was in January 2022, not recently.
Sources: BBC News " How the Tonga Hunga volcano produced the most intense lightning ever seen

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “heavy snow and ice has frozen jets in Munich bound for Dubai's global warming conference.”
Justification: A Facebook video shows an airplane tipped over by heavy snowfall in Munich. But that plane was not bound for Dubai, United Arab Emirates, the site of the United Nations Conference of the Parties, aka COP28, a global climate change summit. Flight records show an Austrian company operates the airplane and the plane’s last flight was Nov. 15 from Antwerp, Belgium, to Munich.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Audio shows breaking news that “Biden approves $5,200 for Americans older than 25.”
Justification: President Joe Biden did not approve a subsidy worth $5,200 for Americans older than 25. An expert analyzed the audio and deemed it fake, citing the telltale "robotic" cadence of an AI-generated voice.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Pizzagate “expert” went to jail for child pornography
Justification: Former ABC News investigative journalist James Gordon Meek was sentenced in September to six years in federal prison for possessing and transporting child sexual abuse images. Meek never debunked the Pizzagate conspiracy theory. He mentioned the theory once in an article about Russian propaganda in Syria.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a family learning their debt was resolved by the “American Debt Relief program” for American citizens and legal residents who “have over $20,000” in credit card debt.
Justification: This video clip appears to have originated on the TikTok account of a prospective Tulane University student receiving word in 2019 that she had been accepted. There is no federal program called the "American Debt Relief program" available to Americans who have more than $20,000 in credit card debt. The video directs viewers to a private debt settlement company.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows “American soldiers praying for their country, for Israel before being deployed to defend Israel” in 2023.
Justification: This photo is more than 6 years old. U.S. troops have not been deployed to fight in the Israel-Hamas war.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows President Joe Biden invoking the Selective Service Act.
Justification: This video of President Joe Biden announcing that he is invoking the Selective Service Act for a military draft was generated by artificial intelligence. It was first uploaded in February.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Black flag hoisted over a mosque in Iran is a “call to all of Islam for war.”
Justification: The Imam Reza shrine in Iran hoisted a black flag in mourning after the explosion at a Gaza hospital. It’s not uncommon for the shrine to hoist a black flag in mourning.
Sources: Instagram post by Holy Shrine of Imam Reza

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: 1936 in the United States was “much hotter than 2023.”
Justification: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration data shows that in the contiguous U.S., the first nine months of 2023 were 1.64°F warmer than the parallel period in 1936. There’s overwhelming evidence that human-caused climate change is warming the Earth and leading to more intense and frequent heat waves.
Sources: Center for Climate and Energy Solutions
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s National Centers for Environmental information

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Elon Musk and the Dubai billionaire have unveiled new software called ‘Quantum AI.’”
Justification: This is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: New York’s fraud case against Trump “has nothing to do with his home in Mar-a-Lago.”
Justification: In 2022, New York Attorney General Letitia James filed a lawsuit alleging that former President Donald Trump and the Trump Organization "created more than 200 false and misleading valuations of assets" to defraud financial institutions. Trump has denied wrongdoing. In September, a New York Supreme Court judge ruled Trump had inflated his Mar-a-Lago estate’s value. Regardless of Mar-a-Lago’s exact value, the question of whether Trump assets’ values were inflated is central to the New York fraud case.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: New York Attorney General Letitia James said President Joe Biden “is an embarrassment to all that we stand for.”
Justification: Video footage of New York Attorney General Letitia James shows her criticizing then-President Donald Trump in 2018, not President Joe Biden now.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Egypt is now at war with Israel.”
Justification: There have been no credible news reports or government declarations that Egypt is now at war with Israel.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Every President we ever had in the United States of America was a draconian reptilian.”
Justification: Claims that politicians are reptilian are part of an unfounded and long-standing conspiracy theory.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There is a serial killer in Cincinnati.” Seven bodies were found “chopped up.”
Justification: Cincinnati officials said only one woman has been found dismembered in the city, contrary to social media rumors of a serial killer on the loose in Cincinnati.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. Rep. Mike Johnson is the 45th speaker of the House.
Justification: U.S. Rep. Mike Johnson is the 56th speaker of the House. Then-Rep. John McCormack, D-Mass., was the 45th speaker of the House

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video proves that the United Nations is “setting up shop in U.S. states.”
Justification: The video was first posted in 2017. It shows United Nations peacekeeping vehicles manufactured in the U.S. and stored at a State Department warehouse in Hagerstown, Maryland, before they are shipped overseas. A State Department spokesperson told PolitiFact that the vehicles were used exclusively in U.N. peace operations abroad.
Sources: Statement from a State Department spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Switzerland’s distribution of iodine tablets means the government is worried about nuclear war.
Justification: For years, Switzerland has distributed iodine tablets to residents living within 50 kilometers (31.1 miles) of one of the country’s three nuclear power plants. It last distributed such pills in 2014. Its current distribution doesn’t suggest it’s worried about nuclear war.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden declared a federal emergency and deployed the National Guard in October.
Justification: This video is about an emergency declaration in Vermont after heavy rains and flooding in July; we found no evidence that President Joe Biden declared a national emergency in October and deployed the National Guard as a result.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The life span of a wind tower generator lasts just three to four years.
Justification: A study by energy industry experts showed that an average wind turbine generator lasts around 25 to 75 years. A spokesperson for the wind farm mentioned in the post said its wind turbine generators are expected to last around 20 years. ​
Sources: Search on U.S. Wind Turbine Database

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden confirms WW3 live on TV.”
Justification: President Joe Biden urged aid for Israel and Ukraine in a recent primetime address; he didn’t declare World War III.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Oprah FREAKS OUT after 15 kids are finally found on Maui.”
Justification: This story is unfounded. Allegations about 15 missing children discovered after the Maui wildfires stemmed from a fake news story.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “NATO troops deployed to Ukraine.”
Justification: No NATO troops in Ukraine, NATO says

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Hamas launching a “rocket attack.”
Justification: These images are from a video game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows children disappearing from inside a school bus.
Justification: The video is edited to show a religious dramatization of the rapture, the moment some Christians believe Jesus Christ will return to Earth to bring believers to heaven. The video is one of many "rapture pre-enactments" created by the Christian organization Turning Point for God, which says it hopes to grab viewers' attention with dramatic clips.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith advertising “$5,600 health spending cards.”
Justification: This video was altered. That’s not actress Jada Pinkett Smith promoting free health spending cards.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump controls U.S. military.”
Justification: Former President Donald Trump doesn’t control the military.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Man cuts off wife’s head after DNA test proved none of 6 kids are his own.”
Justification: This isn’t an authentic news story.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Justin Trudeau’s plane was filled with cocaine when he landed in India for the G20 summit.
Justification: We found no evidence to support this claim. The person who made the claim — India’s former ambassador to Sudan — called it a "credible rumor" and did not provide evidence to support it. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s office said the claim is false. NewsMobile, an Indian fact-checking site, reported that senior Indian government officials also said the claim is false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: New York Attorney General Letitia James and Judge Arthur Engoron valued Mar-a-Lago at $18 million.
Justification: New York officials did not determine the value of former President Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. The property appraiser in Palm Beach County, where the estate is located, assessed the property and determined its value. In evaluating the property, Palm Beach County officials account for Mar-a-Lago’s being a deed-restricted private club. Unlike a private home, the property’s value is determined by the amount of income it generates as a club.
Sources: New York Attorney General Letitia James
Supreme Court of the state of New York

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Patent shows 5G towers are used for brainwashing.
Justification: U.S. patent No. 5356368A is not related to 5G towers. It’s for a meditation aid by the Monroe Institute, a nonprofit organization, according to a Monroe Institute spokesperson.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "‎The emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, has threatened that if the bombing of Gaza does not stop, he will cut off the supply of gas to the world.”
Justification: Qatar’s emir hasn’t threatened to cut off the world’s gas supply if the bombing of Gaza doesn’t stop. The country’s government has tried to mediate in the Israel-Hamas war, but has made no such threat.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin “warns ‘global terrorist’ Klaus Schwab his ‘days are numbered.’”
Justification: Russian President Vladimir Putin didn’t say this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Israeli Air Force…striking terror targets in Gaza” in October.
Justification: This video is from May 2023.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Footage shows “Palestinian freedom fighters shot down 4 Israelis fighter jets.”
Justification: This footage is from Arma 3, a combat simulation video game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Campaign finance disclosures showed Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis took part in a “massive money laundering and election fraud” scheme.
Justification: A report highlighted more than 200 contributions to Willis’ campaign with no donor information. This isn’t proof of a money laundering scheme. Georgia’s campaign finance laws don’t require donor information for donations worth $100 and below. All the contributions with no donor information were within this range.
Sources: Georgia Government Transparency and Campaign Finance Act
Rules of the State Ethics Commission

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Katie Hobbs no longer governor of Arizona.”
Justification: Katie Hobbs is still Arizona’s governor. On Sept. 27, the state’s treasurer said she would briefly serve as acting governor, as mandated by the state constitution, while Hobbs was out of state on business.
Sources: OFFICE OF THE ARIZONA STATE TREASURER

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez crying on CNN.
Justification: This video doesn’t show  Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez crying on CNN.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A new deadly pandemic is at our doorstep.”
Justification: The World Health Organization, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other public health authorities track disease outbreaks worldwide and alert the public about emerging health threats. But no new global health crisis has been declared.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Cries of Victory in Israel — Gaza Now Belongs to Israel! HAMAS Surrenders Desperately!”
Justification: Israel has yet to launch an expected ground invasion into Gaza in response to an Oct. 7 terrorist attack by Hamas militants. There are no credible reports that Hamas leaders have surrendered.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows magnetic meat for sale in U.S. grocery stores.
Justification: The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service said meat and poultry establishments must follow regulations and undergo inspections to ensure their products don’t contain any hazards, such as metal pieces. The texture or moisture of a packaged meat or poultry product — and even the angle at which it's held — may cause a magnet to stick to the packaging, but that doesn’t mean the meat is magnetic or contains metal, the USDA said.
Sources: Email exchange with a U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service spokesperson
U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service
U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service website

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A fact-check proves Michelle Obama is “a he.”
Justification: Former first lady Michelle Obama is not a man.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows President Joe Biden admitting “shady role in Maui fires.”
Justification: This video doesn’t show that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows footage of recent violence in Israel.
Justification: This is a clip from a video game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: At a United Nations summit, President Joe Biden and U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres warned of a planned disaster.
Justification: The statements mentioned in the video were not warnings about a planned disaster. President Joe Biden misspoke about "accelerating the climate crisis" and immediately corrected himself. U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres’ was discussing climate change when he said humanity had opened the "gates of hell."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows all highways closed in Berlin “right now.”
Justification: Multiple clips in this video are from previous years and places other than Berlin. We found no evidence to support the claim that all highways closed in Berlin on Sept. 24 when the post was shared, or anytime around then.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Three minutes ago Trump cries after losing everything after new evidence exposed.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pentagon releases NASA footage of 2,000 mile long UFO near Saturn.”
Justification: The Pentagon released no such footage, a Defense Department spokesperson said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Hillary Clinton on a “lethal injection medical table.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Whoopi, Joy and Sunny Threaten To Resign ‘Immediately’ If Candace Owens Joins The Panel.”
Justification: This story was fabricated and originated on a satirical website. A spokesperson for "The View" said the claim is not true. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a Federal Emergency Management Agency “concentration camp” in Hawaii.
Justification: his isn’t a Federal Emergency Management Agency camp. It’s a tiny home community on Oahu, Hawaii, for unhoused people. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Janet Yellen arrested for treason.”
Justification: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen wasn’t arrested. This claim is unfounded. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Walmart must pay $500 to U.S. families who made purchases in 2022.”
Justification: These claims are unfounded. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Under Project Hamilton, “every dollar you hold in your bank account, your wallet and even your retirement” will be confiscated and “replaced with a dangerous new totally digital dollar.”
Justification: Project Hamilton is a collaborative research project between the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Digital Currency Initiative. The project is focused on studying the feasibility of a hypothetical central bank digital currency, not implementing one. The Federal Reserve says on its website that its research into central bank digital currency is a way to explore safe payment options, not to reduce or replace cash. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Digital Currency Initiative
The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Poland declares war on Russia.”
Justification: Poland has increased its military presence along its border with Belarus, Russia’s ally, but hasn’t declared war against either country. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hillary Clinton in trouble as her dark web video leaked.”
Justification: This is a baseless conspiracy theory. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Giant human skeletons as large as 36 feet have been “unearthed and documented” in historical records.
Justification: Giant skeleton hoaxes have been circulating online for years. Many can be traced back to edited contest pictures. PolitiFact found no evidence to support claims that giant human skeletons have been discovered and documented. In 2012, researchers found that a skeleton dating back to the third century had a rare growth condition called pituitary gigantism. They estimated that person would have been about 6.5 feet tall.
Sources: The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A World Economic Forum video reveals conspiracy behind COVID-19 spread.
Justification: A 2021 World Economic Forum video used the COVID-19 pandemic as an analogy to warn world leaders to prepare for potentially damaging cyberattacks. There is no evidence it was code for a broader conspiracy involving COVID-19 spread. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. Rep. Nancy Pelosi was arrested.
Justification: Former House Speaker, Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., wasn’t arrested. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Walmart must pay $500 to customers who made purchases in the last 180 days.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. We found no evidence in news reports or other credible sources that Walmart is required to make any such payment to customers. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video proves U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland faces “a lying charge” after giving a fake number to Sen. John Kennedy, R-La., at a hearing.
Justification: The video does not show U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland facing a "lying charge." Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Cornell Law School Legal Information Institute

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Princess Diana, actor Heath Ledger and musician John Lennon were “killed for exposing the truth.”
Justification: Princess Diana died after a car crash and actor Heath Ledger died of a drug overdose. Musician John Lennon was assassinated, but not for "exposing the truth." Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Elon Musk promising $45,000 in Canadian currency for participating Canadian citizens.
Justification: This video was altered. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows an April 2023 clown attack in Paris.
Justification: This video is not recent and isn’t related to clowns. It’s from a 2015 news broadcast. It shows a crowd in Paris that began running because of a potential gun threat, which turned out to be a false alarm. Clowns were neither involved nor pictured. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows Sen. Rand Paul in a bathrobe on the steps of the U.S. Capitol.
Justification: Both Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., and the image’s creator confirmed that the picture was generated by artificial intelligence. The photo is in response to the Senate’s relaxed dress code, which has caused controversy among politicians.
Sources: Phone interview with spokesperson for Sen. Rand Paul. R-Ky.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Obama finally reveals how personal chef drowned in mysterious pond accident.”
Justification: Tafari Campbell, the Obama family’s personal chef, drowned in July while paddleboarding near the Obamas’ home in Martha’s Vineyard, Massachusetts. The state’s office of the chief medical examiner ruled his death an accident. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “everyone will be wiped out in 21 days.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden is going to trial for “treason,” “sedition” and “crimes against humanity.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The mothers of Major League Soccer players “file complaint against Leo Messi.”
Justification: This story originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows former first lady Michelle Obama “accidentally reveals what really happened to their chef.”
Justification: We found no evidence to support this claim. The drowning death of Tafari Campbell, the Obamas’ personal chef, was ruled accidental.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: CNN reported “breaking news” that the Pentagon announced a plan to “implant Americans with nanotech particles.”
Justification: The claim originated from Alex Jones, a known peddler of conspiracy theories. He used clips of an Army-sponsored conference in 2017, which discussed the future of conflict. The Pentagon did not announce a plan to "implant Americans with nanotech particles," and CNN reported no such "breaking news." Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: TRADOC Mad Scientist 2017 Georgetown: Neurotechnology in National Defense w/ Dr. Giordano
U.S. Department of Defense press releases

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “CNN just said Cash App went bankrupt and any funds you had in your account would have to be awarded to you through bankruptcy court.”
Justification: Cash App’s mobile payment service was disrupted Sept. 7, but the platform hasn’t declared bankruptcy, and CNN didn’t report as much.
Sources: Email interview with Anna Beth Jager

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Elon Musk said President Joe Biden “has one month left to live.”
Justification: We found no evidence to support this claim. The video also does not provide corroborating evidence.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: CNN reported that “Barack Obama’s ex-boyfriend admits he was ‘prime suspect’ in gay serial killer case.”
Justification: CNN didn’t report that former President Barack Obama was implicated as a suspected serial killer.
Sources: Email interview with Anna Beth Jager

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos are evidence of “satanism in public schools.”
Justification: A digital creator made these photos using artificial intelligence.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Joan Rivers’ daughter threatens to expose Michelle Obama.”
Justification: This is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Speaker at World Economic Forum conference proposed adding COVID-19 vaccines to water supply.
Justification: A speaker at a 2022 World Economic Forum news conference did not propose adding COVID-19 vaccines to the water supply. She discussed water equity and said addressing it is in everyone’s interest, comparing it with vaccination during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Sources: Global Commision on the Economics of Water

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: CNN reported Sept. 7, 2023, that President Joe Biden’s family admitted “he died and was replaced by an actor in 2019.”
Justification: The video was posted in 2022 by a TikTokker with a satirical account. CNN has made no such news report.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “We have over a million people right now that are under emergency travel restrictions … and this is due to poison being released into the air.”
Justification: After air quality alerts were issued Aug. 20 and Aug. 21 for parts of Indiana and Ohio, news reports included guidelines that encouraged people to avoid driving if possible. Those guidelines were just suggestions; they were not mandatory and did not restrict anyone’s travel.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Shots fired T.L Hanna High School 1 seriously injured.”
Justification: This didn’t happen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Barack Obama’s late chef’s wife comes out to expose Obama family.”
Justification: This video offers no evidence that the wife of the late Tafari Campbell, personal chef to the Obama family, "exposed" the Obama family in any way or blamed them for her husband’s death. We also found no evidence to support the claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Clearwater Beach during Hurricane Idalia.
Justification: This video shows a waterspout on Clearwater Beach, Florida, in June, not Hurricane Idalia making landfall in August.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A new Florida law says “a father must submit a DNA test before signing the birth certificates.”
Justification: We found no evidence of any Florida law that requires fathers to complete DNA testing before they can sign their children’s birth certificates. A new state paternity law makes it easier for many fathers to assume parental responsibility. The law acknowledges unmarried fathers’ rights by expanding a state statute that previously defaulted natural guardianship to the mother. Fathers can establish paternity by signing a form in front of a notary public in a hospital at the child’s birth.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The WHO is developing a pandemic treaty that will remove current human rights protections, enforce surveillance and censorship and eliminate freedom of speech.
Justification: World Health Organization member states are drafting an accord focused on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response. An early draft of the accord, which is not finalized, included language about protecting human rights and member state sovereignty. The accord is a work in progress, but experts have said the WHO lacks the power to make a member state act, or restrict rights or freedoms, against its will.
Sources: Email exchange with a World Health Organization spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Mom of Barack Obama’s chef speaks out to expose Obama family.”
Justification: We found no evidence to corroborate this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Judge Cannon been ordered to DISQUALIFY herself in Trump's case.”
Justification: Judge Aileen Cannon has faced calls to recuse herself in the federal classified documents case against former President Donald Trump, but she hasn’t been ordered to do so.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Tafari Campbell was “murdered.”
Justification: Tafari Campbell’s drowning death was ruled accidental.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video suggests Canada wildfires were deliberately set to advance “smart cities” push.
Justification: Wildfires in Canada were caused by record heat and drought. There is no evidence they were set deliberately or linked to efforts to advance "smart cities."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows the state of “Great Britain now,” with “78,000 people under the water.”
Justification: There are no credible reports that 78,000 people are "under the water" in Great Britain. This video contains numerous clips from past weather events, some of which are not in Britain. The video’s opening image was not from a disaster at all but from a staged 2019 climate protest near London’s Tower Bridge.
Sources: Third UK Climate Change Risk Assessment (CCRA3) future flood risk main report

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A FEMA office in Chicago is proof of a conspiracy.
Justification: After parts of Chicago experienced major flooding this summer, the Federal Emergency Management Agency set up several disaster recovery centers in the city and surrounding suburbs where residents could get federal assistance and funding.
Sources: Email exchange with a Federal Emergency Management Agency spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: As of Aug. 25, "Luis Rubiales has resigned as the president of the Spanish Football Federation."
Justification: Spain soccer president Luis Rubiales had not resigned as of Aug. 29.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows that Attorney General Merrick Garland “cries like kid after Taylor Greene calls out stupid ‘Trump’s Arraignment.’”
Justification: This video doesn’t show Attorney General Merrick Garland as he "cries like a kid." He is not in the video at all.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: BBC News reported that British residents “no longer need to work” thanks to an investment project from Elon Musk.
Justification: This video was altered and the claims in it are false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “WEF admits Maui wildfires orchestrated to transform Hawaii into 15-minute cities.”
Justification: The World Economic Forum made no statement saying the Maui wildfires were orchestrated. The cause of the wildfires has not been identified, but authorities have pointed to dry conditions, low humidity and high winds as contributing factors. The island’s aging electric power infrastructure is also under scrutiny. There is no evidence the disaster was an intentional effort to build a 15-minute city in Maui.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Military arrests FEMA Deputy Administrator Erik Hooks.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s deputy administrator was arrested. This claim originated on a site that regularly publishes fabricated stories.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Code red emergency - poison released in the air” affecting 127 million people.
Justification: This August caption misses the context that "code red" air quality warnings in the U.S. were removed after a few days. The video it refers to was first posted on YouTube on June 29, when wildfires in Canada affected the air quality in multiple U.S. states.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “King Charles exposed at Buckingham Palace as ancient reptilian shapeshifter.”
Justification: King Charles III is a human, not a reptile.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Wildfires do not completely burn out cars, glass and all, yet leaving nearby trees and utility poles still standing upright.”
Justification: It is common for trees, utility poles and more isolated features to remain standing even after wildfires destroy other structures in the same area, wildfire experts told PolitiFact. Wildfires that spread in areas where structures and other human developments meet wildlands and vegetation are often spread by flying embers, also known as firebrands, experts said. Those embers can blow past trees or poles, but larger structures that allow the accumulation of those embers are more vulnerable. Experts said the fire damage in Hawaii looked like standard wildfire damage, similar to what has been seen in the past.
Sources: National Institute of Standards and Technology
U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Fox News reported on “an energy-saving device that can save 90% of electricity” from Elon Musk.
Justification: The images in this post were altered.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hillary Clinton was “EXECUTED December 31, 2018.”
Justification: Hillary Clinton was not killed in December 2018. She has made numerous public appearances in the years since.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows military planes over Nashville "dispersing materials into the atmosphere" for geoengineering.
Justification: A video claimed to show military planes spreading materials for "geoengineering." We found no evidence of any such weather-modifying activity.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “We’re seeing two massive explosions on U.S. critical infrastructure in the past 24 hours that have caused power outages.”
Justification: We found no news reports of massive explosions in the U.S. causing extensive damage in the 24 hours before a video claiming such destruction occurred was shared on Facebook or in the 24 hours before it was released on YouTube. On July 24, first responders in Pennsylvania extinguished an explosive fire after a specialized transformer failed, according to news reports. Officials suspect a Virginia gas line might have exploded July 25 because of environmental cracking. We found no evidence that these explosions caused widespread power outages or gas shortages.
Sources: U.S. Department of Transportation Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There has been zero response from local, regional or federal officials” to aid people affected by the Maui, Hawaii, wildfires.
Justification: The video posted Aug. 21 ignores that government aid was made available hours after the wildfires started.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: FEMA and Red Cross are “confiscating” donations meant for Hawaii wildfire victims.
Justification: The Federal Emergency Management Agency coordinates with numerous nonprofits and volunteer organizations to distribute donations. FEMA said neither it nor the American Red Cross have confiscated donations. A statement provided by the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency’s Joint Information Center said that items were sorted and wrapped in plastic because during the disaster’s early stages, there was no designated storage building. Some of those items were clothing and food that could be stored safely at room temperature. Hawaii Gov. Josh Green told people to not believe the misinformation circulating on social media about the fires and emergency aid.
Sources: Email interview with FEMA News Desk
Email interview with a spokesperson from the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Malaysian doctor put to death for giving COVID injection under the (Nuremberg) Code.”
Justification: Malaysia has had a moratorium on executions since 2018 as the country began debating abolishing the death penalty. The country has supported COVID-19 vaccination; in 2021, the nation required federal employees to get vaccinated. The Nuremberg Code is a set of principles related to medical experiments on humans. The COVID-19 vaccines are not experimental — they were deemed safe in clinical trials with willing participants.
Sources: The New England Journal of Medicine

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “articles of impeachment to be filed against President Joe Biden today!”
Justification: This video is from May 2023. Articles of impeachment weren’t filed against President Joe Biden on Aug. 19.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The federal government has just declared a major food shortage emergency" in six states.
Justification: The federal government did not declare a "food shortage emergency," despite a claim by a YouTuber user who makes frequent allegations about emergencies.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Lucky Charms contains an unsafe amount of cleaning compound trisodium phosphate.
Justification: Trisodium phosphate is a common food additive used in processed foods to balance pH and improve texture and boost shelf life. It is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and the European Food Safety Authority and considered safe to consume. Trisodium phosphate is present in minute quantities in food. Higher concentrations of trisodium phosphate are used as acleaning product, and can be irritating and dangerous if large amounts come into contact with the skin, eyes or mouth. The dose matters. The small quantities in food do not cause dangerous or acute health effects.
Sources: Email Interview with the European Food Safety Administration

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Country singer Jason Aldean sued “The View” co-host Whoopi Goldberg.
Justification: This claim originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Official statement — Putin assassinated in the Kremlin!”
Justification: There is no evidence that Russia’s president was assassinated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show people wearing Ku Klux Klan hoods in the mini-mart owned by someone involved in the Montgomery riverfront brawl.
Justification: These photos were taken in 2020 at grocery stores in California and Colorado, not at the store of a man allegedly involved in a recent riverfront brawl in Montgomery, Alabama.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Smart-city plans are behind wildfires in Tenerife.
Justification: A wildfire in Tenerife, the largest of Spain’s Canary Islands and a popular tourist destination, burned for 10 days before being stabilized Aug. 24. The fire burned about 37,000 acres of woodland, but did not affect main cities or tourist areas, officials said. Smart cities refer to cities that use technology to help them run more efficiently and improve quality of life. Installing such technology would not require the destruction of cities, despite social media claims tying the concept to fires in Maui and Tenerife.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Barack Obama “reacts to chef’s wife blaming him for the death of her husband Talafi Cambell.”
Justification: This recording isn’t authentic. We found no evidence that the wife of the late Tafari Campbell, personal chef to the Obama family, blamed the former president for her husband’s death.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video showing celebrities, politicians and other notable figures with black eyes proves they are part of the Illuminati.
Justification: The Illuminati is a centuries-old conspiracy about a secret society of elites that controls the world. A more recent theory baselessly says newsmakers photographed with black eyes have them as part of an initiation into the Illuminati. The vast majority of the black eyes on people seen in a video making this claim have simple explanations, such as accidents or stage makeup.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The White House delivered an “official statement” July 28 that we “need to be getting prepared for something big to happen, potentially to our critical infrastructure.”
Justification: The White House did not warn of an imminent attack to critical infrastructure. The claim cited a report by The New York Times about the discovery and tracking of Chinese malware implanted in networks controlling power grids, communications systems and water supplies servicing military bases. The National Security Council has said it is working to defend the U.S. from any potential disruptions. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hiroshima and Nagasaki were never nuked.”
Justification: The United States dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in Japan in August 1945.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Michelle Obama finally responds to Obama’s hidden gay secret.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Bill Gates said, “We’re taking things that are genetically modified organisms, and we’re injecting them into little kids’ arms” in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Justification: A COVID-19-related TikTok post used a Bill Gates quote on injecting kids with genetically modified organisms out of context. Gates in 2015 was talking about the need to test genetically modified organisms in food much as testing is done with medicines.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Miss USA boycotts Miss Universe pageant: ‘I’m not competing against a man.’”
Justification: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows “the oldest man in the history of mankind” recorded by Guinness World Records.
Justification: This claim originated on a website that published fictitious news stories.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show Target is pushing "evil agenda" on kids.
Justification: A digital creator used generative artificial intelligence to create images of occult-themed merchandise and store displays at the retailer Target. The images were created to "mock" people who boycotted the store, believing it was selling satanic clothing, the creator said in a Facebook comment.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Luke Bryan pulls his videos from CMT: ‘Time for the Bud Light treatment.’”
Justification: This story originated on a self-described satire website. We found no evidence that country music star Luke Bryan removed his videos from Country Music Television to show support for Jason Aldean. CMT told journalists it had pulled Aldean’s "Try That in a Small Town" music video from rotation.
Sources: Emailed statement from a spokesperson for CMT

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There was a recent attempt to assassinate Donald Trump in Reno, Nevada.
Justification: This video is from 2016. On Nov. 5 that year, Donald Trump, then a presidential candidate, was rushed off a rally stage by the Secret Service after someone shouted "gun." At the time, some of his supporters claimed Trump had survived an assassination attempt. A weapon was not found at the rally.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Walmart must refund 2022 customers $500.
Justification: This isn’t an authentic offer from Walmart.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “US Navy SEALs are arresting Ron DeSantis” for running a child sex trafficking ring.
Justification: There is no proof that Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis was arrested July 25. He was in a car crash the same day but was uninjured.
Sources: U.S. Special Operations Command to Host Capabilities Demonstration

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Sen. Ted Cruz asking the Supreme Court to file charges against an aide to Attorney General Merrick Garland.
Justification: This video doesn’t show that. Rather, it shows Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, questioning a deputy attorney general during an April Senate Judiciary Hearing.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Borax can be used to treat a variety of health problems, including joint pain, kidney stones, osteoporosis and chronic fatigue.
Justification: The cleaning product borax should not be consumed as an alternative to boron supplements or naturally occurring boron in foods, experts said. Ingesting borax can cause gastrointestinal problems, rashes, headaches and convulsions. Consuming large amounts could lead to death. Boron is a naturally occurring mineral in many foods, and the average person gets enough boron just from eating a healthy diet, experts said.
Sources: Email exchange with Dr. Kelly Johnson-Arbor
Email exchange with U.S. Food and Drug Administration spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a van “‘Queer testing’ kids without parental approval … (that) involves clothing removal.”
Justification: A Facebook video suggested that children were being "queer tested" without parental approval. The video shows what appears to be a van LabQ Diagnostics used for COVID-19 testing. We found the same video shared in April 2022 with different text that said students were being tested for COVID-19. The video does not explain what it means by "queer testing," and we found nothing to suggest such a test exists.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Beyoncé “is a defendant in a major human trafficking case.”
Justification: The singer Beyoncé was among 38 defendants named in a 2020 lawsuit by a woman alleging they were part of a criminal enterprise engaged in decades of abuse, including sex trafficking and torture. The lawsuit was dismissed a month after it was filed as "frivolous" by a judge, who wrote that the claims within "rise to the level of the irrational." We can find no credible evidence that Beyoncé is a defendant in a human trafficking case or has been credibly accused.
Sources: United States Southern District of New York

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: MSNBC’s Joy Reid hawked diet gummies in an interview with CNN’s Anderson Cooper.
Justification: A video that claimed to show MSNBC host Joy Reid being interviewed by CNN’s Anderson Cooper about her weight loss success using diet gummies is a deepfake. Reid said on Facebook the video isn’t real, and a CNN spokesperson confirmed that the interview did not happen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Two pipeline workers in the Chicago area were given fentanyl-laced water bottles.
Justification: NPL Construction Co. said that a claim that two of its workers were poisoned by fentanyl-laced water they received from a passenger in a car is inaccurate. Officials in two Chicago suburbs said there have been no reports that this incident happened, and a Drug Enforcement Administration official in Chicago called the claims "urban legends" in a tweet. A similar claim emerged in San Diego and was shared by a gas and electric company there, but a company spokesperson said it was later determined that the incident could not be confirmed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Under the “2023 Solar Incentive Program,” U.S. homeowners can “now qualify to get a full, state-of-the-art solar system at absolutely no cost from the government.”
Justification: The U.S. government does not provide free solar panels, an Energy Department spokesperson told PolitiFact. The Facebook post promising free solar panels links to another site with a disclaimer: "‘No Cost’ means that you may not be required to put any money down at the time of installation if you qualify. Solar is not free, but it usually saves homeowners thousands of dollars more than the initial investment."
Sources: Emailed statement from a spokesperson for the Department of Energy
Office of Energy Efficiency & Renewable Energy

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows ‘truth’ that fungus may be the “next government project.”
