Justification: A video showing a scientist warning about the dangers of mutating fungus to humans is from the opening scene of the HBO series "The Last of Us."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “(Joe) Biden just gets up and leaves during a live TV interview.”
Justification: President Joe Biden didn’t leave in the middle of his June 29 interview with MSNBC’s "Deadline: White House" anchor Nicolle Wallace. A 10-second clip of his exit was taken out of context; this happened at the end of the 20-minute interview.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Doctors in the Netherlands “ordered” to euthanize “citizens with autism and other minor disabilities, even if the patient does not currently express any desire to die."
Justification: A 2002 euthanasia law passed in the Netherlands allows patients to request a doctor’s assistance in ending their lives following strict guidelines. Netherlands’ government clearly states that a patient, not family or friends, must consent to euthanasia, and a doctor is not required to perform the procedure. A recent study found that some patients have cited their autism spectrum disorder or an intellectual disability as the main reason why they wanted to end their lives. The law does not require a person to be suffering from a physical ailment when seeking euthanasia.
Sources: World Federation Right to Die Societies

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “7 MINUTES AGO: Mel Gibson Cries For PROTECTION From Hollywood Elite After Sound of Freedom.”
Justification: This claim conflates two different events: the 2023 release of a movie and a 1998 interview in which actor Mel Gibson talks about Hollywood. He doesn’t cry "for protection from Hollywood elite."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump recently dispatched troops to the border.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump didn’t just send troops to the U.S.-Mexico border, nor does he have the authority to take such action.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show children wearing satanic clothing and participating in a satanic club.
Justification: The photos of children participating in satanic rituals at school were created by generative artificial intelligence. The After School Satan Club, organized by The Satanic Temple, hosted a meeting at a public elementary school in Virginia. But these AI-generated photos do not show the club or real children.
Sources: The American Civil Liberties Union of Virginia

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows that Royal Canadian Mounted Police investigators determined that “dozens of wildfires in Canada” were caused by arson in 2023.
Justification: The stories cited as evidence of recent arson-caused wildfires include structure fires that were quickly extinguished and old cases from previous years. Only two of the examples pertained to suspected arson cases this year.
Sources: Email interview with Cpl. Tasha Adams

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows that “George Soros is going bankrupt.”
Justification: We found no evidence that billionaire philanthropist George Soros is going bankrupt, as a recent social media post claims.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Walmart is selling bicycles for $6.95 instead of recycling them.
Justification: This is a scam.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows people holding up their phones to film President Joe Biden, but “every phone there is turned off.”
Justification: People weren’t holding up turned-off cellphones at a White House event July 4. The late afternoon sun’s brightness made the phone screens appear dim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a Senate committee hearing witness who “cries to Josh Hawley for ‘no jailtime.’”
Justification: This video doesn’t show that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “In Switzerland, it is illegal to flush the toilet after 10 p.m. in apartments to avoid disturbing neighbors.”
Justification: This is an urban myth, according to news reports. In Switzerland, local authorities set quiet hours and apartments often have long lists of house rules. But these regulations and rules do not prevent people from flushing toilets late at night.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Justin Trudeau is being investigated by the (Royal Canadian Mounted Police).”
Justification: Canada’s Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is not under investigation for obstruction of justice.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: France said it would shut down internet services “to control the riots.”
Justification: Two French governmental agencies issued statements describing as fake a purported news release saying the government had decided to restrict internet access. There is no evidence that France announced a stoppage of internet services amid riots over the fatal police shooting of a teen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Police say thousands of people witnessed a “demonic portal opening above White House.”
Justification: No such reports were made, according to the Arlington County Police Department.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Free dental implants” are available “through Dental Grants.”
Justification: A webpage claiming to offer grants for free dental implants provides no access to any such grants.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Barack Obama “is being sent to Gitmo.”
Justification: There is no evidence that former President Barack Obama is being sent to Guantanamo Bay to be imprisoned. After a video was posted July 4 making the claim, a July 6 Instagram post showed Obama visiting Athens, Greece, to attend an event.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Bill Gates is behind the five recent cases of malaria in the United States.
Justification: For years, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, a philanthropic organization, has supported efforts to eradicate malaria, but not in the U.S., where the disease is rare. Five recently reported cases in Florida and Texas are the first instances of locally acquired malaria in 20 years. The Gates Foundation has awarded grants to Oxitec for its malaria programs in Africa and Central America. The foundation has not financed the biotechnology company’s U.S.-based mosquito program, which is unrelated to malaria. In the U.S., Oxitec is genetically modifying a type of mosquito to prevent the spread of certain diseases. This type of mosquito does not carry malaria.
Sources: Email interview with Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation spokesperson
Email interview with Joshua Van Raalte
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Bibles banned in California moves one step closer to evil reality."
Justification: A 2018 video is being recirculated to misleadingly suggest that California’s legislature recently moved to outlaw the Bible. A 2018 California bill, which did not become law, would not have banned the Bible.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Zero Amish children diagnosed with cancer, diabetes or autism."
Justification: Experts, studies and news coverage show that there are not "zero" Amish children diagnosed with cancer, diabetes and autism.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The World Economic Forum "wants to slaughter millions of pet cats and dogs to fight climate change."
Justification: We found no mention of killing pets on the World Economic Forum’s Twitter account or website. The organization said the claim was unfounded when it first surfaced in December.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows Disney is opening pediatric transgender clinics.
Justification: Statements made at a City Council meeting by a man claiming to be Disney executive Alan Bergman were intended to be satire. The man in the video is Mark Dice, a conservative YouTuber, who often speaks at local council meetings in the public comment portion to satirically mock perceived liberal causes. Disney has not announced any plans to open transgender clinics for children.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Kevin McCarthy “announces impeachment proceeding for Biden regime.”
Justification: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy threatened to begin an impeachment proceeding against Attorney General Merrick Garland. McCarthy did not initiate those proceedings.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The sand storm headed our way is an attempt by Bill Gates to block out the sun.”
Justification: Saharan dust clouds regularly make their way from North Africa across the Atlantic Ocean to Florida, especially during the summer months. The clouds — masses of dry, dusty air kicked up from the Sahara desert and carried away by winds — are a naturally occurring phenomenon. Bill Gates has not proposed blocking out the sun. He has donated to Harvard University researchers who are hoping to test spraying aerosols into the stratosphere, a solar geoengineering technology to combat climate change. That test was later called off.
Sources: National Hurricane Center's Tropical Analysis and Forecast Branch

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video showing someone in military gear outside a Georgia Waffle House proves that Donald Trump is president.
Justification: Donald Trump lost the 2020 election. Joe Biden is president. Former presidents are entitled to lifetime protection by the Secret Service, thanks to legislation passed by Congress in 1965. The Columbus Police Department in Georgia confirmed it provided a motorcade for Trump on June 10.
Sources: Phone interview with Columbus Police Department

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “breaking news” because “President Trump just dropped a bombshell!!!”
Justification: This video is from November 2022.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: NASA warns of “internet apocalypse,” which “means they can execute the Great Reset in silence without anyone knowing it.”
Justification: In 2018, NASA launched the Parker Space Probe to study the sun and space weather, which could disrupt Earth’s power grid and throw satellites off course. But NASA has not used the phrase "internet apocalypse." There’s no evidence this Parker Space Probe mission is paving the way for "the Great Reset." This is a widely debunked conspiracy theory.
Sources: NASA’s High Energy Astrophysics Science Archive Research Center
The Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Deaths of four alternative medicine doctors show they are being targeted for their ideas.
Justification: There is no evidence to support the claim that the recent death of Dr. Rashid Buttar — known for spreading COVID-19 misinformation — and the 2015 deaths of three other doctors were suspicious. Buttar said in a March interview that he had been hospitalized in January, and information shows he had health issues dating to 2016. The 2015 deaths involved natural causes, a suicide and a murder in which the victim’s husband was convicted.
Sources: " Poisoned: A deep dive into the mass bioweapon & envenomation agenda

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: More than “200 dogs showed up and lined up around the block” for a man’s 100th birthday celebration.
Justification: Dog lover Robert Moore recently celebrated his 100th birthday in San Jose, California. To mark the occasion, his family invited neighbors to line up with their dogs outside a family home. More than 200 canine friends came.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden died and Vice President Kamala Harris was sworn into office.
Justification: Joe Biden is not dead. He remains U.S. president.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Donald Trump called up Putin today and made a new deal that will save America.”
Justification: The video was originally posted in 2016, after Russian President Vladimir Putin made his first phone call with then-President-elect Donald Trump. There are no reports of a phone call between the two in 2023.
Sources: The Next News Network YouTube video

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows singer Tim McGraw talking about diet gummies.
Justification: This video was altered. Tim McGraw isn’t hawking diet gummies.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, telling U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., that he is “not even an expert” and shutting him up.
Justification: The video does not show this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Monkey virus DNA found in COVID-19 shots”
Justification: An Epoch Times article cited an April study, which has not been peer-reviewed, that found part of a DNA sequence called an "SV40 promoter" in two expired Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine vials. But one of the study’s authors told PolitiFact this is not the same as simian virus 40, or SV40, which can cause tumors in monkeys. "Promoters" have long been used in molecular biology to drive gene transcription, the process of making an RNA copy of a gene’s DNA sequence. On its own, the SV40 promoter cannot cause cancer, molecular biology experts told PolitiFact. Monkey DNA and the SV40 virus also are not listed among the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines that federal regulators have approved for use. Pfizer told PolitiFact that monkey DNA was not used in its vaccine.
Sources: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez “faces 5 Years in Jail For FEC Crimes."
Justification: This video is from 2019. Campaign finance violation allegations in 2019 against Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y. were unsubstantiated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “New California bill charges parents with child abuse for refusing to ‘affirm’ their kid’s gender identity.”
Justification: California Assembly Bill 957, still under consideration by the state’s Legislature, would add a parent’s affirmation of a child’s gender identity to a list of considerations a judge must weigh when resolving custody disputes. The bill would amend one section of the California family code and would not change the penal code, where the crime of child abuse is outlined.
Sources: California Legislative Information " California Family Code Division 8
Email interview with Family Policy Alliance
Email interview with Ralph Richard Banks
Interview with Spokesperson for California Assemblymember Lori Wilson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Mel Gibson child sex-trafficking documentary blocked by Hollywood!”
Justification: Mel Gibson’s publicist has said he’s not involved in this project. It’s being produced by Nick Nanton of DNA Films.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “current weather situation in Karachi.”
Justification: This video shows a collection of movie clips and old storm footage.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows former President Donald Trump addressing the nation on June 16.
Justification: This video is from November 2022.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Recent haze in New York City was caused by “Bill Gates’ sun-dimming technology.”
Justification: Recent smoky skies in New York were thanks to wildfires burning in Canada, according to the National Weather Service — not sun-dimming technology.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A lawyer for former President Donald Trump released new proof of 2020 election fraud.
Justification: The video footage featured in this claim is not new. It’s from 2020 and has been previously debunked.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The five people aboard the Titan submersible “have been found dead.”
Justification: A search is still underway for the Titan submersible that disappeared June 18 en route to see the wreckage of the Titanic. As of this Facebook post’s publication — and this story’s publication — the five people aboard had not been found dead.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Titan submersible was found June 21 with all five passengers alive.
Justification: A June 21 Facebook post falsely claimed that the Titan submersible was found with all passengers alive. The claim was made while search efforts were still ongoing.
Sources: NBC News: " Live coverage: Missing Titanic submersible live updates: Desperate push to find sub before oxygen supply runs out

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Tucker Carlson advertising Affordable Care Act subsidies.
Justification: This video was altered.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Breaking dead DNC leaker has just been identified.”
Justification: This supposed "breaking news" video was published on YouTube in 2018, and includes misinformation about Seth Rich, a Democratic National Committee staffer who was slain in 2016. He wasn’t the source of Democratic Party emails provided to WikiLeaks.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Audio is of “the knocking they caught from the submarine” that imploded on the way to view the Titanic wreckage.
Justification: U.S. and Canadian officials have not released audio of underwater banging noises heard during their search for the Titan submarine. The watercraft imploded following its June 18 oceanic descent to view the Titanic wreckage. There’s no evidence that alleged audio being shared on social media is authentic. A U.S. Coast Guard official said noises heard during the search are not believed to be related to the Titan.
Sources: Spokesperson for Canada’s National Defence and the Canadian Armed forces

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Pentagon “said we accidentally sent $6.2 billion to Ukraine.”
Justification: The Pentagon did not say it sent Ukraine $6.2 billion by mistake. It said it made an accounting error, overvaluing U.S. weapons and other military support sent to Ukraine by $6.2 billion. The error has the effect of allowing for $6.2 billion more in military aid to be given to Ukraine.
Sources: Kiel Institute for the World Economy

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Mel Gibson exposing Hollywood elites and the satanic child trafficking.”
Justification: This video shows Mel Gibson criticizing the Vatican and some members of the Catholic Church. In the footage, he doesn’t mention Hollywood or even allude to child sexual abuse.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Ringing in your ears can cause total shutdown in under two years” but a pill can make tinnitus disappear.
Justification: The claims in this post are "completely spurious," a doctor specializing in hearing loss and tinnitus said.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Bradley Kesser

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: World Economic Forum “calls for AI to rewrite Bible, create ‘religions that are actually correct’”
Justification: Articles and social media posts misconstrued remarks Yuval Noah Harari, a Hebrew University of Jerusalem history professor, made about artificial intelligence during a recent interview. Harari does not hold a leadership position at the World Economic Forum, and his comments on AI were not made at a WEF event.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Dr. Anthony Fauci getting “confronted on what was exposed about him last night.”
Justification: This video is from January 2022.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Elon Musk talking about an “AI cryptocurrency trading platform” he launched.
Justification: This video was altered. Musk didn’t discuss cryptocurrency in the original footage, nor did we find an affiliation between him and this purported trading platform.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Guantanamo Bay detention camp remaining open is proof that Joe Biden is not the president.
Justification: Joe Biden is president.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Country singer Miranda Lambert is giving away “free belly melt kits.”
Justification: This post isn’t authentic.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows an aide to former President Donald Trump “grilling” former President Barack Obama.
Justification: This video doesn’t show that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Trump "hasn't been 'indicted.' It's all part of the Operation.”
Justification: A federal grand jury indicted former President Donald Trump on 37 counts relating to the mishandling of classified documents. Trump is expected in court June 13.
Sources: U.S. District Court Southern District of Florida

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Boiling tap water causes fluoride in the water to be “more toxic.”
Justification: Boiling tap water does not transform flouride in the water and does not make the water toxic. Boiling water can kill contaminants.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The U.S. "takes 87% of all the prescription medications in the world."
Justification: Experts said there is no reason to believe that the U.S., which accounts for about 4% of the world’s population, consumes the vast majority of all prescription medications.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
IQVIA Institute for Human Data Science

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "F.ight BREAKS as C.omer SHUTS UP Biden's lawyer with B0MBSHELL."
Justification: A Facebook video did not show a fight break out during a congressional hearing. The video is a clip from a Feb. 8 U.S. House Oversight and Accountability committee hearing, where former Twitter executives testified about their roles in limiting tweets about a New York Post story on Hunter Biden’s laptop.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows an aide to U.S. Rep. Nancy Pelosi snapping at former U.S. Rep. Trey Gowdy.
Justification: No aides to U.S. Rep. Nancy Pelosi appear in this video.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: 30 tons of lost ammonium nitrate on a California-bound train suggest an orchestrated conspiracy.
Justification: About 30 tons of ammonium nitrate disappeared from a rail car on a train traveling to California in April. The chemical compound is used in fertilizers and explosives and can be dangerous to store. Dyno Nobel Ltd., an explosives company, and the Union Pacific Railroad are still investigating the incident, but each said foul play is not suspected and that a leak in the rail car was likely the cause.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Elon Musk and Jack Ma presenting “a new software called ‘Quantum AI.’”
Justification: This video shows Jack Ma and Elon Musk disagreeing about artificial intelligence, not debuting a new product.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “50 U.S. politicians who received satellite phones were taken to an undisclosed government bunker facility to ensure a Continuation of Government.”
Justification: Satellite phones were issued to at least 50 U.S. senators, but the lawmakers did not enter hiding. The phones are a security measure to be used in an emergency.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Arizona BANS Electronic Voting Machines.”
Justification: The Arizona Senate passed a resolution to ban voting equipment made with foreign parts in March, but it does not have the power to override state election laws. Any changes to election equipment would require a new law signed by the governor, who has previously vetoed similar legislation. The theory that state lawmakers have complete control over how elections are run is based on a fringe constitutional interpretation.
Sources: Arizona State Sen. Sonny Borrelli letter

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show Target selling children’s clothing with satanic imagery.
Justification: The creator of these photos confirmed they were generated by artificial intelligence.
Sources: Facebook direct message exchange with Dan Reese

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan asking U.S. Rep. Jerry Nadler, “What are you hiding?”
Justification: This doesn’t happen in the video.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-Calif., is facing charges after “lying” to Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio.
Justification: There is no evidence that Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-Calif., is facing charges.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Gabby Petito’s last text to her mother included an acronym for “Send The Authorities Now.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim. The idea that STAN is an acronym for "send the authorities now" appears to have emerged only after Gabby Petito’s disappearance.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Electric vehicles are a "giant computer that can be controlled remotely from some cloud-based central grid."
Justification: The technology is not in place for someone at a central grid to control where your car drives against your will.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There is no war in Ukraine.”
Justification: The war in Ukraine is real and continuing, despite social media posts claiming otherwise.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Recent wildfires in Canada were simultaneously ignited using weapons.
Justification: Canada’s wildfires were largely caused by lightning.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Adam Schiff just got served” with a $16 million fine for Russia collusion investigation.
Justification: Rep. Anna Paulina Luna, R-Fla., submitted two separate resolutions to the U.S. House of Representatives: one seeking to expel Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., from Congress; and one that would force him to pay a $16 million fine. Luna said the resolutions stem from Schiff’s role in promoting FBI and Department of Justice investigations into possible collusion between former President Donald Trump and Russia during the 2016 election. Neither resolution has been brought to a vote.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The blue, pink, and white colors in the progress pride flag represent pedophiles
Justification: The light blue, pink and white colors featured in the new and popular progress pride flag represent the transgender community whose flag features the same color. The colors do not represent people who are attracted to children or virgins.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Military, Trump thwart deep state blackout.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows former President Donald Trump attacking the Clintons in 2023.
Justification: This video is from 2016.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows first person from a Honduras caravan to be granted asylum in the U.S.
Justification: This claim first appeared in 2018, when a caravan from Honduras made its way to the United States border. The photo is not of an asylum seeker from that group; it’s from a 2009 adult photoshoot.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: FedNow is a new “monetary system” that’s “going to cost you.”
Justification: The FedNow Service is a new instant payment service the Federal Reserve is launching in July. It’s for financial institutions such as banks and credit unions to transfer funds. It has no relationship to a central bank digital currency. It is not a consumer-based payment app and fees listed on a FedNow website would be paid by depository institutions choosing to use the service, the Federal Reserve said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The sun prevents skin cancer.”
Justification: Most skin cancers are caused by excess exposure to ultraviolet radiation, which the sun emits. Health institutes widely recommend protecting oneself from too much sun exposure.
Sources: US Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If you shopped at Walmart in 2022, you could be entitled to a $500 refund!”
Justification: The Facebook posts lead users to a bogus website, not an official Walmart page. There is no evidence that Walmart is refunding customers $500 for shopping at their stores in 2022.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hillary Clinton has Parkinson’s disease.”
Justification: There is no evidence that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has Parkinson’s disease. This is a debunked rumor that originated during the 2016 presidential election. Neurologists with the Parkinson’s Foundation dismissed the claims in 2016, and Clinton’s physician previously identified ongoing conditions such as hypothyroidism and seasonal allergies, not Parkinson’s. The doctor who made the claim is a Florida anesthesiologist who has never examined  Clinton as a patient.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows former President Barack Obama referring to his wife, Michelle as “Michael.”
Justification: When Obama said "Michael and I,"  he was referring to the son of former Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Mike Mullen.
Sources: The Obama White House YouTube video
The White House Office of the Press Secretary

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Pelosi CRIES LIKE KID after McCarthy kicked her out as speaker.”
Justification: This viral video doesn’t show former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi crying.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Sebi was killed “for revealing the truth” about the health benefits of burdock plants.
Justification: Alfredo "Dr. Sebi" Bowman died in 2016 after contracting pneumonia while in jail in Honduras. In 2019, his family debunked claims about his death.
Sources: Healthline: What Is the Dr. Sebi Alkaline Diet

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jamie Foxx is on Life Support in ICU at this hour … Family is preparing for the worst.”
Justification: Actor Jamie Foxx is not on life support, despite claims to the contrary. His daughter, Corinne Foxx, posted on Instagram that her father has been out of the hospital "for weeks" and is on the mend.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The NEXT pandemic is here and children are the target, says Bill Gates.”
Justification: An avian influenza outbreak has killed tens of millions of wild birds and poultry worldwide since 2020; the virus has also been found in some mammals. In March, after an outbreak among poultry at a farm in England, two people tested positive for the bird flu. Neither had any symptoms and have since tested negative. The U.K. Health Security Agency said the risk of bird flu in humans is low, and there’s no evidence of person-to-person transmission. It is monitoring the virus. Microsoft Corp. co-founder and philanthropist Bill Gates in October 2022 took part in a simulation designed to help leaders prepare for future outbreaks. In it, a fictional virus disproportionately affected children.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email exchange with spokesperson for the U.K. Health Security Agency
Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The government has been putting ground up human teeth and bone in our food and calling it 'calcium phosphate.’”
Justification: Human teeth and bones that are ground into calcium phosphate ash after undergoing alkaline hydrolysis, an alternative process to burial or cremation, are not added to food. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration prohibits the use of human remains in food products, according to a spokesperson. The 2017 video footage shows the alkaline hydrolysis process at the University of California, Los Angeles’ Donated Body Program. The ashes from bodies donated to that program were spread off the coast of Camp Pendleton in California.
Sources: The future of death: Inside the machine that dissolves corpses | WIRED Originals

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Goldfish crackers contain a dangerously high amount of weed killer.”
Justification: Trace amounts of glyphosate, a weed-killing chemical used in products like Roundup, are found in many foods, but the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency says the amounts "are not of concern" for consumers.
Sources: Special Session of the Joint Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Street lights are connected to mRNA.”
Justification: There is no evidence that numbers and letters on streetlights are connected to messenger RNA, or mRNA, proteins or the COVID-19 vaccine.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un “just ordered the evacuation of the capital city.”
Justification: We found no evidence that North Korea recently evacuated its capital city, Pyongyang. The video shared with the claim was created in April 2017 — but it also included unconfirmed information. The 2017 evacuation reports were attributed to a Russian news source. PolitiFact searched Google and the Nexis news database and found no credible reports that Pyongyang was evacuated in 2017 or on May 18, when the post was shared.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “CNN announces today there will be no more live audiences at town halls.”
Justification: CNN didn't make such an announcement. The network confirmed the claim was fabricated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An Arizona judge was “forced to overturn” an election and ruled “274,000 ballots must be thrown out.”
Justification: When this video was first shared on social media, no decisions had been reached in an election lawsuit filed by former Arizona Republican gubernatorial candidate Kari Lake. The judge had not overturned the election and ballots had not been thrown out. On May 22, the day after the video was posted, a Maricopa County judge dismissed Lake’s lawsuit, ruling she had failed to prove her claim that election officials violated the law by not verifying signatures on mail ballots. The judge reaffirmed that Democrat Katie Hobbs won the election.
Sources: Superior Court for the state of Arizona in Maricopa County
Superior Court of Arizona in Maricopa County

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau posed improperly with South Korean National Assembly Speaker Kim Jin-pyo because he “had a bit too much to drink.”
Justification: A video shows Trudeau standing at his full height before Kim Jin-pyo cracked a joke about their heights, prompting him to stand lower to match their heights.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "1,000,000 Ukraine soldiers wiped out”
Justification: United States and European officials estimate as many as 120,000 Ukrainian soldiers have died or been injured in the war. We find no basis for a "1 million" estimate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows the U.S. Pentagon “is under attack.”
Justification: The Pentagon was not attacked. A fake photo was used in a false claim about an explosion.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. destroyer recently fired at an armed Iranian ship.
Justification: A Facebook video presented as "breaking" news about a U.S. Navy destroyer firing at an Iranian ship in the Persian Gulf is not new. The USS Mahan fired a warning flare when a boat got too close to it in April 2017.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The best type” of drinking water is H3O2, from fruits, “a more structured form of water.”
Justification: Something called ‘H3O2’ is touted as the best drinking water, but it’s not better than regular H2O.
Sources: Harvard T.C. Chan School of Public Health
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Both murderers in Texas were not only illegals, but gang members” and were “most likely tied to MS-13.”
Justification: Authorities identified Mauricio Garcia, 33, and George Alvarez, 34, as perpetrators in two separate mass killings in Texas. Garcia was named in a May 6 mass shooting in Allen and Alvarez was named in a May 7 incident in Brownsville. Both men are U.S. citizens. Garcia had no criminal incarceration history in Texas, where he was born. Police have not said he was affiliated with a gang. Alvarez, meanwhile, has an extensive criminal history, but police did not confirm whether he was affiliated with any criminal group like a gang.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a fight breaking out in a U.S. House of Representatives committee hearing.
Justification: No fight breaks out in this video clip of a 2018 U.S. House of Representatives committee hearing.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows the “Grim Reaper” appearing at King Charles III’s coronation.
Justification: The person in the video is a verger — a member of the Westminster Abbey community — not the Grim Reaper.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “When fentanyl burns it smells like popcorn.”
Justification: Fentanyl is a deadly synthetic opioid that is odorless and tasteless, making it difficult to detect. However, low-cost test strips can be used to check drugs for traces of fentanyl. Fentanyl is often mixed with other drugs, such as heroin, cocaine and methamphetamine, to make them more powerful and more addictive. There have been few reports of fentanyl-laced marijuana.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "There is no Biden presidency. The real Biden was executed for his crimes long ago along with Clinton."
Justification: President Joe Biden and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton are alive and well. They were not executed and replaced with imposters.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If you need Girl Scout cookies this year and don’t have a local troop to support, please consider buying from Troop 6000, which is entirely made up of girls living in NYC’s homeless shelters.”
Justification: Girl Scouts of Greater New York’s Troop 6000 consists of children living in temporary housing in New York City’s shelter system. Members attend weekly meetings in more than 20 shelters around the city, according to the troop’s website. Troop 6000 sells Girl Scout Cookies annually. There’s a link online for people to order from the troop.
Sources: Girl Scouts of Greater New York
Statement from a Girl Scouts of the USA spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows U.S. Rep. Madison Cawthorn receiving an “ovation” after confronting U.S. Rep. Nancy Pelosi.
Justification: This video doesn’t show that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Chemtrails are being put into the atmosphere and are trickling down into soil and water, becoming “the real cause of disease.”
Justification: Atmospheric chemists and geochemists dispute the existence of "chemtrails." Contrails are line-shaped clouds produced by aircraft engine exhaust, according to experts. They do not pose health risks to humans.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows House Speaker Kevin McCarthy calling on Vice President Kamala Harris to “step down.”
Justification: This video doesn’t show that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The ocean is "flat" and "contained" by land features that jut up from a flat (not spherical) earth.
Justification: Sea level is uneven across the planet. Several factors influence the ocean’s varied topography, including underwater mountains, underwater cliffs and undersea currents. Gravity holds the ocean down to the planet.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The flag of Washington’s District of Columbia has three red stars. One for each city state in the three-city empire.”
Justification: Washington, D.C.’s flag is based on President George Washington’s family coat of arms. Neither Washington D.C. nor London are independent city-states, and we found nothing to substantiate claims that the two cities comprise an "interlocking empire" with the Vatican.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Emergency stimulus loans “are finally available to U.S. citizens up to $5,000 even with poor credit.”
Justification: There are no new stimulus payments as described in this Facebook post, according to the U.S. Treasury Department.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Ukraine was “nuked.”
Justification: • A Facebook video does not show Ukraine being struck by a nuclear bomb. It shows a Russian missile strike against the Ukrainian city of Pavlohrad.• Credible news coverage of the incident doesn't mention a nuclear attack.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Fauci arrested.”
Justification: Dr. Anthony Fauci wasn’t arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Barack Obama was arrested after his campaign “took $30 million illegally from Commie China fugitive.”
Justification: Rapper Prakazrel "Pras" Michel was convicted of charges related to an international conspiracy to influence Obama and Trump. Former President Barack Obama was not indicted.
Sources: United States of America v. Prakazrel Michel

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Texas Republicans just voted to give a Republican appointee the power to single-handedly CANCEL election results in the state’s largest Democratic county.”
Justification: Some vote centers in Harris County, Texas, ran out of ballots on Election Day in November. The Houston Chronicle found that the sites were without ballots from 15 minutes to three hours. The Texas Senate voted in favor of SB 1993, which says the secretary of state will call for a new election if a county runs out of ballots at 2% of voting sites. The bill says it applies only to counties with a population of at least 2.7 million people, which means it applies only to Harris County.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says U.S. Rep. Nancy Pelosi “is guilty of treason.”
Justification: U.S. Rep. Nancy Pelosi wasn’t found guilty of treason.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Putin JUST SHUTDOWN All Oil To The US, Collapsing The US Economy!”
Justification: This isn’t accurate. The U.S. banned all imports of Russian oil, natural gas and coal in March 2022 after Russian President Vladimir Putin invaded Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Babysitter on crystal meth eats 3-month-old toddler.”
Justification: This story originated on a satire site.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul wants “quarantine camps” and “imprisonment” if you’re suspected of having a disease.
Justification: A rule that sparked a legal dispute does not call for quarantine camps. New York state has not set up quarantine camps, and does not plan to, experts told us. The disputed rule allows the state to quarantine or isolate people who have been exposed to or have been diagnosed with a serious illness.
Sources: New York State Attorney General Letitia James

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Breaking Trump quietly announces Hillary’s prosecution is moving forward.”
Justification: This video is from 2016, when Donald Trump was president-elect. It takes a comment Trump made then out of context and exaggerates it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "NASA just announced a 100-foot-wide fissure-crack just opened up Yellowstone volcano in 24 hours.”
Justification: A 100-foot crack on a rock wall at Grand Teton National Park in 2018 has no connection to volcanic activity at nearby Yellowstone National Park, as a Facebook post falsely claims.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A robot with artificial intelligence “self-terminated” after 15 minutes of manual labor.
Justification: During a dayslong trade show, a prototype robot fell a few times while demonstrating its ability to move boxes in a warehouse setting. The manufacturing company, Agility Robotics, said the falls did not mean the robot consciously decided to stop working.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Oil pulling” improves overall oral health, strengthens gums, helps prevent cavities, whitens teeth and reduces plaque.
Justification: Oil pulling is not recommended by the American Dental Association for improved oral health. Some studies have suggested the practice might have benefits, but experts say more research is needed. The most proven way to improve oral health, strengthen gums, prevent cavities, whiten teeth and reduce dental plaque, experts say, is to brush and floss regularly.
Sources: Journal of Indian Society of Periodontology

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows U.S. Rep. Doug Collins exploding “with rage after Pelosi admits dirty ‘squad’ plan for Trump impeachment.”
Justification: This video doesn’t show that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Kamala Harris talking nonsensically about today, tomorrow and yesterday.
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris did not make these comments during an April 25 speech at Howard University. This video was manipulated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Anheuser-Busch closing half its U.S. breweries” after Dylan Mulvaney backlash.
Justification: The claim originated on a satirical website. Anheuser-Busch has faced conservative backlash after a partnership with a transgender social media influencer, but it has not closed any of its U.S. breweries as a result.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows House Speaker Kevin McCarthy announcing U.S. Rep. Nancy Pelosi “will be impeached.”
Justification: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy didn’t announce that U.S. Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., will be impeached. ​U.S. senators and representatives generally can’t be impeached. The Senate Historical Office says the legality is "ambiguous," and practically speaking, it doesn't happen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video proves that “our own government is acknowledging that they’re spraying the skies” with toxic chemicals.
Justification: Former CIA Director John Brennan did not say that the government is spraying toxic chemicals into the air. Brennan spoke in 2016 at the Council on Foreign Relations about stratospheric aerosol injection, a proposed method of geoengineering that could mitigate the effects of global warming. It involves spraying particles, such as sulfur dioxide, into the stratosphere to reflect sunlight. The technology is not currently in use. Congress last year directed the federal Office of Science and Technology Policy to prepare a five-year research plan assessing the risks and hazards of climate interventions, known as geoengineering. The research would not involve releasing materials into the atmosphere, a spokesperson for the office said.
Sources: Emailed statement from White House Office of Science and Technology Policy spokesperson
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Adam Schiff will be impeached.”
Justification: This video does not show any discussion about U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., supposedly being impeached. Congress has only once tried to impeach one of its members — a senator in 1797. That case set a precedent that members were not "civil officers" and therefore not subject to impeachment. They can, however, be expelled by a two-thirds vote in their chamber. There are no news stories to suggest Schiff is at risk of being expelled, either.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: HIV is not contagious.
Justification: HIV is spread through bodily fluids, primarily from unprotected sex or the sharing of drug-injection equipment such as needles.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Nike lost a lawsuit against antisemitism and has to give away gift cards to its customers.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Israel is banning Christianity.
Justification: A bill, introduced by two ultra-Orthodox members of the Knesset, the Israeli legislature, would prohibit one person from trying to convert another person from one religion to another. However, the measure is unlikely to become law. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he would prevent the bill from becoming law.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Lead paint was not banned to protect children’s health, but because it would protect people from radiation.
Justification: Lead paint was banned for use in residential homes in 1978 because exposure to the toxic substance causes severe health and development problems in children. There is not enough lead in lead paint to offer protection against radiation. Although there is some concern about the danger of long-term exposure to radiation emitted by wireless technology, there’s no conclusive evidence to date that it is causing health problems in humans.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan slapping special counsel Robert Mueller.
Justification: This didn’t happen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Pentagon plan and a CDC poster proves that a “zombie apocalypse” is coming.
Justification: An unclassified document from the Defense Department detailed a plan against a zombie apocalypse as a training exercise. It was not a real scenario. The Centers for Disease Control included a poster of a zombie in a a campaign to highlight the importance of being prepared for any type of disaster, such as a hurricane or pandemic.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows Sen. John Kennedy, R-La., playing a phone conversation between Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., and Hunter Biden.
Justification: The video shows no such thing. ​
Sources: Kennedy: SVB collapsed because Biden regulators failed

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “FEMA camps are open for the upcoming arrests for crimes against humanity.”
Justification: This is not an official press conference. The person in the video falsely claims to have jurisdiction "over any governments, courts and corporations." Claims about FEMA camps are part of a longstanding and debunked conspiracy theory.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: BlackRock owns 59 million shares of Dominion Voting Systems and 45.7 million shares of Fox News. BlackRock sued itself and fired Tucker Carlson as part of the lawsuit.
Justification: BlackRock, a large financial investment management company, owns shares of Fox Corp., but not Dominion Voting Systems. BlackRock owns about 59 million shares of the company Dominion Energy. We found nothing to suggest that the energy company and voting technology company were connected beyond sharing a similar name. There is no evidence that Fox News and Carlson’s decision to "part ways" was connected to the $787.5 million defamation settlement Fox reached with Dominion Voting Systems in mid-April.
Sources: Statement from Dominion Energy spokesperson Ryan Frazier

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg “has been arrested.”
Justification: Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg wasn’t arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows John F. Kennedy Jr. in a “real presidential convoy.”
Justification: This video doesn’t show John F. Kennedy Jr., who has been dead since 1999.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Sen. Chris Murphy running away because Sen. Ted Cruz said “just shut your mouth.”
Justification: This twists a testy floor exchange.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Canada just made it illegal to protest against the LGBT!”
Justification: A bill introduced in the Legislative Assembly of Ontario would prohibit acts of intimidation against LGBTQ+ people within 100 meters, or 328 feet, of temporarily designated safety zones. Unless the bill becomes a legislative priority for the Progressive Conservative Party, the majority party that controls the agenda, it is unlikely to pass before the legislative session ends.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: George Soros is banned in Russia, Pakistan, Turkey, Hungary, Poland and the Philippines.
Justification: A spokesperson for George Soros said the philanthropist has received no official communication from any government that would limit his ability to travel to any of the six countries mentioned. The Open Society Foundations, which Soros founded, is banned in Russia.
Sources: Open Society Foundations in Turkey fact sheet

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "They have been preparing for mass extinction with these death caskets" in Madison, Ga.
Justification: The burial vaults, or grave liners, seen in the video are owned by Vantage Product Corp., which leased the land in Madison, Georgia, to store the vaults for people who prearranged for their funerals. There is no evidence linking the vaults to a mass extinction.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows footage of the war in Ukraine.
Justification: This footage is of a video game, not the war in Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a crowd erupting and Hillary Clinton crying during a committee hearing.
Justification: This didn’t happen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images show “Putin has been arrested.”
Justification: Images that claim to show Russian President Vladimir Putin being arrested are fake. Putin had not been arrested at the time the photos were first shared online.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Silicon Valley Bank “donated $73M to 'BLM Movement'”
Justification: A conservative think tank reported that since 2020, Silicon Valley Bank donated or pledged to donate more than $70 million to causes "related" to the Black Lives Matter movement. The think tank defined "related" causes as "organizations and initiatives that advance one or more aspects of BLM’s agenda." Black Lives Matter is not one entity with a set agenda. It is a decentralized international activist movement with no formal hierarchy. Silicon Valley Bank’s charitable contributions that were counted in the think tank’s total went primarily to groups and initiatives that had no clear association with the Black Lives Matter movement.
Sources: Statement from the Black Lives Matter Global Foundation Network
The Claremont Institute and The Center for the American Way of Life

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Elon Musk saying he bought Twitter and unblocked Andrew Tate’s Twitter account because “we need to escape the suppression from the matrix and expose the global elites.”
Justification: The video is a deepfake. It is manipulated from video that originally showed Elon Musk speaking during an April 2022 TED Talk interview months before he bought Twitter. That interview didn’t mention Tate. Musk reinstated Tate and others in November 2022 in what he called a free-speech effort.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: TV host “Dr. Phil” endorsed a “2023 seniors benefits program.”
Justification: This is not an authentic ad featuring Dr. Phil.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Vitamins aren’t FDA approved, but Twinkies are.”
Justification: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has no role in approving food products before they hit store shelves, though it can approve food and color additives before they are used in food.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo of person holding sign shows the shooter who killed six people at a Nashville, Tennessee, school.
Justification: A photo of a person holding a sign that features five long guns sandwiched between the words, "trans rights … or else" was taken March 27 at a nonviolent protest in Oklahoma City. It does not show the 28-year-old person who shot and killed six people March 27 at The Covenant School in Nashville, Tennessee. The photo was taken after police had already shot and killed the Nashville attacker, according to news reports and a Twitter user who claims to have taken the photo.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump is actually another man wearing a Trump mask.
Justification: There’s no evidence to support the claim that former President Donald Trump is actually someone else wearing a Trump mask.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: DO Black credit card is part of a government plot to control people’s lives.
Justification: Mastercard introduced the DO Black credit card in 2019 as a way for people to measure their carbon footprint through their purchase activity. Instead of a typical spending limit on the card, DO Black limited spending based on carbon emissions. The card restricted spending once a person reached their yearly carbon emissions limit. The credit card was discontinued in 2022. There is no evidence the card was part of a plot to control people’s lives under a single, totalitarian government.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Pennsylvania Sen. John Fetterman has a body double.
Justification: This photo doesn’t show a body double for Sen. John Fetterman, D-Pa. The photo that claims to show the "new" Fetterman was taken in May 2022.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis saying he made certain political choices because “that’s where the money is.”
Justification: The video is a deepfake. It was manipulated from footage of Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis’ February 2022 speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference. In the real speech, DeSantis didn’t mention the claims in the altered video. The manipulated video misrepresents DeSantis’ decisions on red flag gun laws and COVID-19 vaccine mandates.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, “sends Biden straight to jail.”
Justification: U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, didn’t—and can’t—send President Joe Biden to jail.
Sources: House Committee on the Judiciary hearing

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden received a military funeral service Jan. 20, 2021
Justification: President Joe Biden is alive. There is no evidence that he received a military funeral service the day he was inaugurated in 2021. The "Executive One" flight featured in the post was carrying first lady Jill Biden, who had attended the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s women’s championship game in Dallas.
Sources: Federal Aviation Administration Air Traffic Organization Policy
White House Office of the first lady pooled press reports

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. public schools don't teach the Declaration of Independence.
Justification: Educational standards in California, Missouri, New York and other states require that kids be taught the Declaration of Independence.
Sources: The Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas crying after a question from an aide to former President Donald Trump.
Justification: This video doesn’t show that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hillary Clinton indicted.”
Justification: Hillary Clinton wasn’t indicted.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump just shared a bombshell letter from Stormy Daniels debunking DA Bragg's case.”
Justification: The letter is not new information. Daniels released the letter in 2018 and, shortly after, recanted what she said in it. Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg has been building a case involving Trump with full public knowledge of the 5-year-old letter.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The FedNow program “is going to replace your paper currency.”
Justification: The FedNow Service is an instant payment infrastructure developed by the Federal Reserve. It is set to launch in July. It will not replace paper currency. The Federal Reserve is considering a central bank digital currency, but has not implemented one. The Federal Reserve said that in the first week of April, it would start certifying participants ahead of the system’s July launch.
Sources: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System
Executive Order on Ensuring Responsible Development of Digital Assets
Phone call and email with Federal Reserve press office

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images show a great white shark on the beach in North Carolina.
Justification: A shark-tracking organization and local police confirmed that a great white shark did not beach in the Outer Banks of North Carolina. A misinformation expert said the images shared in the post appear to be AI-generated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Brittney Griner’s shocking detention photos leaked online.”
Justification: Old photos of WNBA star Brittney Griner when she was in Russian custody are being repackaged online as leaked images, but they were shot and shared by news outlets such as  The Associated Press.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., “is now worth $29 million dollars.”
Justification: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y.’s latest financial disclosure report, filed in September 2022, lists assets amounting to $4,004 to $60,000 and liabilities amounting to $15,001 to $50,000.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Solar companies “have to give solar panels away for completely no net cost.”
Justification: The federal government does not require solar companies to give away solar panels.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “At a top robotics company in Japan this week, four robots being developed for military applications killed 29 humans in the lab.”
Justification: We found no evidence to substantiate a Facebook video’s claim that robots designed for military use recently shot and killed 29 people in a Japanese lab. The woman who made the claim in 2018 credited an anonymous source. Since then, the claim has been repeatedly debunked. The footage in the Facebook video does not depict actual robots attacking humans. It was created using motion-capture technology and computer-generated imagery, according to the production company that made the videos.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pelosi cries like a kid after Trump’s lawyer proves her client ‘innocence.’”
Justification: This didn’t happen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Anheuser-Busch CEO resigns” after Bud Light partners with transgender social media influencer Dylan Mulvaney.
Justification: The claim that Anheuser-Busch’s CEO resigned originated from a satirical blog. Anheuser-Busch confirmed that the claim is false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Nashville, Tennessee, school shooter was Samantha Hyde.
Justification: The Nashville, Tennessee, school shooter was not named Samantha Hyde. The name is a variation of the "Sam Hyde" meme that often surfaces after mass shootings and other tragic events, dating to 2015. A photo of a Pennsylvania resident also was misrepresented as one of the Nashville shooter.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Pouring soda on raw pork will cause parasites to emerge.
Justification: Pouring soda on raw pork will not cause parasites to emerge. Trichinella parasites found in raw or undercooked meat are microscopic and cannot be seen with the naked eye.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In Ohio, “there are 75,000 acres of farmland, fertile farmland, that are all now being poured down with acid rain.”
Justification: The Ohio Department of Agriculture denied that the Feb. 3 freight train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, caused acid rain to pour down on farmlands. Although the controlled burn of vinyl chloride could have produced hydrochloric acid, a component of acid rain, it would have long dissipated. ​ An atmospheric scientist plotted trajectories for how air molecules in and around the incident site could have traveled when the train derailed and when the controlled burn began, and concluded that the likelihood of toxic acid rain in Ohio was "essentially nonexistent."
Sources: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry
Australian Government Department of Climate Change

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Monster Energy’s logo uses a sign of the anti-Christ as part of its marketing effort.
Justification: Monster Energy’s logo isn’t a code for "666," known in the New Testament as the number of the beast, as this video says. The Hebrew characters for the number of the beast are written out as Tav, Resh, Samech and Vav. McLean Design, the marketing firm that launched this design in 2002 for Hansen Beverage Co., said its aim was to make the drink competitive with Red Bull, which then dominated the market. It hoped the design would "create a new aggressive brand for an untapped aggressive consumer. Simple, powerful, iconic, all attitude and impact, capable of carving real share out of Red Bull’s 75%." It said nothing about satanic imagery or the anti-Christ. A Monster spokesperson in 2014 described the devil theory as "fabricated," "delusional" and "fanatical."
Sources: Phone interview with Rabbi Philip Weintraub

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo of electric charging station “powered by diesel generator” is emblematic of the electric vehicle movement.
Justification: A 2018 photo of an electric vehicle charging station powered by a diesel fuel generator was part of a test by an Australian to see whether it would work for EV drivers in remote areas without a network of charging stations. Most EV drivers in the U.S. recharge their vehicles at home or at a growing network of charging stations across the country.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. Sen. Josh Hawley made U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland cry at a committee hearing.
Justification: Video footage from this Senate Judiciary Committee hearing shows that U.S. Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., didn’t make U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland cry.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows President Joe Biden recalling an alien encounter.
Justification: This video was altered by compiling footage from three different town hall appearances.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "We’re just burning 300 gallons of jet fuel to de-ice this clean energy wind turbine … that needs 80 gallons of synthetic oil to operate."
Justification: Swedish company Alpine Helicopter took a picture in 2015 of one of its helicopters using hot water to de-ice the blades of a turbine at a wind farm in Uljabuouda, Sweden. Using 300 gallons of fuel just to de-ice a single wind turbine, as the post claims, is an exaggeration. PolitiFact found no credible source for the Facebook post’s other claim that the wind turbine uses 80 gallons of synthetic oil derived from 12,000 gallons of crude oil to operate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The United Kingdom’s “Parliament closed its borders to prevent Harry and Meg from flying to the UK in order to protect the king.”
Justification: This is baseless. The United Kingdom didn't close its borders at all, much less to stop Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, from traveling there.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows that certain drinks can “test positive” for COVID-19 when using at-home COVID-19 tests.
Justification: A Facebook user claimed that Minute Maid Peach Punch tested positive for COVID-19 on a rapid test. The test appeared to display positive results, but that doesn’t mean the test detected the virus. Research shows that certain substances can cause rapid antigen tests to display false positive results, particularly when used without the test’s provided buffer solutions. Rapid COVID-19 tests are meant to analyze human samples, not drinks, so those positive results do not mean the tests are inaccurate, an expert said.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Alexander Edwards
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The five people that died in that plane crash … were supposed to go to Ohio to test the water, the soil and the air quality in East Palestine.”
Justification: Five environmental consulting firm employees were en route to Cleveland on Feb. 22 to investigate an explosion at a metals plant when their plane crashed in Arkansas shortly after takeoff, killing everyone on board. Despite claims, the people onboard the plane were not going to East Palestine, Ohio, where a train carrying toxic chemicals derailed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “BREAKING Trump preps Marines to stop presidential coup.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim. Donald Trump is no longer the U.S. military’s commander in chief.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden is “in Gitmo.”
Justification: President Joe Biden isn’t in the Guantanamo Bay detention camp.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Clinton ally mysteriously dies.”
Justification: Former Clinton White House official Dana Hyde died from injuries sustained from severe jet turbulence.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The January 6 committee disbanded immediately after the new footage was released.”
Justification: The House Select Committee to investigate the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol shut down in early January. It didn’t disband in connection with a March 6 Fox News segment.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The White House Visitor Center is displaying a photo of a fake President Joe Biden.
Justification: The photo in the post shows President Joe Biden’s official presidential portrait.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Clinton aide found dead, tied to tree in apparent murder.”
Justification: The death of a former Clinton White House aide was ruled a suicide, not murder, according to authorities and the aide’s family.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Trump supporters lining up on Fifth Ave in Manhattan on Sunday.”
Justification: This video is from October 2020.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows “what railways in Ohio look like while we send $40 billion to Ukraine.”
Justification: The image in the widespread photo is from a 6-year-old video that showed an old railway in Ohio. It had already been fixed by the time the Feb. 3 derailment happened in East Palestine. The Biden-Harris administration announced plans to help railway infrastructure in Ohio, including managing $4 billion to improve rail safety.
Sources: White House FACT SHEET: Biden-⁠Harris Administration deploys additional federal resources to East Palestine

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Big-box stores are refunding and crediting customers for fraud and discrimination.
Justification: These Facebook posts follow a familiar pattern, promising customers a payout from big-box stores for alleged company wrongdoing. But there’s no evidence to support their claims.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Harry could be exiled to Botswana after he was deported from the United States due to an expired visa.”
Justification: Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, were recently asked to leave their home on the grounds of Windsor Castle west of London. But we found no evidence to support claims that Harry was deported from the U.S., or that he will be dispatched against his will to Botswana.
Sources: Embassy of the Republic of Botswana

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “USA gives final warning to Uganda to legalize homosexuality,” or no aid.
Justification: The viral video clip is from 2014, not 2023. The U.S. did restrict aid to Uganda in 2014 over anti-LGBTQ legislation, but today the U.S. offers over $950 million dollars per year to the African nation. We found no evidence that the U.S. has publicly threatened to reduce aid over recent LGBTQ legislation in Uganda, but the U.S. State Department says it is monitoring the legislation’s progress.
Sources: Email interview with State Department spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Official govt docs expose Michelle Obama’s 14 year history as a man.”
Justification: Michelle Obama was never a man.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Drinking or using tap water treated with chlorine is dangerous because “chlorine is a poison.”
Justification: Chlorine is one of the most commonly used chemicals to disinfect water in the United States. For more than 100 years, chlorine has been used to protect against diseases, such as salmonella and norovirus. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency limits the amount of chlorine allowed in water supplies at 4 milligrams per liter. Water with chlorine levels within the legal limit is safe to drink and for other uses. This amount of chlorine is unlikely to cause any negative health effects, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Elon Musk banned U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez from Twitter.
Justification: Elon Musk didn’t ban U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., from Twitter. Her accounts are active.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Crowd erupts as Chip Roy grills Kamala Harris as she lies in Congress” in video.
Justification: This video shows a clip of a February 2023 House Judiciary Committee hearing. Vice President Kamala Harris wasn’t there.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump is the “current sitting” commander in chief.
Justification: Donald Trump is a former president of the United States. President Joe Biden is the commander in chief.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A $2 million grant for Georgia’s DeKalb County amounts to a “private takeover of election offices.”
Justification: The Center for Tech and Civic Life is granting DeKalb County $2 million for elections. Grant funds can be used for equipment and materials, voting sites or personnel. The overall purpose is to help plan and operate safe and secure elections. Local election officials will continue to administer elections based on state laws.
Sources: DeKalb County Deputy Chief Financial Officer Preston Stephens
Georgia Public Radio reporter Stephen Fowler

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The train that derailed in Ohio was carrying “over 300,000 gallons of a chemical that was banned in 1974.”
Justification: In 1974, the Consumer Product Safety Commission banned the use of vinyl chloride in aerosols. It is still used primarily to produce polyvinyl chloride, or PVC, one of the most widely produced plastics in the world.
Sources: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry
McGill Office for Science and Society

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The moon is a habitable place.”
Justification: Available research suggests the moon is uninhabitable. The moon has a thin exosphere that contains a variety of atoms and molecules, including helium, argon, sodium and potassium. It is not breathable. Water molecules have been found on the moon, but not in liquid form and H2O molecules are incredibly scarce there.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden was “shot” in a “behind-the-scenes execution.”
Justification: President Joe Biden is alive and has been traveling around the world.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Muslims by the millions are converting to Christianity.”
Justification: This claim is based on a 20-year-old anecdote that lacks evidence. Experts said it’s hard to quantify the number of religious converts from Islam to Christianity. Some people may not announce their faith publicly because of safety concerns. Others just may not formally declare what their religion is, which could leave numbers underreported. In a 2015 poll of 70 countries based on population data on births and deaths and, where available, estimated rates of religious conversion, the Pew Research Center found that 31% of the world’s population was Christian and 24.1% was Muslim. The Muslim faith was the fastest-growing at the time and was projected to equal the number of Christians by 2060.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The officers who beat Tyre Nichols targeted him because he was “allegedly dating” one of their wives.
Justification: Neither investigators nor attorneys for the officers arrested in Tyre Nichols’ death have released any solid information about the officers’ motives. Police in its initial report said Nichols was pulled over for reckless driving, but the Memphis, Tennessee, police chief has since said surveillance footage does not substantiate that. Nichols’ stepfather Rodney Wells described as untrue any claims Nichols was involved with the wife, girlfriend or ex of an officer who was charged in his death. The investigation into Nichols’ death continues; PolitiFact found no evidence among the available information to substantiate this claim.
Sources: Emailed statement from FedEx communications principal Heather Wilson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Mark Zuckerberg launched a platform last month "that allows each user to earn from $500 a day without even leaving home."
Justification: This post falsely claims that Mark Zuckerberg recently launched a platform called Libra in which people can passively earn $12,000 a month. Libra was the original name of a Facebook-led cryptocurrency project, and it was scuttled last year.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar is "facing 40 years in prison and deportation after seven new crimes uncovered."
Justification: The same claim was made in 2020 and was debunked.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The dog dewormer fenbendazole can cure cancer in humans.
Justification: The National Cancer Institute said it has no evidence that supports the claim. The Food and Drug Administration has not approved fenbendazole to treat or prevent cancer in humans. Some peer-reviewed studies have found potential in fenbendazole, a dog deworming drug, in treating human cancer and recommended further study. But there is no proof it’s a cure.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden signed an executive order “making health insurance free for qualifying Americans.”
Justification: The executive order this post cites was signed by President Joe Biden in 2021, and it doesn’t provide free health care for Americans.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “the earthquake in Turkey.”
Justification: This footage was filmed in Saudi Arabia and predates the recent earthquake in Turkey and Syria.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The U.S. State Department has started a special immigrants visa “evacuation operation.”
Justification: This claim isn’t legitimate, a State Department spokesperson said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "In the month since Republicans took the House majority," they are trying to "impose a 30% tax on everything."
Justification: While adding the sales tax, the bill would also end federal taxes on income, payroll, estates and gifts. The bill has limited support in the House. Top Democrats, including Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and President Joe Biden, have pledged to kill it.
Sources: Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There are no humans” on the International Space Station.
Justification: A crew of seven astronauts live and work on the International Space Station. It has been continuously occupied since 2000.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Black Americans are not descended from people who were taken from Africa to be enslaved.
Justification: Over the course of 400 years, millions of Africans were taken from their homes and forced onto ships crossing the Atlantic Ocean, bound for Europe and the Americas for the purpose of enslavement. This is widely documented — in letters, ship manifests, drawings, literature, legislation and other artifacts. Even science has revealed the genetic legacy of this forced migration.
Sources: National Museum of African American History and Culture

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The United States of America “no longer exists” because President Joe Biden “signed away our sovereignty as a nation.”
Justification: President Joe Biden signed the Declaration of North America on Jan. 10 following talks with Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. It is not a legally binding document and has no bearing on U.S. sovereignty. The declaration contains a list of broad commitments among the three countries on topics such as sustainability and migration.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Global warming is a “fraud.”
Justification: Climate change is not a fraud. A vast majority of the world’s scientists agree that climate change is real and driven by greenhouse gases released into the atmosphere from human activity.
Sources: California Office of Planning and Research

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Seven ecological disasters in less than 2 weeks. … We are under attack.”
Justification: The National Transportation Safety Board said there’s no evidence of foul play or sabotage in the Feb. 3 train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio. We found no evidence of sabotage in six other derailments this month or signs that they posed threats from hazardous materials.
