A truck that spilled chemicals in Arizona was an accident, and there is no long-term threat from the spill, officials said. A fire that burned plastic planters in Florida is still being investigated, but fire officials said it’s likely a propane tank exploded. There were no hazardous materials released, officials said.
Sources: Email exchange with National Transportation Safety Board spokesperson
Osceola County Fire Rescue and EMS

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Congress “erupting” over U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz’s remarks.
Justification: This video doesn’t show Congress "erupting" over U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz’s comments.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In Australia, "All joggers must wear a helmet.”
Justification: A sign warning that a new Australian law requires joggers to wear helmets was created in 2017 by Wowser Nation, a satirical art collective looking to draw attention to what they called the "Australian nanny state."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An ingredient in some of Chick-fil-A’s dipping sauces can cause serious health problems.
Justification: Some of Chick-fil-A’s dipping sauces contain a small amount of calcium disodium ethylene-diaminetetraacetate, or EDTA, a common food additive that helps preserve flavor, color and texture. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has determined calcium disodium EDTA is safe to consume in small quantities.
Sources: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows birds that “dropped dead” in Kentucky after the train derailment in Ohio.
Justification: This photo was taken in April 2018 in Little Rock, Arkansas. A local ornithologist said the birds may have died after getting intoxicated from fermented berries and then falling from high heights.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Unusual cancers” are “exploding right into stage 4" and those cancer cells have “the spike protein."
Justification: Fact-checkers have repeatedly debunked the claim that COVID-19 vaccines cause cancer. A recent post that repeated the claim cited comments from a doctor who is facing unprofessional conduct charges for allegedly making false and misleading public statements about the COVID-19 pandemic and vaccines.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Backyard chicken flocks have stopped laying eggs, and the feed is responsible.
Justification: There is no evidence that chicken feed is being sabotaged or impacting the number of eggs that backyard hens are laying, poultry science experts said. Several feed suppliers, including Tractor Supply Co., say they haven’t changed their formulas. Aside from a current outbreak of avian flu affecting commercial U.S. poultry populations, experts said reasons behind sudden drops in egg production in small flocks may include management mistakes, improper nutrition, parasite infection, disease and environmental stress.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The average American has anywhere from 5 to 15 pounds” of stool stuck in their gut.
Justification: Doctors said average people do not have 5 to 15 pounds of stool "stuck" in their gut, despite claims circulating on social media. The cells that form the lining of the intestine regenerate continuously, meaning that stool does not remain stuck there for extended periods of time. Experts also said, despite what some digestive supplements sellers might claim, that it is impossible to fully eliminate all the waste in the gut because it is always being formed.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Darren Brenner
Email interview with Dr. Geoffrey Preidis

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The earthquake in Turkey is a "scripted" use of geo engineering weather modification HAARP
Justification: The High-frequency Active Auroral Research Program, or HAARP, uses radio waves to study the atmosphere. It cannot be used to manipulate the weather or cause disasters such as earthquakes. Turkey sits in a region with a lot of seismic activity, experts said. The two earthquakes on Feb. 6 that have killed more than 40,000 people were the deadliest in Turkey since a 1939 quake there killed 33,000 people.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hospital photo of Damar Hamlin proves “he’s a corpse.”
Justification: Damar Hamlin is alive.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Transportation Security Administration spent “a couple hundred million dollars” on gender-neutral screening technology.
Justification: The Transportation Security Administration spent $18.6 million on gender-neutral screening technology, not "hundreds of millions," as a video claimed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Richard Belzer died because of a COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: There’s no evidence Richard Belzer’s death is connected to a COVID-19 vaccine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a “man burning the Quran in Sweden.”
Justification: This video of a man burning a Quran was shot in Denmark in 2021, not Sweden.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “BREAKING GOP approves resolution to expel Omar from Congress! It’s over for her!”
Justification: The Alabama Republican Party State Executive Committee passed a resolution in 2019 urging its representatives in the U.S. House to expel U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar, D-Minn., from Congress. Nothing happened.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show someone in a President Joe Biden mask at the State of the Union.
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Michigan State University shooter is a 21-year-old man named Lynn Dee Walker.
Justification: A Feb. 13 shooting at Michigan State University in Lansing, Michigan, has left three people dead and another five hospitalized in critical condition, according to university police. University police have identified the gunman as 43-year-old Anthony Dwayne McRae, who they say acted alone. McRae died of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound after being confronted by law enforcement off campus and had no affiliation with the university, police said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Pregnancy tests include a “hidden Plan B” pill.
Justification: Pregnancy tests do not contain an emergency contraception pill. Test manufacturers said a tablet is included in tests to absorb moisture.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows a deputy U.S. marshal “keeping a close eye” on President Joe Biden at the State of the Union address on Feb. 7.
Justification: This isn’t a deputy U.S. marshal, a U.S. Marshals Service spokesperson said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Document shows that Hunter Biden paid Joe Biden $50,000 a month in rent.
Justification: This is wrong. The figure in question — $49,910 — matches the quarterly rent for office space at House of Sweden, home to the Swedish and Icelandic embassies on K Street in Washington, D.C. Business records show that an office for Rosemont Seneca Advisors, an investment firm co-founded by Hunter Biden, was located there. House of Sweden pointed us to a spokesperson for Sweden’s National Property Board, who confirmed to PolitiFact that Hunter Biden paid $49,910 in quarterly rent for an office space in House of Sweden.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: People who stole U.S. Postal Service uniforms are posing as postal workers and robbing people at gunpoint.
Justification: The U.S. Postal Service’s law enforcement arm told PolitiFact it has no knowledge of a uniform store theft, and we found no evidence of a series of armed robberies involving fake mail carriers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows migrants faking tears for news cameras.
Justification: This video clip from 2020 shows migrants reacting after Greek authorities fired tear gas on them, according to multiple news reports.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Aretha Franklin’s 1968 song ‘A Natural Woman’ deemed ‘offensive’ by trans community.”
Justification: The Twitter account said its call to have Aretha Franklin’s "(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman" removed from online music platforms was a parody.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Walmart is giving some women $500 grocery store credit as part of a discrimination settlement.
Justification: A spokesperson for Walmart said this isn’t true.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Tee Higgins "isn't even leaving the hospital till he knows (Damar) Hamlin is OK."
Justification: Cincinnati Bengals wide receiver Tee Higgins has attended practices while remaining in contact with the family of Buffalo Bills safety Damar Hamlin, who was injured after colliding with Higgins during a Jan. 2 game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Grant Wahl died because of the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: An autopsy found that journalist Grant Wahl died of a ruptured aortic aneurysm, according to his wife. She said that his death was unrelated to COVID-19 vaccines.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Attorney General Merrick Garland saying, “Wait for revenge.”
Justification: This video shows a May 2021 Senate Appropriations Committee hearing on domestic violent extremism. Attorney General Merrick Garland testified at the hearing, but he didn’t implore Sen. John Kennedy to "wait for revenge."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows Rep. Jim Jordan threatening House Speaker Nancy Pelosi with “‘possible’ jail time.”
Justification: Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, doesn’t threaten House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., with jail time in this video.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The cost of eggs has gone up 700%.
Justification: Overall inflation rose 6.5% year-over-year in December 2022, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Food costs rose at a rate of 10.4%. Eggs saw the biggest price jump of any single food item over the last year. The average cost increased 60%, according to the Consumer Price Index.
Sources: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Kari Lake’s lawsuit “exposes Arizona used no signature verification.”
Justification: Kari Lake, the 2022 Republican nominee for Arizona governor, filed a lawsuit after she lost the election that asked a court to declare her the winner or order Maricopa County to set a new election. Lake’s lawsuit alleges Maricopa County mishandled mail ballot signature verification, citing what it said were the statements of three signature verification workers who said the process was flawed. A judge has yet to rule on those allegations, but Maricopa officials disputed the allegations in her lawsuit. Lake’s complaint echoed allegations from the 2020 presidential election. A judge rejected a 2020 lawsuit that alleged Maricopa improperly verified signatures.
Sources: Arizona Republic opinion by Laurie Roberts
Superior Court for the state of Arizona in Maricopa County

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Cellphones can be used to pop popcorn kernels.
Justification: This video was produced in 2008 as part of a viral marketing campaign for a Bluetooth headset. It’s physically impossible for phones to pop kernels as portrayed in the video, an expert said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Sen. Josh Hawley told professor, “I will not use your pronouns.”
Justification: This video shows neither Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., refusing to use a University of California, Berkeley professor’s pronouns, nor her asking him to do so.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A $5,000 stimulus loan is available.
Justification: False promises of stimulus loans have spread over social media. There are no stimulus loans as described in a Facebook post. Such a program would require action by Congress.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows the deadly Jan. 15 plane crash in Nepal.
Justification: This video shows a 2021 plane crash in Russia, not the 2023 crash in Nepal.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Andrew Tate officially gets sentenced to 15 years in prison! (Found guilty).”
Justification: Andrew Tate was arrested in Romania amid rape and human trafficking allegations, but he hasn’t been charged, convicted or sentenced. A judge recently extended his detention until Feb. 27.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows wreckage of the recent plane crash in Nepal.
Justification: This video shows a tour of a set from the 2005 movie, "War of the Worlds," not wreckage from the Jan. 15, 2023, plane crash in Nepal.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: MMA fighter Victoria Lee died because of a COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: Claims that Victoria Lee’s recent death was related to a COVID-19 vaccine are unsubstantiated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Russia’s Army was “destroyed.”
Justification: Morale is low among Russian forces, news reports suggest, but the country’s army hasn’t been destroyed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows Jim Jordan saying the 2020 “election was stolen.”
Justification: In this video, U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, denies that he said the 2020 election was stolen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The war in Ukraine is “all over.”
Justification: The war in Ukraine isn’t over. Ukraine’s foreign minister said Dec. 13 that Russian forces could be capable of launching a "large offensive" by the end of January.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Actor Isaac Kappy was murdered for exposing Hollywood pedophiles.
Justification: This claim is unfounded. Authorities say that actor Isaac Kappy died by suicide.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Sen. John Kennedy telling Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas, “You will be impeached.”
Justification: An 11-minute Facebook video shows Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas answering questions from senators during a 2021 hearing about the Biden administration’s border policy. Impeachment was not mentioned in the exchange. Apart from this claim, Congressional GOP leaders have intensified calls to impeach the secretary.
Sources: Sen. Ted Cruz and Sen. Lindsay Graham’s Letter to Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Federal Reserve “has suspended the availability of new currency.”
Justification: Before the COVID-19 pandemic, the Federal Reserve offered holiday currency special ordering periods. That was suspended in 2020 and 2021 during the pandemic. The agency said this year it will permanently discontinue the special ordering periods. The agency continues "to pay out new currency to depository institutions in all denominations periodically throughout the year," it said. The agency announced in December that a new series of notes is in production.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Every single Republican blocked Ketanji Brown Jackson’s SCOTUS appointment.”
Justification: Last year, Kentanji Brown Jackson was confirmed to the Supreme Court on a 53-47 vote in the Senate. Three Republican senators — Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, and Mitt Romney of Utah — joined all 50 Democrats in voting to confirm Jackson.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Americans who worked through the pandemic are being paid up to $26,000 by qualifying for the Employee Retention Credit.”
Justification: Congress created the employee retention tax credit to incentivize employers to keep paying staff after business activity dropped due to the COVID-19 pandemic. For 2020, the maximum employee retention credit was $5,000 per employee and for 2021, the maximum amount was $21,000 per employee, experts said. The credit is paid to eligible employers, not employees.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows Rep. Matt Gaetz threatening Robert Mueller with jail time.
Justification: Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., doesn’t threaten Robert Mueller with jail time in this video. It’s just the latest video to make wild claims about events that don’t really happen in the clip.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez crying after “Ted Cruz gets up and humiliates her to her face.”
Justification: This video doesn’t show Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., crying over remarks by Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “MRNA vaccines are being injected into our food supply.”
Justification: MRNA vaccines are not widely used on livestock in the United States, experts said. Even when given to livestock, mRNA vaccines cannot enter humans’ food supply. The vaccines rapidly disappear after injection, an expert said. MRNA vaccines for COVID-19 have been given to millions of Americans and have a strong safety record.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: England’s Oxfordshire County Council has passed a trial "climate lockdown," “confining residents to their own neighbourhoods.”
Justification: Officials in England’s Oxfordshire County voted to try a traffic reduction system that involves limiting the use of private cars in certain areas.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: If a sealed bag of raw poultry appears “puffy,” it means the protein is not safe to consume.
Justification: A sealed packaged bag of raw chicken that appears puffy "is not an indicator of spoilage," according to the trade association National Chicken Council.
Sources: Email interview with National Chicken Council spokesman Tom Super

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In Texas, a person can register a dead relative to vote and then cast a mail ballot in their name.
Justification: When Texans submit a voter registration application, their name, birth date, driver’s license number or four digits of their Social Security number are compared with records from the Texas Department of Public Safety and Social Security Administration. That process would flag an application on a dead person’s behalf. The Texas secretary of state receives information regarding people who have died weekly, or monthly, depending upon the data. That information is immediately forwarded to county voter registrars so that they can remove those individuals from their voter rolls. County officials remove thousands of dead people from the voter rolls each month.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Kamala Harris resigns in shock after Biden’s ‘mandatory’ border trip…Trump jails ‘corrupt’ VP.”
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris has not resigned, nor is there any suggestion she will. This Facebook post with thousands of views has no source information backing up its claim. It features a video from Newsmax criticizing Harris but reports nothing about a resignation or jailing.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The government is giving every household a $500 Walmart shopping credit to help with inflation.
Justification: The link from this post goes to a page that uses Walmart’s logo but isn’t affiliated with Walmart. Walmart advises customers to avoid buying, selling or checking a gift card balance "on online marketplaces outside of Walmart.com." There is no information from Walmart promoting this offer, which appears to be a scam. A spokesperson for Walmart told PolitiFact the claims in the post aren’t accurate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Norway readies its military to counter Biden.”
Justification: Norway sent its military to guard part of the Nord Stream pipeline network as a safety precaution following a series of leaks that European authorities believe were deliberately made. Russia and Western countries have accused one another of sabotaging the pipelines. An investigation into the leaks continues, and no suspect has been named.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Jan. 6 hearing “was abruptly canceled after it was revealed that news networks would not be showing it.”
Justification: A hearing of the U.S. House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol was originally scheduled for Sept. 28 but was postponed to Oct. 13. The hearing was rescheduled because of Hurricane Ian’s impending arrival.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Merrick Garland catches Trump planning to flee.”
Justification: We found no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Donald Trump is back on Twitter,” thanks to Elon Musk.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump’s Twitter account remained suspended as of Oct. 10, 2022. Elon Musk has indicated he plans to follow through with buying Twitter, but the deal has not yet been finalized.
Sources: Twitter advanced search for tweet in claim

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Judge Aileen Cannon “loses her license.”
Justification: Aileen Cannon is licensed to practice law in Florida, where she is a U.S. district judge. Florida Bar records show she has no disciplinary history.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donald Trump’s “rally just got shut down after no one shows up.”
Justification: A recent "pro-Trump rally" in Washington, D.C., was organized by supporters, not Trump, and was scantly attended. But it wasn’t canceled.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video footage showing Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi hiding on Jan. 6, 2021, shows the U.S. Capitol attack “was a setup.”
Justification: During its Oct. 13 hearing, the U.S. House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol played video footage of congressional leaders hiding and evacuating the Capitol on Jan. 6. On Oct. 14, CNN obtained about an additional hour of the video and published some segments. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s daughter filmed lawmakers during the attack using her handheld camera, according to the speaker’s spokesperson. There was no camera crew. The Jan. 6 attack was not a setup. More than 400 people have pleaded guilty to one or more charges linked to the riot, and judges have sentenced nearly 290 people. Damage to the Capitol was estimated at more than $1.5 million.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: California’s Senate Bill 107 means “your child can now be taken from your custody if you do not affirm gender-reassignment surgery.”
Justification: A new California law provides legal protections for parents fleeing states that have banned gender-affirming health care for youths. The law clarifies that California courts have jurisdiction over any custody cases that may arise from parents taking their children to the state for care. It doesn’t give the state permission to take custody of a child if one parent disagrees with a child’s decision to seek gender-affirming health care. ​
Sources: Office of California Gov. Gavin Newsom
Phone interview with California State Sen. Scott Wiener

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Recent blood clots or strokes in four major athletes are an unwanted effect of COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: NHL player Kris Letang in November suffered his second stroke, which his doctor said was caused by a tiny hole in his heart at birth. NFL rookie Max Mitchell is out for the season with blood clots his father said were caused by a hereditary condition. NFL player Henry Anderson missed two months on the field after suffering a stroke, but doctors could not determine its cause. Tennessee college basketball player Tamari Key’s season ended because of blood clots in her lungs. Few details were released about her condition.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "55,000 years ago the world was 2 degrees warmer Celsius than it is today.”
Justification: Antarctic ice cores show that temperatures there were nearly 7 degrees Celsius colder in that region 55,000 years ago. Even if it were true that the Earth was warmer then, it would not rebut human-caused climate change. The Earth goes through temperature cycles, but human-made climate change is accelerating that process.
Sources: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Aileen Cannon has been arrested.
Justification: Aileen Cannon wasn’t arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: This video shows Chuck Grassley demanding Joe Biden’s “resignation.”
Justification: Sen. Chuck Grassley doesn’t call on President Joe Biden to resign in a video shared on social media, as a Facebook post suggests. He criticized the FBI.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Connecticut ballot initiative on early voting would "remove the requirement of a certified seal from certain ballots."
Justification: A ballot question in Connecticut asks voters whether the state constitution should be amended to allow the General Assembly to permit early voting. Nearly all states offer in-person early voting. Connecticut is one of the few states that doesn’t. The amendment would eliminate a constitutional requirement that certain copies of election results sent to the secretary of state be under seal. A state official told us this is a reference to a wax seal used in the 1800s and is not a change that makes election results less official.
Sources: Diana Evans op-ed in Connecticut Mirror
League of Women Voters of Connecticut

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Parasite cleanses "kill herpes by starving the parasites in the stomach."
Justification: Parasite cleanses are ineffective and can harm people’s health, according to an expert in parasitic diseases. Diagnosing and treating a parasite requires visiting a medical professional and taking specific antiparasitic medication.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Human Meat Project is using donated bodies and organs to create “alternative meat consumption options.”
Justification: The website HumanMeatProject.com exists, but the group said it is not actually soliciting donated bodies and organs to create alternative meat products. The site is "purely a conceptual art project and will not be acted out in real life," according to the group’s website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: North Korea has taken military action against Russia.
Justification: Recent news coverage of diplomatic ties between North Korea and Russia indicates the nations’ relations are strengthening, not collapsing.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump woken up from his bed by police.”
Justification: The post features a video from MSNBC showing a member of the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. It does not mention anything about police rousing Trump. There’s no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Dr. Oz wins seat.”
Justification: No one has won this race. The election isn’t until Nov. 8.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pennsylvania is under a court order to count their ballots on election day and not after!!”
Justification: Republicans filed a petition in court in Pennsylvania challenging state election officials’ guidance that counties count mail and absentee ballots that lacked a date or had the wrong date. On Nov. 1, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled that undated or incorrectly dated ballots must be segregated and not counted. The two-page court ruling does not change the timeline for counting ballots.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dark spots on potato chips are “infected with throat mold.”
Justification: Ring rot is a bacterial infection that breaks down a potato’s vascular system. It is not harmful to humans and potatoes with ring rot are safe to eat. Harmless dark spots can form on a potato chip because the potato it was made from was bruised or converted its starches into sugars. Discoloration of the potato’s vascular system can also cause the spots.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “California is registering non-citizens to vote and has refused to cooperate with the Federal Election Integrity Program.”
Justification: California does not allow noncitizens to vote in its general or primary elections. Eligible voters must be 18, a U.S. citizen and a California resident. San Francisco did once have a law allowing noncitizens to vote in local school board elections, but a judge overturned it in 2022, saying it violated the state’s constitution.
Sources: America’s Best Pics and Vids post

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Antony Blinken “confesses that Biden” is responsible for the Nord Stream pipeline leaks.
Justification: Antony Blinken said the Nord Stream pipeline leaks presented an opportunity to ease European dependence on Russian energy supplies; he didn’t say Joe Biden was responsible for the pipeline’s leaks.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There’s “evidence of a massive transfer of completed, curated ballots” that are fraudulent in the 2022 election.
Justification: These are old unfounded claims from shortly after the 2020 presidential election. The U.S. Postal Service, its inspector general and the FBI investigated the 2020 election fraud allegations and found no evidence to corroborate them. We found no news reports or other credible sources to support the claims in the Facebook post that there’s evidence of current, massive election fraud.
Sources: U.S. Postal Service Office of the Inspector General

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a faulty New York voting machine invalidated a GOP vote in governor’s race.
Justification: The machine referenced in the claim is called AutoMark and is made by the company Election Systems and Software. It’s used to electronically mark and fill in ballots for those who may be physically incapable of doing so. It does not tabulate ballots.
Sources: New York State Board of Elections

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Obama Foundation stored classified documents in an abandoned furniture warehouse.”
Justification: The National Archives and Records Administration temporarily kept classified records from the Obama administration in one of its facilities that had been converted from a former furniture store, but they were later moved to a facility in the Washington D.C. area. Neither President Barack Obama nor the Obama Foundation ever controlled them.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Obama & Clinton are being arrested by the military.”
Justification: This is unfounded. Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton weren’t arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Rand Paul telling Nancy Pelosi “she’s a traitor.”
Justification: This video doesn’t show Rand Paul calling Nancy Pelosi a traitor. In the clip, the Kentucky Republican criticizes a bill to give aid to Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Future and Malia Obama are expecting first child together.”
Justification: Claims that Malia Obama is expecting a child with the rapper Future originated on a satirical Instagram account that shares fake headlines.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The true meaning of Hurricane," or Her-ricane, is the spirit of "the African woman who has been stolen."
Justification: The term "hurricane" is derived from a word coined by the indigenous people of the Caribbean, according to the Merriam-Webster dictionary. This claim previously appeared in a 2017 book by comedian and civil rights activist Dick Gregory. While it had rhetorical power, it does not appear to reflect etymological research.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: At an Atlanta Braves celebration, President Joe Biden “demanded that all the little kids come up on stage to sit on his lap.”
Justification: President Joe Biden invited the Atlanta Braves to the White House on Sept. 26 to honor their 2021 World Series victory. After a team photo, Biden invited children in attendance to get their photo taken with him and the team. At no point did Biden tell or encourage anyone to sit on his lap. He kneeled down at one point for a photo with a small boy.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden admitted having an inappropriate relationship with a minor.
Justification: President Joe Biden’s Sept. 23 remarks at a Democratic National Committee event did not include him admitting to an improper relationship with a minor.
Sources: Email interview with White Press Office

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Nostradamus “accurately predicted Queen Elizabeth II’s passing.”
Justification: Nostradamus, a French astrologer in the 1500s, did not mention Queen Elizabeth II in his writing. The prediction about her death is based on an interpretation of Nostradamus’ writing by author Mario Reading.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The World Economic Forum has called for the end of “wasteful private car ownership.”
Justification: A report by the World Economic Forum detailed ways society could address the growing scarcity of metals used in green energy technologies, including using car-sharing instead of private car ownership. The organization never advocated for ending private car ownership and never called it "wasteful."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: House Democrats kicked Nancy Pelosi from office.
Justification: The U.S. House of Representatives didn’t kick Nancy Pelosi out of office. The chamber has expelled only five lawmakers in more than two centuries, most recently in 2002.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Meghan Markle wasn’t allowed to attend Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.
Justification: Meghan Markle attended the queen’s funeral.
Sources: The royal family attends Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: As Hurricane Ian approached, President Joe Biden said, “a vital part of preparing for hurricane season is to get vaccinated now.”
Justification: President Joe Biden made the remarks about getting vaccinated for COVID-19 ahead of hurricanes in August 2021, when the delta variant was causing COVID-19 cases to surge. Biden recommended people become vaccinated ahead of hurricanes so that they would be prepared to evacuate and shelter with others during storms. He didn’t promote it as a means of protecting people against hurricanes, as claims have suggested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: 2018 interview shows Bill Gates has changed his position on clean energy
Justification: During a 2018 energy forum, Bill Gates decried the idea of quick fixes for climate change. He said more action is needed to address climate change beyond the development of affordable renewable electricity sources. Gates’ comments did not reveal that he has changed his position on clean energy or previously "admitted the truth" about the clean energy movement.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “North Korea sent more than 100,000 troops to Russia for the Ukraine War!”
Justification: North Korea has not sent any troops to Russia to help fight in Ukraine, and officials in Moscow have denied they offered the chance to help. North Korea has expressed interest in sending construction workers for any rebuilding efforts in Russian-controlled Ukrainian territories.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The FBI confirmed” that Ashley Biden said her father molested her.
Justification: Two Florida residents pleaded guilty to stealing and selling items, including a personal diary that belonged to a relative of a then-former government official who was running for national office. News reports have widely reported that the case involved property belonging to Ashley Biden, daughter of President Joe Biden. The diary was obtained by conservative group Project Veritas, which said it declined to publish it because it could not verify its authenticity. Another conservative group, National File, in October 2020 published what it said was a digital copy. The FBI did not verify the diary’s contents in its announcement of the plea deal or in charging documents.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Russian army has surrendered in Donetsk!”
Justification: There have been no confirmed reports of Russian soldiers surrendering to Ukrainian forces in the Donetsk province in eastern Ukraine. When this post was made, Russia was threatening to annex the area. There have been unverified reports provided by the Ukrainian government of Russians surrendering elsewhere in the country. Russian residents have also reportedly been fleeing to other countries to avoid President Vladimir Putin’s mobilization order calling on 300,000 reserve soldiers to fight in the war.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump lawyers all quit on him at the same time.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that former President Donald Trump’s lawyers representing him in an investigation of his handling of classified documents have all quit. Days after this claim was made, Trump’s lawyers submitted a filing to the court on his behalf. Trump has parted ways with his attorneys in the past.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Barack and Michelle Obama are not the real parents of their children.
Justification: Former President Barack Obama and former first lady Michelle Obama are the real parents of Sasha and Malia.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: If Jeff Bezos’ net worth reaches $1 trillion, “he could literally end world poverty and give everyone $1 billion and he will still have $91.5 billion left.”
Justification: A Facebook post used bad math to claim that if Jeff Bezos’ net worth was evenly distributed, everyone would receive $1 billion and Bezos would still have $91.5 billion left for himself. If Bezos’ fortune of $149.5 billion was shared among the world’s population, each person would actually get about $19.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jeffrey Epstein’s lawyer became a federal judge” and “was the person to sign off on the Mar-a-Lago search warrant.”
Justification: Bruce Reinhart, a federal magistrate judge, signed the warrant for the FBI’s Aug. 8 search of former President Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. Reinhart never represented financier Jeffrey Epstein. Reinhart represented some of Epstein’s employees, including his scheduler, who were accused of abetting Epstein’s alleged sex crimes against underage girls.
Sources: BBC "Who was Jeffrey Epstein? The financier charged with sex trafficking

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The pope, Xi and Putin all meet to plan world events!”
Justification: Trips by the pope and Chinese President Xi Jinping to Kazakhstan overlapped, but the men weren’t expected to meet. Xi met separately with Russian President Vladimir Putin this week in Uzbekistan.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Chinese military convoy enters Ukraine from Russia.”
Justification: We found no evidence to support claims that China has entered Ukraine from Russia, much less that this video shows a Chinese military convoy in Ukraine. The footage has appeared online elsewhere in the context of a recent joint military exercise in Russia’s Far East region.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: To qualify for Ohio SNAP benefits, “now a family of 3 can make up to $3,660 a month and it used to be $2,700, so it’s gone up almost $1,000 a month.”
Justification: Each fiscal year, to adjust for rising costs of living, the U.S. Department of Agriculture increases the monthly income limits that determine eligibility for the federal Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. For fiscal year 2023, which begins Oct. 1, the gross income limit will increase by $116 for a household of three, in nearly all states.
Sources: Ohio Department of Job and Family Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pelosi’s panel ready to arrest Trump.”
Justification: The U.S. House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol doesn’t have the authority to arrest former President Donald Trump.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Lifeguard/football player Joe Biden got five draft deferments for asthma during Vietnam.”
Justification: President Joe Biden did receive five draft deferments, but they were granted because he was a student, first in college and then law school. Later, Biden underwent a physical exam and received a Selective Service 1-Y classification — which specified that he could be drafted only in a national emergency — because of his asthma.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Soursop cures cancer.
Justification: Research in animals and via test tubes suggests that soursop could be used to treat cancer, but studies evaluating its efficacy and safety in humans are lacking.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Vladimir Putin “is fleeing the war!”
Justification: There’s no evidence that Russian President Vladimir Putin is abandoning the war in Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In the United Kingdom, “Charles cedes throne to William immediately.”
Justification: The throne passed to Charles, Queen Elizabeth II’s eldest son, after she died. He was officially proclaimed King Charles III.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Barron Trump has been kicked out of school for fees.”
Justification: Barron Trump was not kicked out of his private school in West Palm Beach, Florida, a school spokesperson said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “President Xi of China under house arrest” amid “coup by the PLA.”
Justification: China President Xi Jinping in Beijing on Sept. 27 made his first public appearance since a Sept. 16 trip to Uzbekistan. The timeline of his absence from public view would fit with the country’s strict zero-COVID policy, which requires international travelers to quarantine at a hotel for seven days, followed by three days of home isolation. Days after the rumors of a coup began circulating, Xi was prominently mentioned in a state-run media report announcing delegates for next month’s National Congress of the Communist Party of China, where he is expected to be granted an unprecedented third term as president.
Sources: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People’s Republic of China

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: All banks will soon have to turn over all coins to federal government ahead of pivot to using only electronic transactions.
Justification: The Federal Reserve is piloting an instant payment protocol, called the FedNow Service, which is expected to be more widely available to financial institutions and individuals in mid-2023. The program will not require banks to turn over all physical currency.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Under new Illinois law, these crimes are “nondetainable": “Burglary, robbery, arson, kidnapping, DUI offenses, even DUI involving a fatality, most drug offenses, and even 2nd degree murder.”
Justification: A law that eliminates cash bail in Illinois will go into effect Jan. 1. It removes money as a factor in determining whether a suspect can be released while awaiting trial. The new law did not create "nondetainable" offenses. Prosecutors can still petition judges to detain suspects, and must provide evidence to prove the suspects are a public safety threat or flight risk. All of the crimes listed in a Facebook post could result in a suspect being detained until trial.
Sources: Law Offices of Winer and Winer
Loyola University of Chicago Center for Criminal Justice
The Institute for Illinois' Fiscal Sustainability at the Civic Federation

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: King Charles III signed “a proclamation stating that Donald Trump won the 2020 presidential election and is the rightful president by law.”
Justification: When Queen Elizabeth II died Sept. 8, King Charles III ascended the throne. Charles was formally proclaimed king at an accession ceremony Sept. 10. During that ceremony, he signed an oath to uphold the Church of Scotland. There’s no evidence he issued a proclamation about the 2020 U.S. presidential election.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Queen Elizabeth II being carried across a river by African porters.
Justification: This photo, taken when Elizabeth was a child, shows a European traveler being carried across a river by African porters in Senegal. It doesn’t show the queen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “We all know the Queen’s been dead for a while now,” and her death is part of a dark conspiracy involving pedophilia or child trafficking.
Justification: Queen Elizabeth II died Sept. 8. She was photographed in Scotland two days before her death. There is no evidence to support the conspiracy theory that the queen had links to a pedophilia ring.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says of 9/11, “Two planes can’t cause three buildings to collapse in free-fall time.”
Justification: Social media posts perpetuated conspiracy theories about how the World Trade Center buildings in New York City collapsed on 9/11. World Trade Center Building 7 was brought down by uncontrollable fires, not a plane crash. The building also collapsed at a rate slower than free-fall time. The World Trade Center complex was designed to withstand the impact of a Boeing 707, a smaller and lighter aircraft than the ones that hit the twin towers.
Sources: National Institute of Standards and Technology

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Queen Elizabeth II “feeding Africans like chickens.”
Justification: This video was made in what is now Vietnam nearly 40 years before Queen Elizabeth II was born. The woman in the 1889 film is throwing coins, not food.
Sources: India Today. Fact Check: Woman throwing money at colonised kids is NOT Queen Elizabeth

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Student debt relief is taxable by the Internal Revenue Service.
Justification: The up to $20,000 of federal student loan forgiveness announced by President Joe Biden won’t be subject to federal taxes, according to the White House. The federal American Rescue Plan signed into law in 2021 includes a provision to exclude counting federal student loan relief as taxable income through 2025. But six states could count the money as taxable income, unless they make legislative or administrative changes, according to one analysis.
Sources: Email exchange with H&R Block spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An obscure filing with the Federal Election Commission shows Biden has formally announced his bid for another term.
Justification: • President Joe Biden has not officially announced a bid for a second term. The notion that he did so in an obscure federal disclosure filing on Aug. 30 is inaccurate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The IRS is hiring 87,000 new agents to police people who will owe more federal tax after having their student loans forgiven.
Justification: • The IRS is expanding its workforce after a decade of funding cuts and a projected wave of retirements, but it has nothing to do with President Joe Biden’s plan to forgive student loan debt.• The 87,000 figure is from a 2021 Treasury Department assessment of how much funding it would take to fill that many full-time positions across the agency, not only in enforcement jobs. The report laid out a plan of phasing in those hires over 10 years. It was a plan; it did not represent a final decision of how congressional funding would be spent.• The federal government will not impose any income taxes on canceled student debt. A provision in the American Rescue Plan of 2021 makes forgiven student loans tax-free at the federal level through 2025.
Sources: Email interview with a spokesperson at the Treasury Department

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Earth just started spinning faster than ever before and scientists are gravely concerned.”
Justification: On June 29, 2022, Earth completed a rotation about 1.59 milliseconds faster than the 24-hour standard. That’s the shortest day on record since we started atomic timekeeping in the 1960s. That doesn’t mean anything dangerous for Earth’s inhabitants. With enough speeding up of the Earth’s rotation, atomic timekeepers could one day add a "negative leap second," or remove one official second from one day.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Nancy Pelosi set to resign from Congress as Trump files impeachment lawsuits against her.”
Justification: Claims that Donald Trump filed a lawsuit to impeach House Speaker Nancy Pelosi are wrong, and they misunderstand how impeachment works.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “With the combined salary of the 87,000 new IRS Agents ($81,456 average annual salary), you could put a police officer ($55,117) in every public school in the nation (97,568) and still have 31,007 police officers or $1,709,012,819 left over.”
Justification: Using reliable data sources for salary and public schools, the hypothetical cost of hiring 87,000 IRS tax enforcement agents would be about $6.04 billion, less than the projected $6.96 billion cost of putting police officers at every U.S. public school. But regardless of the data source used, the claim involves back-of-the-envelope math based on averages. About half of the nation’s public schools already employ law enforcement or school resource officers, federal data show.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden “employed actors to portray Marine guards” during a Sept. 1 speech.
Justification: There is no evidence that the Marines who stood behind President Joe Biden during his Sept. 1 speech in Philadelphia were actors. The White House rebutted the claim. The claim came from Real Raw News, a website known for sharing wildly unfounded claims about politicians and the military.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden called Pope Francis the “famous African American baseball player in America."
Justification: The video between President Joe Biden and Pope Francis from October 2021 was edited to remove the context of the conversation. The "famous African American baseball player" Biden was talking about was Satchel Paige, who made his Major League debut in his 40s. Biden referenced Paige in a story he told the pope about aging.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Walmart management is helping with rising prices with $500 grocery cards for $2.”
Justification: We found no evidence that Walmart is virtually giving away $500 grocery gift cards. This post appears to be a scam designed to collect personal information from unsuspecting visitors.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Documents prove White House behind entire FBI targeting of Trump. Biden lied."
Justification: The National Archives first told the Justice Department in early February that records retrieved from Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago home in January contained classified records. That referral is what launched the criminal investigation into Trump’s handling of the documents, the Justice Department said in an affidavit seeking a search warrant of Trump’s home. The search was carried out Aug. 8. The Justice Department requested that the White House allow the National Archives to turn over the documents for review, a step required by the Presidential Records Act. The White House granted the request April 11.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The federal government is providing free solar panel installation and $8,500 incentive checks to eligible homeowners.
Justification: The federal government is not offering free solar panel installation plus incentive checks. Eligible homeowners who install solar energy panels could qualify for tax credits, according to the U.S. Energy Department.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a statement from Donald Trump on Sept. 8, 2022.
Justification: The speech in this video was delivered in December 2020, when Donald Trump was still president.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Queen Elizabeth II was a reptile.
Justification: Queen Elizabeth was a human, not a reptile.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Boeing 757 didn’t fly into the Pentagon on 9/11.
Justification: A Boeing 757 crashed into the Pentagon on 9/11, despite online claims suggesting otherwise.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Fox News sought the legal "right to tell lies."
Justification: Fox News didn't contend it had no legal obligation to be truthful, nor did a court uphold that. The lawsuit cited in the post involved two reporters who sued a Fox affiliate over breach of contract and retaliatory firing in 1998. The reporters said the Fox affiliate made revisions to a story that distorted the truth. Although the station denied such allegations, it did argue that the First Amendment barred judicial review of editorial discretion. An appeals court sided with the Fox affiliate, but it did not address the station's First Amendment argument.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden threatened to assassinate Ukraine’s former president.
Justification: A phone call recording from 2016 between then-Vice President Joe Biden and then-Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko was leaked in 2020, but as it recirculates in 2022, it’s wrongly being used to claim Biden threatened to kill the former head of state.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The National Guard was activated Jan. 6, 2021, and “is in complete control.”
Justification: Former President Donald Trump did not activate the National Guard during or after the U.S. Capitol attack on Jan. 6, 2021 The notion that the U.S. military controls the federal government is unfounded and false

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "FEC charges (Beto O'Rourke's 2018 campaign) Illegal Campaign Contributions."
Justification: Beto O’Rourke’s 2018 U.S. Senate campaign entered into a dispute resolution program with the FEC regarding some finance contributions that were prohibited or in excess of federal limits. The campaign paid a civil penalty of $5,900 and terminated the political committee, FEC documents show. The FEC has civil, not criminal, jurisdiction. O’Rourke was not criminally charged, as the post suggests.
Sources: Certifications: Beto for Texas and Gwendolyn L. Pulido
FEC Form 99 submission by Beto for Texas

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Sarasota, Florida, teachers told they cannot purchase books, accept donated reading materials, order from Scholastic or hold book fairs.
Justification: Sarasota County Schools asked teachers to temporarily stop buying library books and accepting donated reading materials to allow Florida's Department of Education to issue guidance on how to comply with HB 1467, which heightens scrutiny on school library and instructional materials. Book fairs already slated for the fall can remain as scheduled. Scholastic book orders placed by students are allowed if first reviewed by parents.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Another continent may exist beneath Antarctica, which is also home to homicidal sea creature of unknown origin
Justification: There is irrefutable evidence that the density of Earth is greater than that of the crust layer, geophysicists say. That fact renders it impossible for any kind of civilization or infrastructure to exist beneath a continent. The claim of a homicidal, squidlike creature known as "Organism 46B" was adopted from a satirist named C. Michael Forsyth, who has said it is fictitious.
Sources: Museum of New Zealand | Te Papa
Online Books Page with the University of Pennsylvania Digital Library

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The FBI “spent more time investigating” the Jan. 6 Capitol attack than 9/11.
Justification: The FBI’s 9/11 investigation began Sept. 11, 2001, the day of the attacks. The investigative team grew smaller over the years, but documents show the attacks were still under investigation nearly 15 years later. The FBI’s Jan. 6 investigation began the day of the attack and continues nearly two years later.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Russian army is withdrawing from Ukraine!” in September 2022
Justification: There have been no reports that Russia is withdrawing from Ukraine. Russian President Vladimir Putin said during a Sept. 7 speech, after this post was made, that Russia’s forces will continue to push farther into the country. The U.S. Defense Department estimates that about 80,000 Russian soldiers have been wounded or killed in the conflict since it began.
Sources: General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Supreme Court will put Donald Trump back in office in October
Justification: Donald Trump can run for president again in 2024. But social media posts suggesting he has been or is about to be reinstated are wrong. The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to take up an election law case pertaining to the powers of state legislatures. A ruling is expected next summer that could affect future elections, but not results from 2020.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Reuters reported that “White House employee Andrew Bates did use Nazi symbolism in a recent tweet."
Justification: Reuters Fact Check did not report that a White House staffer used a Nazi symbol in a tweet. Images purporting to show a screenshot of such an article are fake. Biden administration officials have shared versions of the pro-Biden "Dark Brandon" meme, including one that some Twitter users claimed featured a Nazi symbol. That meme’s original creator said the design was based on a movie poster and featured an eagle, America’s national bird, not a Nazi symbol.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Amazon is “running a promotion and giving away random packages for just $1!”
Justification: The Facebook posts include a link that appears to be an Amazon form for purchasing an unclaimed parcel for $1. But the link directs people to malware. It is possible to buy unclaimed parcels from Amazon by using websites like Liquidation.com, or at a local swap meet.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The deaths of U.S. Rep. Jackie Walorski, R-Ind., and actor Anne Heche are suspicious and linked because they “partnered fighting against pedophilia.”
Justification: There is no evidence that U.S. Rep. Jackie Walorski, R-Ind., and actor Anne Heche were working together or knew each other before their deaths. Heche died from injuries sustained in a Los Angeles car crash that a medical examiner ruled accidental. Walorski died following a head-on vehicle collision in Indiana.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump asked “for troops around the Capitol to make sure everyone is safe,” on Jan. 6, 2021, but was “turned down by the Democrats.”
Justification: There is no record of former President Donald Trump authorizing or requesting thousands of National Guard troops for the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Several Trump administration officials who have testified before the House select committee investigating Jan. 6 said they never heard Trump request National Guard support before or during the attack. Congressional Democrats did not deny a request for troops. The D.C. National Guard reports only to the president. If such a request had been made, they would not have had the authority to deny it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. is testing new most deadly nuclear bomb from B-1B Lancer.”
Justification: This isn’t accurate, according to the U.S. Air Force.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Send your postcards to 5 key states to decertify fraud” in the 2020 election.
Justification: Some conservative activists have advocated for decertifying ballots cast in 2020, alleging fraud. But no such decertification process exists, and there’s no evidence of widespread fraud. Federal law says that elections offices must retain ballots cast in federal races for 22 months. After that date, election officials can destroy ballots. The roots of the ballot retention rule comes from a civil rights-era law, but it also has the practical effect of freeing  storage space for ballots in the next election.
Sources: House of Representatives Committee on the Judiciary
USC 20701. Retention and preservation of records and papers by officers of elections; deposit with custodian; penalty for violation

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Quotes Sarah Palin as saying “when Jesus celebrated Easter with his disciples there were no Easter bunnies or egg hunts.”
Justification: Sarah Palin never said this. The quote being circulated online is fake and was published by a satirical newspaper in 2013.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “People born before 1957 are getting $1,728 added to their Social Security checks.”
Justification: This is a scam.
Sources: Statement from Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Steve Bannon crying, “Trump is going to jail.”
Justification: We found no evidence that Bannon said this. He doesn’t say it in the video in the post.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video implies talk between Barack Obama and Kamala Harris has coded references to pedophilia.
Justification: The Biden campaign released a video in September 2020 featuring a conversation between former President Barack Obama and then-vice presidential candidate Kamala Harris. Followers of the Pizzagate and QAnon conspiracy theories claim the exchange was filled with coded messages about pedophilia. The followers provided an FBI document and a leaked email to Obama as proof of the conversation’s hidden meaning. The document and email are fakes, and the conspiracy theorists’ allegations are unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Ted Cruz leaks new document obtained from Hunter’s laptop implicating Nancy Pelosi.”
Justification: A pair of unrelated clips of U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, are wrongly described as showing him leaking a document from Hunter Biden’s laptop that implicates House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A New England Journal of Medicine study found that vaccinated people are “5X more contagious than the unvaccinated 10 days after SARS-CoV-2 infection.”
Justification: A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine found that people infected with delta or omicron variant COVID-19 could shed virus and remain potentially infectious for six to eight days after the onset of symptoms or their initial positive polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. The study did not find that people vaccinated against COVID-19 remain contagious for COVID-19 longer or recover more slowly than people who were not vaccinated against the virus. The study has important implications about how long people should isolate after they contract COVID-19 to avoid infecting others, said one of the study’s co-authors, Dr. Amy Barczak of Massachusetts General Hospital.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email interview with Dr. Amy Barczak of Massachusetts General Hospital’s Infectious Diseases Division and a scientist at the Ragon Institute
The New England Journal of Medicine

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Clark County poll worker acting illegally by asking people to place their ballots into a bag outside of a drop box.
Justification: Washington state began allowing a vote-by-mail option for counties in 2005, which allows residents to send in their ballots or deposit them at drop boxes. Vote-by-mail was implemented statewide in 2011. State law requires election officials to prevent overflow at drop box sites, so authorized workers are typically sent to drop box sites before the polls close to collect ballots. Ballots can be left with the authorized workers or deposited in the box.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The IRS is about to double in size, with 87,000 new armed agents and an additional $80 billion in order to primarily enhance IRS enforcement and operations.”
Justification: The Inflation Reduction Act provides $80 billion to the IRS over a 10-year period, allowing the agency to hire up to 87,000 employees across the agency, not just in enforcement. Those hires would come as about 50,000 workers are expected to retire in five to six years. The heads of the IRS and the Treasury Department each said the money will not be used to increase audits of people making less than $400,000. The IRS has long had a Criminal Investigation division with a small number of armed special agents. Taxpayers facing routine audits, most of which are conducted by mail, do not encounter those agents.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Ted Cruz erupts as FBI director tries to defend Biden over Mar-a-Lago raid” in video.
Justification: This video shows Ted Cruz in 2020 and 2021 discussing matters unrelated to the Mar-a-Lago search.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video claims Google Street View shows Antarctica with green vegetation and brick buildings.
Justification: Satellite images of Antarctica show the continent covered in snow with no patches of green landscape anywhere.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Monkeypox is a complete, fake sham” that’s “designed to force lockdowns, mandates and shots.”
Justification: The virus has infected nearly 48,000 people worldwide and killed at least 13. It is not life-threatening in most cases, but in rare cases the virus can be fatal, especially if contracted by children younger than eight, women who are pregnant or breastfeeding, and those with weakened immune systems as well as eczema, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Most documented cases so far have been among men who have sex with men. But monkeypox is transmitted through close contact with people who are infected, meaning anyone who has close contact with others could be at risk.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show “an IRS agent training class.”
Justification: These are photos of college accounting students participating in an on-campus simulation to learn about the work of IRS criminal investigation special agents.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Bill Gates and AOC say that a cow emits more pollution than a car."
Justification: Neither Bill Gates nor Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez have said cows emitted more pollution than cars. Cows emit methane into the atmosphere by belching as a result of a fermentation process in their stomach. Cars emit carbon dioxide by burning fuel for energy. While methane is nearly 30 times more potent than carbon dioxide in contributing to climate change, it breaks down in the atmosphere after 12 years. Carbon dioxide remains in the atmosphere for several hundreds of years.
Sources: Email with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Mitch McConnell saying Nancy Pelosi “should be jailed!”
Justification: This video doesn’t show Mitch McConnell saying this, nor did we find other instances of him saying Nancy Pelosi should be jailed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “US Army in Ukraine.”
Justification: U.S. Army members aren’t in Ukraine, according to the Department of Defense. The Pentagon relocated National Guard members in February who were training Ukrainian military members in February.
Sources: Email interview with Lt. Col. Garron Garn

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Inflation Reduction Act expanded free health insurance to Americans under 65.
Justification: The Inflation Reduction Act has been described as the most significant health care legislation since the Affordable Care Act, but it didn’t usher in free health insurance for Americans.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Rep. Adam Kinzinger “admits Trump won” the 2020 presidential election.
Justification: Adam Kinzinger said Trump had won the "Trump versus Kinzinger war" over the soul of the Republican Party. He didn’t say Trump won the election.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “96% of U.S. climate data is corrupted.”
Justification: There is widespread consensus that average temperatures are rising both in the U.S. and globally. Although not all temperature stations are stationed in areas with ideal research conditions, experts said those that aren’t are maintained in order to provide a consistent historical record of temperature changes over time. The data is also evaluated and adjusted for potential biases. Research does not reflect that data used from poorly sited temperature stations yields biased conclusions.
Sources: Email interview with Donald J. Wuebbles
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Climate Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Screenshots show that conservative political commentator Ben Shapiro received more than $20,000 in Paycheck Protection Program loan forgiveness.
Justification: Someone named Ben Shapiro in Los Angeles received nearly $21,000 in Paycheck Protection Program loan forgiveness, but that person worked in the real estate industry, according to a ProPublica database. Conservative political commentator and media personality Ben Shapiro is based in Florida. He has a different middle initial than the Shapiro in California who records show received a Paycheck Protection Program loan. Shapiro, the media personality, said on Twitter that he never got a federal Paycheck Protection Program loan. We found no evidence to contradict this.
Sources: Emailed statement from Ben Shapiro and The Daily Wire spokesperson Alyssa Cordova

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Liz Cheney cries like kids after loses in ‘primary’ against Trump’s pick,” two days before the primary election.
Justification: The Wyoming primary election will take place Aug. 16, and preliminary results for the election won’t be available until after polls close at 7 p.m. local time. Although polling shows that U.S. Rep. Liz Cheney is expected to lose her re-election bid, no vote has been counted yet.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Empty store shelves at a Walmart in South Carolina were because of a meat shortage.
Justification: These images show meat department coolers that were being repaired because of mechanical issues at a Walmart in Columbia, South Carolina. A Walmart spokesperson said no product was wasted, and the meat was returned to shelves once the problem was fixed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Free health allowance is available at no cost.”
Justification: President Joe Biden has not announced a new initiative to give Americans more than $5,000 in cash or credit to cover health care. It’s not safe to turn over personal information to unfamiliar websites.
Sources: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Benadryl can be used to reduce swelling from rattlesnake bites.
Justification: Benadryl is the name brand for a type of antihistamine, a drug that blocks the effects of histamines, which the body creates when it detects something harmful, such as infections or allergens such as dust, pollen or mold. Rattlesnake venom is highly toxic and can kill cells and tissue, coagulate blood and cause paralysis. The only known drug effective for treating venomous snakebites is antivenom, also known as antivenin, specific to the snake that inflicted the bite.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “‘Monkeypox’ is only circulating in countries where the Pfizer vaccine has been distributed and is being used to advance a Technocratic Great Reset."
Justification: "The Great Reset" is an unsubstantiated and widely debunked conspiracy theory, which holds that a group of elites is using the coronavirus to reorder societies and economies around the world in the hopes of creating a global totalitarian regime. Monkeypox cases have been reported in countries that aren’t distributing the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine. The monkeypox outbreak isn’t an attempt to hide cases of Pfizer "COVID-19 vaccine-induced shingles." There’s no credible evidence that the COVID-19 vaccines cause shingles.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Baby carrots are soaked in bleach and can cause cancer.
Justification: Baby carrots are made from longer-sized carrots, and they are rinsed with a diluted solution of chlorine and bleach — but that solution is tightly regulated and is no more harmful than the chlorine levels in tap water.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jill Biden makes stunning admission after” President Joe Biden tested positive for COVID-19.
Justification: Jill Biden said the president was "doing fine" and "feeling good" after his COVID-19 diagnosis.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Synthetic cyanide-based B12 is a "toxic ingredient in your kids vitamins."
Justification: Cyanocobalamin is a man-made version of vitamin B12. Health organizations and pediatricians say it’s safe to consume.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Herman B. Gray

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Congratulations to the IRS on winning the $846.3 million Mega Millions Jackpot.”
Justification: Lottery winnings are considered regular taxable income by the Internal Revenue Service, and the winner of the $1.34 billion Mega Millions jackpot will be taxed according to the highest rate, which is 37%. The lump-sum payment of the jackpot is about $780.5 million, of which $288.7 million will go toward federal taxes. If the whole $1.34 billion jackpot was taxed, the IRS would receive $495.8 million.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Birx "changes tune on" COVID-19 vaccines and "admits vaccines don't work."
Justification: Birx's past statements show she has remained largely consistent in her view that COVID-19 vaccines do not provide long-term immunity. In December 2020, she said that vaccines would not prevent an increase in COVID-19 cases. She didn't "admit" that vaccines don't work. In a July 22 Fox News interview, she said, "I think we overplayed the vaccines, and it made people then worry that it's not going to protect against severe disease and hospitalization. It will." She also recommended people be vaccinated, saying, "we do believe it will protect you."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "A Jackson, Tennessee, employee passed out this morning from handling a dollar bill with fentanyl on it."
Justification: Fentanyl is a highly potent synthetic opioid used to treat severe and chronic pain. Illegal fentanyl has been linked to a rise in fatal drug overdoses because of its potency and cheap cost. People cannot overdose from fentanyl just by touching it or being in its presence.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Phone interview with Perry County Sheriff’s Office spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Antifa was already inside the Capitol with floor plans dressed as Trump supporters" on Jan. 6, 2021, proving the attack “was 100% a setup."
Justification: The Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol was not a "setup" by antifa activists who were "already inside the Capitol with floor plans dressed as Trump supporters." The viral Facebook post making that claim revived a debunked conspiracy theory. A University of Chicago research group that has examined 900 people charged to date has found no evidence of antifa involvement in the day's events. A video captured amid the attack does not show antifa; it shows a group of pro-Trump rioters, including some whose support for former President Donald Trump has been documented in charging documents, discussing the Capitol’s layout after breaching it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Jim Jordan said, “It’s finally happening! Adam Schiff will be impeached.”
Justification: U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan didn’t say this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The gunman at Greenwood Park Mall was a CIA asset.”
Justification: A gunman killed three people and wounded two others after firing into a crowd at a Greenwood, Indiana, shopping mall on July 17. An armed bystander returned fire and ended the mass shooting. Analysis of active shooter incidents shows that this rarely happens. There’s no evidence that the gunman at Greenwood Park Mall was a CIA asset or that the attack was a CIA operation.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy makes $11 million a month and has a net worth of $596 million.
Justification: There is no proof that Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has a net worth of $596 million or receives a monthly income of $11 million. Leaked financial documents showed Zelenskyy had several assets like real estate property and cars, but not enough to corroborate the claim made on Facebook. A report by Forbes found the Ukrainian president’s net worth was closer to $20 million to $30 million.
Sources: Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The emissions generated by watching 30 minutes of Netflix is the same as driving almost 4 miles.”
Justification: Comparing driving with Netflix streaming is difficult and depends largely on the car, driving speed and streaming device, among other factors. This rumor has recently resurfaced as a screenshot of a tweet and a response. The original tweet, from @BigThink in 2019, has been deleted, and the article that it was promoting has been corrected to remove the error. A better estimate of carbon emissions suggests driving 4 miles is equivalent to streaming about 45 hours of Netflix.
Sources: BigThink: Online video streaming is making climate change worse
Email interview with BigThink editor Alex Berezow
International Energy Agency: Fact-check: What is the carbon footprint of streaming video on Netflix?
Screenshot posted on Facebook page Premium Internet Curation
The Shift Project: Did The Shift Project really overestimate the carbon footprint of online video?

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The CDC has classified monkeypox as an airborne form of herpes that can lead to paralysis.
Justification: Monkeypox spreads primarily through close physical contact, including direct contact with monkeypox rash. There’s no evidence the CDC classifies it as "airborne" or has said it can spread to people who are 15 feet away from someone who is infected. Monkeypox symptoms typically last two to four weeks, according to the World Health Organization and CDC. The disease is not classified as a form of herpes, and the WHO does not list paralysis as a complication of severe monkeypox cases.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In its July  “red alert” for extreme heat, the U.K.'s Met Office warned that high temperatures could cause blood clotting.
Justification: The U.K.’s Meteorological Office warned about extreme heat in the United Kingdom in mid-July. However, the office did not warn about blood clots, as the office focuses on weather.
Sources: American Heart Association: Twenty-seven ways a heat wave can kill you
Express: Blood clots: Heat can cause blood to turn ‘sticky’ warns expert - the one thing to avoid
JAMA: Association of extreme heat with all-cause mortality in the contiguous U.S.
MSN: " Your blood thickens and clots: What extreme heat can do to your body
National Institute of Health: Extreme heat in the U.S. linked to an increased number of deaths
Telegraph: What extreme heat can do to your body – and how to stay safe
Yale Medicine: The link between J&J’s COVID vaccine and blood clots: What you need to know

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Germany weather maps show media exaggerating effects of climate change.
Justification: A green map from 2017 and red map 2022 with summer temperatures show two different things in two different formats, though they appeared on the same TV show. German public broadcasters shared weather forecasts that were produced by different offices before 2020, when they became standardized. A red heat map seen in a 2022 forecast was also seen in 2017 on a similar show on public broadcasting.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images of Plymouth Rock prove sea levels are not rising.
Justification: There is no evidence Plymouth Rock is the exact boulder where Pilgrims first disembarked the Mayflower in Plymouth in 1620, nor that it was found at sea level. The rock has also been moved several times since it was identified. Plymouth Rock has been submerged before, during extreme weather and exceptionally high tides. Experts said it is not a useful landmark for measuring sea level changes. Global sea levels are rising at an increasing rate.
Sources: History.com "The real story behind Plymouth Rock
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Tides & Currents

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden threatens to assassinate Ukraine president.”
