Justification: N/A

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The entire banking system in Canada is closing down.
Justification: Rogers Communications, a Canadian telecommunications giant with millions of customers, had an outage July 8 that affected many activities, including bank transactions. The company blamed the outage on a coding error. The major outage is over and the Canadian government is investigating.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "To date, nobody has been able to show that there is a law for the average American citizen working day in and day out to pay an income tax."
Justification: •U.S. laws about income tax requirements are in the Internal Revenue Code, found in Title 26 of the United States Code. The laws have been repeatedly upheld by courts.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: You can't pour water on flames from an electric car battery because “water makes lithium burn."
Justification: U.S. authorities have conducted a substantial amount of research on how to extinguish lithium-ion batteries. A report from the Fire Protection Research Foundation found that water can be used to put out a burning lithium-ion battery, although it requires copious amounts to complete the task.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Know what they always find in Alzheimer’s patients? Excessive aluminum in the brain. Know what makes your body hoard aluminum? Fluoride.”
Justification: •Evidence does not support the claim that aluminum is increased in the brains of people with Alzheimer’s disease, or that aluminum is a cause of the disease.•Fluoride is considered safe in both drinking water and toothpaste, which are the main ways people consume it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The Sun is out of place, the Moon is out of place and the stars are out of place. The compasses are off" because of a shift in the Earth’s poles.
Justification: The sun and moon are constantly changing positions in the sky because of the Earth’s tilt and the moon’s orbit. But they have not diverged from what astronomers expect. The Earth has two types of poles — magnetic and geographic. They move independently of each other but in slow and predictable ways.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donald Trump gave a speech in Prescott Valley, Arizona, on July 18, 2022.
Justification: Old videos of former Vice President Mike Pence in Arizona in 2020 and former President Donald Trump in Texas in 2022 are being mischaracterized as a Trump speech in Prescott Valley, Arizona, on July 18, 2022. His July 16 event there was rescheduled for July 22.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Supreme Court FINALLY signs VERDICT to IMPEACH Speaker Pelosi as Hunter’s Laptop IMPLICATES her.”
Justification: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is not being impeached and the Supreme Court has no impeachment powers. The U.S. Constitution gives Congress the authority to impeach a federal official. Pelosi is not connected to the saga of Hunter Biden’s laptop.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Consuming “rice and beans, milk, cheese, butter and eggs” causes disease by age 30.
Justification: There is no scientific evidence that eating rice, beans, milk, cheese, butter or eggs frequently causes disease. They are safe to consume in moderation. The claim comes from a self-educated herbalist known as "Dr. Sebi." No scientific evidence supports his alkaline diet or his theory that mucus and acidic foods cause all diseases. According to physicians, our bodies regulate pH naturally, and dietary choices cannot substantially impact it.
Sources: Clinical Journal of the American Society of Nephrology
Email interview with Dr. Benjamin Caballero
Email interview with Dr. Scott Kahan

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Brittney Griner is really a man.
Justification: Basketball star Brittney Griner has spoken often about bullying and criticism she’s faced over her body. She described being called a boy at school because of her physical appearance in an interview with ESPN Magazine after posing naked for its Body Issue in 2015.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Adults over 51 can receive $$$ in additional spending for groceries and expenses.”
Justification: Medicare Advantage is a health plan for Medicare-eligible adults that’s provided through private insurance, not the federal government. Certain plans can include a prepaid debit card to use for certain medical expenses or a grocery stipend to purchase healthy foods. Only adults 65 and older and people with certain disabilities are eligible for Medicare.
Sources: Email with Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: House Democrats have kicked Rep. Ilhan Omar out of Congress
Justification: U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar is facing a Democratic primary challenger in August, but she is still a member of Congress. The House has the power to expel a member, but it’s been used only twice in the modern era, most recently in 2002.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden impeachment in progress.”
Justification: The Democrats, who control the House of Representatives, have not initiated impeachment proceedings against Joe Biden, a president from their own party.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Claims the James Webb Space Telescope is “fakery they got for the masses”
Justification: There is no evidence supporting the claim that the James Webb Space Telescope is fake. The development and launch of the James Webb Space Telescope has been well documented. There is plenty of scientific evidence proving that the Earth is round, broadcasting through space is possible and there is more than one galaxy in the universe.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: This is the 911 call placed by the migrants trapped in the truck found in San Antonio.
Justification: A recording of a 911 call is being falsely shared on Facebook claiming it’s from the migrants found dead on June 27 in San Antonio. The recording is from a call published on YouTube by Noticias Telemundo on February 11, 2021 where another group of immigrants were stuck in a tanker truck.
Sources: Press Release from the Department of Justice

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: KFC is giving away chicken bucket vouchers to customers who share a Facebook post before July 20.
Justification: Newly created Facebook accounts are offering Facebook users the chance to win free KFC chicken buckets. This is a scam.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An image shows a “UFO photographed on June 21, 2014 by the pilot from the cockpit of an F-16 military plane flying near Lackland Air Force Base of the United States located in San Antonio, Texas.”
Justification: There’s no evidence an image viral on Facebook depicts a pilot spotting a UFO in 2014. The image is an iteration of a years-old meme, which has been edited in numerous ways since at least 2008 to depict the same pilot flying beside different objects in the sky.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: CNN coverage has evidence of the “single most egregious, real-time example of electronic vote fraud.”
Justification: Government officials have called the "Hammer and Scorecard" conspiracy theory, which is consistent with this claim, disinformation and nonsense. Voting machines have safeguards to prevent inconsistencies in votes being casted for any one candidate. A recanvass of votes for the 2019 Kentucky governor’s race found no evidence of voter fraud.
Sources: Archive of Chris Krebs’ Twitter post

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Drought is a lie” designed to limit farming, reduce the food supply and ultimately control Americans.
Justification: More than 50% of the contiguous United States was experiencing drought as of July 12, according to National Integrated Drought Information System data. The Facebook post links the claim that "drought is a lie" to unsubstantiated conspiracy theories. Some places have set regulations to conserve water because it is scarce, but there’s no evidence these actions are tied to efforts to reduce the food supply and control Americans.
Sources: U.S. Department of Commerce and Agriculture

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Kevin McCarthy said Nancy Pelosi “should be prosecuted and jailed.”
Justification: We found no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Donald Trump was in a presidential limousine as he left his Jan. 6, 2021, rally at the White House Ellipse.
Justification: The Secret Service told PolitiFact that former President Donald Trump was in an SUV as he was driven away from his rally at the White House Ellipse on Jan. 6, 2021. A photo circulating on Facebook of Trump in a presidential limousine was taken in 2020.
Sources: Statement from the U.S. Secret Service

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Moscow was engulfed in flames” after a giant explosion.
Justification: According to reports, there were some recent fires at factories outside of Moscow. But Moscow wasn’t engulfed in flames.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images from Hunter Biden’s laptop show Joe Biden naked with a young girl.
Justification: The images of a naked man and a young girl were taken from a years-old pornographic video. They do not show President Joe Biden.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Planned Parenthood clinics are “closing down all over the country” because Roe v. Wade was overturned.
Justification: No Planned Parenthood clinics have closed since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade on June 24, according to the organization. A handful of clinics closed and merged across several states in anticipation of the ruling. Planned Parenthood representatives have said that was so the organization could better use its resources if Roe was overturned. At least one new clinic is opening, and clinics in states where abortion is not banned have reported seeing surges of new patients.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Putin humiliatingly blows up all weapons and facilities" on Snake Island by retreating Russian troops.
Justification: Russia withdrew its troops from Snake Island on June 30 following a string of attacks on the island by Ukraine’s military. The Russian military characterized the withdrawal as a "gesture of goodwill." The Ukrainian government claimed Russia bombed the island, which lies off the Ukrainian coast, following its troop withdrawal, but the attack has not been independently verified.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Fast food chain Wendy’s was “exposed for using horse meat.”
Justification: Wendy’s does not use horsemeat in its hamburgers. The social media rumor is 5 years old, and has been debunked before. The government has not said it found horsemeat in the company’s food.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "ADHD does not exist."
Justification: ADHD stands for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder. In a viral video, clinical psychologist and advocate Umar Johnson claims the American Psychiatric Association added the "H" in ADHD so pharmaceutical companies could sell more medicine and make more money. But that's untrue. Children were being prescribed a stimulant to treat attention disorders even before the term attention-deficit disorder, or ADD, was coined in 1980. Studies that evaluated racial disparities in ADHD diagnoses found that Black children were less — not more — likely to get diagnosed with ADHD compared with white children displaying similar behavior. There is evidence that ADHD is being overdiagnosed among the entire population of children. But misdiagnoses occur because of a lack of trained professionals, a researcher said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video claims Moscow turned into “sea of fire after being attacked by two mysterious missiles.”
Justification: The video does not show a missile attack against the city of Moscow. Footage used in a social media video claiming to be from the attack was taken from unrelated incidents.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Claims the U.S. military is using "polymer drone flies" that look and act like a large fly.
Justification: The video shows a person handling an actual fly, not a mechanical drone used by the U.S. military. The military does use small drones, but they are about 7 inches long and use rotor blades to fly.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “SCOTUS overturned the 2020 election.”
Justification: N/A

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The mass shooting in Highland Park, Illinois, was a “false flag.”
Justification: This claim is baseless. The shooting suspect has confessed, authorities said, and witnesses have told reporters what they saw.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images show Highland Park shooter had antifa connection
Justification: None of the images supposedly pulled from Crimo’s social media feeds have been verified and the evidence supporting their authenticity is thin. Screenshots of Crimo’s supposed Instagram account omitted information, such as a username, that could have been used to verify it.
Sources: Email interview with Lake County Sheriff's Office

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Belarus declares war on Poland.”
Justification: Belarus has threatened to retaliate against Poland in the case of "Western provocations" amid Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, according to news reports, but it hasn’t gone so far as to declare war against the country.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Fluoride will eat a hole through concrete, so it’s not safe for your teeth.
Justification: Hydrofluorosilicic acid is an additive used to fluoridate community water supplies in the U.S. Like many chemicals, it is caustic in its concentrated form. But it never reaches consumers, and the resulting fluoride it produces is diluted in water treatment plants to a safe amount in drinking water. Toothpastes made by Colgate and other companies use different fluoride compounds, typically stannous fluoride, sodium fluoride or sodium monofluorophosphate.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Phone interview with Dr. Howard Pollick

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows the aftermath of a mass shooting in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania.
Justification: City officials in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, reported that during an event, two juveniles got into a fight. Someone threw firecrackers on the ground, and someone shouted, "Gun!" causing a mass panic and stampede. There was no mass shooting.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Shooter in Highland Park, Illinois, “bought the gun illegally.”
Justification: Robert Crimo III, who opened fire during an Independence Day celebration in Highland Park, Illinois, had a history of encounters with local police, but was not barred from legally purchasing weapons. Investigators told news outlets that Crimo obtained the proper identification needed to legally purchase firearms and passed several background checks before buying his weapons legally. Neither law enforcement officials nor the shooter’s family members used the state’s red flag law and petitioned to prevent him from acquiring guns.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Fox offers Chris Wallace's Sunday spot to Candace Owens."
Justification: Fox News did not offer former anchor Chris Wallace’s old show, "Fox News Sunday," to conservative commentator Candace Owens. The network confirmed that this is fake.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Sri Lanka’s president, Estonia’s prime minister and Ukrainian diplomats were arrested.
Justification: While some media outlets have reported that Sri Lanka’s leaders are trying to flee the country because they fear being detained, they haven’t been arrested, and neither have Estonia’s prime minister or several Ukrainian ambassadors.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Illinois high school to implement race-based grading system in 2022-2023 school year
Justification: Illinois high school administrators are not grading students based on their race Administrators are working to develop an approach for equitable grading, though it will rely on objective assessments of whether students have mastered the material. West Cook News, the source of this claim, is part of a group of websites that has taken funding from conservative groups.
Sources: Oak Park and River Forest High School
Oak Park and River Forest High School District 200

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. military arrests Michael Sussmann.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded and originated on a site with a history of publishing false information.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: With the $53 billion spent in Ukraine aid, the U.S. “could pay five SWAT members $80,000 each and have them at EVERY school front door.”
Justification: The U.S. has spent $53 billion on aid to Ukraine as part of a bipartisan effort to oppose Russia’s invasion of the fledgling democracy. More than $3 billion goes toward U.S. schools safety equipment and personnel every year, according to market research analysis and federal figures. Researchers largely agree that armed officers at K-12 schools do not prevent mass shootings or other gun-related incidents from happening. Instead, experts recommend threat assessment programs to help school staff identify behavioral warning signs among students and intervene to provide support before violent incidents occur.
Sources: Journal of the American Medical Association Network
Rand Corp. and University at Albany

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "President Biden confirm(ed) everyone will receive their $1k gas checks this week!!"
Justification: •The federal government is not issuing gas stimulus checks.•Ten states have approved tax rebate payments that range from $75 in Idaho to $850 in Maine. Six other states are considering similar measures.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Prince Harry and Meghan “have finally signed the divorce papers.”
Justification: Claims that Prince Harry and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, divorced are baseless.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Florida man on drugs kills imaginary friend and turns himself in.”
Justification: The mugshot in the Facebook post belonged to a man arrested for a crime distinct from the details included in the post. A spokesperson for the Jacksonville Sheriff’s Office found no record that such an incident occurred.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Speedway is offering $500 fuel cards for $1.95 to help customers with rising fuel costs.
Justification: This is a scam. Speedway is not offering customers $500 "fuel cards" for $1.95 because of high gas prices.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A BP oil executive named Brice Cromwell blamed the Biden administration for high gas prices.
Justification: The BP oil executive Facebook users attribute the post to doesn’t exist — the company confirmed there is no staff member by the name of Brice Cromwell. Gas prices have little to do with the president, no matter who’s in office. In 2020, gas prices fell significantly because of the pandemic’s effects on the global economy. Prices began rising again due to pandemic recovery, and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine made a significant impact on the global supply of oil.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “USDA is predicting egg prices will be $12 a dozen by fall 2022.”
Justification: •The U.S. Department of Agriculture did not predict that eggs will cost $12 per dozen in fall 2022, a spokesperson said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "In Zimbabwe, people have started selling their toes for thousands of dollars due to (the) high cost of living.”
Justification: Rumors that people in Zimbabwe are selling their toes for cash started as an online joke, but were taken seriously by many. The country’s deputy information minister visited a mall where the sales were allegedly happening and declared the claims false.
Sources: Agence France-Presse via the South China Morning Post

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The man who killed the Uvalde, Texas, school shooter “wasn't even an on-duty police officer.”
Justification: Jacob Albarado, a Border Patrol agent from Uvalde, Texas, rushed to Robb Elementary School to help evacuate children and rescue his daughter and wife. The off-duty agent didn’t didn’t shoot and kill the 18-year-old gunman. A tactical unit did that, authorities say. Albarado appeared on "Today" and confirmed that he wasn’t on duty and didn’t have any gear but said he helped evacuate children from outside.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Military take over on May 11 confirmed!”
Justification: N/A

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden just resigned from the White House.”
Justification: This is unfounded misinformation.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Bill Gates planned a smallpox-type outbreak.
Justification: Philanthropist Bill Gates has spoken about the importance of preparing for future pandemics. Gates’ comments are not evidence that clusters of monkeypox, a virus related to smallpox, were planned.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Justin Bieber’s Ramsay Hunt syndrome and Hailey Bieber’s blood clot were caused by COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: Justin Bieber and his wife, Hailey, each shared details about their medical conditions in videos on social media. Neither mentioned COVID-19 vaccines as being a factor. It is not known publicly if either have been vaccinated. Experts say there is no increased risk of shingles, of which Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a type, after COVID-19 vaccination.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A “public health warning” was recently issued for fluoride toothpaste.
Justification: In 1997, the FDA started requiring fluoride toothpastes to include a warning advising people to seek professional help if they swallow more toothpaste than they used for brushing. A recent social media post falsely suggests that’s a new public health warning.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Baby boomers didn’t have autism, seizures, allergies and other ailments when they were kids.
Justification: Today’s childhood diseases and ailments also existed when baby boomers were kids, though in some cases, the rates of such illnesses have increased.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
SIDS Sudden Infant and Early Childhood Death: The Past

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: 95-item list of food-destroying incidents demonstrates that “you are duped if you think they aren’t planning a food shortage.”
Justification: Most of the incidents included in this 95-item list of agricultural incidents involving fires and "destroyed" poultry were not suspicious, according to authorities. More than 10 items were duplicates, factually incorrect or did not appear to have happened at all. Fifty incidents involved thousands of chickens or turkeys being killed because they were exposed to a highly contagious avian influenza. More than 15 items on the list were fires that officials said weren’t suspicious. Experts in fire research and avian influenza said the list’s legitimate incidents do not demonstrate that there is an ongoing effort to create food shortages.
Sources: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Thousands of cattle that recently died in Kansas weren’t killed by the heat.
Justification: Claims that chemtrails or a scheme to cause a food shortage were behind recent cattle deaths in Kansas are wrong. Experts blame the heat.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Ukrainian soldiers shooting down Russian helicopters.
Justification: This isn’t a real video showing the Ukrainian military shooting down Russian helicopters. It’s a simulation from the Arma 3 video game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There are more females on Facebook than alive in the world.
Justification: The number of monthly active users on Facebook is about half the number of female users than what this post claims.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. military at the White House arresting Congress.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. No U.S. congressional lawmakers have been arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump is addressing to the nation today.”
Justification: This is false. Joe Biden is president, not Donald Trump.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. Orders MILLIONS Of Smallpox Vaccines Amid Global Monkeypox Outbreak.”
Justification: The U.S. government recently moved to convert smallpox vaccines it had already paid for under an existing contract to freeze-dried doses that have a longer shelf life. The Department of Health and Human Services says this is unrelated to recent monkeypox outbreaks, though some of the smallpox vaccines may be used to respond to monkeypox.
Sources: Statement from the Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Aaron Salter Jr. was killed by a mass shooter because he was working on creating a water-powered car engine.
Justification: Aaron Salter Jr. was a retired Buffalo police officer who worked as a security guard at Tops Friendly Markets, and in his spare time, he worked on an invention to fuel cars with water electrolysis, which breaks water down into hydrogen and oxygen to use the hydrogen as fuel. There’s no evidence that Salter was killed for his work. Salter was among other victims in the Buffalo mass shooting who were targeted for being Black.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Barack Obama announced Joe Biden’s death.
Justification: This is baseless.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: CNN is recycling crisis actors in reports about a man dying in Afghanistan in 2021 and at the Uvalde, Texas, school shooting in 2022.
Justification: A bogus tweet from accounts masquerading as CNN falsely asserted that the same man died in multiple events. CNN did not make these reports. The name used to identify the man in the photo, Bernie Gores, is fake. The image shows a video gamer.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden approved a “new card” that “gives free health insurance to Americans” who are 25 and older.
Justification: Some Americans do qualify for federal subsidies to help them pay for health insurance plans, but there isn’t a magic free health insurance card forthcoming. An image in this post has been doctored to look like a live news broadcast of President Joe Biden announcing this new card, but the photo was taken during a foreign policy speech at the State Department in 2021.
Sources: U.S. Embassy in the Democratic Republic of Congo

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden resigned and “Trump is the new president.”
Justification: This claim is baseless.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The sale of more than 600,000 Wisconsin deer licenses shows that Wisconsin’s hunters are the “eighth largest army in the world.”
Justification: Wisconsin sold about 569,000 deer licenses that included gun privileges in 2020. Wisconsin sells nonresident licenses for gun deer hunting, so there’s no way to know that the people who purchased licenses to hunt with firearms in Wisconsin are state residents. A group of 600,000 armed hunters wouldn’t constitute a strikingly large global force, as the post claimed.
Sources: Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources - Agent Training

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: They passed the flu off as COVID-19, and “they’re going to do the same thing with monkeypox and shingles.”
Justification: Flu cases dropped during the pandemic because of lockdowns and masking, the CDC said. Monkeypox and shingles each result in blistering skin rashes, but they look different on the body. Testing for each disease is different, with monkeypox confirmation being done at the CDC.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Esther Freeman

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Studies show plastics can help combat climate change.
Justification: Some studies have found that plastic packaging is less environmentally damaging than alternatives, but this doesn’t negate plastics' negative impact on human health and marine environment.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The World Health Assembly was canceled "after the Geneva airport was coincidentally blown up."
Justification: • The airport in Geneva, Switzerland, did not blow up. A fire broke out at a building under construction outside the perimeter of the airport.• The 75th World Health Assembly, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization’s member states, opened as scheduled on May 22 in Geneva.• A "pandemic treaty" will not be agreed upon at the World Health Assembly.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Fox News and Candace Owens tweeted that “New studies show that 68% of those who used ivermectin to treat or prevent covid are suffering long-term bowel and urinary incontinence.”
Justification: Tweets that claim people who used ivermectin to treat or prevent COVID-19 are now suffering "long-term bowel and urinary incontinence" are fake. Ivermectin has been studied as a COVID-19 treatment, but neither the Food and Drug Administration nor the National Institutes of Health recommend using ivermectin to treat COVID-19.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Uvalde, Texas, mass shooter was an “illegal alien.”
Justification: •Salvador Ramos, who police said shot and killed 19 students and two teachers in Uvalde, Texas, was a U.S. citizen, Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos of a person in a skirt show the Uvalde, Texas, school shooter.
Justification: These photos aren’t of the person authorities said shot and killed children and teachers at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde County, Texas, on May 24.
Sources: Andy Ngo and Christina Pushaw tweets

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Florida Highway Patrol has a semi-truck … The FHP uses a fleet of three such ‘hidden in plain sight’ trucks to snitch on bad drivers.”
Justification: Florida does have semi-trucks in its patrol fleet. But there is only one such vehicle that can be used in patrol capacities, and it’s not disguised. Images of the truck posted on Facebook show that it has the agency’s logo on it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A 2021 article about monkeypox that used a photo of a shingles rash proves the monkeypox virus is a hoax.
Justification: A website misused a photo of a shingles rash in a story about monkeypox, but that doesn’t prove the monkeypox virus is a hoax.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos of monkeypox lesions prove the current virus outbreak is a hoax.
Justification: News organizations have reused images of monkeypox infections over the years to illustrate the disease’s symptoms but that doesn’t mean it’s fake.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Americans can get up to $50k in relief” from a “new benefit that just got released last week."
Justification: • There is not a new government benefit available to Americans. The video directs viewers to a website that provides quotes for private loans.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The current monkeypox outbreak was planned by government and industry leaders.
Justification: • There is no evidence a recent surge in monkeypox cases was planned by government and industry leaders.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “They just exposed Mark Zuckerberg as a CIA agent.”
Justification: More than a decade after The Onion published a satirical video claiming Facebook was created by the CIA, false claims that Mark Zuckerberg is a CIA agent are still spreading on social media.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Russian tank column totally destroyed by attack helicopter.”
Justification: Another clip from the video game Arma 3 is being mischaracterized. Social media posts claim it shows Russian tanks getting destroyed. That’s wrong.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There’s a “‘positive correlation’ between higher mask usage and COVID-19 deaths.”
Justification: In many areas, higher rates of masking are a common reaction to higher rates of COVID-19. When there is a high risk of catching or dying from the virus, more people wear masks in order to protect themselves. Masking in itself does not cause deaths. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends people wear masks as one line of defense against transmission because COVID-19 is transmitted through respiratory droplets. While any mask is better than none, its protective benefit varies by the mask type, make and fit.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email Interview with  Professor Beny Spira of the department of microbiology at the University of Sāo Paulo in Brazil
European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
Journal of the Royal Society Interface

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “(Pfizer) says do not breastfeed. Baby formula shortages everywhere. Gates promotes brand new artificial breast milk technology. All within less than a 2 week period. …Nothing to see here."
Justification: •Claims that Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine isn’t recommended while breastfeeding were based on outdated information from United Kingdom health officials — not from Pfizer — issued when the vaccine rollout was in its earliest stages. Once more safety data became available, UK officials updated their guidance and now recommend COVID-19 vaccination for those who are breastfeeding.•Domestic baby formula shortages are linked to supply chain problems that began during the COVID-19 pandemic, plus the recall of some formula that led to a manufacturing plant shutdown.•There’s no evidence that an investment in BIOMILQ – a startup that makes artificial breast milk – by a fund that Bill Gates is involved in has anything to do with the shortage.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: This image shows the victims of the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas.
Justification: The photo published on Facebook is not of the Uvalde, Texas victims. The Facebook post uses a photo of the 20 students and six adults that were killed in the Sandy Hook school shooting in Newton, Connecticut in 2012.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "More people die from hands, fists, feet, than rifles.”
Justification: FBI crime statistics show that 662 homicides in 2020 were committed with personal weapons, described as "hands, fists, feet, etc." The statistics also show that 455 homicides were committed by rifles. There were 13,663 homicides committed with guns, including 4,863 where the type of firearm wasn’t specified.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Monkeypox “was created in a lab and given via injection.”
Justification: Monkeypox was first observed in lab monkeys in 1958, but it wasn’t created there.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Swedish health authorities considering introducing restrictions because of monkeypox outbreak.”
Justification: As of May 25, Sweden had confirmed one case of monkeypox and the United States has confirmed two cases, according to an organization that tracks infectious disease data. Swedish Health Minister Lena Hallengren said there are no current plans to introduce "limits or restrictions on how we live due to monkeypox," and discouraged people from likening monkeypox to COVID-19.
Sources: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
Regeringskansliets "​​Infection with smallpox virus is classified as a general dangerous disease
The Public Health Agency of Sweden
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Uvalde, Texas, school shooter was a “transsexual leftist illegal alien named Salvatore Ramos.”
Justification: Misinformation is spreading about the identity of Salvador Ramos, who authorities say is the person who killed at least 19 children and two teachers at a Texas elementary school on May 24. We found no evidence to corroborate claims that Ramos was transgender or a "leftist," and officials have said he was a U.S. citizen, not an "illegal alien."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Bill Gates is behind the monkeypox outbreaks.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support the claim that Bill Gates is behind the monkeypox outbreak. Experts suspect it started to spread at raves in Europe.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Monkeypox is biological warfare “against us by our governments.”
Justification: The monkeypox virus is on a list of select agents and toxins the U.S. government hasdetermined"have the potential to pose a severe threat to both human and animal health, to plant health, or to animal and plant products." But there’s no evidence to support the claim that recent outbreaks are biological warfare.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows helicopters in Ukraine “being picked off in ambush - Short range air-to-air missile”
Justification: This is a clip from the Arma 3 video game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Mars Rover photo captured by NASA shows a doorway, suggesting extraterrestrial life.
Justification: NASA officials and Mars experts dismissed claims that the doorway is evidence of extraterrestrial life and said the formation is an unremarkable, naturally-occurring crevice that matches many others seen around the planet.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Suggests a January traffic accident involving lab monkeys was responsible for spreading monkeypox to humans.
Justification: • There is no evidence that the lab monkeys from a January traffic accident in Pennsylvania were infected with monkeypox, or that they spread it to humans.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Russian desert base and infrastructure hit by Bayraktar TB2 drone.”
Justification: This is from a video game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Don't let this formula shortage scare you!!! Make your baby some hemp milk w/sea moss. It’s easy I promise!”
Justification: •Babies fed formula made from similar combinations of ingredients have suffered cardiac arrest, rickets and other deficiencies, according to the Centers for Disease Control Prevention.•Experts warn against making homemade formula and say consuming it can result in adverse health effects for infants. Homemade formula isn't safe and does not meet babies’ nutritional needs.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The United States can’t import baby formula because of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement.
Justification: Almost all of the infant formula consumed in the U.S. is domestically produced. Importing baby formula to the U.S. is allowed but uncommon. The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement established specific rules for importing baby formula from Mexico and Canada. However, many regulations around imports existed before the USMCA was adopted in 2020.
Sources: Cornell Law School’s Legal Information Institute
Office of the United States Trade Representative

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos of the alleged Buffalo shooting gunman show two different people.
Justification: Hair color can look different depending on lightning, among other factors. Two images of the alleged Buffalo gunman with slightly different shades of hair does not prove the photos show two different people. They’re both Payton Gendron.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Mark Zuckerberg was arrested.
Justification: Claims that Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg was arrested are unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says video shows "Ukrainian forces shoot down Russian plane carrying hundreds (of) troops on Kyiv airport."
Justification: •The crash footage is from 2021, when a prototype military plane crashed outside Moscow.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Supreme Court Justices Amy Coney Barrett and Samuel Alito said that the U.S. needs a “domestic supply of infants” to meet the needs of parents seeking to adopt.
Justification: The phrase was not written by Supreme Court Justices Amy Coney Barrett and Samuel Alito. The line appears in the opinion draft as a footnote and came from a 2008 U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention document about adoption data. The draft says the opinion was authored by  Alito. It does not list Barrett as an author.
Sources: Supreme Court Roe v. Wade draft opinion
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Disney stock is down more than 70% and attendance is down more than 55%! 10.1 million people canceled their Disney+ subscription."
Justification: While the Walt Disney Co.’s stock value has decreased since the company spoke out against the law nicknamed "don’t say gay" by critics, it fell by 25%, not 70%. Disney reported growth in theme park attendance and guest spending in its latest quarterly report. The company also reported that its streaming service, Disney+, had a 33% increase in subscribers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “We have 76% of Americans living paycheck to paycheck, meaning they are one paycheck away from poverty.”
Justification: Different surveys yield different figures, but we found no recent data putting the percentage of Americans living paycheck to paycheck as high as 76%. Data from 2020 through 2022 found that between 50% and 63% of Americans report living paycheck to paycheck. But there is no clear definition for the phrase "paycheck to paycheck," so people should be skeptical of statistics based on the concept, one economist said.
Sources: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Goat’s milk is a good substitute for baby formula.
Justification: Giving your baby goat’s milk in lieu of formula carries health risks.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The U.S. government’s inaction over buffalo killing that harmed Native American populations in the 1800s shows it is now “is creating food shortages” so that Americans are more “dependent on the government.”
Justification: Millions of buffalo were killed by hunters in the late 1800s. By 1873, welcoming the extinction of the buffalo to suppress Indigenous peoples had become "de facto government policy," according to Andrew Isenberg, a professor of American History at the University of Kansas. Ukraine and Russia are key exporters of agricultural products such as wheat and barley, which has caused concern about future food shortages in some parts of the world. The U.S. is experiencing a baby formula shortage because of a large recall, pandemic-related supply chain issues, and the highly concentrated nature of the formula market. There is no evidence the shortage was intentionally created by the government.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Due to the baby formula shortage Tricare will now pay to have it shipped directly to you.”
Justification: •Tricare, the U.S. Defense Department’s health care program, does not cover the cost of formula for all infants, only for those with metabolic disorders.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Amber Heard plagiarized lines from the movie “The Talented Mr. Ripley” in her opening statement during the Johnny Depp libel trial.
Justification: Multiple reviews of the proceedings show that Heard did not make the comments attributed to her online.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says photo shows "the sharpest image of the sun ever recorded."
Justification: •The photo, from 2021, has been "heavily software-processed" and digitally enhanced, the photographer said.•In March, the highest resolution photo of the sun’s full disk and its corona was captured by a satellite.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Finland joins NATO.”
Justification: Finland has said it will apply to join NATO, but it’s not a done deal, and Turkey has said it doesn’t favor the country’s membership.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says photo shows "one of Tesla's lithium supply mines where entire mountains are eliminated."
Justification: •The photo shows a copper mine in Chile, not a mine for lithium.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images show Joe Biden surrounded by U.S. Marshals.
Justification: The men pictured in a photo with President Joe Biden are Secret Service agents and White House staffers, not U.S. Marshals.
Sources: Statement from the U.S. Secret Service

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A recent photo shows the “Russian Orthodox Church blessing a rocket called Satan.”
Justification: A photo being shared amid the war in Ukraine shows Russian priests blessing a missile before a parade in 2015. It doesn’t show them blessing the so-called "Satan 2" missile that was unveiled a year later.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Suggests Megan Thee Stallion was not shot in the foot.
Justification: •Megan Thee Stallion initially told police and doctors her injury was caused by broken glass; later she recanted that explanation.•Amedical report from the day Megan was shot shows that there are bullet fragments in her foot, media outlets reported.•Police charged Tory Lanez with assault with a semi-automatic firearm in connection with the shooting, and prosecutors have said they believe the evidence substantially supports the charges.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "148th Kentucky Derby winner Rich Strike jockey Sonny Leon just turned down a White House invite, saying 'If I wanted to see a horse's ass, I would have came (sic) in second.’"
Justification: •There is no evidence that Sonny Leon, the winning jockey from the 2022 Kentucky Derby, made that remark, or that he received or declined an invitation to the White House.•A joke about Kentucky Derby winners declining White House invitations has been circulating since at least 2018 — when it was attributed to a horse — and has been debunked.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Homemade baby formula recipes offer a ‘viable option’ during U.S. shortage
Justification: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration advises against making homemade formula and says consuming it can result in adverse health effects for infants. The American Academy of Pediatrics also strongly advises against homemade formula, saying it isn't safe, does not meet babies’ nutritional needs, and could also lead to risks of contamination and infection.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donations of baby formula to Ukraine helped cause the current U.S. shortage.
Justification: •A Mississippi nonprofit, Operation Ukraine, sent $10,000 worth of baby formula to Ukraine in March.•There is no evidence that the donated formula contributed to current U.S. baby formula shortages, which are attributed to supply chain problems that began during the COVID-19 pandemic, plus the recall of some formula that led to a manufacturing plant shutdown.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Roe v. Wade happened because a woman lied about being raped by black men.”
Justification: •The U.S. Supreme Court did not consider the circumstances of plaintiff Jane Roe’s pregnancy when ruling on the landmark case in 1973. An alleged rape was never mentioned in court or in the court’s ruling.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If you earn $100 and pay $33 income tax you’re left with $67. You then buy $67 worth of fuel and in doing so pay a 48% fuel tax (fuel tax = $32.16 + $6.70 GST). This means that the government just got $71.86 tax from your hard earned $100.”
Justification: The claims don’t explicitly say in what country this alleged 48% fuel tax exists. One Facebook post references an Australian politician and both posts were shared by users in Canada, so PolitiFact compared the tax policies in both countries. Income tax rates in Australia and Canada are determined by how much a person makes. Consumers in Australia and Canada do pay fuel and sales taxes on gasoline, but these fees do not amount to 48% of the purchase.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Your state will send you free infant formula if you call Enfamil and Similac customer service numbers.
Justification: A spokesperson for Abbott, the maker of Similac told us, this claim is false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Amazon will ship baby formula to U.S. addresses if you change your preferred country on its website from the U.S. to Canada.
Justification: Parents with U.S. addresses can’t order baby formula from Amazon in Canada that’s sold and shipped by Amazon or sold by a third-party seller and shipped by Amazon. It’s possible that parents could find a third-party seller on the site to ship it to them directly, but some medical experts warn against that, and it will likely be more expensive.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The infant formula shortage was purposely created because Mark Zuckerberg and Bill Gates invested in artificial breast milk.
Justification: A national shortage of infant formula unfolded due to a recall by a major U.S. manufacturer of baby food and existing supply chain issues associated with the COVID-19 pandemic. There’s no evidence that an investment in BIOMILQ – a startup that makes artificial breast milk – by a fund that Mark Zuckerberg and Bill Gates are involved in has anything to do with the shortage. BIOMILQ says it’s still three to five years away from getting a product to market.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Suggests Amber Heard snorted cocaine while on the stand in court.
Justification: •There is no evidence that Amber Heard used cocaine while on the stand in court.•The claim fits a pattern of social media posts aiming to discredit Heard.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The NewProfilePic app is Russian spyware.
Justification: The NewProfilePic app does not access users’ banking information or contact lists, and it does not send their information to Russia. The servers that host users’ images are based in the U.S., not Russia. It is true that the app’s domain was initially registered in Moscow. A spokesperson for the company explained it was the former address of the founder, who has both Russian and Ukrainian heritage. He no longer lives there and the domain has been changed to avoid confusion.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says people can follow a 1960 recipe for homemade baby formula as a workaround during the current shortage.
Justification: •The U.S. Food & Drug Administration advises against making homemade formula and says consuming it can result in adverse health effects for infants.•The American Academy of Pediatrics also strongly advises against homemade formula, saying it isn't safe and does not meet babies’ nutritional needs.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows abortion rights activist urging women to "run on down to the abortion clinic" if they get pregnant.
Justification: Sister Cindy, whose real name is Cindy Smock, has been preaching with her husband at college campuses for more than 40 years. She describes herself as "pro-life." She uses exaggerated rhetoric and what she describes as humor to try to relate to students. Her remarks about women running down to abortion clinics were sarcastic and said in response to Missouri State University students chanting "my body, my choice," according to a local reporter in Missouri.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An adenovirus is a combination of viruses, gastrointestinal virus, pneumonia and COVID-19 mixed together to “kill our children.”
Justification: Adenoviruses are not new, nor have they been "developed." They are a group of viruses that cause common infections, ranging from mild colds to more serious illnesses like pneumonia. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has linked it as a possible cause for the recent outbreak of hepatitis cases in children, and is investigating the growing number of cases.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Students in Wilkes County, North Carolina, “identify themselves as cats or ‘furries’” and “have asked for litter boxes to be placed in school restrooms for them to use.”
Justification: The school district said it’s unaware that any student has requested a litter box in school bathrooms.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Anthony Fauci said lockdowns are a method for coercing people to comply with COVID-19 vaccinations.
Justification: •Dr. Anthony Fauci did not indicate at any point in a 90-second comment that lockdowns should be used as a tool of coercion. He was specifically talking about vaccine efficacy and uptake in China, where there is an ongoing lockdown.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Alkaline foods” can heal the body of cancer.
Justification: While the alkaline diet encourages healthy eating, it can’t cure cancer as some people claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Elon Musk tweeted, “The fact that an 18 year old can't take out a $10,000 business loan” but “can take out a $100,000 student loan tells you everything you need to know.”
Justification: PolitiFact found no evidence that Musk tweeted this. The purported tweet did not appear on Musk’s official Twitter, and we could not find an archived version of it either.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Arnold Schwarzenegger slept on the ground in front of a bronze statue of himself because he had been turned away from a hotel.
Justification: •The photo was a joke, according to stories written when it was taken, in 2016.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The White House presented commemorative coins” dedicated to Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
Justification: The commemorative coins honoring Volodymyr Zelenskyy were created for sale by a private company called the White House Gift Shop, not the U.S. government.
Sources: Email correspondence with the White House Historical Association
U.S. Patent and Trademark Office website
White House Gift Shop on Twitter

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “DeSantis erases Disney’s tax exempt law. Will cost Disney $200 Mil in taxes. Per year!”
Justification: The tax district provided Disney with several privileges, but it did not make the theme park tax-exempt. Disney World paid more than $780 million in state and local taxes in fiscal year 2021. PolitiFact found no evidence to substantiate the claim that DeSantis’ action would cost Disney $200 million in taxes a year.
Sources: The Florida Senate: Bill Analysis and Fiscal Impact Statement
The Reedy Creek Improvement Act of 1967

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Red Cross sells your donated blood to hospitals for $150 and then that hospital charges you thousands for a blood transfusion.”
Justification: The American Red Cross sells donated blood to hospitals on a "cost-recovery basis." The price a hospital pays for blood varies depending on location and other factors, but reports indicate prices have ranged from around $180 to $300 since 2000. The cost a hospital incurs for giving a transfusion varies, as does the cost it charges patients. Several reports indicated hospitals charge patients thousands of dollars for a transfusion.
Sources: Applied Health Economics and Health Policy
Email interview with Dr. Claudia Cohn
George Washington University Hospital Price Estimator

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Wearing foot patches can help adults grow inches in weeks.
Justification: Except in rare cases of endocrine abnormalities, adults can only increase their height with surgery.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The “Franklin scandal” broke in 1989 “when hundreds of children were apparently flown around the US to be abused by high ranking ‘Establishment’ members."
Justification: Lurid claims about a child sex trafficking ring took hold in Omaha, Nebraska, in the late 1980s, but multiple grand juries found that the allegations were unfounded — "a carefully crafted hoax."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Lilibet, baby daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, "made her first appearance with the queen.”
Justification: •Lilibet has not met Queen Elizabeth.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Space X’s Starlink internet constellation has angered Russia as it was reported that the Starlink satellite constellation was used to guide the fire” on the Russian ship Moskva.
Justification: •There are no credible government or media reports that indicate the Starlink satellite service was used to facilitate the attack on the Russian ship Moskva.•The Russian government did not order the destruction of the Starlink satellite service. That claim originated on a fraudulent website falsely identifying itself as the official website of a Russian political party.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Fires at food processing plants are an “attempt to starve us.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that a string of fires at food processing plants is intentional. The U.S. Department of Agriculture said there is currently no food shortage or disruption of the food supply in the country.
Sources: Email exchange with Jonesboro Fire Department Chief Kevin Miller
Emailed statement from the American Association of Meat Processors

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hillary Clinton is in jail at Gitmo at the moment.”
Justification: Yet another claim about Hillary Clinton being imprisoned in Cuba is false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Bath and Body Works products are not recommended during pregnancy because they are suspected of “damaging fertility or the unborn child.”
Justification: A Bath & Body Works safety data sheet includes warnings about skin irritation, infertility and organ damage. These disclosures aren’t new or limited to Bath & Body Works. Home fragrance companies are required to post these notices on their websites. The disclosures are meant for manufacturers and emergency workers — not consumers — who need to know how to handle, store or dispose of large quantities of chemicals, the company said. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists told PolitiFact that it has no official recommendation about pregnant women not using Bath & Body Works products. People who are pregnant should speak to their doctors if they have questions about any product.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "With 40 billion dollars, Elon Musk could have given each of the 330M people living in America a million dollars and still had $7B left over.”
Justification: The math is incorrect. Splitting $40 billion among 330 million Americans would give each person only $121.21. The author of the original tweet acknowledged his "viral tweet about bad math."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Paying taxes is optional!!”
Justification: Federal law dictates who owes taxes, how much is owed and when that amount is due; paying those taxes is mandatory, not optional. Failing to pay the taxes you owe could result in fines, criminal charges or your property being seized. This claim is linked to a complex, persistent and unfounded conspiracy theory.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Videos show that Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy uses cocaine.
Justification: Two viral videos purported to show that Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy uses cocaine. One video appeared to show cocaine on Zelenskyy’s desk as he spoke, while the other appeared to show him saying that he uses the drug routinely. The first video was doctored; in the original, there is no white substance on Zelenskyy’s desk. The second video was deceptively edited; in the original, he denied using drugs.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows “satanic death cult high priestess” Oprah Winfrey condoning and promoting “pedophilia and sex trafficking.”
Justification: A video on TikTok tries to tie talk show host Oprah Winfrey to child sex trafficking and abuse, but it takes her comments out of context.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Elon Musk just fired the entire Twitter board of directors.”
Justification: Twitter’s board has agreed to sell the company to Elon Musk but the deal won’t be finalized until after shareholders vote to approve it. Twitter hasn’t said when that vote will take place, but there’s some speculation it could happen at the company’s annual meeting on May 25.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "America (is) trying to overthrow the Ukraine government just as the shadow government has infiltrated and overthrown the US government."
Justification: •The U.S. has provided more financial, humanitarian and military support to Ukraine than any other nation since the outbreak of war, according to the Kiel Institute for the World Economy’s Ukraine Support Tracker.•The U.S. has not sent combat troops to Ukraine.•There is no evidence to support the claim that a shadow government has infiltrated and overthrown the U.S. government.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “White House physician demands Biden’s immediate resignation following his ‘obvious’ cognitive decline.”
Justification: •The current White House physician gave President Joe Biden a full medical evaluation in November and said he is fit to carry out his duties.•A former White House physician who has never been Biden’s physician — and is now a Republican member of Congress — has called for Biden’s resignation, saying he has declined cognitively.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Tylenol is the #1 cause of acute liver failure in the US with 27% of people dying & kills at least 100,000 per year from its use.”
Justification: Acetaminophen is the main active ingredient in Tylenol and hundreds of other medications. Acetaminophen overdose is the leading cause of acute liver failure in the U.S. About 1,600 to 2,000 cases of acute liver failure occur in the U.S. each year, and the condition is not always fatal. About 450 deaths per year are related to acetaminophen-associated overdoses, according to the FDA. That number is nowhere near 100,000 deaths — and there is no reason to think that each of those deaths was due to Tylenol, specifically.
Sources: The New England Journal of Medicine
University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “War Begins — F-35, F-16 and MiG-29 NATO intercept and destroy Russia Jets in Polish air space.”
Justification: Claims that NATO jets intercepted and destroyed Russian aircraft are false, according to the military alliance.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Jackie Chan is dead.
Justification: There’s no credible evidence to support the claim that Jackie Chan is dead. He recently posted online about the death of his friend, Kenneth Tsang. Chan is often the subject of death hoaxes.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: You can “reverse HIV naturally.”
Justification: While good nutrition is important for people with HIV, changes in diet won’t reverse the virus, for which there is not yet a cure.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Vladimir Putin “ended the Rothschild's control over Russia by nationalizing the Russian centralized bank."
Justification: •Russian President Vladimir Putin was not responsible for the nationalization of the Russian centralized bank, which took place in 1917.•The Rothschild family banking business has had an office in Russia since the 1990s, but it has no oversight over the country’s currency or monetary policies, which are controlled by the Bank of Russia.•The Rothschild family long has been the target of conspiracy theories, and their wealth is believed to be responsible for inspiring the anti-Semitic trope that Jewish people "control" the world’s money.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says JFK. Jr is masquerading as QAnon promoter Juan O. Savin.
Justification: John F. Kennedy, Jr. died in a plane crash in 1999. He is not living, and is not working with QAnon.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The President of Ukraine owns a $35 million home in Florida and has $1.2 billion in a overseas bank account.”
Justification: There is no proof that Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy owns a $35 million home in Florida. The claim originated from a source that appears to be backed by the Russian government. The Pandora Papers leak did show Zelenskyy owned several offshore companies and other assets, but nothing that could corroborate the claim made on social media.
Sources: Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Italian football agent Mino Raiola has died after suffering from an illness.”
Justification: Mino Raiola responded to false rumors about his death, tweeting that his current health status was "pissed off."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Congratulations to Ruben, knighted by the Queen. Now goes by the name, Sir Ruben.”
Justification: • A photo of the knighting of Simon Russell Beale was edited to replace the English actor with the black cat.• The image was shared on Ruben’s official Facebook profile on April Fools’ Day.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: As with people vaccinated against COVID-19, “many people who were NOT vaccinated also experienced zero or mild symptoms.”
Justification: •Unvaccinated people still experience higher rates of hospitalization and death from COVID-19 than vaccinated people.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Footage of the Bidens celebrating Easter at the White House is fake.
Justification: Claims that the Bidens faked an Easter egg roll at the White House were rooted in the inaccurate claim that they were standing behind a phony presidential seal, but it’s authentic. The same one was photographed with the Trumps around Easter in 2017.
Sources: Harry S. Truman Little White House

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If your roommate catches HIV, you will be exposed to it and will probably contract it too, given long enough.”
Justification: HIV is primarily spread through anal or vaginal sex or by sharing needles. For transmission to occur any other way — including casual contact, biting, kissing and spitting — "something very unusual would have to happen," the CDC says.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “It’s been proven that sugar triggers and causes cancer. … So the best thing to do to prevent cancer is to avoid sugar.”
Justification: Health experts have not found a direct link between sugar in a person’s diet and cancer. Consuming large amounts of sugar can lead to weight gain, putting a person at a higher risk of certain cancers and other diseases.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Vladimir Putin “released 35,000 children from tunnels and subway in Ukraine.”
Justification: This unfounded claim originated on a website known for publishing misinformation.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Ukraine was responsible for the Kramatorsk train station bombing.
Justification: There’s no credible evidence that Ukraine was behind the April 8 attack at the Kramatorsk train station. A video used to bolster this claim is fake — it did not come from the BBC. The claim has largely been spread by pro-Kremlin accounts following reports of civilian casualties and contradict earlier Russian posts that initially took credit for the bombing. The Tochka-U missile used in the attack, and the serial number on it, isn’t proof that it came from the Ukrainian army. Several news reports, legitimate photos and videos show that Russia has used these missile systems recently.
Sources: Center for Strategic and International Studies Missile Defense Project

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: MSNBC’s Mika Brzezinski said, “Elon Musk is trying to control how people think. That’s our job.”
Justification: The video is from 2017 and "Morning Joe" co-host Mika Brzezinski was talking about Donald Trump, not Elon Musk. After criticism the day the show aired, Brzezinski said her statement "that is our job," was misinterpreted to suggest the media’s role is to tell people what they should think.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hunter Biden arrested this morning.”
Justification: The latest false claim that Hunter Biden was arrested came on April 19, but like the misinformation that came before it, it’s wrong.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Disney lost 172,000 reservations recently, valued at around $636 (million) in revenue lost.”
Justification: PolitiFact found no evidence or news reports to corroborate the claim. Disney’s most recent earnings report said the revenue from its parks increased by $7.2 billion. The next figures will be reported in May.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: George Soros injected "$33 million" into Black Lives Matter.
Justification: A representative for Soros’ Open Society Foundations told PolitiFact that it has not directly given money to the Black Lives Matter organization. The $33 million figure is old. It comes from a Washington Times article that pointed to Soros' donations to social justice groups, several of which were active before the founding of the Black Lives Matter organization.
Sources: Email interview with Open Society Foundations’ communications officer

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: McDonald’s added xylitol to its ice cream which is toxic to dogs.
Justification: McDonald’s soft serve ice cream, found in the fast-food chain’s cones and other desserts, does not contain xylitol, the company said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Disney+ has had over 350,000 cancellations in the last five days.
Justification: There is no evidence that shows that over 350,000 Disney+ subscriptions were canceled "in the last five days." The figure comes from unsourced social media posts. Disney does not routinely release information on subscriber numbers. The company last released statistics in its quarterly report in February 2022. The next update will be during Disney’s next quarterly earning call in May.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Brooklyn subway attack was a false flag.
Justification: There’s no evidence to support baseless claims that the mass shooting in a Brooklyn subway was a staged event. The attack was real.
Sources: United States District Court Eastern District of New York

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: People protesting the Dakota Access pipeline “were intentionally poisoned” by government officials in North Dakota when a pilot “knowingly sprayed poisonous chemicals” over protesters’ camps.
Justification: During months-long protests in North Dakota that began in 2016 and persisted through 2017, thousands of protesters who opposed the Dakota Access pipeline clashed with security and police on several occasions. Protesters were pepper-sprayed, tear-gassed and doused with water in freezing temperatures. There is no evidence to suggest planes sprayed poisonous chemicals over the protesters’ camps. People who participated in the protests and officials have refuted these claims. The claims seem to stem from news of a private rancher’s illegal use of the rodenticide Rozol in 2016 in the same vicinity as the protests, in an attempt to kill prairie dogs. Researchers and state officials who studied the incident found no link to the protests or protester illnesses.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Schools are putting litter boxes in bathrooms to accommodate kids who identify as furries.
Justification: •School districts in several states have debunked the claim that they are providing litter boxes in bathrooms.•We did not find any credible news reports that say schools are providing litter boxes.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: March 2022 moon crash was orchestrated by the government and visible from Earth.
Justification: •Evidence indicates the rocket part was "space junk" from a Chinese rocket mission in 2014 and the crash was unintentional, scientists said.•The impact was not visible from Earth, and the videos included in the post were made in 2020 and 2021 using visual-effects software.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The COVID-19 vaccines contain “HIV lipid wrappers.”
Justification: None of the approved COVID-19 vaccines contain any HIV material. Lipids are fat molecules that encase and protect the mRNA in the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines. They have no relationship with HIV, experts said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "No one visiting Disney can get in” because of protest.
Justification: A protest organized by Moms for America was held April 16 at an intersection near one of many entrances to the sprawling Walt Disney World Resort property in Orlando, Florida. No roads were blocked and no one was denied entry, police and protest organizers said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Poland palace that Biden visited is fake.
Justification: Multiple photographs, videos and news articles show that President Joe Biden visited the Presidential Palace in Warsaw on March 26, where he met with President Andrzej Duda. While there appears to be something covering the exterior of the building at the entrance, wider shots show the entirety of the building and courtyard. Duda’s office confirmed renovation work on the palace has begun. Biden was also photographed and recorded during a visit with U.S. troops on March 25 and giving a speech on March 26.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: John D. Rockefeller coined the term “fossil fuel” to trick people into thinking that his product was scarce and drive up the price when fossil fuels are actually “the second most abundant liquid on the planet.”
Justification: John D. Rockefeller was not responsible for coining the term "fossil fuel." It was first used by German chemist Caspar Neumann in the 1700s. Oil might be abundant, but it’s not that simple, energy experts said. It took millions of years to yield the barrels of oil that are being drilled now, and just because oil exists somewhere, doesn’t mean it’s economically or technically possible to extract it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Just passed into law today: You cannot go 5 miles over speed limit” in North Carolina.
Justification: There was no new law passed on April 11 stating that drivers in North Carolina can’t go 5 mph over the speed limit. Like many other states, North Carolina follows absolute speed limits, which means that a person driving at any speed past the posted limit in an area is in violation of the law. However, the state allows what’s known as basic law, which means that a person can drive at speeds that are reasonable and prudent under safe conditions.
Sources: Interview with First Sgt. Christopher Knox

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Volodymyr Zelenskyy is a cousin of George Soros, Pentagon official says."
Justification: •Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and billionaire philanthropist George Soros are not cousins. ​The claim is "entirely false," said a spokesperson for Soros’ Open Society Foundations.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Fuel containing 15% ethanol will ruin a car engine.
Justification: •The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and an academic study have said that fuel containing 15% ethanol is safe for cars, trucks and sport-utility vehicles made in 2001 or later. More than 90% of vehicles on U.S. roads meet those specifications.•Many car manufacturers have okayed the use of E15 fuel in vehicles that were made in the last 10 years.•It is not recommended for on-highway and nonroad motorcycles; vehicles with heavy-duty engines, such as school buses; non-road vehicles like boats; engines in non-road vehicles such as lawnmowers; light-duty trucks; and medium-duty passenger vehicles,according to the EPA.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: 2004 video shows Anthony Fauci is ignoring science on natural immunity with regard to COVID-19.
Justification: Dr. Anthony Fauci said in a 2004 video that a woman who had recently had influenza didn’t need to get a flu vaccine. The science on the durability of immunity from a COVID-19 infection isn’t clear, and experts recommend getting a vaccine for added protection. Fauci, in public comments, has spoken positively about natural immunity from a COVID-19 infection, but with reservations.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Nicole Iovine
Email statement from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Leftist justice reform” is the reason that the NYC subway shooting suspect wasn’t in jail at the time of the attack.
Justification: Frank James, the New York subway shooting suspect, wasn't out of jail because of "leftist justice reform." His prior arrests came decades ago. The arrests that occurred in New York, for example,  were in the 1990s, most occurring when Republican Rudy Giuliani was mayor of the city and well before current justice reform efforts by prosecutors.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A bird pooped on Joe Biden during his speech” in Iowa.
Justification: President Joe Biden gave a speech in Iowa at a bioprocessing plant to discuss a new ethanol strategy to lower gas prices. A substance landed on his jacket mid-speech, leading many to think a bird had left its mark. Video from the scene clearly shows what one newspaper called distillers grains flying around from the top of a large pile near where the president was speaking.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Joe Biden is giving smartphones away to illegal border crossers.”
Justification: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcements has been using a smartphone application since 2018 to track immigrants detained and released by the agency after entering the country illegally. ICE will give a smartphone loaded with the application to immigrants who do not have their own devices. The smartphones are not enabled for personal use and cannot make phone calls or browse the internet.
Sources: Email with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden was confused, “turned around and shook hands with thin air” after a speech.
Justification: After the end of his speech at North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University, Biden turned around and gestured toward the onlookers to his right, who rose to applaud him. He wasn’t trying to shake hands with an imaginary person. Biden was at the university to speak about his administration’s efforts on economic renewal, and to visit the campus’ new engineering and innovation complex.
Sources: North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University
Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene Twitter post

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Twitter employee named Jackson Mulholland resigned in a tweet after Elon Musk joined the company’s board.
Justification: Elon Musk became Twitter’s largest shareholder on April 4 and gained a seat on the company’s board. A viral tweet from a person who claimed to be a Twitter employee who resigned over the news came from a satirical account. That account also claimed the user worked backstage at the Oscars the night Will Smith slapped Chris Rock. A Twitter spokesperson said that the person was not a current or former employee.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: After Russia invaded Ukraine, Google Maps “opened all military and strategic facilities in Russia.”
Justification: • Google told PolitiFact that it has not made any "blurring changes" to its satellite images of Russia.• Some of the Russian facilities that social media users claim are now suddenly visible have been available in high resolution on Google platforms for years.
Sources: Email exchange with Google’s press office. April 19

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Barack Obama tweeted, “Has anyone checked to make sure Donald Trump doesn’t have a Russian birth certificate?”
Justification: Barack Obama did not tweet, "Has anyone checked to make sure Donald Trump doesn’t have a Russian birth certificate?" The tweet bouncing around social media is fake.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Biden changes his mind and now wants to resume building Trump’s wall."
Justification: • Repair work is planned on the existing border wall, including closing gaps, cleaning up work sites and stabilizing eroding areas.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy wore a Nazi cross symbol.
