Justification: An Iron Cross visible on some of Zelenskyy’s military green T-shirts is not a Nazi symbol. It represents the official emblem of Ukraine’s armed forces and includes the country’s coat of arms in the center. The Iron Cross is a commonly used, famous German military medal. It’s not a hate symbol on its own. It was turned into a Nazi symbol when the regime superimposed a swastika in the center.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Want a healthy, happy baby? Skip the Well Baby visits. They… make your baby sick.”
Justification: Well-baby and well-child visits are regular check ups with pediatricians that are intended for the purpose of monitoring growth and development in babies and children. Doctors, health organizations and data stress that well-child visits are incredibly important for a child’s health. Children are more likely to get sick from outside sources like school or family, not doctor’s offices, experts say.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Phone interview with Dr. Joseph F. Hagan

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Russian soldiers using weapons that have been in a cupboard since Soviet times.”
Justification: The soldiers seen in the video don’t appear to be wearing Russian uniforms, an expert on land warfare said. The uniforms appear to match those worn by soldiers in the Kenya Defence Forces. A longer version of the video says the soldiers are members of the Kenyan military.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows a Home Depot worksheet on “privilege” used to train its employees.
Justification: An internal Home Depot document called "unpacking privilege" defines social and white privilege and gives examples of what different types of privilege look like. It’s a real document, but it was created as a resource by Home Depot’s Canadian division and was not made or approved by the company’s corporate office, nor is it part of any required training for any Home Depot employees.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: News networks covered Brett Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearing live but not Ketanji Brown Jackson’s hearing.
Justification: News networks are covering Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation hearing live online and in some cases on the air. The coverage is comparable to how news networks reported on the initial days of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearing. After  four days of hearings, sexual assault allegations against Kavanaugh emerged and another hearing was scheduled on Sept. 27 to address them. News networks canceled their regular programming to air that hearing live.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Sudden death in adults and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome are caused by vaccines.
Justification: •Multiple studies and scientific reviews found no association between vaccination and deaths in people of any age — adults or children — except in rare cases. More recently, a CDC study found no increased risk for death among COVID-19 vaccine recipients.• Research studies and safety reviews also do not show any links between childhood vaccines and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, which is the unexpected death of a seemingly healthy baby.•Vaccines are tested in clinical trials prior to public use, and multiple systems are in place to monitor their safety after they are released for public use, according to the CDC. Serious adverse reactions are rare, and the benefits of vaccination far outweigh the risks.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows a helicopter rescue mission in Afghanistan where wounded men were loaded onboard.
Justification: •The helicopter pilot said in an interview that it was a routine mission and they were loading prisoners, not wounded soldiers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Chris Rock apologized after 94th Academy Awards, saying, “Last night I crossed a line that I shouldn’t have and paid the enormous price of my reputation as a renown comedian.”
Justification: N/A

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Colorado Governor Jared Polis has just signed into law a bill legalizing abortions through all nine months, up until the moment of birth.”
Justification: Colorado’s law guarantees an individual’s right to use or refuse contraceptives, to continue a pregnancy and give birth, or to have an abortion. Abortions that take place later in a pregnancy are rare; less than 1% of abortions occur at or later than 21 weeks gestation.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Pfizer staged the Will Smith and Chris Rock confrontation at the Academy Awards because it "has a new alopecia medication coming out."
Justification: •There is no evidence that Will Smith slapping Chris Rock at the Academy Awards was staged. Smith apologized for his actions and the Academy has initiated disciplinary proceedings against him.•Pfizer is developing two medications to treat alopecia areata, an autoimmune disease that causes hair loss. The earliest anticipated date for federal regulatory approval of either drug is 2023.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “California introduces new bill that would allow mothers to kill their babies up to 7 days after birth.”
Justification: The bill is meant to ensure that people are not investigated, prosecuted or incarcerated for ending a pregnancy, experiencing pregnancy loss or for losing a baby after it is born due to a pregnancy-related cause, according to Assembly Member Buffy Wicks, the lawmaker who introduced it. Women in California have been prosecuted for delivering stillborns after using controlled substances. Wicks said she amended the language to specify that it would only prevent people from being prosecuted if a post-birth death occurred because of a pregnancy-related cause.
Sources: National Health Service Surrey and Borders Partnership

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows crowds shouting profanity at Joe Biden.
Justification: The clips that purportedly show people shouting profanity at Biden do not depict real events; they were edited. The original videos prove that crowds weren’t cursing at Biden in these speeches.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A Florida court sets atheist holy day” on April 1.
Justification: The Florida court case detailed in the Facebook post is a work of fiction. Some people appeared to recognize the satirical nature of the anecdote, but others seemed to believe it was a genuine court case.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There was a raid on the Biden residence yesterday by the military!”
Justification: Claims that the military invaded the Biden residence are unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Democrat’s New Plan: Tax billionaires to lower the deficit by $1 TRILLION and fund clean energy independence. Republican’s New Plan: Raise taxes on households earning less than $50,000 by an ADDITIONAL $4,500 after CUTTING taxes for the rich.”
Justification: The comparisons of tax policies are exaggerated and lack important context. The description of the Democratic tax plan mentions parts of President Joe Biden’s proposed budget, but stretches the impact of a higher tax on wealthy individuals. The Republican plan appears to reference part of the agenda put forth by Sen. Rick Scott, R-Fla., in February. Scott did not set an exact tax rate when he proposed extending income tax to all Americans, and not all of his fellow Republicans have embraced his plan.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "JUST IN: The Vatican has invited Chelsea Clinton, Dr. Fauci, New Age figure Deepak Chopra and the CEOs of Moderna and Pfizer to speak at a May conference focusing on 'health' and the 'soul.'"
Justification: •This is not breaking news. The conference was held in May 2021 after being postponed a year due to the COVID-19 pandemic.•It featured religious leaders, doctors, scientists, ethicists, policymakers and high-profile people, including entertainers and athletes, and focused on COVID-19 and other global health threats.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A baby’s immune system can’t handle antigens from vaccines, because new food must be introduced slowly to identify allergic reactions.
Justification: Vaccines given to babies do not overload the immune system, according to the CDC. Babies encounter more antigens in their daily environments than those they receive through vaccines. Food contains larger amounts of allergens, which is why the CDC recommends introducing new foods slowly.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Space Foundation has erased the honors previously bestowed on Yuri Gagarin, the first man to ever be in space. His name was stripped ‘in light of current events.’”
Justification: The Space Foundation removed Yuri Gagarin’s name from an upcoming fundraising event after it received derogatory and anti-Russia comments on its social media accounts. The organization did not revoke any formal honors from the cosmonaut. Exhibits related to Gagarin are still on display at the foundation’s gallery in Colorado, and his accomplishments will still be celebrated at the annual event, the group said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The United Nations sent out an email instructing staff not to use the words “invasion” or “war’” when referring to Ukraine.
Justification: An email was sent on March 7 instructing some U.N. staff members not to use the words "war" or "invasion" when discussing the conflict between Russia and Ukraine. The message came from a regional office without clearance and is not considered official U.N. policy, organization officials told PolitiFact. U.N. leaders including Secretary General António Guterres and Rosemary DiCarlo, the organization’s under-secretary-general for political and peacebuilding affairs, used the words in tweets before and after the email was sent.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hunter Biden has been arrested!”
Justification: This information is unfounded. Hunter Biden wasn’t arrested, and the source a Facebook post attributes died in 1999.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In 1975, then-U.S. Sen. Joe Biden opposed efforts by President Gerald Ford to aid South Vietnam and evacuate refugees.
Justification: This claim lacks important context about Joe Biden’s stance on the Vietnam War when he was a senator. Biden’s priority was evacuating U.S. citizens and Vietnamese refugees. Biden expressed concerns that providing military aid to the South Vietnam government could escalate the already tense situation in Vietnam. After Saigon fell to the North Vietnamese military, Biden supported a resolution welcoming Vietnamese refugees to the U.S.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Amy Coney Barrett overturned a $6.7M verdict after a prison guard repeatedly raped a 19-year-old inmate who was 8 months pregnant.”
Justification: Barrett, who was one of a three-judge panel, was not ruling on the $6.7 million jury award itself, but rather whether a Wisconsin county was liable to pay the damages. The judges ruled in favor of the county because they found that the guard’s actions were outside of his job duties and training. In a similar case, Barrett ruled with the majority that a different Wisconsin county was responsible for damages for failure to supervise and train a guard who was convicted of sexually assaulting inmates.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Putin beheaded bioweapon engineers in Ukraine.
Justification: There is no evidence Putin beheaded 12 bioweapon engineers in Ukraine. This claim comes from Real Raw News, a blog that has shown a pattern of fabricating news about politicians being executed or arrested by the military. Though the story claims Putin told former President Donald Trump about the alleged beheading, a spokesperson for Trump said the account is baseless.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Foo Fighters drummer Taylor Hawkins died from a COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: The cause of death for Foo Fighters drummer Taylor Hawkins is not yet known. Rumors that he died from a COVID-19 vaccine are unfounded.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A man was arrested “for wearing a T-shirt that says ‘We The People’ and has a picture of the ‘Statue of Liberty.’”
Justification: A man was removed from a meeting in handcuffs after refusing to comply with a Utah Senate committee’s decorum rules; the rules required that he remove a sticker supporting a bill under consideration. He wasn’t arrested because his T-shirt said "We The People."
Sources: SENATE REVENUE AND TAXATION STANDING COMMITTEE

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Germany imposes a 19% tax on feminine hygiene products but a 7% tax on books, so one company is packaging tampons as books.
Justification: •Effective Jan. 1, 2020, Germany reduced its tax rate from 19% to 7% on female sanitary products.•The "Tampon Book" was a 2019 protest against Germany’s previously higher tax on female sanitary products.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Alopecia isn't a medical disease; it's an aesthetic one."
Justification: •The term alopecia broadly refers to hair loss from any cause, including normal aging.•Some types of alopecia, such as alopecia areata, are an autoimmune disease, a type of illness that occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks part of the body, according to the American Academy of Dermatology Association.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden didn’t sign an antilynching bill in a ceremony outside the White House on March 29.
Justification: News reports, video recordings and photos from media organizations corroborate White House photos that show President Joe Biden signing an antilynching bill and speaking to a seated audience in the Rose Garden.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows "NATO resupplying Ukrainian farmers anti-tank supplies."
Justification: A viral photo of a helicopter airlifting a tractor predates Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine. An Indian tractor manufacturer posted it on Twitter in November 2020. The helicopter in the photo is labeled "Indian Air Force." India is not a member of NATO.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The former Miss Universe-Ukraine, Anastasiia Lenna, turned in her high heels for some combat boots to fight for her country.”
Justification: The viral photograph shows Anastasiia Lenna, the 2015 Miss Grand Ukraine winner, posing with an airsoft gun. She confirmed that she did not join the Ukrainian military and said she posted the staged image to inspire people.
Sources: Times of India Fact Check: No

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show “Ukrainian farmers are slowly starting to build their own army.”
Justification: These images of Ukrainian farmers seizing Russian military equipment with tractors have not been verified, and several of them were digitally altered using photos that predate the 2022 conflict.
Sources: Reverse image searches on Google and TinEye

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: CDC Director Dr. Rochelle Walensky said she gets COVID-19 reports from CNN.
Justification: In November 2020, CNN reported that the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine was 95% effective at preventing COVID-19. At that time in 2020, Dr. Rochelle Walensky was a professor at Harvard Medical School and head of the infectious diseases division at Massachusetts General Hospital. In a March 3, 2022 interview, Walensky referenced the CNN report she heard in 2020, before she became CDC director.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows “massive explosion as Ukraine destroyed 280 Russian tanks to pieces using U.S. Javelin missiles."
Justification: •Footage in the video has been repurposed from other sources — including the U.S. National Guard — and is not from Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Comparing the price of oil and gas in June 2008 to March 2022 shows that oil companies are “price gouging.”
Justification: Experts who study the price of oil and gas said it can take weeks for gasoline prices to respond to changes in crude oil costs. In 2008, an economic recession caused a supply shortage that drove up oil and gas prices. Currently, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, increased labor costs, the pandemic and additional taxes and inflation have all contributed to rising gasoline prices. The same factors weren’t at play in 2008, making direct comparisons misleading.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Ukrainian civilian fleeing Kyiv captures footage of downed Russian tie fighter."
Justification: •The footage is from a 2014 short video by a German TV network, and the aircraft is a TIE fighter from Star Wars.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Two years ago we were “drilling our own oil for $27 a barrel.” Now, thanks to Joe Biden, we’re “paying $105 a barrel to Russia.”
Justification: The U.S. was selling its oil for about $27 per barrel — not  drilling for that price, energy experts said. And, due to the pandemic, it was losing money in the process. Energy analysts said that the notion that the U.S. has been paying $105 per barrel for Russian oil probably isn’t too far off, though it’s hard to pinpoint. In general, prices were going up throughout January and February, so the U.S. was paying more for all oil imports, not just those from Russia. The current, higher prices are largely attributable to Russia’s war in Ukraine and to a sluggish response to energy demands after the pandemic slowdown.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Oprah reveals her fully-natural solution that allowed her to drop 62 (pounds) in six weeks.”
Justification: •Oprah Winfrey has not endorsed a diet pill.•The claim is "completely false," a spokesperson for Winfrey said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. imports 1% of its oil from Russia while “Exxon, Chevron, BP and Shell profits are at their highest level in over 7 years.”
Justification: U.S. gas prices, which were already on the rise following pandemic-related changes in supply and demand, hit a new price per gallon high March 8 that hasn’t been seen since July 2008. The price increase was partly attributed to the invasion of Ukraine as Western countries imposed economic sanctions on Russia for its aggression. Several major oil companies — Exxon, Chevron, BP and Shell — reported record-breaking profits before the invasion.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A West Virginia inspection sticker on an Uber” proves the car was not in Ukraine.
Justification: A West Virginia State Police captain confirmed that the Uber’s window decal was an expired inspection sticker from the state. But that doesn’t mean that the car itself wasn’t in Ukraine. The video showing the car was recorded in Irpin, Ukraine, according to Reuters, which owns the video. It's not uncommon for cars to be exported from the U.S. to other countries, including Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Gas is high because they shut down production in the U.S.” under the Biden administration.
Justification: Gas prices soared to an average $4.173 per gallon on March 8, according to AAA, breaking a 2008 record. Oil production in the U.S. in President Joe Biden’s first year was on par with 2020 and higher than in two of the four years Trump was president. Increased consumer demand, inflation and the war in Ukraine are among the factors in the rising price at the pump, experts say.
Sources: Email exchange with Patrick De Haan

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "People who have had cancer in the past, they get the COVID jab and now, they're getting cancer two to three, four months later and it's the same cancer they had except much worse."
Justification: •There is no data to suggest that COVID-19 vaccines lead to cancer recurrence.•Because cancer is a common disease, and hundreds of millions of people have been vaccinated against COVID-19, some people will have cancer recurrence around the time of their vaccination. It does not mean the vaccine caused the cancer, experts say.
Sources: Idaho Department of Health & Welfare DHW Voice

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A recent on-air protest can’t be real because "there are no live on air television broadcasts in Russia. None. Ever.”
Justification: An employee at state-owned Channel One in Russia recently interrupted a live news broadcast to protest the war in Ukraine. Multiple experts say there are live news broadcasts and other live events on Russian TV. A former employee of the station said that all Channel One news is live. An expert we spoke with said that’s because of the country’s many time zones.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Ukraine issued a press release about Joe Biden
Justification: •The press conference was held in May 2020 and featured a Ukrainian lawmaker, Andrii Derkach, who is described by U.S. officials as an active Russian agent.•Recordings of President Joe Biden that Derkach released corroborate Biden’s description of his dealings in Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Biden "wants to buy lithium from China for electric cars."
Justification: The U.S. currently buys lithium from China but the White House isn’t trying to buy more; it’s trying to buy less. President Joe Biden recently announced that his administration is giving $35 million to MP Materials, an American mining company, to expand a rare earths project in California and plans to extract lithium from around the state’s Salton Sea. The efforts are aimed to make the U.S. less dependent on foreign products amid supply chain disruptions by increasing domestic mining and processing of lithium and other materials.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Russian President Vladimir Putin meeting with South Korea’s president.
Justification: •The video shows a 2019 meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korea leader Kim Jong Un.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows current “leaked footage of heavy war between Russia vs Ukraine”
Justification: •The footage does not show the current invasion of Ukraine by Russia. It was taken from old videos of the Ukrainian military.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Deceased Ukrainian fighter pilot Col. Oleksandr Oksanchenko was the “Ghost of Kyiv.”
Justification: Col. Oleksandr "Grey Wolf" Oksanchenko, a decorated Ukrainian pilot, was killed in combat on Feb. 25. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky awarded him posthumously with the title of Hero of Ukraine, along with 11 other military service members. Unconfirmed reports hold that an unidentified pilot, who has come to be called the "Ghost of Kyiv," downed six Russian planes on the first day of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. We do not find evidence that this was Oksanchenko.
Sources: Ministry Defence of Ukraine official website

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Just a reminder that right before Ukraine was invaded, Hillary was found to be guilty of spying on a sitting U.S. president.”
Justification: Clinton has not been indicted on any charges stemming from alleged spying on Trump. This claim is another dramatic oversimplification of a recent legal filing by Special Counsel John Durham.
Sources: U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Anthony Fauci has not spoken or appeared publicly for several weeks.
Justification: Claims that Dr. Anthony Fauci stopped appearing or speaking in public are wrong. He continues to regularly give interviews to national and local news outlets, and he’s appeared at White House press briefings concerning the coronavirus.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “In April 1997, there was a ‘gas out’ conducted nationwide in protest of gas prices. Gasoline prices dropped 30 cents a gallon overnight.”
Justification: There is no evidence a 1997 gasoline boycott reduced gas prices "30 cents a gallon overnight." Reducing demand via a gasoline boycott could decrease gas prices, but avoiding buying gas on one day to participate in a "gas out" will likely have a limited impact, experts said. The idea of a "gas out" has been promoted in chain emails and social media posts for decades.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Leonardo DiCaprio gave Ukraine $10 million.
Justification: Leonardo DiCaprio didn’t donate $10 million to Ukraine, but blogs reported otherwise.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Putin Vows to ‘Crush’ Child Traffickers in Ukraine”
Justification: • This claim originated in an article published by a website known for sharing misinformation, including one previous false claim on Ukraine.• Russia’s president stated many reasons for the invasion. Ending child trafficking was not among them.• According to the U.S. State Department, Russia is failing to deal with human trafficking within its own borders.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “And just like that, your $15/hr doesn’t buy you as much as $7.50/hr did a year ago.”
Justification: Over the last year, consumer prices rose 7.5%, outpacing the average employer pay raise of 5.7%. But this claim exaggerates the impact inflation has had on wages. A person who earned $7.50 an hour in 2021 would need to earn $8.06 in 2022 to have the same buying power. The claim wrongly suggests a person would need to earn more than $15 an hour to have the same buying power.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Facebook video shows “counting Biden’s votes at 2 a.m.”
Justification: While some election offices in 2020 continued to process and count ballots overnight after the polls closed, that is a sign of a routine process and not fraud. The Facebook user who shared the video said it was a joke.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Ukraine has been shooting residents of Donetsk and Lugansk just because they wanted to speak Russian.”
Justification: Russia has leaned on claims that Ukraine has killed Russian speakers in the country and that Russians are the targets of genocide there, but there’s no evidence to support that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The word "alcohol" derives from the Arabic term for "body-eating spirit"
Justification: The English word "alcohol" has Arabic roots that can be traced back to the word "al-kuhl," which refers to the cosmetic kohl. PolitiFact and other fact-checking organizations found no connection between the origins of the word "alcohol" and a body-eating spirit.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An image shows “Ukrainian soldiers praying.”
Justification: •The photo dates to at least 2017. When posted on Facebook at that time, its caption said it showed U.S. soldiers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Wladimir Klitschko has auctioned off his 1996 Atlanta Olympic Games gold medal to raise money for the children of Ukraine.”
Justification: In 2012, Ukrainian former professional boxer Wladimir Klitschko auctioned off the Olympic gold medal he won in 1996, raising $1 million for Ukrainian children. In March 2022, Facebook users circulated a post that recounted Klitschko’s gesture without specifying that it took place over a decade earlier. The post left the misleading impression that Klitschko sold the medal amid Russia’s ongoing invasion of Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show “Ukrainian Christians pray outdoors, in the snow, for their country in this phase of war danger.”
Justification: • The photos do show Ukrainians in prayer, but the images are actually years old. One picture was first shared online in 2015, the other in 2019.
Sources: Email exchange with Marc Ira Hooks
Email exchange with the press office of the International Mission Board. Feb. 22

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “NEW: Biden Admin. instructs Americans to social distance and wear masks in the event of a Nuclear Fallout.”
Justification: The website Ready.gov provides information on preparing for, responding to and mitigating emergencies. One page on the site provides safety guidelines, including social distancing and mask wearing, in the event of a nuclear explosion. The Federal Emergency Management Agency said the language is not "new," nor is it related to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The language on distancing and masking was added during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “News report accidentally reveals doctors giving ‘banned’ COVID treatment to the Queen.”
Justification: An image of a drug containing ivermectin was included in a news report about Queen Elizabeth II’s COVID-19 diagnosis "as a result of human error," according to the Australian network that broadcast the news report. The network issued a statement saying it did not intend to suggest a doctor had endorsed the ivermectin drug or that the queen was taking ivermectin. The anti-parasitic ivermectin is not approved in Australia to treat COVID-19, nor in the United Kingdom, where the queen lives. It’s also not approved in the U.S. as a COVID-19 treatment.
Sources: Email exchange with Dr. Mukesh Haikerwal

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky “has joined the front lines with his troops.”
Justification: •Aphoto of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky dressed in military fatigues is from 2021.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Thomas Jefferson said, “If serving in an elected office ever becomes a career, corruption will surely follow.”
Justification: In a letter to James Madison, Thomas Jefferson expressed concern over the failure of "rotation in office." A Monticello historian said that concern was likely in reference to the presidency. We found no record of Jefferson saying, "If serving in an elected office ever becomes a career, corruption will surely follow."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Ukrainian soldiers saying goodbye to loved ones amid Russia’s 2022 invasion.
Justification: The scene in the clip is not a legitimate depiction of Ukrainian soldiers leaving loved ones to fight Russia in 2022. It’s from a 2017 Ukrainian documentary film.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Ukrainian TikToker shows how to drive an abandoned Russian armored vehicle.
Justification: The clip does not show a Ukrainian woman teaching people how to drive an abandoned Russian armored carrier amid the war. The TikToker is a Russian auto-blogger named Nastya Tuman and the video is from February 2021.
Sources: Email exchange with Irina Kulemzina and Marina Yurieva

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show Ukrainian citizens destroying two Russian tanks with Molotov cocktails in Kyiv.
Justification: Four photos showing scenes of fire, billowing smoke and people engaged in a fight date back to 2014 anti-government protests in Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Luc Montagnier's death is linked to his "exposing" that there's HIV in the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: The COVID-19 vaccines don’t cause AIDS. We found no evidence that Luc Montagnier said they did, or that he was killed for saying so.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Ukrainian fighter-ace known as the 'Ghost of Kyiv's real name is Samuyil Hyde.”
Justification: Sam Hyde is a comedian whose name has been used as an online meme since 2015, linked to tragic events throughout the world. There is no evidence that the mysterious "Ghost of Kyiv" pilot in Ukraine actually exists. If the pilot does exist, it’s not Samuyil Hyde.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says CNN reported Queen Elizabeth II died.
Justification: Misinformation has circulated online since Buckingham Palace announced on Feb. 20 that Queen Elizabeth II has COVID-19. Claims that CNN reported she died are false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "An 8-year-old Ukrainian girl confronts a Russian soldier telling him to go back to his country.”
Justification: •The photo was taken in 2012 in the West Bank, when a Palestinian child confronted an Israeli soldier.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Bill Gates hatches 'horribly stupid' plan to block out the sun"
Justification: •Harvard researchers proposed a small-scale experiment that would spray aerosols into the atmosphere to reflect some sunlight back into space, a technology aimed at minimizing global warming. The experiment would measure the risks and effectiveness of the technology.•The experiment is funded in part through Harvard’s Solar Geoengineering Research Program, and Bill Gates is among the donors to that program.•The claim first surfaced in 2021 and has been previously debunked.
Sources: Philosophical Transactions of The Royal Society

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: This photo shows "headache treatments in 1890s known as vibration therapy."
Justification: •Vibration therapy was a real headache treatment in the 1800s, but academic literature says it was vastly different from what is depicted in this photo.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A 2022 CNN report said, “Russia deploys two nuke bombers in US backyard, Venezuela.”
Justification: A CNN segment about "Putin making military moves in America’s backyard" is spreading on social media. The segment ran in 2018, not during Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: This "footage" shows Russia attacking Ukraine.
Justification: Two videos circulating on social media that claim to show heavy fire and missiles being launched in Ukraine are not legitimate. They are simulations from video games.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo of a wounded young child was captured in Ukraine in 2022.
Justification: A 2018 photo showing a wounded child in Syria is circulating as the Russian invasion of Ukraine wages on. The photo does not depict a child injured during the current conflict.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Ukrainians altered this street sign to tell Russian troops to go “f---” themselves.
Justification: An image of a Ukrainian road sign pointing in three different directions and telling Russian troops to "go f—" themselves isn’t genuine. The lettering was digitally altered. Ukrainian officials shared the image to encourage residents to help dismantle and obscure street signs to confuse Russian troops.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The war in Ukraine is “scripted and staged.”
Justification: News reports, testimonies of citizens-turned-fighters, and a swift global response all fly in the face of baseless claims that Russia’s war on Ukraine is "staged."
Sources: C-SPAN State of the Union Address
PolitiFact Lie of the Year: Coronavirus downplay and denial
United Nations Human Rights Office of the High Commissioner

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The IRS is taking money away from people who received unemployment benefits.
Justification: Receiving unemployment benefits does not mean that a federal income tax refund will be reduced. A tax refund, which occurs when a tax filer overpays their federal income taxes, can be reduced to pay off money owed to the government. Federal tax refunds can be reduced up to 100% to pay unpaid state income taxes and child support.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "It was revealed in court” on Feb. 23, 2022 “that Tory Lanez DNA WAS NOT found on the weapon in the Meg Thee Stallion case."
Justification: •Reporters who cover the court proceedings said no such claim was made.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hillary is taken to Gitmo.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded and there’s no evidence to support it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows man diving off a high bridge and into a swimming pool on a moving boat.
Justification: •The video used special effects. The man, who is a professional extreme sports athlete, dove into a river, not a pool.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Only 16% Of Canadians Would SUPPORT Trudeau After Trucker Protest!”
Justification: A recent public opinion poll found that a majority of respondents didn’t think Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s handling of the trucker protest made them want to vote for him. But the poll didn’t ask whether they would support him or not.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Sean Penn’s trip to Ukraine in November is evidence the war is staged.
Justification: Reports that Sean Penn had been working on a documentary on the conflict in Ukraine as early as November is not evidence that the February invasion was staged. Armed conflict along the Ukraine-Russia border first erupted in 2014.
Sources: Office of the President of Ukraine Facebook post

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Russia unveiled a nuclear weapon, "Satan 2," that is "capable of destroying everything breathing in the world."
Justification: •Russian state media says the missile can destroy anarea the size of Texas or France, not the world. We could not find more objective reports detailing the same destructive power.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Ottawa may euthanize truckers’ pets as punishment.”
Justification: Ottawa By-law & Regulatory Services in a tweet told protesters that animals brought to demonstrations may be taken into protective custody if their owners are jailed. Pet owners would have eight days to make arrangements to retrieve their animals. The Ottawa Humane Society, where the animals would be taken, says it "keeps every adoptable animal until the right home is found, regardless of length of stay." Euthanasia is only considered  if the animal is "suffering severely or incurably" or considered too dangerous to adopt out.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Donald Trump refusing to shake hands with Justin Trudeau.
Justification: •Video and still photos from the 2018 meeting show that then-President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau shook hands.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The United States buys "206,000 barrels of oil a day" from Russia but "shut down domestic oil production a year ago."
Justification: The U.S. imports oil from about 80 countries. The federal government never ended domestic oil production in the U.S.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a Ukrainian fighter pilot shooting down a Russian plane.
Justification: A Ukrainian pilot nicknamed the "Ghost of Kyiv" is rumored to have shot down several Russian aircraft. It is unclear if such a pilot exists. A 22-second video that social media users suggested might show the "Ghost of Kyiv" shooting down a Russian plane is a simulation that was created in a video game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The second booster has eight strains of HIV.”
Justification: •The ingredients of COVID-19 vaccines are published and do not include HIV.•The vaccine ingredients do not change between doses.Each shot in the mRNA COVID-19 vaccine series, including the booster, has the same ingredients.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Girl Scouts support "Planned Parenthood and pro-abortion politicians."
Justification: •Girl Scouts of the USA has no relationship or partnership with Planned Parenthood, and has not endorsed any person or organization.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “MSNBC announced Trump won 2020 election.”
Justification: An MSNBC clip was mischaracterized as evidence that the network announced Donald Trump won the 2020 election. A guest who was a former Trump aide made the claim, and the show’s host called it false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Comedian Heather McDonald collapsed on stage as a result of the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: Heather McDonald’s husband said that there’s no medical connection between her fall and the shot.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Biden and most Democrats want to cap insulin prices at $35 per month. All 50 Republicans in the Senate are opposed to it.”
Justification: A proposal by Democrats would have limited cost-sharing for insulin to $35 monthly for insured patients with diabetes. It was one part of President Joe Biden’s much-larger Build Back Better plan, which Republicans were united in opposition against. Several Republican senators have supported legislation in the past to address the high cost of insulin, and at least one – Sen. John Kennedy of Louisiana – has proposed price caps.
Sources: Sen. Susan Collins " Senator Collins Applauds CMS Announcement That Will Cap Medicare Beneficiaries’ Insulin Co-Pay at $35 Per Month

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "According to Congress, travel nurses need a pay cap.”
Justification: There has been no legislation proposed in Congress to cap pay for traveling nurses. A letter signed by nearly 200 legislators called for an investigation into high pricing by staffing agencies, but its authors insist they do not want to cap wages for traveling nurses. Some states are considering capping how much staffing agencies can charge healthcare facilities. This could lead to lower salaries for traveling nurses, one expert said.
Sources: Massachusetts Executive Office of Health and Human Services
Statement from ​​the American Health Care Association/National Center for Assisted Living

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trudeau declares Emergencies Act amounting to near martial law in Canada.”
Justification: •Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he will not call in the military as part of the Emergencies Act.•The Emergencies Act gives banks the right to temporarily freeze accounts being used to support protesters’ blockades without obtaining a court order.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows "This is happening right now...in Australia!! 1.5 Million showed up for a Freedom March/Rally."
Justification: •The aerial photo was taken at the Woodstock Music and Art Fair in 1969.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Turkey, Brazil, Britain, Sweden, Spain, Czech Republic, Mexico, El Salvador, Japan and Singapore canceled all COVID-19 quarantine procedures, testing and compulsory vaccination and are considering COVID-19 “just a seasonal flu.”
Justification: •Turkey, Brazil, Britain, Sweden, Spain, Czech Republic, Mexico, El Salvador, Japan and Singapore each continue to have quarantine and COVID-19 testing protocols.• None of the countries ever had compulsory COVID-19 vaccination for their entire adult population. Some require COVID-19 vaccination for certain workers.•Some European leaders have said COVID-19 should be treated as endemic, similar to influenza, but the World Health Organization says that’s premature. COVID-19 appears to have a higher infection fatality rate than influenza.
Sources: U.S. Embassy and Consulates in Brazil
U.S. Embassy and Consulates in Japan
U.S. Embassy and Consulates in Mexico

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Got the old killdozer loaded up heading for Ottawa.”
Justification: •The armored bulldozer known as "Killdozer," was dismantled in 2005.•It was piloted by a disgruntled Granby, Colorado, resident who caused $7 million worth of damage in the town in 2004.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says C.S. Lewis wrote, “They believed blindly everything they heard or read in the papers. They gave up their freedoms.”
Justification: Several versions of this passage about luring souls to hell have been attributed to C.S. Lewis but he didn’t write them.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden wants to eliminate a regulation that requires school districts to report allegations of teacher on student rape, alleged rape, and sexual assault.”
Justification: •The U.S. Department of Education’s Office for Civil Rights withdrew a proposal that would have stopped the collection of some data about sexual misconduct by school staff.• The proposal would not have affected the reporting of alleged misconduct to school or law enforcement authorities.•Under a new proposal, the data will continue to be collected.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A molecule found in a Himalayan fungus "kills cancer cells with 40 times potency."
Justification: A fungus called Ophiocordyceps sinensis, also known as caterpillar fungus, is found in the Himalayas and often used in traditional medicine to treat illnesses like cancer. Researchers in the United Kingdom are developing a chemotherapy drug derived from an antiviral compound found in the fungus. The drug is currently in the early stages of human testing, but laboratory tests have shown it has the ability to kill cancer cells.
Sources: Email with the National Cancer Institute

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President John F. Kennedy “was planning to end the Federal Reserve.”
Justification: Experts who have studied economics and President John F. Kennedy’s policies said there was no evidence he was planning to end the Federal Reserve. An executive order that has been cited as support for this theory in the past did not limit the power of the Federal Reserve.
Sources: Congressional Research Report Library of Congress

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “President Biden's Air Force One pilot got fired after this vertical take off.”
Justification: •The footage is from a video game and does not depict actual events.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The CDC was “normalizing blood clots” by tweeting about the health condition before the Super Bowl.
Justification: Well before COVID-19 existed, the CDC had tweeted out warnings about blood clots. Blood clots are common, affecting about 900,000 Americans each year, and can be deadly. There is not an increased risk of blood clots from the Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines. Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine, the only other COVID-19 vaccine used in the U.S., has been linked to rare cases of thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS).
Sources: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A grand jury trial begins into crimes against humanity" involving a fabricated coronavirus pandemic.
Justification: •The video is a simulation that does not depict actual legal proceedings.•The notion that the coronavirus pandemic is fabricated is part of an effort to deny or downplay the virus and is unsubstantiated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: COVID spelled backward is “divoc” which means "possession of the evil spirit" in Hebrew.
Justification: "Divoc" is not a Hebrew word. The closest existing word in the language is "dibbuk," which means evil possession, but the two are not the same, linguistic experts said. COVID-19 is an abbreviation of "coronavirus disease 2019." "CO" stands for "corona," "VI" stands for "virus" and "D" stands for "disease." The number 19 reflects the year it was identified — 2019.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Fifty percent of the Ottawa police force have all turned in their resignation.”
Justification: No one has resigned because of the demonstrations, according to the police department and police union.
Sources: Email interview with Constable Paramjit Singh

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Queen Elizabeth II is dead.
Justification: News of Queen Elizabeth II’s death is a perennial hoax that may fool more people the older she gets. But make no mistake: Buckingham Palace announced on Feb. 20 that she tested positive for COVID-19 — not that she died.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a Washington Post headline and graphic about COVID-19 deaths are misleading.
Justification: Data shows deaths from COVID-19 have spiked to their highest numbers in a year due to the highly transmissible omicron variant. Unvaccinated Americans and people over age 75 have been particularly hit hard by the variant, according to the Post. The Washington Post graphic is not in conflict with the headline.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Bob Saget predicted his death
Justification: Actor and comedian Bob Saget was found dead in his Florida hotel room in January. Medical examiners concluded that Saget died of accidental head trauma. Social media users circulated a video that suggested Saget predicted his death. Saget’s so-called prediction was actually just a joke about the fact that his wife Kelly Rizzo’s favorite movies are mostly crime dramas.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Johns Hopkins University confirms: You can be vaccinated with a PCR test, even without knowing”
Justification: Johns Hopkins researchers developed microdevices known as "theragrippers" that were designed to "latch onto intestinal mucosa and release drugs into the body" over an extended period of time. But they are not being used for vaccine delivery, a spokesperson said. The devices have been tested in rats, but are not approved for use in humans.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “CNN confirms Trump WILL be ARRESTED.”
Justification: A guest on a CNN show said he thinks former President Donald Trump will be indicted. The network did not report that Trump will be arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Grocery chain Aldi will send people who share a Facebook post a “bag full of family necessities” worth $750, and 100 random bags also have a voucher for $500.
Justification: The grocery store chain Aldi is not delivering bags of free food to customers who share a Facebook post. The message came from an account based in Indonesia, where Aldi has no presence. Any announcements from the company will come from its verified social media accounts, according to an Aldi official.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Ivanka Trump charged with major crime.”
Justification: Neither Ivanka Trump, nor her brothers, are facing any criminal charges. The Trump Organization was reinstated on Feb. 14 as a defendant in a civil lawsuit brought by Washington, D.C.’s attorney general. That lawsuit alleges that Trump’s inaugural committee misspent nonprofit money at the Trump International Hotel in D.C. to benefit the Trump organization.
Sources: Office of the Attorney General for the District of Columbia
The Superior Court of the District of Columbia

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Requesting a chargeback is “a better way to get back at” GoFundMe.
Justification: GoFundMe took down the "Freedom Convoy 2022" fundraiser page, saying it violated a policy against promoting violence and harassment, and said it would refund those who donated. Social media users encouraged people to dispute the donation charges on their credit cards, suggesting it would force GoFundMe to pay chargeback fees for each transaction. An expert said it is unlikely banks would allow customers to pursue chargebacks after a company has announced it will issue refunds.
Sources: Email interview with Chargebacks911 Chief Operating Officer

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Crisis actor in Germany forgets he’s filming on TV.”
Justification: A video that some social media users claim shows a crisis actor in Germany was actually filmed in Austria, and it shows protesters demonstrating against climate policies.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says that President Joe Biden said Americans will start seeing “direct deposits in their bank accounts this weekend,” and that Medicare recipients will get back $2,880.
Justification: A video of Biden talking about a new round of stimulus payment is faked, taking clips from unrelated events and featuring an imitator mimicking the president’s voice. The video repurposes comments made by White House press secretary Jen Psaki on March 11 regarding the American Rescue Plan Act. The federal government has made no announcement about Medicare recipients getting $2,880.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The federal government requires “COVID passports to visit the movies.”
Justification: While some cities and states have required proof of vaccination to access certain establishments, like movie theaters, the federal government has not mandated such credentials.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pennsylvania had 2.6 million mail in votes that the court of appeals of PA held to be unconstitutional. Umm that alone means Biden lost PA.”
Justification: In 2019, the GOP-led Pennsylvania General Assembly passed Act 77, which included no-excuse mail voting. After Trump lost the Nov. 3 election, Republicans filed a case arguing that the mail-in ballot provisions were illegal. The state Supreme Court dismissed the petition as untimely. A Pennsylvania court ruled Jan. 28, 2022, that Act 77 was unconstitutional and that establishing no-excuse mail voting would require a constitutional amendment. The ruling, which is being appealed, doesn’t change the fact that Biden won Pennsylvania.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Texas Roadhouse is sending vouchers for a free steak dinner for four to everyone who shares and comments on a Facebook post.
Justification: Texas Roadhouse is not giving out free vouchers for a free steak dinner for four. The post is from an unverified account on Facebook masquerading as the Texas Roadhouse account.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows a patient experiencing claustrophobia and having a panic attack during a CT scan.
Justification: The radiographer who shared the image was doing so to explain how hoaxes are created on the internet and said it showed a patient waking up to movement and simply raising his head.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden gave Congress an exemption from vaccine mandate
Justification: President Biden’s executive order mandating COVID-19 vaccines for federal workers applies only to those in the executive branch of government. Congress is in the legislative branch, one of three separate but equal branches. "Another way to think about it is that members of Congress work directly for the people, not for President Biden," a law expert told PolitiFact.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Large, peer-reviewed research study proves ivermectin works” as a COVID-19 preventative.
Justification: Experts we spoke with point out serious flaws in the study’s methodology and conclusions. Health officials in Itajaí said that most residents they initially distributed the drug to did not take all five doses as recommended. The FDA and World Health Organization still do not recommend the use of ivermectin in treating or preventing COVID-19 outside of clinical trials. One of the study’s authors said ivermectin seemed to work  at preventing COVID-19, but he never said it was "proven."
Sources: Email from World Health Organization spokesperson
Email interview with Dr. Flavio Cadegiani
Email interview with Dr. Nikolas Wada
The Municipal Health Department of Itajaí

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Few, If Any, Doses of Spikevax or Comirnaty Available in United States, Despite FDA Approvals”
Justification: •Spikevax and Comirnaty are brand names for the Moderna and Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines, respectively. The drug formulation is the same for the branded and non-branded vaccines.•The non-branded vaccines are widely available in the U.S., and Comirnaty also is available in the U.S.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Omicron is “the fastest-spreading virus known to humankind."
Justification: • When measuring the speed of global spread, the omicron variant of SARS-CoV-2 is the fastest in history, experts say.• When measuring the speed of transmission between individuals, measles is the most contagious virus, according to theCenters for Disease Control and Prevention. Each person who contracts it can infect 12 to 18 other people, in a population not protected by vaccines and other preventative measures.• But omicron is not far behind on that measure, either, coming in at a close second. Each person who contracts the omicron variant of COVID-19 can infect 7 to 14 people in an unvaccinated, unprotected population.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says 700 CIA agents were arrested.
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Moderna COVID vaccine is no longer recommended due to heart inflammation.”
Justification: •The Moderna COVID-19 vaccine has not been discredited. A new recommendation about the vaccine applies only to those under the age of 31 in one European country, Belgium.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "British data show the COVID shots are an abysmal failure, as COVID infection rates in the U.K. are higher among the ‘fully vaccinated’ in all adult cohorts.”
Justification: •The data cited is only from England, not all of the United Kingdom.•The data shows the rate of hospitalization and death is "substantially greater" in unvaccinated people compared with vaccinated people, according to the U.K. Health Security Agency.• In England, the rate of a positive COVID-19 test is higher in vaccinated people aged 30 and older, compared with unvaccinated people. However, that is expected in a country with very high vaccine coverage.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donald Trump “never left” the White House.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump lost the 2020 election and left the White House on Jan. 20, 2021. Joe Biden is president.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Binding masks to your face with gauze and wrapping pantyhose around your face and mask are now “suggestions to make your mask more ‘effective.’”
Justification: Vice wrote about research that assessed the effectiveness of popular "hacks" meant to improve the fit of KN95 and surgical masks. The researchers evaluated seven different "fit hacks," some of which involved rubber bands, tape and pantyhose. The study concluded that while some hacks improved the effectiveness of the masks, they were "very uncomfortable and unlikely to be tolerated for extended periods of time."
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Since 2000, the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy have been spraying the entire United States sky with the toxic brew of chemicals and other biologic agents."
Justification: • So-called "chemtrails" are not real, according to atmospheric chemists and geochemists.• The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency says it is not aware of any deliberate release of chemicals or biological agents into the atmosphere, and the U.S. Air Force says the theory is a hoax.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden announces Medicare stimulus that provides free dental work to all Seniors who need it! Crowns and implants included.”
Justification: • President Joe Biden did not announce a Medicare stimulus for dental work, and video footage of him included in the post is from June 2020, before he was elected president.• The traditional Medicare insurance program does not cover most dental care or procedures.• Some private insurance companies sell certain Medicare plans that are allowed to offer coverage for dental work. The plans must be purchased and coverage varies. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Dyson is canceling their contract with Walmart and selling off Dyson Supersonic” hair dryers “only for $1!”
Justification: Walmart isn’t selling the Dyson Supersonic hair dryer for $1. The post is from an unverified account on Facebook masquerading as a Walmart account.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Vaccine makers “are shipping lots of jabs with varying ingredients, potency & EVEN placebo lots.”
Justification: • The claim was originally made by a German conspiracy theorist who has repeatedly shared false information about COVID-19.• The FDA told PolitiFact that those claims are false and Pfizer told PolitiFact that it does not ship COVID-19 vaccines with varying ingredients or potency.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Johns Hopkins virologist "James Kelly" said the COVID-19 vaccine “discriminates, divides, and judges society as it is.”
Justification: According to Johns Hopkins Medicine, there are no virologists named James Kelly at the hospital even though an anti-COVID-19 vaccine statement has been attributed to him. We found no evidence that any Johns Hopkins doctor said this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hundreds of ‘illegals’ were dropped off at Florida hotel.
Justification: Workers shown in a video arriving at a Florida hotel are in the U.S. legally as part of the H-2A visa program. The program allows employers to bring foreign nationals in to fill temporary, seasonal agricultural jobs. Under H-2A guidelines, participating employers must show that there are not enough U.S. workers who are able and willing to fill the jobs and that hiring the workers won’t adversely affect wages or conditions for similar U.S. workers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: ‘The Simpsons’ predicted Canada’s trucker convoy protest.
Justification: The video combines clips from two separate episodes to make it seem like the TV show predicted the Canadian trucker convoy. The episodes, one showing Homer Simpson surrounded by a trucker convoy and the other showing Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau fleeing from his office, aired 20 years apart.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: American citizens “pay $155 billion annually to make sure illegal immigrants are taken care of better than American citizens”
Justification: Determining the exact cost of illegal immigration is complex, but reports estimate that immigrants in the country illegally cost less than $155 billion annually. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security estimated there were about 11.4 million immigrants illegally in the U.S. as of January 2018.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows a crash in Eminence, Indiana.
Justification: This photo was taken in Fort Worth, Texas, in 2021 after freezing rain coated the roads there and caused a deadly crash. It wasn’t taken in Eminence, Indiana, as a recent Facebook post claimed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: American taxpayer dollars provide “free housing, free medical, free state identification” to immigrants in the country illegally.
Justification: Most immigrants living illegally in the country are not eligible for benefits from federal programs. A valid Social Security number is needed to receive most federal benefits. Immigrants in the country illegally are not issued Social Security numbers. They may qualify for state and local public assistance programs. Some immigrants illegally in the country also pay taxes, and that helps cover the costs of assistance programs.
Sources: Email exchange with a spokesperson from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Email interview with a spokesperson from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Food and Nutrition Service
Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy
PolitiFact "Trump says 'time has come' for law restricting federal assistance to immigrants. It already exists
Research Institute on Social and Economic Policy
South Carolina Appleseed Legal Justice Center
The Center for Law and Social Policy
The National Conference of State Legislatures
Udall Center of Studies in Public Policy at the University of Arizona

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: $2,000 stimulus checks were due on Jan. 19.
Justification: There has been no federal legislation authorizing another round of economic stimulus checks. Some states are disbursing federal funds to individuals, but the eligibility for those funds varies.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In the U.S., myocarditis cases among ages 12 to 20 numbered four in 2019; four in 2020; and 2,236 in 2021.
Justification: •The risk of myocarditis, inflammation of the heart muscle, from COVID-19 vaccines is small and symptoms are normally mild. But contracting COVID-19 is "a strong and significant risk factor for myocarditis," especially among children under 16 years old, according to the CDC.•Professional medical groups and federal public health agencies have said the benefits of the COVID-19 vaccine far outweigh the risks.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Jen Psaki said in January 2022 that people will start seeing direct deposits in their bank account this weekend and payments to eligible Americans will continue for several weeks.
Justification: An old video of White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki talking about stimulus payments is from March 2021, but it’s being mischaracterized as a recent video and maybe fueling false hopes of more federal money for Americans.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “It begins. Wisconsin Assembly votes to remove electoral votes from Biden.”
Justification: Republican Rep. Timothy Ramthun, a denier of Joe Biden’s electoral victory, introduced a resolution on Jan. 25 seeking to recall Wisconsin’s 10 electoral votes, alleging they were fraudulently certified. The privileged resolution was referred to the Rules Committee, as required by Assembly rules. That committee’s chair called the resolution "illegal" and said he has no plans to advance it. Biden won Wisconsin by more than 20,000 votes, and there has been no evidence of fraud in the election that would have affected the outcome.
Sources: Republican Rep. and Assembly Majority Leader Jim Steineke’s tweet

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "If the FAA is worried about what the 5G deployment will do to the planes, what do you think it will do to our bodies?"
Justification: •The Federal Aviation Administration’s concern about 5G technology is that it could cause wireless interference with instruments onboard aircraft.•Current evidence does not support the claim that 5G technology is a health hazard.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: COVID-19-induced pneumonia is "is actually mast cell degranulation of the lungs," a type of allergic reaction.
Justification: Medical doctors disputed a Facebook claim that COVID-19 pneumonia is actually "mast cell degranulation of the lungs," or an allergic reaction. Symptoms of COVID-19-induced pneumonia include shortness of breath, increased heart rate and low blood pressure.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Meilan King Han
Phone Interview with Dr. Pranatharthi Chandrasekar
The American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “All communications to families from the US Navy have been halted.”
Justification: Evidence is lacking to prove that all communication between Navy service members and their families has been halted. A Navy spokesperson, Lt. Cmdr. Devin Arneson, said the Navy makes every effort to maintain open communication between sailors and their families.
Sources: Interview with Duty Officer of Defense Press Operations
Interview with U.S. Navy Spokesperson Lt. Commander Devin Arneson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A German doctor discovered the COVID-19 vaccines include graphene oxide or graphene hydroxide, and the full list of ingredients is secret because of the emergency use authorization.
Justification: •COVID-19 vaccines do not contain any form of graphene.•The vaccines are not experimental. They have undergone months of clinical testing; data shows they are both safe and effective; and they have been safely administered to hundreds of millions of Americans.•The full list of ingredients for all three vaccines approved for use in the U.S. — Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson — has been shared by manufacturers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The CDC director just said that 75% of ‘Covid deaths’ occurred in people with at least four comorbidities.”
Justification: In an interview on "Good Morning America," CDC director Rochelle Walensky referenced a study of vaccinated people that found that more than 75% of COVID-19 deaths in the group occurred in individuals who had at least four other illnesses or diseases, known as comorbidities. Wallensky cited the study as evidence that vaccines were effective. An edited clip of the interview omitted the context that the study involved only vaccinated people, leaving the false impression that the 75% statistic reflected all COVID-19 deaths and that the pandemic’s severity had been exaggerated.
Sources: US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Clarence Thomas’s wife was one of the organizers of Jan 6th"
Justification: Ginni Thomas expressed her support for "MAGA people" rallying in DC on the morning of Jan. 6, 2021. She later amended her Facebook posts to make clear they were written before the attack on the Capitol building. There’s no evidence Thomas had a role in organizing the rally. She has not been subpoenaed by the House select committee investigating the attack.
Sources: House select committee to investigate the January sixth attack on the U.S. Capitol
Select Committee to investigate the January sixth attack on the U.S. Capitol

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Washington’s State Board of Health will discuss mandatory COVID-19 quarantines and vaccine requirements for schoolchildren at a Jan. 12 meeting.
Justification: Washington’s State Board of Health is discussing proposed rule changes to its administrative code, but they are related to HIV language, not to quarantine or isolation policies. The proposed changes do not suggest that law enforcement be used to enforce COVID-19 vaccination. There is no vote scheduled on requiring COVID-19 vaccines for children to attend school. An advisory group assigned to make a recommendation on that subject is expected to give an update on its progress.
Sources: PolitiFact phone interview with Keith Grellner
Washington State Board of Health and Department of Health Technical Advisory Group

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There (are) over 800 prison camps in the United States, all fully operational and ready to receive prisoners. They are all staffed and even surrounded by full-time guards, but they are all empty. These camps are to be operated by FEMA.”
Justification: •A FEMA spokesperson said the claim is false.•There is no evidence to support the claim, and there are many reports that debunk false claims about FEMA camps.•Claims about FEMA camps are part of a longstanding conspiracy theory that picked up steam during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Walgreens refrigerators are scanning shoppers’ hands and foreheads for “the mark of the beast,” and that “if you don’t have the mark later on, you won’t be able to buy.”
Justification: • Cooler Screens are designed to provide targeted advertising and promotions based on shoppers’ behaviors and other factors. They are not scanning people for a specific "mark."• Cooler Screens maintains its system is incapable of collecting specific personal information like vaccine status.• There is no evidence to suggest Cooler Screens’ technology is collecting data on who is vaccinated against COVID-19 or that it will ban people from shopping. It is designed to get people to buy.
Sources: Email exchange with Cooler Screens spokesperson ​​Gayle deDie

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Half a million sharks could be killed to make the COVID-19 vaccine."
Justification: Squalene is an oil-based compound that can be found in plants and animals, including humans. The compound, found in high concentrations in shark livers, is typically used in cosmetics and medicines for its hydrating and immunity-boosting properties. Although squalene is used in some vaccines as an immune booster, it’s not utilized in any of the nine COVID-19 vaccines currently in use across the globe. Though an advocacy group warned that half a million sharks could be in jeopardy if COVID-19 vaccines used the squalene, The New York Times analyzed that figure and found it to be dependent on too many variables to be verified.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If you stop testing (for COVID-19) it all goes away and people just have colds like before.”
Justification: Ending testing for COVID-19 wouldn't mean an end to the pandemic. It would just mean the spread and severity of the virus would go unknown. Vaccinated people with the virus will often develop mild, cold-like symptoms, but are still infectious.
Sources: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Most Americans on minimum wage earn less than a Dickensian allegory for destitution.”
Justification: Dickens’ character Bob Cratchit, making 15 shillings a week, was not among the lowest-paid workers in the Victorian era. Comparing the worth of a salary in 1840s England to today is an imperfect science. Working conditions today are quite different with the advent of the 40-hour work week.
Sources: PolitiFact email interview with George Boyer
PolitiFact email interview with Gregory Clark
PolitiFact email interview with James Kincaid
PolitiFact email interview with Samuel Williamson
PolitiFact email interview with Vincent Geloso

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jan. 6 was NOT an insurrection…but Nov. 4 at 3 a.m. was!”
Justification: •The Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol involved rioters armed with real and makeshift weapons trying to overturn the election. An extensive body of evidence includes video documentation and many eyewitness accounts.• The 2020 presidential election was not an insurrection; Joe Biden was legally elected president. Late-night spikes in voting results reflected the effort to count unprecedented numbers of mail-in ballots and are not proof of fraud.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Pfizer made $37 billion in profit in its last quarter.
Justification: Pfizer reported $24.09 billion in revenue for the third quarter of 2021, and a net income of $8.15 billion. The company generated $13 billion in global revenue for the quarter from its COVID-19 vaccine, Comirnaty.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Biden's CDC Director ADMITS Her Own Employees Aren't Getting Vaccinated."
Justification: A Facebook post with a video clip of a Senate committee hearing on the U.S. COVID-19 response misrepresents what CDC Director Rochelle Walensky said about vaccination among agency employees. Walensky did not say that her employees are avoiding or refusing vaccination. As of Dec. 8, 2021, 97.1% of employees in the Department of Health and Human Services, which includes the CDC, had received at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Electric vehicles would not have fared well in the Virginia snowstorm traffic jam.
Justification: Extreme cold can reduce the range of a moving electric vehicle by as much as half. However, when those vehicles are idling in a long traffic jam, their motors aren’t running, unlike gas-powered cars. So, in severe cold, the only draw on the EV battery would be the heating system and other electrical accessories. Cars with internal combustion engines are at risk of running out of gas or having their batteries die in a situation like the Virginia snowstorm.
Sources: PolitiFact email interview with Jeremy Michalek

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video clip shows a failed attempt by China to launch airstrikes near Taiwan.
Justification: •The video is footage from a live broadcast of a video game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Wisconsin voter roll has over 120,000 active voters who have been registered to vote for over 100 years.”
Justification: Wisconsin municipalities kept their own registration records — and the smallest municipalities weren’t required to keep records at all — until a 2002 federal law required a statewide database and a standard format. When a municipality’s system didn’t track a voter’s date of birth or initial date of registration, a default date was entered into the statewide system: 1/1/1900 for date of birth and 1/1/1918 for date of registration. Such placeholders for missing information have been used by other states as well. As of the fall of 2021 in Wisconsin, there were still about 3,700 active voter records that contain default information for date of birth and about 120,000 records exist in the system with a default date of voter registration.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “India has nearly 1.4 billion citizens. Nearly 800 million of them live in extreme poverty — less than $1.90 per day. Yet EVERY singly (sic) Indian citizen is required to have a valid form of ID to vote in national elections.”
Justification: •India requires citizens to have a valid form of identification to vote in national elections. But citizens must first enroll as new voters and be included on electoral lists.•Reports indicate that some citizens — mostly minorities and women — have not been able to get their names added to the electoral lists or were removed from the lists, which means they cannot vote.•An estimated 134 million people in India live on less than $2 per day; the post significantly overstates the number.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden “has the lowest approval rating of any president ever.”
Justification: Joe Biden recently clocked the lowest approval rating in his presidency, according to one poll. But it’s not the lowest of any president ever. Comparing approval ratings among presidents at about a year into their presidency, former President Donald Trump had the lowest approval rating.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden said “dozens of police were killed” during the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol but “exactly zero people” died that day.
Justification: Five police officers who responded to the attack on the U.S. Capitol died in its aftermath. U.S. Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick died after suffering two strokes several hours after the attack. Four Capitol Police and Washington Metropolitan Police officers died by suicide in the weeks following the attack. Four people who attended the pro-Trump rally that turned into an attack on the Capitol also died, including a woman who was fatally shot by police.
Sources: America's Best Pics and Videos post

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump “is fluent in Japanese.”
Justification: Trump is not fluent in Japanese. During his time as president, Trump required translation services when meeting with Japanese officials and other foreign dignitaries.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Betty White said Dec. 28, days before she died, “Eat healthy and get all your vaccines. I just got boosted today.”
Justification: Betty White did not say "I just got boosted today" days before she died. The quote circulating on social media is fake, her agent confirmed to PolitiFact.
Sources: Phone correspondence with the Los Angeles Police Department

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Senior citizens qualify for a Medicare “flex card” that pays for groceries, dental costs and prescriptions.
Justification: •Medicare, the federal health insurance program for senior citizens and those with disabilities, does not provide flex cards.•Private insurance companies that sell certain Medicare plans are allowed to offer customers a prepaid debit card. The cards are available in some areas, monetary limits are often much lower than advertisements indicate, and what can be purchased with them is also limited.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Vaccines are why flights have been shut down worldwide.
Justification: Airlines said bad weather and staff shortages due to COVID-19 infections were to blame for flight cancellations.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A tragic end today” for CNN’s Sanjay Gupta
Justification: • Dr. Sanjay Gupta is alive and appeared on CNN in the days after his alleged death.• The death hoax in the Facebook post linked to a spam advertisement that falsely claims Gupta is the CEO of a company that sells CBD gummies.• Similar advertisements relying on fake celebrity endorsement scams have been used to sell other cannabis products.
Sources: Email exchange with CNN spokesperson Neel Khairzada

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: If you have “natural immunity,” getting vaccinated against COVID-19 “is more likely to harm you severely.”
Justification: Getting the COVID-19 vaccine after you’ve been infected with the virus isn’t more likely to harm you. In fact, one study found that people who have been infected and vaccinated are better protected than people who were never infected.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
