Main Claim: CDC "will revoke the emergency use authorization" of the PCR COVID tests because those tests don't differentiate between COVID and flu viruses. "Translation: They've been adding flu cases to Covid cases when using that test.”
Justification: Posts circulating on Facebook and Instagram incorrectly claim that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is withdrawing its COVID-19 test because it cannot differentiate between the COVID virus and flu viruses. The CDC’s emergency use authorization from the Food and Drug Administration was not for a test that is distributed or sold but a protocol specifying which reagents were needed to test for the COVID virus. According to experts, the CDC chose to withdraw its EUA request because it wanted to direct laboratories and testing facilities to use a protocol that tests for multiple viruses at once, not just the COVID virus, to save time and resources as flu season approaches.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email interview with Dr. Christopher Polage

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Flights across America are backed up because airline crews are “refusing the mandated jab” and walking off boarded flights.
Justification: Major flight cancellations from Spirit and American airlines have stemmed from myriad issues, including severe weather, staff shortages and system outages — but not protests of vaccine mandates. United, Frontier and Hawaiian Airlines have announced vaccine requirements and policies for their employees in recent days. None of them have reported protests from their employees.
Sources: Email interview with Frontier Airlines spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Ethylene oxide used in COVID-19 testing swabs “literally changes the structure of the building blocks of your own body.”
Justification: Ethylene oxide gas is used to sterilize around half of the medical equipment that is used across the United States. The equipment is then aerated so that any residual ethylene oxide can be released and dissipate. The gas is a known carcinogen and can cause health issues if a person is exposed to a high concentration, but any trace amounts of ethylene oxide on a cotton swab would not be enough to cause harm or change a person’s DNA.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kathy Hochul is Nancy Pelosi’s stepsister.
Justification: They aren’t related.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Thanks to (Israel's) sacrifice, we now know that natural immunity is far superior with 1% experiencing re-infection while 40% of new cases were previously vx'd."
Justification: • Comparing COVID-19 reinfection rates among the unvaccinated and vaccinated to gauge protection against the virus ignores the dangers of contracting COVID-19 and the protections against severe illness that vaccines provide.• Among Israelis who were fully vaccinated and experienced breakthrough infections, COVID-19 vaccines were 88% effective in preventing hospitalization and 91% effective against severe illness.• Israel’s early vaccine campaign that resulted in more than 60% of its population being fully vaccinated has led to huge reductions in serious cases and deaths in the country.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Two federal government buses “stopped in front of a Mexican restaurant in the very small town of Green Cove Springs Florida… The passengers were illegal immigrants, straight from the southern border.”
Justification: Law enforcement officials in Green Cove Springs denied the claim in the Facebook post. There was an event, as advertised by the Mexican consulate, at a restaurant to provide consular assistance and COVID-19 vaccines.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. military holding White House for Trump’s return.”
Justification: This is an unfounded claim that originated on a website that has previously published fake news.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Novak Djokovic said of Simone Biles: “Pressure is a privilege, my friend. ...If you are aiming to be at the top of the game you better start learning how to deal with pressure…”
Justification: A reporter referenced Biles in a question, but Djokovic’s response did not directly deal with Biles. The reporter later clarified that Djokovic was referring to himself in his answer. The social media post omits that Djokovic also referenced feeling pressure "on the court" in his response.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Mail-in voting requires no signature verification.
Justification: In 2020, 31 states had laws requiring signature matching for mail-in voting, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. States without signature matching requirements use other processes to verify absentee ballots, which may include providing photocopies of ID documents when returning the ballot, getting the ballot envelope signed by a witness, getting the ballot envelope notarized, or some combination of these steps. Voter fraud, including for mail in ballots, is statistically rare among the millions of mail in ballots cast in each election cycle.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “60% of patients admitted to the hospital in the UK have been fully vaccinated”
Justification: AU.K. health official misspoke when he said, "around 60% of the people being admitted to hospitals with covid have been double vaccinated." He later issued a correction. Partly or fully vaccinated individuals made up about 40% of people who were hospitalized in the U.K. between February and July. Public health officials said that’s due to the U.K.’s high rates of vaccination and the spread of the delta variant. The vaccines are still effective at reducing the number of infections that result in hospitalization.
Sources: Email Interview with spokesperson for Public Health England

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the white man who wanted Rosa Parks’ seat on the bus was suffering from ADHD and anxiety.
Justification: Rosa Parks was arrested in 1955 in Montgomery, Ala., for refusing a bus driver’s order to give up her seat to a white man. Her act of civil disobedience kicked off the Montgomery Bus Boycott to protest segregation in the bus system. There are no known records about the passenger. Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder was not officially recognized as a diagnosis by the American Psychiatric Association until the late 1980s.
Sources: Email interview with Lopez D. Matthews

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Quotes Abraham Lincoln as saying, “You cannot help the poor by destroying the rich.”
Justification: The quote comes from the Rev. William J.H. Boetcker’s "Ten Cannots."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "They didn't allow" Simone Biles "to take her ADHD medication."
Justification: Biles has said she withdrew from several events in the Tokyo Games because of stress that put her in physical danger while doing gymnastics routines. But she has since announced she will return to the competition. In 2016, Biles said she had ADHD and was taking medication for the condition. She received an exemption to use the medication while in competition. There have been no authoritative statements on whether Biles has continued taking medication for ADHD, or whether she was barred from taking any medication during the Tokyo Olympics.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: COVID-19 vaccinations are “a violation of the Nuremberg code."
Justification: One of the Nuremberg principles is that humans should not be subject to medical experiments without their voluntary consent. The COVID-19 vaccines have been tested in clinical trials with people who gave their consent. The Facebook post is also based on the premise that COVID-19 vaccinations are medical experiments and that’s not true, an expert told us.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Alert: Law enforcement and the Red Cross have advised that there are people going door to door indicating that they are authorized to do testing for Coronavirus.”
Justification: The Red Cross is not going to people’s homes to offercoronavirus tests Despite social media reports, there’s no evidence this is an active or pervasive scam. ​
Sources: Office of Arkansas Attorney General Leslie Rutledge

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: 229 Christian missionaries were sentenced to death in Afghanistan.
Justification: Variations of this Facebook post have circulated since 2009. It is false.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Rand Paul’s medical license was just revoked!”
Justification: This claim originated in a self-described satirical post.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "100 Sailors at sea. All vaxxed. All with COVID (seven) weeks following deployment."
Justification: Breakthrough infections, where someone who is fully vaccinated gets infected, are expected with the COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines. The vaccines are highly effective at protecting people who are infected from developing severe symptoms or becoming hospitalized.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Florida Agriculture Commissioner Nikki Fried “suspended gun rights — no due process — just because she says these people were merely ‘involved’ in January 6.”
Justification: Florida law states that Fried’s department shall suspend gun permits for people who are arrested or charged with a crime that would disqualify someone from having a gun license, including felonies. Fried suspended gun permits for about two dozen people charged with crimes in connection to the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. Due to a privacy law for permit holders, we do not know the specific charges against them. Charges against riot participants that day include obstruction of law enforcement, violence with a deadly weapon, assault, and unlawful possession of a firearm on Capitol grounds. Permit holders who receive a notice about a suspension can request a hearing.
Sources: Florida Agriculture Commissioner Nikki Fried press release
Florida Statute 790.06 License to carry concealed weapon or firearm

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: General Motors “admits the 'clean' energy used to charge electric cars comes from coal, 95% coal, to be exact."
Justification: The claim appears to allude to a clip from a 2010 news conference in Lansing, Mich., about an electric vehicle. In that clip, a GM executive acknowledges that electricity in Lansing likely was produced by coal or natural gas.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “More than 40 military tribunals testified.”
Justification: We found no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "If your employer is mandating any pokes, do not quit. Make them fire you. That way you get unemployment benefits."
Justification: Unemployment benefits are not guaranteed to workers who get fired for protesting their companies’ vaccine requirements. It’s likely they’d be denied such benefits, experts said. Unemployment payments are provided to Americans who fall out of a job through no fault of their own. Getting fired for cause or misconduct is a different story.
Sources: U.S. Department of Justice Office of Legal Counsel

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Post says a recent bill passed, and “We get another stimulus check for $2500 at July 30, 2021”
Justification: The post links to a picture of a gorilla making an obscene hand gesture

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Ambassador Susan Rice Tribunal, Gavin Newsom indicted.”
Justification: The claim of military court action against the two prominent Democrats is baseless and was made by a website with a history of producing false information.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The coronavirus can’t be so dangerous because there are no biohazard bins for COVID-19 masks and gloves.
Justification: The coronavirus spreads almost exclusively through respiratory droplets carried through the air. It does not live or spread on surfaces, so masks and gloves used by the general public to protect against COVID-19 infection aren’t considered medical waste that requires special handling. Medical waste containers, or biohazard bins, are used by health care facilities for items contaminated with hazardous infectious materials such as blood or other internal body fluids. Personal protective equipment used by the general public doesn’t need to be disposed of like medical waste. Masks to prevent the spread of COVID-19 can be thrown away in the trash because the coronavirus doesn’t spread or survive easily on surfaces.
Sources: Centers for Disease and Safety Control
Phone interview with Dr. Paul Offit

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The government will be infiltrating” personal text messages.
Justification: Politico reported that Biden allies such as the Democratic National Committee plan to work with wireless carriers to fight misinformation. The party told PolitiFact it notifies carriers of mass texts that  "spread scams and disinformation." There is no evidence that the Biden administration is seeking to "infiltrate" private text messages between individuals.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Income taxes are voluntary."
Justification: Federal law spells out the circumstances when people owe taxes and says that they must pay them. People who have challenged those laws by not paying taxes have ended up in prison.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Five JetBlue pilots died from the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: Four pilots and one inflight crew member have died this year, but JetBlue said there is no connection to the COVID-19 vaccine. The obituaries of the five men do not mention the vaccine. The obituary of one man says he died of cancer, and the obituary of another man says he died after an accident.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “It makes no sense to require vaccinations for the previously infected.”
Justification: People who have had COVID-19 do have some level of immunity; however, the CDC recommends vaccination because it provides better protection. Naturally acquired immunity may not be as effective against variant strains of the virus that cause COVID-19.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health
Phone interview with Paul A. Offit

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video montage shows Kamala Harris and others faking vaccination.
Justification: • A video montage that purports to show fake vaccinations depicted real events in misleading ways.• One clip in the montage shows then-Vice President-elect Kamala Harris being vaccinated. There is no evidence that the vaccination was fake.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A bodyguard of a high-ranking Democrat in Congress fired the shot that killed Ashli Babbitt on Jan. 6.
Justification: Officials have not released the identity of the person who fired the gunshot that killed Ashli Babbitt during the Jan. 6 attack, but the Capitol Police confirmed the person was not assigned to any Congress member’s security detail.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Newly obtained emails show UCSF harvesting the clitorises, testicles and penises of murdered babies.”
Justification: Live Action, an anti-abortion nonprofit organization, obtained emails documenting tissue collection by UC San Francisco researchers through the California Public Records Act. The group stated that the emails show researchers harvesting the genitalia of "murdered babies," but that claim is not accurate. UCSF conducts biomedical research on fetal tissue that is donated after miscarriages and abortions. Abortions are not performed specifically to obtain fetal tissue. UCSF scholars’ work includes research surrounding the fetal development of reproductive organs, which can yield new medical knowledge and help develop treatments for a variety of conditions and diseases.
Sources: Contraception: An International Reproductive Health Journal

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Kansas City Chiefs QB Patrick Mahomes has left training camp and says he will ‘not play another down in the NFL’ until the team changes their name.”
Justification: The claim came from a known parody account. It’s not true.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Carbon dioxide “is not a problem. The Earth has more than enough land and ocean plant life to metabolize it.”
Justification: • Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have reached record highs.• Build-up of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is an indicator that plants and the oceans can't absorb fossil-fuel waste fast enough.• Absorbing excess carbon dioxide is harmful to oceans and sea life because it increases acid levels in the water.
Sources: American Association for the Advancement of Science
Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Biden concedes 6 million votes."
Justification: Biden misspoke about the the number of voters in the 2020 election, in which he defeated Donald Trump by 7 million votes. He did not concede any votes.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says George Floyd’s criminal history includes “23 arrests,” “3 car thefts” and many violent crimes.
Justification: Court documents from Harris County, Texas, where George Floyd lived most of his life, show that he was criminally charged in nine cases. The post exaggerates the charges and includes crimes that Floyd was not charged with.
Sources: Copy of Order for Case Amendment
Copy of complaint in aggravated robbery from Harris County District Clerk
Copy of complaint in illegal trespass case
Copy of plea deal in theft from person charge
Harris County District Clerk court records and documents

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There are “22 million illegal aliens living in America and ... voting illegally.”
Justification: Many reliable entities such as the Pew Research Center estimate that there are in the ballpark of 11 million people living illegally in the U.S. One 2018 study from Yale put the number closer to 22 million, but the study has been subject to criticism. There is no evidence that 22 million people in the U.S. without legal permission voted illegally in the 2020 election or regularly vote in American elections.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Protest video shows “resistance” to “President Macron’s plan for mandatory COVID vaccinations of all French citizens.”
Justification: France has had protests against new vaccination mandates for health workers. The protest shown in the video was not in France. It was a student protest in Nairobi, Kenya.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Coca-Cola has lost $4 bil in market value as people are boycotting Coke for their ‘try to be less White’ statement.”
Justification: Coca-Cola’s market value dropped by$4 billion on June 14, the day that international soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo was moved two bottles of Coke to the side in favor of water during a European Football Championship press conference. An expert said it’s  difficult to prove causation related to stock price movements, but that it’s not likely the June drop was triggered by criticism that flared months earlier in February after news broke that Coke’s employee diversity training included a message telling people to "try to be less white."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows an electric car charging station that uses "12 gallons of diesel fuel per hour, and it takes three hours to fully charge a car to get 200 miles. That's 36 gallons for 200 miles. 5.6 mpg."
Justification: The operator of the charging station said it gets its power through the local utility company, not diesel. Electric car charging stations do not typically run on a diesel generator. Charging stations are connected to an electrical grid supplied by whatever the local power source is. A diesel generator was used in an experiment to power an electric car charging station. The experiment found that a car charged through the station was more fuel efficient than driving a diesel-powered car.
Sources: Email with Electrify America Spokesperson Mike Moran

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In the 2020 presidential election, “4,255 ballots in Fulton County, Georgia,  were scanned multiple times” and “3,390 went to Biden.”
Justification: Some 200 ballots in the 2020 presidential election initially were double-counted in Fulton County, where heavily Democratic Atlanta is located. But the double-count, once identified, didn’t change the official result of Biden defeating Trump in Georgia. There’s no evidence of thousands of double-counts.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Headlines show CNN published contradictory reports about hydroxychloroquine in 2020.
Justification: • Social media users juxtaposed the headlines of two CNN stories about hydroxychloroquine by the same author from April and July 2020 in an effort to prove that the network was contradicting itself.• The April headline said President Trump was "wrong in so many ways" about hydroxychloroquine, while the July headline said a study found that the drug "helped coronavirus patients survive better."• The stories did not contain conflicting information, and later versions of the July story had a longer headline that more clearly described the limitations of the study findings.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “This week the military was moving big equipment into the major big cities preparing for the Maricopa audit results.”
Justification: Contractors involved in a GOP-ordered review of Maricopa County, Ariz., ballots cast in the 2020 presidential election are expected to submit their findings to the state Senate in August. There’s no evidence to support the claim that the military is preparing to respond to the release of the results. State and federal military officials told PolitiFact that they are not involved in the ballot review in Arizona.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photograph shows members of the U.S. women’s soccer team kneeling during the national anthem at the Tokyo Olympics.
Justification: • The photo showing some members of the U.S. women’s soccer team kneeling during the  national anthem was taken in February 2021 at the SheBelieves Cup, not at the Tokyo Olympics.• Members of the U.S. women’s national team took a knee on July 21 ahead of their first Olympic match, as did teams from Great Britain, Chile, Sweden and New Zealand. At the time, the national anthem was not playing.• Team members stood during the national anthem on July 21.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Drivers with no DUIs are getting up to $610 back in savings.”
Justification: This is a potential scam. Experts with the American Property Casualty Insurance Association said they are unaware of any such program. Some DMVs have access to drivers’ records; however, they are not giving money away.
Sources: Email exchange with a representative from California DMV Office of Public Affairs
Email exchange with a representative from Washington D.C. Department of Motor Vehicles

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “CDC quietly deletes 6,000 COVID vaccine deaths from its CDC website total in one day.”
Justification: Anyone can report the occurrence of an "adverse event" following vaccination to a government database known as VAERS. But these reports themselves are not verified and do not indicate whether the reported adverse event is linked to or caused by a vaccine. There hasn’t been any definitive proof that a COVID-19 vaccination led to someone’s death. The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention did make an error on its website in reporting deaths that occur after vaccinations, but corrected it the same day.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Queen Elizabeth and her husband Prince Philip were found guilty in the disappearance of 10 native children from the Catholic-run Kamloops residential school”
Justification: Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip never visited the Kamloops Indian Residential School. The alleged arrest warrant originated from an unrecognized court and conspiracy website.
Sources: First Nations Studies Program at the University of British Columbia
Pacific Mountain Regional Council of The United Church of Canada
Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says in February Facebook post that "Britney won."
Justification: A February post being reshared gives the false impression that Britney Spears won a court fight to have her father removed from a conservatorship that controls her affairs. Her win in one court ruling was relatively small and her father still retains control over much of her life through the conservatorship, which she continues to fight in court.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “BREAKING: Pennsylvania initiated a FULL audit of the RIGGED ELECTION”
Justification: Pennsylvania has not initiated a full audit for the 2020 election. Pennsylvania already used risk-limiting audits for the 2020 election. They did not reveal fraud.
Sources: Email exchange with Common Cause Pennsylvania
Phone interview with York County Offices

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "People are being diagnosed with delta variant" even though "there is no delta variant test."
Justification: Routine tests that determine whether an individual has COVID-19 do not reveal whether the disease was caused by the delta variant — mass testing of national COVID-19 samples does.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. sanctions mean “Cuba can’t trade with any country or any company whatsoever.”
Justification: Experts and evidence shows that Cuba can and has traded with other countries. While the nuances in the U.S. embargo can make it difficult for foreign companies to trade with Cuba, there is no evidence that they can’t.
Sources: The American Presidency Project Proclamation 3447 – Embargo on All Trade with Cuba

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Ex-AARP members wrote this letter criticizing the “Biden Regime.”
Justification: This letter was written by ex-AARP members in 2009. They were critical of then-President Barack Obama’s administration, not the "Biden Regime." It’s been edited and altered in the years since to include new language that didn’t appear in the original letter.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine is "99% graphene oxide," which is "toxic to the human body and causes a number of problems.
Justification: Pfizer says it does not use graphene oxide and no such ingredient is listed in any of the three COVID-19 vaccines authorized for use in the U.S.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Dr. Anthony Fauci in an email "advises a family member to use (hydroxychloroquine) and antibiotic therapy, the same evening in which in a press conference he attacked (President Donald Trump) on the usefulness of  (hydroxychloroquine) to fight the virus.”
Justification: • We found nothing in Dr. Anthony Fauci’s publicly disclosed emails to indicate that he urged a close relative to use hydroxychloroquine.• Fauci was consistent in his emails in arguing that anecdotal evidence suggesting hydroxychloroquine’s efficacy against the coronavirus would need to be demonstrated in a controlled clinical trial before recommending its use.• Fauci’s stance in his private emails mirrored what he said publicly.
Sources: Searchable database of Anthony Fauci’s publicly released emails

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Members of the US Women’s National Soccer team turned their backs on the flag as a 98-year-old World War II veteran played the anthem.
Justification: The players turned in order to face the U.S. flag during the anthem.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Maxine Waters just introduced a bill to re-name Memorial Day — George Floyd Day."
Justification: In the days before Memorial Day, social media users claimed that California Congresswoman Maxine Waters introduced a bill to rename Memorial Day in honor of Geroge Floyd. This is false. Waters did not introduce a bill to change Memorial Day to "George Floyd Day." Waters co-sponsored the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act of 2021 in February, but the bill doesn’t propose renaming Memorial Day.
Sources: Library of Congress. " H.R.1280 - George Floyd Justice in Policing Act of 2021.
Library of Congress. " H.R.3466 - To provide a remedy for survivors and descendants of the victims of the Tulsa
Library of Congress. " Representative Maxine Waters

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Canadian mayor said Muslims must integrate after they “demanded removal of pork in all school canteens in Montreal.”
Justification: This is an old hoax.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Coolmath Games is being taken down cause it was run by the Mexican drug cartel?”
Justification: • Coolmath Games says it isn’t shutting down.• There is no evidence Coolmath Games has connections to or is being run by the "Mexican drug cartel."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “San Francisco Allowing Children to ‘Consent’ to Covid Vaccine Without Parents Approval.”
Justification: Misleading posts on Facebook and Twitter say minors in San Francisco are consenting to COVID-19 vaccines without their parent’s permission. San Francisco issued a health order allowing emancipated minors and those considered "self-sufficient" to consent to receive the Pfizer vaccine. San Francisco issued further guidance for healthcare providers administering COVID-19 vaccines to minors. The guidance says healthcare providers are required to do everything possible to get the consent from a parent or legal guardian before giving a vaccine.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
City and County of San Francisco Vaccine Dashboard
Guidance for City and County of San Francisco (CCSF) Healthcare Providers Administering COVID-19 Vaccines to Minor Patients
San Francisco Health Order allowing minors to consent to vaccines

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says President John F. Kennedy said, “There are people in Washington, D.C., in positions of power to whom the border is just a nuisance, and I think some of them believe that illegal immigration is a moral good. It is not.”
Justification: N/A

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Military ready to act on audit results!” in Arizona
Justification: The GOP-organized review of 2.1 million ballots cast in Maricopa County in the presidential election started in late April. Organizers expect findings to be released in a report later this summer. There’s no evidence to back the claim that the military is preparing to respond to the release of the results. Spokespersons for the Arizona National Guard and the U.S. Army said their agencies aren’t involved.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Charcoal activated tablets “will counteract most date rape drugs.”
Justification: Experts do not advise using activated charcoal to "counteract" drugs used in rape and other sexual assaults — it’s unlikely to be effective and its application is best determined on a case by case basis.
Sources: American Academy of Clinical Toxicology and European Association of Poisons Centres and Clinical Toxicologists
European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Facebook said that if you support the NRA you will get kicked off.”
Justification: Facebook allows NRA supporters on the social media platform and has made no statement about kicking them off. The NRA has an active Facebook page with more than 4.7 million followers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Marine painted his house red, white and blue after he "was told by his neighbors that he could not fly the American flag in his yard all year long."
Justification: The house painted like an American flag is real. It’s located in Cambridge, Maryland. The homeowner told PolitiFact he painted the house like a flag in 2012 following a dispute with the city’s Historic Preservation Commission. The paint job was not done recently, nor was it done by a Marine whose neighbors said he couldn’t fly an American flag everyday, as several Facebook posts falsely claim.
Sources: Reverse image searches on Google and TinEye

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Airlines begin to ban vaccinated people after Pilots die due to vaccine”
Justification: British Airways said four of its pilots died in recent months. The deaths aren’t linked to the COVID-19 vaccines. There is no evidence of airlines banning vaccinated people.
Sources: Email exchange with British Airways Press Office
Email exchange with International Air Transport Association Corporate Communications

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi “won’t let Capitol police testify about what happened Jan. 6.”
Justification: After meeting with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the chairman of a new select committee to investigate the Jan. 6 riot said the inquiry would start with testimony from Capitol police officers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Gov. Gavin Newsom has “no power or authority” to extend the state of emergency in California because it expired “automatically” on May 6, 2020.
Justification: A state of emergency must be ended by the governor or by concurrent resolution in the state Legislature at "the earliest possible date that conditions warrant," according to the law. Legal experts say the law gives public officials broad discretion to determine when it is appropriate to end a state of emergency. Experts said Newsom is likely continuing the state of emergency so that he can reimpose restrictions if COVID-19 cases spike. A state of emergency declaration also allows officials to access state resources and receive federal assistance, which could aid California’s reopening efforts.
Sources: Cornell Law Library Legal Information Institute

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “California literally just told everyone to not charge their electric cars due to power shortage.”
Justification: The California Independent System Operator, which oversees the operations of the state’s power grid, issued a Flex Alert last week amid the first heat wave of the summer. The alert asked Californians to conserve electricity when possible. It included several tips, including a suggestion to avoid charging electric cars during peak power usage hours. Most electric car drivers top off their battery regularly rather than charging it from empty to full. Therefore, many cars are equipped with charging timers and require only a few hours of charging each day, so Californians can easily avoid charging vehicles during peak hours. Experts say California’s power grid can comfortably support up to 5 million electric cars on the road. Currently, there are about 635,000 electric vehicles registered in the state, according to the California Energy Commission.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Haiti, Tanzania and Madagascar refused the COVID-19 vaccines and now all three of their presidents have died unexpectedly.
Justification: There is no evidence that the deaths of Jovenel Moïse, John Magufuli and Didier Ignace Ratsiraka were connected to their governments’ refusing COVID-19 vaccines. Moïse was the only one assassinated, and experts say his death will likely only further hinder the vaccine effort in Haiti, not help it. Ratsiraka was not Madagascar’s president at the time of his death. His last term ended in 2002.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Ivanka Trump was targeted in the Florida condominium building collapse.
Justification: With search-and-rescue efforts still under way, authorities say it will be some time before an investigation can be done in earnest to try to determine what caused the partial collapse of a condo building that’s about a block from where Ivanka Trump reportedly lives.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the Wyoming State Parks Department said it “discovered what looks like a giant root system stemming from the base of the Devils Tower.”
Justification: This claim originated as satire. Geologists say Devils Tower is formed of a rare igneous rock called phonolite porphyry.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows Mike Tyson wearing a T-shirt with an anti-vaccine message.
Justification: A photo of Mike Tyson wearing a T-shirt from his apparel line was altered to appear as if the shirt had an anti-vaccine message.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A study found an “82% miscarriage rate” among women between 30 days and 20 weeks pregnant who got an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: This is a misrepresentation of the data. It doesn’t account for all the pregnancies being evaluated. The majority of women are either still pregnant, or have not yet had follow-ups with researchers. Until all the pregnancies are evaluated and more authoritative data is released, any statistic on this topic should be considered preliminary.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A heat wave melted turbine blades at a Texas wind farm.
Justification: Both the National Weather Service in Houston and a spokesman for the company that manages the wind farm shown in the Facebook post confirmed the blades were damaged by a storm, not excessive heat.
Sources: National Weather Service Houston Twitter post

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Japan has banned all (Black Lives Matter) apparel from the Olympics. No one can kneel or raise fists during the anthems either."
Justification: Host countries do not set the rules for athletes participating in the Olympics, that’s the job of the International Olympic Committee. Since the 1970s, the IOC’s charter has a rule prohibiting athletes from making any form of political expression and doesn’t single out a specific ideology or movement.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION recently reversed its stance on children getting the Covid vaccine.”
Justification: Social media posts falsely claimed that the World Health Organization recently reversed its policy and said children shouldn’t be vaccinated against COVID-19. The posts were referencing an actual WHO webpage, but the guidance was originally posted on April 8 and reflected the organization's stance that vaccine supply is limited in some countries and children shouldn’t be prioritized over other high-risk groups because COVID-19 disease is milder in kids. The WHO updated the guidance for children on its webpage on June 23 based on a recent scientific advisory meeting in which the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine was found to be safe for those ages 12 and up.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email exchange with World Health Organization Media Relations
Email interview with Dr. Rachel Vreeman

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says George Floyd died "because he had a system full of fentanyl and meth," and “beat women and held guns to their pregnant bellies.”
Justification: Two autopsy reports ruled that George Floyd’s death on May 25, 2020, was a homicide. Floyd’s heart stopped when former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin restrained him for several minutes with a knee on his neck. Chauvin was convicted on all three counts of killing Floyd. A medical examiner found high levels of fentanyl in his system, but experts in toxicology, cardiology and drug use stated death by overdose was unlikely or impossible. Details surrounding Floyd’s past criminal history have been fabricated or exaggerated since his death. Floyd was involved in a 2007 aggravated robbery, but he was not found to have beaten or held a pregnant woman at gunpoint.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Lauren Boebert received a PPP loan for her restaurant.”
Justification: Records show that a restaurant called Shooters Sports Grill in Ohio received a Paycheck Protection Program loan for $233,305, not Shooter’s Grill, Boebert’s restaurant in Rifle, Colo. Boebert did not receive a Paycheck Protection Program loan, her communications director said.
Sources: No Lie with Brian Tyler Cohen tweet

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A flag expressing support for police officers violates the U.S. Flag Code.
Justification: In accordance with the U.S. Flag Code, the black and white flag with the blue stripe in the center is not technically an official version of the American flag. The black and white flag with the blue stripe — which adopts the likeness of the American flag — does not violate the U.S. Flag Code.
Sources: Phone interview with NAVA President Peter Ansoff

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: News organizations and sponsors ignored the accomplishments of Kim Rhode, a six-time Olympic medalist, because of her support of the Second Amendment.
Justification: There is no evidence to support this. Several prominent news organizations have reported about Rhode’s Olympic accomplishments, as well as her support of gun rights. The sport of shooting often receives less big-name sponsors due to its lack of fanfare. Rhode didn’t qualify for the 2020 games.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi “said Trump is BEST PRESIDENT ever” and “holds new election” for him
Justification: The claim is fabricated.
Sources: Press release from Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The unvaccinated have escaped every single strain or 'variant’” of SARS-CoV-2.
Justification: Unvaccinated people are more vulnerable to contracting COVID-19, including the virus’s more transmissible variants. Mutations of the coronavirus can cause more severe symptoms among unvaccinated people.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Donald Trump signed the Insurrection Act and “still is president.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that Trump invoked the law during his final days in office. He is not president anymore.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Listerine mouthwash can be effectively used as a mosquito repellant.
Justification: Studies have found that a refined form of eucalyptus oil can be used as an alternative to DEET to repel mosquitos. Most plant-based repellents contain a concentration of at least 10% of the oil, whereas Listerine has less than 1%, not enough to be effective against mosquitoes.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Journal of the American Mosquito Control Association

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden gets brutal impeachment.”
Justification: Joe Biden was not impeached.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the Pentagon killed a man who invented a water-powered fuel cell for cars.
Justification: The government did not kill an Ohio man who claimed to have invented a water-powered car. He died of a brain aneurysm caused by high blood pressure.
Sources: Email with the Department of Defense
The Columbus Dispatch website via Internet Archive Wayback Machine

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Marjorie Taylor Greene said, “People are dying who have never died before.”
Justification: We found no evidence that Marjorie Taylor Greene said this. It has previously been falsely attributed to former President Donald Trump, and a similar quote was wrongly attributed to President Joe Biden. It was Ernest Hemingway who once wrote something similar.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden agrees to Pelosi's request to resign.”
Justification: This is a fabricated claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Congress created “a generous mortgage relief program” for veterans.
Justification: • There is no evidence that Congress established a program that would substantially reduce veterans’ mortgage payments.• Veterans are advised to be wary of offers to refinance VA home loans that promise the ability to skip a mortgage payment, offer extremely low interest rates or otherwise seem too good to be true.• If you follow the links provided in the Facebook posts, LowerMyBills includes disclaimers indicating that they do not provide calculations for a "new house payment" as the post claims.
Sources: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau "CFPB and VA WARNO: VA refinancing offers that sound too good to be true

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Not one word” from Joe Biden and Kamala Harris honoring service members for Memorial Day.
Justification: President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris each posted a tweet on May 29 about the holiday weekend without mentioning service members. They also made multiple social media posts honoring military members and their families and participated in Memorial Day events, including the annual wreath-laying ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery. Biden honored service members in speeches throughout the weekend.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a 2010 Rockefeller Foundation report shows the COVID-19 pandemic and the international response were “meticulously planned at least 10 years ago.”
Justification: The report, which explored "the role of technology and the future of globalization," presented four possible future scenarios of how the world might evolve, including one in which an influenza pandemic and lockdowns occurred. The scenarios were hypothetical. They weren’t predictions or plans.
Sources: Rockefeller Foundation and Global Business Network

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Emails show "Fauci's fellow scientist could tell early on that the (coronavirus) looked manufactured."
Justification: One email to Fauci from a credible researcher noted the possibility of an engineered virus, but said more work was needed. Other emails came from less credible voices and cited no evidence.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: COVID-19 vaccines are creating the coronavirus variants.
Justification: Several coronavirus variants emerged before the vaccines were rolled out in late 2020. The COVID-19 vaccines help reduce the spread of the virus, therefore decreasing the likelihood that it will mutate and create new variants. Slow vaccine uptake can cause more variants, since the virus continually looks to evolve and escape any immunity — natural or vaccine-induced. Public health experts say this doesn’t mean that people shouldn’t get vaccinated, but just the opposite, as faster uptake slows this from happening and will leave people better protected from the virus in the process.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Emails show that Fauci knew "hydroxychloroquine worked [and] emailed friends about it being effective."
Justification: In his emails, Fauci acknowledged the existence of anecdotal evidence claiming hydroxychloroquine's effectiveness against COVID-19 but never endorsed it himself and said he was waiting for results from a clinical trial for any definitive proof. The clinical trial ended last June after researchers found the drug provided no additional benefit in treating the virus.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Police defunding is to blame for “skyrocketing murder rates” in Philadelphia, Minneapolis, Portland, New York City, Chicago, Los Angeles and Washington, D.C.
Justification: Homicides rates have gone up in the seven places highlighted in the post. But a link between higher homicide rates to police budget cuts has not been proven. A proper evaluation of budget changes and their impact on crime would require a study that controls for multiple factors that influence criminal activity, including poverty and joblessness.
Sources: Portland Police Bureau Budget Details and ChangesFY 2019-20 and FY 2020-21

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Fauci’s emails leaked.”
Justification: Dr. Anthony Fauci’s emails didn’t ‘leak.’ They were obtained via the Freedom of Information Act.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Study: hydroxychloroquine can boost COVID-19 survival chances by nearly 200%."
Justification: A study says a certain dosing of hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin "improves survival by nearly 200%" among hospitalized COVID-19 patients who received invasive mechanical ventilation. The study is posted on a website that publishes "preprints" — studies that "have not been finalized by authors, might contain errors and report information that has not yet been accepted or endorsed in any way by the scientific or medical community." Experts called the study poorly designed and caution against drawing conclusions about cause and effect.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says BLM activist Sasha Johnson tweeted, “The white man will not be our equal but our slave.”
Justification: Tweets about enslaving white people were not sent by prominent BLM activist Sasha Johnson. The account was fake. Twitter has suspended the account that published the tweet.
Sources: Taking the Initiative Party information page

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Cuomo opens New York 72 hours before his daughter's wedding.”
Justification: • On June 15, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced that state-mandated COVID restrictions would be lifted because 70% of adult New Yorkers have received a COVID-19 vaccine.• Cuomo’s daughters aren’t "getting married any time soon," according to a spokesperson.• Claims about a Cuomo wedding seem to have started because of a Buffalo News article from 1993.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Viral immunologist says COVID-19 vaccines’ “spike protein” means people are being inoculated “with a toxin.”
Justification: Experts say there is no evidence that the vaccines produce a toxin that could cause heart problems and neurological damage, as Canadian viral immunologist Byram Bridle maintained. Bridle has not produced evidence to prove his claim, which has been widely shared on social media.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Israel’s Iron Dome missile defense system engaged in military combat.
Justification: The footage shows a video game simulation from "Arma 3," the game’s developer confirmed to PolitiFact.
Sources: Email interview with Bohemian Interactive spokesperson Kornelis Vincent Johan van't Land

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The New York Times published an old stock photo of a young girl and claimed Israeli forces killed her during its recent war with Hamas.
Justification: The New York Times mistakenly used an image of a different girl to identify Rahaf Al-Masri, a 10-year-old who was killed in an Israeli airstrike around May 10 in Beit Hanoun, Gaza, along with her three young cousins. The photographer, Maiar Abu Shalback, told us the photo is of a girl named Salma from the Palestinian city of Ramallah and that it was taken in October 2015 at Al-Awael School. Salma is alive and in good health, Shalback said. The Times issued a correction about the photo on its website and featured a different image for Al-Masri that was provided by her family.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “So the unvaxxed have to wear mask (sic) to protect the vaxxinated.”
Justification: • Health experts recommend that unvaccinated people wear masks to protect other unvaccinated or not-fully-vaccinated people.• As of May 30, 40.7% of the total U.S. population was fully vaccinated against COVID-19, leaving a large swath of the population remaining to be fully protected.•  COVID-19 cases in the U.S. have declined dramatically, but on May 29, theseven-day averagefor new daily cases was still more than 18,000 per day.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An image shows the Blue Angels performing a maneuver called the “Hand of God.”
Justification: • The image is a piece of digital art, not a photograph. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Biden administration has decided to cancel $0 in student debt.”
Justification: Biden’s 2022 federal budget proposal does not include a provision for student debt forgiveness. Biden is still considering options, including an executive order, for student debt forgiveness.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Boom! Georgia 1st to decertify election.”
Justification: Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, a Republican, certified the presidential election results in November affirming Joe Biden’s win. He has not sought to undo that process. A judge in May granted a request by a group of plaintiffs seeking to inspect absentee ballots cast in the general election in Fulton County. The plaintiffs allege wrongful counting of fraudulent ballots. The judge’s order does not call for a new election or any attempt at decertification.
Sources: Georgia Public Radio reporter Stephen Fowler
Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger
Office of Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the Novavax COVID-19 vaccine “dumps millions” of dangerous “spike proteins right into your body.”
Justification: U.S. public health authorities and vaccine experts say there is no evidence that COVID-19 vaccines’ spike protein is toxic. A vaccine expert said the vaccine developed by Novamax contains a single viral protein.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Absent from the news — Dominion lost their lawsuits against Rudy Giuliani and Sidney Powell."
Justification: The two defamation lawsuits filed by Dominion Voting Systems, a company targeted with baseless claims about rigging the 2020 presidential election, are still active.
Sources: Public Access to Court Electronic Records

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a photo shows a “lithium mine for hybrid cars.”
Justification: The photo is of a gold mine, not a mine for lithium, which is used to make batteries for hybrid and electric vehicles.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Lumber, gas, wheat, coal and corn cost more in April 2021 "in Joe Biden's America" than they did a year earlier.
Justification: Prices for lumber, gas, wheat, coal and corn were sharply higher in April 2021, about three months after Joe Biden became president, than they were in April 2020. The main reason is the nation’s recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. In April 2020, the pandemic all but shuttered the economy and depressed prices across the board.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "21% of 140,000 ballots were found to be in error in GA.”
Justification: A witness for plaintiffs seeking to inspect absentee ballots in Fulton County testified that there was a mismatch in the number of batches of ballots in the initial count and a risk-limiting audit and that he found a 21% error rate. The Secretary of State’s office said the claim about the error rate is wrong. Georgia’s Republican statewide election officials have said they are confident in the presidential election results, which have already been audited and certified.
Sources: Georgia Public Radio reporter Stephen Fowler
Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Bruno Mars is Michael Jackson’s son.
Justification: Bruno Mars’ father is Peter Hernandez, a doo-wop singer from Hawaii.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Anyone remember Kamala telling Joe during the debate: ‘You will do whatever the Chinese tell you! They gave your son over a billion dollars.’”
Justification: Kamala Harris never said these words to Joe Biden during a debate. Harris did go after Biden for his position on busing to desegregate schools in the 1970s.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Montana is canceling unemployment because of a workforce shortage.”
Justification: • Montana Gov. Greg Gianforte has announced that the state will withdraw from the federal unemployment aid program established to help those out of work during the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the state unemployment aid program remains in place. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An audit of the 2020 election in Maricopa County, Ariz., “is confirming the rumors that real ballots have a special watermark.”
Justification: Maricopa County says it does not use watermarks on its ballots. No evidence has emerged that the audit, led by a firm headed by Doug Logan, who was part of the "stop the steal" conspiracy theories about the election, has found any evidence of watermarks.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: New Jersey “will be out of gas for a week.”
Justification: New Jersey hasn’t run out of gas and it’s unlikely that it will, according to the state’s fuel merchants association.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The Unvaccinated Beware, COVID-19 mRNA Shots Cause Death and Disease Through GMO Shedding"
Justification: • The mRNA COVID-19 vaccines cannot affect people who are not vaccinated.• There is no evidence the COVID-19 vaccines cause infertility or pregnancy complications.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Video shows U.S. Capitol Police gave protesters OK to enter.”
Justification: A video clip from inside of the Capitol on Jan. 6 shows officers speaking to one group of rioters who are already in the building. It is not evidence that the mob was given the OK to enter the Capitol. Capitol Police told PolitiFact the officers in the video are blocking the hallway and attempting to de-escalate the situation. The officers told the crowd to not attack or assault them and to remain calm. The pro-Trump mob forcibly breached the building by pushing past barricades and law enforcement. Some rioters attacked police officers and vandalized the Capitol.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the CDC’s new tracking policy is covering up cases of “breakthrough” COVID-19 infections among vaccinated people.
Justification: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed it is no longer scrutinizing "breakthrough" COVID-19 cases among vaccinated people unless the patient is admitted to a hospital or dies. The agency said the policy will help researchers zero in on the severe cases that concern them most.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email interview with CDC spokesperson Kristen Nordlund

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. Census Bureau confirms huge conflict in total number of voters in 2020 election.”
Justification: The Census Bureau’s population survey data shows that the number of people who reported that they voted in the 2020 election is less than the number of ballots that were cast for president.But that difference doesn’t account for the more than 36 million people who didn’t report whether they voted or not. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An ongoing audit of the 2020 presidential election in Arizona “showed Trump ahead by 250,000” votes, and “nearly 950,000 ballots are declared illegal, nearly all for Biden.”
Justification: Republicans in Arizona’s state Senate ordered an audit of the 2020 presidential election results in Maricopa County, home to Phoenix. The audit is ongoing. No preliminary findings have been released.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "When you can't find gas, remember who executively ordered the Keystone Pipeline to close."
Justification: President Joe Biden’s executive order halted construction on an extension of the Keystone Pipeline, which carries Canadian crude oil to refineries, not gasoline. He did not order the pipeline closed. The supply disruptions and price spike on the East Coast are due to an attack on the operator of the Colonial Pipeline, which carries gasoline from refineries to markets, not a shortage of crude oil.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “First time in 70 years the National Day Of Prayer was not observed in our nation’s capital!”
Justification: There was no public service held at the U.S. Capitol, as there has been in some years — but the day was still observed. President Joe Biden issued the typical proclamation designating the day and participated in a virtual prayer event. The Capitol is closed to public tours amid the COVID-19 pandemic and has been operating under increased security ever since the breach on Jan. 6.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kentucky Derby jockey John Velazquez turned down an invitation to the White House and said, “if I wanted to see a horse’s ass I would of came in second.”
Justification: John Velazquez didn’t say this and he hasn’t been invited to the White House, according to the jockey’s agent.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A year ago we had the lowest unemployment in history without using taxpayers money.”
Justification: A year before the post, in April 2020, the unemployment rate was 14.7%, the highest on record, not the lowest. In late-March 2020, President Donald Trump signed a $2.2 trillion COVID-19 relief bill into law. The unemployment rate bottomed out to 3.6% in April 2019, the lowest since the 1960s.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Michigan has requested a full forensic audit."
Justification: No more audits are planned, according to the secretary of state’s office.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Benjamin Netanyahu gave a speech to Hamas leaders thanking them for uniting Israel.
Justification: This is a fictional speech that first appeared online in 2014.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Caitlyn Jenner “literally killed someone 6 years ago in the streets and was released by a District Attorney.”
Justification: Caitlyn Jenner has become the target of political attention since declaring to run in the likely California recall election as a Republican challenger. Jenner has also received criticism for a fatal car accident that prompted her to pay settlements. Posts across Facebook and Twitter have suggested that Jenner recklessly killed someone in the streets. In 2015, Jenner was involved in the accident where she rear-ended a car into oncoming traffic, which caused the driver’s death. Jenner settled with several of the parties. However, the Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department suggested Jenner be charged for vehicular manslaughter. After an investigation, the Los Angeles County District Attorney’s office found there was no evidence to support whether Jenner was negligent or had broken any major traffic laws. Legal experts say proving these types of cases is difficult because the burden of proof relies solely on the prosecutor.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “About 40% to 50% of CDC, FDA employees are refusing the COVID-19 vaccine, according to” Anthony Fauci and FDA’s Peter Marks.
Justification: Dr. Anthony Fauci and top officials from the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention were asked at a Senate committee hearing what percentage of their employees have received COVID-19 vaccinations. In their responses, none of the three officials said anything about employees who refused to be vaccinated.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An Ohio doctor died from a COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: Claims that an Ohio doctor died from the COVID-19 vaccine are unfounded. His wife has said he died due to an undiagnosed aortic dissection.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: It's illegal for a college, public school or employer to "mandate" the vaccine because it was authorized for emergency use.
Justification: There are no legal mechanisms in place that would prevent any institution, whether it’s an employer or school, from mandating COVID-19 shots, though exemptions can be made for those with certain disabilities or sincerely held religious beliefs, as provided by theAmericans with Disabilities Actand theCivil Rights Act of 1964.
Sources: Phone interview with Dr. Dorit Rubinstein Reiss

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A leaked email from a Liberal Party politician shows the Canadian government's plan to “reset” the economy and seize private property.
Justification: • The email purportedly came from a member of the "Strategic Planning Committee" of Canada, but no such committee exists.• The claim echoes aspects of a widely debunked conspiracy theory known as the "Great Reset." ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photos show Joe Biden didn’t drive himself during an electric vehicle test drive.
Justification: President Joe Biden took a brief test drive in the new electric F-150 Lightning pick-up after delivering remarks on a proposal for American-made electric vehicles and touring a new Ford Motor plant in Michigan on May 18. The Secret Service agent next to Biden was handling a camera on the dashboard, not a second steering wheel.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Chelsea Clinton tweeted, "If Jesus were alive today he'd be working at Planned Parenthood."
Justification: A spokesperson for Chelsea Clinton’s office said this tweet is fake.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Social media posts stated: “Remember Kamala telling Joe during the debate, ‘You will do whatever the Chinese tell you! They gave your son over a billion dollars.’”
Justification: An image shared across multiple social media platforms, including Facebook and Twitter, falsely quotes Vice President Kamala Harris, claiming she said during the Democratic debates that President Joe Biden would do "whatever" the Chinese government said because they gave Hunter Biden "over a billion dollars." Harris never said this, according to transcripts of the Democratic debates. In fact, there is no record of her ever making this statement anywhere. The quote appears to have originated from a pro-Trump Twitter account, @BlessUSA2024, on Jan. 23, 2021. It was then shared by a Facebook Page run by Activated Patriots, a conservative group based in Wisconsin.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Wearing face masks may cause "pulmonary fibrosis" and other health risks in children.
Justification: A flier for an anti-mask rally in Orange County on Monday made claims that children are at risk for serious health diseases such as pulmonary fibrosis. Experts say there is no evidence of this. The flier grabbed the debunked health claims from a theoretical medical journal that claimed to be associated with Stanford University.
Sources: Science Brief: Community Use of Cloth Masks to Control the Spread of SARS-CoV-2

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden is computer generated.”
Justification: Joe Biden briefly appeared before reporters on the White House grounds on March 17. He was not a "holographic image."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “For #Covid vaccines, shingles and even more dangerous and painful skin conditions may be the new thrombocytopenia."
Justification: COVID-19 vaccinations do not infect recipients with shingles or any form of herpes virus, despite some misleading headlines. It is plausible, but unproven, that COVID-19 vaccines could fuel a reactivation of existing, but dormant, herpes virus in some people. An Israeli study found that six women out of a group of nearly 500 people came down with shingles in the days and weeks following vaccination. All six had autoimmune diseases making them more susceptible to shingles. Also, the study was not designed to determine cause and effect. Some other vaccines have shown to reactivate the virus that causes shingles, but so far there is no definitive proof that COVID-19 vaccines do so.
Sources: National Organization for Rare Disorders rare-disease database
Telephone interview with Dr. Amesh Adalja
Telephone interview with Dr. William Schaffner
The New England Journal of Medicine

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Washington Post ends fact-checking for Biden for the remainder of his presidency.”
Justification: • The Washington Post announced on April 26 that it will no longer update a database of Biden fact-checks searchable by date, source and topic. However, it will continue to fact-check the President.• Since the announcement, the Post has fact-checked Biden. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Gas prices highest in a decade. Worst jobs report in 2 decades. Highest inflation in 3 decades. Highest increase in illegal immigration in 4 decades.”
Justification: • Prices for gasoline and consumer products are spiking as a result of the post-pandemic economic recovery. However, they are not at the historical levels cited in the post.• While the April 2021 jobs report was disappointing, it’s far from the worst ever.• The claim of illegal immigration being at record highs is at best speculative, with final numbers not known until this fall.
Sources: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An electromagnetic radiation detector can detect radiation from someone’s COVID-19 vaccination.
Justification: • All human bodies emit some level of radiation.• Experts say there’s no way that a COVID-19 vaccine could impact the amount of radiation a person gives off.• Even after decades of research, there is no evidence that exposure to low-level electromagnetic fields impacts a person’s health.
Sources: Email exchange with Dr. Gregory Poland
Iowa State University of Science and Technology

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says photos show a “boneyard” of electric cars abandoned in France because the cars’ batteries were too expensive to replace.
Justification: Electric cars shown in a field in France are from a fleet of a car-sharing service that failed. The cars are being resold or sold for parts.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Foot Locker donated 200 million dollars to BLM.”
Justification: A Facebook post claims Foot Locker donated $200 million to Black Lives Matter. The company did say it would dedicate $200 million over the next five years toward helping the Black community. Black Lives Matter has not received any large donations from Foot Locker.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Moderna chief medical officer admits: mRNA alters DNA.”
Justification: Messenger RNA vaccines do not alter DNA. In 2017, Moderna’s chief medical officer gave a TED Talk about mRNA and discussed the potential for an mRNA vaccine against the flu. But he didn’t say such vaccines alter DNA.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jay-Z and Beyonce are buying back DMX’s masters for $10 Million and giving to his kids for free.”
Justification: A statement from DMX’s family confirms "no one" purchased rights to DMX’s original seven studio albums.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Bill Gates fights to keep vaccine ingredients secret.”
Justification: Bill Gates has defended intellectual property rights for COVID-19 vaccine manufacturers, but the ingredients in COVID-19 vaccines approved for use in the United States are already public.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Kids in cages" in border facilities are "at 700% capacity."
Justification: News reports in March said a tent complex in Texas, a temporary U.S. border facility holding minors who cross the Mexico border, was at 700% or more of its capacity. Children sleep in see-through plastic pods. The minors arrived unaccompanied and are being housed because of the Biden administration’s policy not to return them to Mexico. The Trump administration was criticized for "kids in cages" — using chain-link enclosures to temporarily house children — because of its practice, from April to June of 2018, of separating children from their parents at the border.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A quarter of a million illegal votes found in Arizona’s audit.”
Justification: The company overseeing a Republican-backed audit of the presidential election results in Maricopa County, Arizona, has not released the results of its analysis. A former adviser to former President Donald Trump has speculated that there were about 250,000 possible illegal votes in the county.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Derek Chauvin had his left hand in his pocket while kneeling on George Floyd.
Justification: Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin wore black gloves and dark pants as he pinned George Floyd to the ground with his knee. As a result, some screen grabs from a bystander’s video of the incident show the color of his gloves blended in with that of his pants. The screen grabs circulating on social media gave the false impression that Chauvin’s left hand was in his pocket. He was actually holding his knuckles to his thigh. USA Today enhanced the brightness and exposure of the screen grabs circulating on social media to accentuate the placement of Chauvin’s hand on his thigh.
Sources: Email and phone interviews with Matthew Stamm

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Derek Chauvin’s trial and conviction for the murder of George Floyd was faked as part of a “false flag.”
Justification: Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin was convicted by a jury of two counts of murder and one count of manslaughter after killing George Floyd in May 2020. Chauvin was present in court but chose not to testify. Several witnesses who did testify were asked by the prosecution to identify Chauvin for the jury in court. In a statement to PolitiFact, Hennepin County Attorney Mike Freeman said Chauvin "is the same person the world has seen on video, in the courtroom and being led away in handcuffs to the maximum security prison at Oak Park Heights." "False flag" conspiracy theories regularly claim that major news events were staged or did not happen. This claim traces back to a QAnon-promoting Telegram account.
Sources: Statement from Hennepin County Attorney Mike Freeman
Twitter direct message exchange with Mike Rothschild

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Children ages 5 to 9 “are not affected by” the coronavirus.
Justification: Most children who get COVID-19 have mild or no symptoms; severe illness is rare. More than 3.6 million children in the U.S. have tested positive, and at least 297 have died. Children can spread the virus to others, even if they don’t have symptoms, which is a key reason for mask requirements in schools.
Sources: Kansas Department of Health and Environment
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden and the Democrats want to remove any term that denotes gender.”
Justification: Biden changed WhiteHouse.gov so that people contacting the White House can identify themselves without a specific gender, but it does not eliminate traditional gender options. Biden’s administration reportedly is considering a gender-neutral designation on federal documents such as passports, consistent with a campaign pledge he made, but traditional gender options would remain. In a party-line vote, the Democratic-led House of Representatives changed its rules document to replace gender-specific references with neutral ones. But the changes apply only to the verbiage in the rules document itself.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Donald Trump returning to Washington “in a blaze of glory on Air Force 1.”
Justification: This video clip was taken in December 2020, when then-President Donald Trump and Melania Trump flew to Florida for Christmas.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden says Americans can only celebrate the Fourth of July if he says so.”
Justification: Biden in March said that if Americans followed COVID-19 safety guidelines, there was a "good chance" they could gather in "small groups" to celebrate the Fourth of July. In April, he urged Americans to wear masks and get vaccinated. He alluded to his March remarks about July Fourth gatherings, but did not say anything more about them. Biden has not said that he might cancel Fourth of July gatherings.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: COVID-19 “has killed less people than the damn flu.”
Justification: About 3.1 million people around the worldhave died of COVID-19since the first case was reported in December 2019. The flu kills an estimated 290,000 to 650,000 people every year worldwide. The average number of U.S. flu deaths has been about 36,000 a year over the past decade. In the United States, about 572,549 people have so far died of COVID-19.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Japan’s prime minister met with Vice President Kamala Harris holding a Trump 2024 sign and wearing a red baseball cap.
Justification: This video was manipulated. Japan Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga was not holding a Trump 2024 sign or wearing a red hat when he met with Vice President Kamala Harris.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says LeBron James said, “We’re at the point where a girl can’t even stab her friends anymore.”
Justification: The quote was made up by a satirical website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Biden Administration is buying Kamala Harris’ book with our taxpayer dollars.”
Justification: Officials say that a single copy of a 2019 children’s book written by the vice president was donated as part of a book and toy drive in Long Beach, Calif., where migrant children are temporarily staying in a shelter.
Sources: Long Beach Convention and Visitors Bureau tweet
Long Beach Toy & Book Drive website

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A McDonald’s restaurant in Elkton, Md., was permanently closed “due to a sex trafficking investigation.”
Justification: This claim is false, according to the town and police.
Sources: Town of Elkton MD Facebook post

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A serial killer is on the loose in Virginia.
Justification: Since November 2020, the bodies of three women have been recovered from different bodies of water in Norfolk, Va., but police say no foul play is suspected.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Two photos show climate change “is a hoax.”
Justification: Water’s-edge photographs don’t show changes in sea level over time. Global sea levels are rising and climate change is the primary reason.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Maxine Waters could be “sentenced” for “jury tampering.”
Justification: An image shared more than 4,700 times on Facebook claimed that U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters, a California Democrat, could be "sentenced" for "jury tampering." Days before a jury convicted former police officer Derek Chauvin of murdering George Floyd, Waters told protesters in Brooklyn Center, Minnesota, that if he wasn’t convicted, they should "get more confrontational." Chauvin is expected to file for appeal, and Waters’ comments on the trial might have an impact on the outcome of his request, according to legal experts. However, there is no evidence that Waters tried to unduly influence jurors’ deliberations. And she would not be charged or "sentenced" for those actions.
Sources: Cornell Law Library Legal Information Institute

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “70% of Americans don't believe a word the mainstream media puts out,” so “everyone who thinks Biden won are only 30% of the population.”
Justification: • According to the most recent Gallup poll, 33% of adults distrust the media entirely, about half of the 70% cited in the post.• Meanwhile, the most recent poll asking about Biden’s legitimacy found that 66% believed he was legitimately elected, which is twice as high as the 30% cited in the post.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “McDonald’s and Coke have both announced no whites will be hired in top positions.”
Justification: Both companies have announced goals to diversify their workforces but they did not say or suggest that they won’t be hiring white people to top leadership positions.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hobby Lobby’s CEO wrote a letter saying the company’s stores may close.
Justification: In 2012 Hobby Lobby CEO David Green wrote a column in USA Today explaining why he was suing the federal government over a provision in the Affordable Care Act. He did not say that the company’s stores could close.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the nation is locked down and there’s “a wide open border.”
Justification: The post is wrong on both counts. There is no nationwide lockdown. Many schools and businesses are open and no state is mandating a stay-at-home order. Thousands of people are arriving at the southern border, but most are being expelled.

Speaker: facebook-posts
