Main Claim: Women’s menstrual cycles and fertility are affected by being around people who have received COVID-19 vaccines
Justification: There are no elements in any of the vaccines that can be passed to another person by proxy. The CDChas advisedthat all authorized COVID-19 vaccines are safe for people who are pregnant and that there is no evidence that shots yield fertility problems or miscarriages.
Sources: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases (NCIRD) at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “This is all about a certificate of vaccination where they get you a national ID, and then the AI can track you.”
Justification: The federal government does not require issuance of a proof-of-vaccination card or, in this case, a biological "national ID." While it’s true there are businesses in the private sector that may require proof of vaccination to render services, it’s a far cry from a government-imposed national mandate. There is no evidence to suggest that COVID-19 vaccinations, once injected, create an invisible, trackable ID in the bodies of those inoculated. Receiving a COVID-19 vaccine does not allow an "AI" system to track your whereabouts
Sources: Acuitas Therapeutics Pfizer/ BioNTech trial results release
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention COVID-19 information page

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Schools stopped teaching children cursive so they wouldn’t be able to read the U.S. Constitution and other historical documents.
Justification: The U.S. Constitution and other historical documents have been archived, reprinted and digitized many times to make them widely accessible and readable. Many public schools stopped teaching cursive writing after it was dropped from Common Core standards in 2010 because of its waning relevance.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: By clicking on a link from a fake USPS text message, “you are sending your precise location to sex traffickers in your local area” so they can kidnap you.
Justification: A claim that sex traffickers are sending out scam USPS text messages to track people’s locations has been making rounds on social media. Experts say that the texts are fake, but it’s a scam to induce people to provide their identity or financial information. There’s no evidence this is linked to sex trafficking.
Sources: Email interview with the United States Postal Inspection Service

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The knife was on the ground when police arrived at the scene of Ma’Khia Bryant shooting.
Justification: Body camera footage released by Columbus police shows that a knife was in Bryant’s hand, not on the ground, when the officer first fired his gun. It hasn’t been confirmed whether it was Bryant who first called the police for help, and we don’t know the details of what happened before the police arrived.
Sources: Columbus Division of Police news conference

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pope Francis is dead.”
Justification: Pope Francis is alive and addressed the public April 21.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Jimmy Kimmel, Jimmy Fallon and Stephen Colbert are “still not doing Biden jokes."
Justification: This is inaccurate. Late night hosts have included Biden in their monologues and nightly shows.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Google Earth blocked people from seeing the Suez Canal.
Justification: The difference in water color for a portion of the canal is due to a day-to-day difference of lighting conditions and camera angles, which can cause color inconsistencies when satellite imagery is stitched together. The same effect can be seen in other locations on Google Earth.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Nostradamus predicted that a “feeble man” would rule the “Western World” after a time of “plague.”
Justification: • There is no mention of this prophecy outside of recent posts on social media websites.• The verses cited contain anachronisms that weren’t in use at the time when Nostradamus was writing. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Colorado “requires photo ID to vote in person, requires signature verification for mail-in ballots, which Georgia got rid of, and prevents campaign workers from giving food, water to voters within 100 feet if they’re wearing campaign apparel.”
Justification: Colorado does not require a photo ID to vote in person. Colorado does verify signatures on a mail-in ballot against its database of voter signatures, a process Georgia replaced with a new requirement for proof of identity. Colorado prohibits people wearing campaign gear from handing out food and water to voters waiting in line;  Georgia prohibits anyone from doing so.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "New poll indicates” Joe Biden’s “approval at 11%, the lowest approval rating of any president in American history."
Justification: Biden’s approval rating in the latest Gallup poll is 54%. An averaging of approval polls says his approval rating is 53.2%.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Georgia’s new voting law “makes it a JAIL-TIME CRIME to drop off grandma’s absentee ballot in a dropbox.”
Justification: Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp signed a sweeping elections bill into law in March. It includes various provisions about in-person and absentee voting. One section of the bill states that it is a felony to take someone’s absentee ballot and deliver it or return it to election officials, unless you fall under a long list of exceptions. The exceptions allow various relatives — including children, grandchildren and spouses — to return a ballot on behalf of their family members.
Sources: Georgia Public Radio reporter Stephen Fowler
U.S. District Court Northern District of Georgia Atlanta Division

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A map shows “all the cargo ships backed up by the Suez Canal. Get ready for shortages and prices to skyrocket.”
Justification: The map in the post shows bodies of water around the Arabian Sea, not the Suez Canal, which connects the Red Sea to the Mediterranean. Experts don’t expect the six-day blockage at the canal to have much impact on supplies or prices in the U.S.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A serial killer is targeting women in Hot Springs, Ark.
Justification: The body of a woman was recently found in Hot Springs National Park in Arkansas, but authorities say their investigation indicates this is an isolated incident. We found no evidence to support rumors related to this case that there are as many as five victims who died at the hands of a serial killer.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the “1986 Vaccine protection act” resulted in “the biggest jump in shots” for children because it gave drug manufacturers “exemption for responsibility of killing people.”
Justification: Congress passed the 1986 National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act in response to lawsuits filed against vaccine manufacturers in the 1970s in which people claimed they were injured after receiving a vaccination but did not provide sufficient evidence. While the number of recommended vaccines did increase after the law was enacted it wasn’t a dramatic jump, as the first new addition to the schedule didn’t come until 1994. Today, the CDC recommends 12 vaccines from birth to age 18, protecting against 16 diseases.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Less than 500 people a year killed by all rifles combined” and “4,000 a year killed by illegals.”
Justification: Fewer than 500 people were murdered with a rifle in 2019, according to the latest annual FBI statistics. Gun-ban proposals have focused on assault-style weapons, not rifles generally. No national statistics are kept on the number of people killed by people who are in the United States illegally, but available estimates indicate it’s far fewer than 4,000 per year.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video says COVID-19 vaccines are “weapons of mass destruction” that “could wipe out the human race.”
Justification: • The claim that the vaccines are being used to kill a large portion of the world’s population is rooted in the widely-debunked "Great Reset" and "Agenda 21" conspiracy theories.• There is no evidence that deaths have been caused by COVID-19 vaccines.• PolitiFact has previously debunked Vernon Coleman’s conspiracy theories about the COVID-19 vaccines.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Toxicology report was made public by the MN prosecution revealing the cause of George Floyd’s death was a fentanyl overdose.”
Justification: Two autopsy reports said the manner of George Floyd’s death was a homicide. Neither said the cause of his death was a fentanyl overdose. The Hennepin County medical examiner found fentanyl in Floyd’s system, but the autopsy said the cause of his death was "cardiopulmonary arrest complicating law-enforcement subdual restraint, and neck compression." Experts told the Washington Post they did not believe Floyd died from the fentanyl.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the suspected Boulder mass shooter is a Muslim "who entered illegally from Mexico and purchased the firearm from a guy that sells stolen guns."
Justification: Ahmad Al Aliwi Alissa apparently is Muslim, based on his online posts and comments from family and friends. There’s no evidence that Alissa’s family, who emigrated to the U.S. from Syria when he was a toddler, entered the U.S. illegally from Mexico. There’s no evidence Alissa purchased a gun illegally. Alissa had legally purchased from a gun store one of the two guns found at the scene, according to police.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If I don’t take the vaccine, I’m at risk for covid. If I do take the vaccine, I’m still at risk for covid PLUS I’m at risk for permanent vaccine side effects. Therefore I’m reducing my risk by not taking the vaccine. That’s the real science.”
Justification: Getting vaccinated reduced the likelihood of COVID-19 infection by as much as 95% in clinical trials. If you get vaccinated and still get COVID-19, vaccines make it less likely that you’ll get seriously ill. There is no evidence of permanent side effects.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Ben Shapiro said on Twitter that his “red pill moment” was sharing cupcakes with poor kids.
Justification: This is not a real post by Ben Shapiro. The screenshot came from a satirical subreddit.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "mRNA is not a vaccine" — it's "actually an operating system" that's run by Bill Gates to program humans.
Justification: The COVID-19 vaccines help prevent the spread of the coronavirus. They are not part of a Bill Gates-run plot to program humans.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: If the voting bill H.R. 1 is passed, “absentee ballots would be mailed out to anyone without proof of the voter’s identity.”
Justification: • A few states already do send ballots to all registered voters, but their process would not be changed by the bill. In every other state, voters would need to choose to receive a mail ballot by notifying election officials.• In addition, anyone receiving a ballot by mail must be registered, which means that election officials will know their identity.• The bill does require states to send mail ballot application forms to all registered voters before federal elections, but sending an application is not the same thing as sending an actual ballot.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Passports aren’t required to enter the United States from Mexico and Canada.
Justification: A valid passport is generally required to enter any of these countries, but eligible travelers can apply for other documents that prove their citizenship that they can use in some circumstances instead.
Sources: U.S. Embassy and Consulates in Mexico

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Ford agreed to invest $900 million at an Ohio plant because Donald Trump “lowered taxes” and is now moving the project to Mexico because Joe Biden is “increasing taxes.”
Justification: The United Auto Workers union told its members that Ford is shifting a vehicle project to Mexico that it had planned to build in Ohio. Ford has not confirmed whether it is making such a shift, but said "the business decision in question was not a result of then-presidential candidate Biden’s corporate tax proposals."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Rachel Levine was Time magazine's "Woman of the Year."
Justification: A Facebook post purports to show Rachel Levine, a transgender woman, on the cover of Time magazine as the magazine’s "Woman of the Year." The cover is fake. A Time spokesperson confirmed that the cover isn’t real. It originated as satire.
Sources: Various reverse image searches on Google
Various reverse image searches on TinEye

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Ted Cruz says owning a gun should be as hassle free as owning a car, which as I recall requires a license and registration."
Justification: PolitiFact found no evidence that Sen. Ted Cruz said "owning a gun should be as hassle free as owning a car." A Cruz spokesperson said the senator never said that.
Sources: Correspondence with Sen. Ted Cruz’s office

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Nike and Lil Nas X are launching “demonic shoes” containing human blood.
Justification: • Lil Nas X and a Brooklyn arts collective called MSCHF are releasing adapted Nike shoes that feature Satan references and a drop of human blood mixed into the sole.• Nike isn’t partnering with Lil Nas X on the project. A Nike spokesperson told us that the company did not design or release the shoes and doesn’t endorse them. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: U.S. Rep. Matt Gaetz was the lone vote in the House against an anti-human trafficking bill.
Justification: The New York Times reported that the Justice Department is investigating whether U.S. Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., violated human trafficking laws. Gaetz said the allegations about him are false. Social media posts juxtaposed the Justice Department investigation with Gaetz’s lone no vote in 2017 against a human trafficking bill that created an advisory committee. In explaining his no vote, Gaetz said it’s important to combat human trafficking. But he said he generally opposes legislation that creates new federal entities if existing federal agencies could handle the problem.
Sources: Department of Transportation Advisory Committee on Human Trafficking final report

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “We spent billions on a border wall and quit when it was 90% finished.”
Justification: Contracts for construction at the southern border total billions of dollars, and Biden has directed a pause in construction. But construction was not 90% finished.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “In a vegan world there would be no pandemics. 100% of pandemics are zoonotic in origin.”
Justification: Worldwide adherence to veganism would not eradicate pandemics. There are other sources by which disease can emerge — and consuming animals is not the only path by which disease can make the jump from animals to humans.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Suez Canal blocked by huge container ship named Evergreen. Evergreen shipping is most likely a cover for human and sex trafficking” by Hillary Clinton.
Justification: There is no evidence that an Evergreen ship stuck in the Suez Canal is linked to a human trafficking operation run by Hillary Clinton. That claim has been pushed by supporters of the baseless QAnon conspiracy theory.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Minority farmers get big bonus, white ones get none,” because of Democrats.
Justification: The COVID-19 relief plan signed into law in March 2021 includes an estimated $5 billion, mostly to pay off debt, for socially disadvantaged farmers — those in groups such as Blacks, Hispanics and Native Americans whose members have been subjected to racial or ethnic prejudice.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Former Las Vegas Raiders offensive tackle Bruce Campbell involved in altercation.”
Justification: The person who first tweeted this video didn’t identify the people involved in the fight. The claim that it was ex-NFL player Bruce Campbell appears to have originated as an attempted joke. There’s no evidence a man in the video is Campbell.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pete Buttigieg’s dog and pony show. He gets out of [the] car to ride his bike a few feet, pretending to save energy.”
Justification: Video captured by a CNN journalist showed Buttigieg flanked by a security detail as he rode a bike following a White House Cabinet meeting. A spokesperson for the Transportation Department said Buttigieg rode his bike to the White House and back to department headquarters after the meeting.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden puts pro-life groups on domestic extremist list, calls pro-life people ‘violent.’”
Justification: Biden ordered a federal assessment of the threat posed by domestic violent extremism. The assessment lists several categories of domestic, violent extremist groups, including ones with "ideological agendas in support of pro-life or pro-choice beliefs." The assessment does not list anti-abortion groups generally as being domestic violence extremist groups.
Sources: U.S. Office of the Director of National Intelligence

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The $1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief bill "awards a $25 million bonus" to House members.
Justification: Nothing in the bill would give any bonus to members of the House or Senate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says President Joe Biden promoted "mandatory vaccines for everybody" in his March 11 address.
Justification: In a March 11 address to the nation, President Joe Biden said the White House would direct state, local and tribal governments to make all American adults eligible to sign up for a COVID-19 vaccine by May 1. He did not say vaccines would be mandatory. Biden previously said he would not institute a federal vaccine requirement. In any case, the federal government’s authority to do so is limited.
Sources: David J. Harris Jr. on Facebook

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Illegal aliens will receive $1,400 stimulus checks.”
Justification: With some exceptions, only people who have a Social Security number can receive a $1,400 stimulus check for themselves. The vast majority of immigrants who are in the country illegally don’t have a Social Security number. The law would still pay $1,400 for each of their dependents who has a Social Security number.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says El Chapo testified in court that he paid off Nancy Pelosi to keep the U.S.-Mexico border open for drug cartels.
Justification: Infamous Mexican drug lord Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán didn’t testify that he paid off U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to keep the U.S.-Mexico border open for drug cartels. He never took the stand during his trial.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "80% of people taking the Moderna vaccine had significant side effects, via Bill Gates."
Justification: Gates was asked in July about 80% of the people in an early trial of Moderna’s COVID-19 vaccine reporting "systemic" side effects such as severe chills and fever. Gates did not say that 80% of people who took that vaccine experienced significant side effects. A U.S. Food and Drug Administration report in December said 0.5% of 15,184 people who received the Moderna vaccine experienced a "severe adverse event."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Finally, a judge has ruled Dominion voting machines were designed to create fraud.”
Justification: A judge ruled in December that an "audit report" on voting in the 2020 presidential election in Antrim County, Mich., be released to the public. The judge did not issue any ruling about the contents of the report. The report, discredited by elections officials, was from a firm thatprovidedanalyses and affidavits for lawsuits brought by allies of Donald Trump,falselyallegingvoter fraud and election irregularities.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Fauci admits he isn’t listening to the science when advocating policy.”
Justification: Anthony Fauci said in a CNN interview that making a "judgment call" was necessary when scientific evidence isn’t available, but he didn’t say he’s not listening to science when he supports COVID-19 policies.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A CNN chyron said the Boulder “shooter was factually Arabic, but morally white.”
Justification: The chyron is fake and did not run on the air, CNN said and PolitiFact confirmed. It was created by the Babylon Bee, a satire website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pelosi’s $1.9 trillion bailout gives EVERY federal employee a $21,000 bonus check… they never lost their job!”
Justification: The law allocates money for an expanded paid-leave fund for federal workers dealing with certain COVID-19-related matters. There is no bonus check. It covers leave that would otherwise be unpaid.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Vaccines send the immune system into “perpetual overdrive” by instructing cells to keep “making the protein of an invader, nonstop, forever and ever.”
Justification: The COVID-19 vaccines that use mRNA technology do not instruct the immune system to make the virus’ spike proteins forever. The mRNA instructions are given at the time of vaccination and are broken down by the body within days.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Burisma admitted in a Ukrainian court to paying Joe Biden $900,000.
Justification: There's no evidence that any such statement was made in court or any new evidence that Joe Biden got money from Burisma.
Sources: Council on Foreign Relations Transcript of Speaking Event ft. Joe Biden
Transcript of Remarks by Then-Vice President Joe Biden to the Ukrainian Rada in Kyiv
Ukraine Prosecutor Says No Evidence of Wrongdoing By Bidens
Video clip from "The Sean Hannity Show"

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden and Kamala Harris forced our troops to sleep on the floor of a garage, yet has authorized $89 million for hotel rooms for illegal immigrants.”
Justification: • The National Guard told PolitiFact that the request to move the troops is believed to have come from a Capitol Police officer acting on his own authority, not from Joe Biden or Kamala Harris.• Axios and Fox have reported that the Biden administration has awarded a contract to use hotel rooms to house and process migrant families. But the contract was for $86 million, not $89 million. Previous administrations, including Donald Trump’s, have used hotels to process migrant families. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Oprah Winfrey for years “pimped young Hollywood girls to Harvey Weinstein to be raped.”
Justification: Oprah Winfrey was once friends with the disgraced entertainment mogul, as many others were, but there is no evidence to corroborate the claim that she arranged or helped Weinstein sexually abuse women.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Nevada AG admits to changing signature verifications manually for over 200,000 votes.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that Nevada Attorney General Aaron Ford said he manually changed more than 200,000 signature verifications during the 2020 election. A former attorney general and campaign chair for former President Donald Trump’s campaign complained about a machine one Nevada county used to verify signatures, saying 200,000 were verified on a setting that could let fraudulent signatures through.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's net worth is “over $1 million.”
Justification: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's latest financial disclosure form showed assets of between $2,003 and $31,000. Her liabilities were listed at between $15,001 and $50,000, indicating that she may have a negative net worth.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Donald J. Trump’s signature is on the new stimulus checks.”
Justification: The Biden White House and the Treasury Department said the checks will be signed by a Treasury official.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Atlanta shooting suspect wrote an anti-China post on Facebook prior to the shootings.
Justification: The post isn’t legitimate and didn’t come from an authentic Facebook account. It was made using an online generator that creates fake Facebook status updates. A Facebook spokesperson confirmed that the post isn’t real and said the screenshots will be removed from the platform.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows a recent White House event was actually filmed at Tyler Perry Studios in Atlanta.
Justification: This is bogus. The photo was not taken at Tyler Perry’s film studio in Georgia. The image shows the signing ceremony of the American Rescue Plan, the government’s $1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief bill. It was held outside the Oval Office at the White House Rose Garden in Washington, D.C., on March 12.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The movie “I am Legend” was based in the year 2021 and people turned into zombies “because of the wrong vaccine.”
Justification: This is inaccurate. The movie was set in 2012, not 2021. The story is about "mutant-like vampires," not zombies, and the outbreak was caused by a genetically-modified virus meant to cure cancer, not a vaccine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Under HR 1, a person can still vote if they are 16, in the U.S. illegally, have no ID and have not registered to vote
Justification: H.R. 1 combines proposals for voter registration, absentee voting, in-person voting, campaign finance and ethics related to federal elections. The House passed the bill March 3 and it now goes to the Senate. The bill would allow 16-year-olds to preregister to vote, but it does not change state voting age requirements. A proposed amendment to lower the voting age to 16 failed. The bill allows only eligible citizens to vote.
Sources: Brennan Center for Justice at NYU

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden executive orders caused price increases of 50 cents in gas and 10% in food.
Justification: The average price of gas is about 34 cents per gallon higher since Biden took office. Experts say Biden’s orders on the Keystone pipeline and oil and gas leasing might affect future gas prices, but have no effect on current prices. Grocery store prices are 3.5% higher than they were one year ago and have risen less than 1% in 2021.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Diesel prices jumped from $1.69 to $3.19 since Biden took office, and the president is to blame.
Justification: Gas and diesel prices have steadily risen in recent months, but it's not related to any presidential policies. Prices dropped as demand dropped amid the pandemic shutdown. But with the COVID-19 picture improving and people moving around more, increased demand is pushing prices up as well. Oil producers will need time to ramp up production to pre-pandemic levels after throttling output throughout 2020.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There are nanoparticles in the COVID-19 vaccine that will help people “locate you” via 5G networks.
Justification: • There is no evidence that the approved COVID-19 vaccines contain technology similar to microchips implanted in pets.• Lipid nanoparticles are among some of the ingredients used in COVID-19 vaccines.• The term "nanoparticle" refers only to size; it has nothing to do with 5G network technology.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Georgia House passed a bill that “makes it a misdemeanor to give food or water to voters waiting in line.”
Justification: Georgia lawmakers have introduced dozens of measures that would overhaul rules for in-person and absentee voting. Georgia HB 531 would make it a misdemeanor to give voters in line food or water. The state House passed the bill. Existing Georgia law states that it is a crime to give gifts to voters.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Oprah Winfrey was wearing an ankle monitor during her Meghan Markle interview.
Justification: There’s nothing to support the recurring claim that Oprah Winfrey is hiding an ankle monitor.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Texas has launched ‘Operation Lone Star’ to finish the border wall themselves.”
Justification: Texas launched Operation Lone Star to combat the smuggling of people and drugs. It was later expanded to also address human trafficking related to illegal border crossings.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden is “now saying he inherited ‘a mess’ at the border. Fact: 9,000 illegals all of 2020. So far in 2021 108,000 entered U.S.”
Justification: President Joe Biden never said he inherited "a mess" at the border from the Trump administration. That comment came from Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer. There were 172,286 southwest border encounters in January and February. Of those encounters, 39,572 were apprehensions. During the 2020 fiscal year, there were 400,651 encounters — more than 200,000 of which were apprehensions.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The “president of Drag Queen Story Hour” was “arrested, charged with child pornography.”
Justification: • Drag Queen Story Hour is a large organization with over 40 chapters in the U.S. and additional chapters in Europe, Australia, Mexico and Japan.• Milwaukee County Circuit Judge Brett Blomme was recently charged for possession of child pornography. He formerly headed a nonprofit called Cream City Foundation.• Cream City Foundation was a "fiscal sponsor" of the Milwaukee chapter of Drag Queen Story Hour, but it played no role in the chapter’s operations. ​Blomme never held any position within Drag Queen Story Hour Milwaukee, much less served as president of the national umbrella organization.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The shooting in Boulder, Colo., was a "false flag like most of the others."
Justification: The Boulder, Colo., shooting wasn’t staged. A gunman killed 10 people at a grocery store.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says “Fallon (Fox), a transgender MMA fighter, has now broken 2 female opponents’ skulls,” and shows a photo of Fox alongside an MMA fighter with a severely bloodied face.
Justification: • During her two-year Mixed Martial Arts career, Fallon Fox fractured one opponent’s orbital bone, also known as the eye socket. In the past, Fox has characterized the injury to her opponent as a skull fracture.• The photo of the woman with the bloodied face was from an MMA fight that did not involve Fox and which took place several years after Fox’s last MMA bout.• MMA is a combat sport and has an overallhigh rate of injury.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows an ice mass hanging inside a Houston home during Texas winter storms.
Justification: The photo was widely shared starting in January 2018 and appears to be from Watertown, N.Y.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Rachel Levine supports “government-funded sex reassignment surgery without parental notification or authorization” for all children.
Justification: • In a 2017 lecture, Levine said that "there are no treatments" for prepubescent children with gender dysphoria.• Performing genital surgery on prepubescent children violates professional standards of transgender medicine.• Gender reassignment surgery is widely restricted to adults over the age of 18.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
World Professional Association for Transgender Health

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Only Nancy Pelosi is “responsible for what happened at the Capitol” on Jan. 6, “security at the Capitol is her job.”
Justification: Capitol security is not solely the responsibility of the House speaker. It is provided by the sergeants-at-arms of the House and Senate, and by the Capitol Police. The House sergeant-at-arms reports to the House speaker, or Pelosi at the time of the attack. The Senate sergeant-at-arms reports to the Senate majority leader — on Jan. 6, Sen. Mitch McConnell. News reports indicate that in the days before the attack,  House sergeant-at-arms Paul Irving resisted calls from the Capitol Police to bring in the National Guard for extra security at the Capitol because of "optics." Irving later testified that intelligence reports didn’t show the need for the extra security, not that he rejected it because of optics.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “FEMA is paying for hotel rooms!!!” for Texas winter storm victims.
Justification: The Federal Emergency Management Agency called the claim a "scam."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The snow is government-generated or fake.
Justification: • Ice and snow have different physical properties. Snowballs initially don’t appear to melt in the presence of heat because the water gets absorbed into the remaining snow.• The butane fueling most lighters produces soot, which plates itself over snowballs, making it appear as if the snowballs are turning black. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The Texas power grid is not part of the US power grid because they wanted to avoid federal regulation.”
Justification: • In the 1930s, Texas energy companies opted for a power grid that didn’t cross state lines to prevent federal regulators from interfering in electrical sales.• In the years since, Texas regulators have fought against federal oversight in major legal battles. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Oil is now $61.30 a barrel and rising drastically! On Jan. 5, it was about $25 a barrel.”
Justification: Neither of the two primary benchmarks for crude oil have been in the $25 per barrel range since May 2020. Both benchmarks were roughly in the $61 range at the time of the Facebook post. But that’s up from about $50 — not $25 — on Jan. 5.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “America has 133 million registered voters,” but “159 million votes” were cast in the 2020 presidential election.
Justification: Experts say as many as 215 million voters were registered for the 2020 election. That far outnumbers the 159 million ballots cast.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The United States was energy independent in 2019 for the first time since 1957. In just 10 days we are sent back 50 years.”
Justification: In 2019, U.S. energy production exceeded U.S. energy consumption on an annual basis for the first time since 1957. That’s one definition of energy independence. The U.S. continues to import millions of barrels of petroleum per day. It’s impossible to say whether the executive orders President Joe Biden signed during his first days in office would reduce current production levels below U.S. consumption needs.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says President Joe Biden canceled Trump’s “child sex ring operation, which saw thousands of arrests last year.”
Justification: Operation Talon was created to target immigrants in the country illegally with sex crime convictions, not solely child sex offenders, and it was shelved by ICE, not Biden, as the agency awaits new operating guidelines from the new administration. There’s no evidence that the program, which is said to have started weeks before Trump left office, was already in operation or responsible for thousands of arrests.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Utah OFFICIALLY starts RECALL for Mitt Romney.”
Justification: A petition is circulating to let residents vote on whether to be able to recall a U.S. senator, but Utah hasn’t started recalling Mitt Romney. The U.S. Constitution "does not provide for nor authorize the recall of United States officers such as senators, representatives, or the president or vice president,"according to the Congressional Research Service.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Facebook users can avoid “problems with your Facebook going against community standards” by changing your settings.
Justification: Facebook’s rules "apply to everyone, all around the world, and to all types of content."
Sources: Email from Facebook spokesperson Kevin McAlister

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi bought $1.5 million “in foreign oil stock day before shut down of American line.”
Justification: • There is no evidence that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi purchased stock in foreign oil companies before the Keystone pipeline project was halted on Jan. 20.• Pelosi’s transaction report filed Jan. 21 does not list any trades involving oil companies.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Heidi Cruz, Ted’s wife, is managing director of Goldman Sachs. They oversee the Texas utilities.”
Justification: Heidi Cruz is a managing director of a Goldman Sachs division, but the financial services company doesn’t oversee Texas utilities. Electric utilities in Texas are subject to oversight by the Public Utility Commission of Texas.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Jerry Nadler said “God has no authority in the House of Representatives”
Justification: Rep. Jerry Nadler, D-N.Y., didn’t say that. He said: "What any religious tradition describes as God’s will is no concern of this Congress," a reference to the constitutional separation between church and state. Nadler was encouraging his colleagues in the House of Representatives to vote in favor of the Equality Act, which would prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden said a racial slur.
Justification: During a recent speech, Joe Biden stumbled over the words "I’m eager." He did not say a racial slur.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Donald Trump will be re-inaugurated as president on March 4, 2021.
Justification: • This conspiracy theory rests on a flawed interpretation of an 1871 bill that consolidated the different neighborhoods of Washington, D.C. into a single entity. The bill did not dissolve the government of the United States and turn the country into a corporation as some QAnon adherents claim.• The 20th Amendment changed the inauguration date from March 4 to Jan. 20.
Sources: An act to provide a government to the District of Columbia

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden “helps build Afghanistan’s pipeline.”
Justification: The U.S. has supported the proposed   Turkmenistan-Afghanistan-Pakistan-India natural gas pipeline since discussions of it began in the 1990s. Construction of the pipeline began in 2015, but it is far from completion. Under Biden, the State Department says it supports energy infrastructure cooperation among Afghanistan and its neighbors. But experts say they are aware of no tangible assistance from Biden’s administration or previous administrations on construction.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Insulin prices rose “with the swipe of (Joe Biden’s) pen.”
Justification: The Biden administration froze a Trump executive order related to drug prices, but the action had no effect on current insulin prices, because the Trump policy had not yet taken effect. The policy was also narrowly targeted to certain low-income patients. Individuals who take insulin could see prices fluctuate for several reasons related to their insurance coverage and the specific medication they use. Some insured patients might face a deductible that resets at the beginning of each year, for example. The research director for GoodRx, a company that tracks drug prices, crunched the numbers for PolitiFact and found that insulin prices are stable.
Sources: Email correspondence with the American Diabetes Association
National Association of Community Health Centers

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey said, “A few right winged nuts won’t affect our bottom line.”
Justification: James Quincey didn’t say this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a video captures sound from the surface of Mars
Justification: The video clip is actually a panoramic photograph taken in 2019 by the Curiosity rover that was edited into video form. The sounds are not from the surface of Mars and were edited onto the video. Curiosity is not equipped with microphones.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If you make $50,000/year, $36 of your taxes goes to food stamps. $4,000 goes to corporate subsidies.”
Justification: • The claim leaves out a lot of necessary detail about the hypothetical taxpayer and his or her tax bill, including status and number of dependents.• Experts say there is no clear definition of "corporate subsidies."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Al Gore said in 2009 that “the North Pole will be ice-free in the summer by 2013 because of man-made global warming.”
Justification: In 2009, Al Gore loosely cited researchers and said there was a "75% chance" the ice could be gone during at least some summer months within five to seven years. He made similar statements multiple other times in the late 2000s.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: In Aberdeen, Miss., “Massive 78% of mail-in ballots proved fraudulent, judge orders election do-over.”
Justification: The election do-over involves the election for alderman in Aberdeen, Miss., population 5,326. A judge found irregularities in the paperwork for 66 of the 84 absentee ballots cast, or 78%. The race had been decided by 37 votes, 177-140. The judge found "significant evidence of voter fraud" on the part of two people who notarized paperwork for absentee ballot applications. He ordered one of them arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Donald Trump's second impeachment "cost $33 million."
Justification: Tax policy experts told PolitiFact there isn’t a concrete estimate for how much Trump’s second impeachment cost taxpayers. The Congressional Budget Office does not have a cost estimate for the impeachment resolution. The $33-million figure appears to stem from an inaccurate report on the costs of former Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation, which has nothing to do with Trump’s second impeachment. Trump’s second impeachment likely did not cost taxpayers much beyond what was already budgeted. Congressional salaries and other institutional costs are built into the budget; there were no witnesses who traveled to Washington; and taxpayers did not cover legal fees.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Identification is required “to get into Washington DC.”
Justification: The PolitiFact team living in the Washington, D.C.-area, reports first hand this isn’t true.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden took down Dr. Seuss and Mr. Potato Head.”
Justification: President Joe Biden wasn’t involved in recent announcements by Dr. Seuss Enterprises and Hasbro. They reflect internal company decisions. Biden broke precedent with two previous administrations for not mentioning Dr. Seuss during his National Read Across America Day proclamation. But efforts to move away from tying the author to the day preceded Biden’s time in office, as did the company’s decision to discontinue some of its titles.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kaleb Torres, a young spokesperson for Shriners Hospitals for Children, has died.
Justification: Kaleb-Wolf Torres, who frequently appears in commercials for Shriners Hospitals for Children, is alive. Social media posts confused Torres with another boy named Kaleb who died.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden didn’t act in response to the emergency in Texas.
Justification: President Joe Biden commented on the situation in Texas and has taken steps to help. On Feb. 14, Biden issued an emergency declaration for the state, opening up funding for FEMA to provide resources such as generators, water, blankets and meals. The National Guard is predominantly a state agency, and over 400 state service members have been deployed in Texas. FEMA can request additional help from the Guard under the emergency declaration if needed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the Atlanta mayor is “shutting the city down for” the NBA All-Star Game weekend.
Justification: Atlanta’s mayor has asked people not to travel to the city, and asked businesses not to hold events in the city, in connection with the NBA All-Star Game being played there on March 7. She has not ordered any formal shutdowns in connection with the game.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden’s inauguration was fake and he is not the legitimate president.
Justification: Claims that the inauguration was fake or that Joe Biden is not the real president are not accurate. There’s no evidence. The inauguration was witnessed by several people and broadcast live by numerous outlets. Biden has been seen several times in the White House.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden’s order stopping the Keystone pipeline “made oil more expensive for us to use.”
Justification: Experts cite a number of reasons why consumers likely won’t see price increases. To stay competitive, Canadian oil producers may absorb the added costs of transporting oil by rail, rather than charging U.S. refiners more. Oil prices are largely determined by world markets. Most of the oil to be carried by the pipeline would have been exported.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The Clinton Foundation folded.”
Justification: The claim is wrong. The foundation has continued to operate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Satan flashed in the halftime Super Bowl satanic ritual."
Justification: The word "Satan" was not flashed on a screen behind The Weeknd during his halftime show performance at Super Bowl LV. Images depicting such an incident actually show a 2017 concert in Copenhagen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. military at the White House arresting Congress.”
Justification: The claim is a headline on an article that cites no evidence that members of the military arrested any members of Congress this week.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Cracker Barrel’s name has racist origins and its logo depicts a whip.
Justification: This is a baseless rumor. The barrel depicted in the logo were for storing soda crackers sold in general stores. That’s the origin of the name. Cracker Barrel said the curve in its logo is a common calligraphy flourish used in the logos of many brands.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden signs 45% capital gains tax. Kiss your inheritance goodbye.”
Justification: Congress has not approved any tax bills under Biden for him to sign, and Biden has not taken any executive action. As a candidate, Biden proposed raising capital gains tax rates for people with higher incomes and changing the estate tax to raise rates and broaden its reach.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden canceled the Keystone pipeline because Warren Buffett “donated $58 million” to his campaign.
Justification: Biden said he issued an executive order canceling the pipeline’s construction permit for economic and environmental reasons. Buffett didn’t make any contributions to Biden’s 2020 presidential campaign.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Nabisco is closing plants in Georgia and New Jersey and “moving to Mexico” because of Biden’s election.
Justification: • Mondelez International, Nabisco’s parent company, will close biscuit bakeries in New Jersey and Georgia by summer 2021.• The company linked the closures to "aging infrastructure and outdated production capabilities," not President Joe Biden’s election.• Mondelez said no U.S. jobs will go to Mexico because of these two closures.
Sources: Email exchange with Laurie M. Guzzinati

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Seniors around the world who died from COVID vaccine are being improperly listed as “natural causes.”
Justification: The article suggests that Hank Aaron and elderly people in Gibraltar and Norway who died about two weeks after being vaccinated were killed by the vaccines. But there is no evidence the vaccines caused their deaths.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An “audit report” found that a voting system used in Michigan in the 2020 presidential election was designed to “create systemic fraud.”
Justification: The report cited is from a firm that provided analyses and affidavits for lawsuits brought by Trump allies, falsely alleging voter fraud and election irregularities. Under oath, Michigan’s election director stated that the report "ascribes motives of fraud and obfuscation to processes that are easily explained as routine election procedures or error corrections." An official hand audit of Antrim County’s votes confirmed that Trump won the county, with only slight changes in the vote totals that had already been certified.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden has “allowed males to compete in girls’ sports.”
Justification: • President Joe Biden issued an executive order that prohibits discrimination based on gender and sexuality in education, housing and immigration.• The order extends protections from a 2020 Supreme Court ruling that addressed discrimination in employment.• The executive order does not mandate any immediate changes that would affect sports participation.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Shell Oil laying off 9,000 workers” because of Joe Biden.
Justification: Shell announced job cuts before President Joe Biden was elected. The company has said this claim is inaccurate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden "really did wipe away" student loan debt.
Justification: During the 2020 campaign, President Joe Biden promised to make federal student loan payments more affordable for Americans, including by forgiving debt for some borrowers who attended public colleges and universities. Neither Biden nor Congress has taken action so far to cancel student loan debt.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Congressional benefits include “free health care, outrageous retirement packages, 67 paid holidays, three weeks paid vacation, unlimited paid sick days.”
Justification: Congress does not get free health care. Members can get coverage through the Affordable Care Act, with the government kicking in to cover a share of the cost. Lawmakers are eligible after five years of service or federal employment for a pension plan that is more generous than most private employers offer. Lawmakers don’t have 67 paid holidays, and it’s difficult to discern how much vacation time they get, given the nature of the job. They can take sick days.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi bought $1.25 million in Tesla stock the day before Joe Biden signed an order “for all federal vehicles” to be electric.
Justification: Nancy Pelosi’s husband, Paul Pelosi, bought Tesla stock options — that is, the option to buy Tesla stock at a certain price — on Dec. 22. Nancy Pelosi publicly disclosed the purchase on Jan. 21, in line with federal law. The purchase occurred more than a month before Biden’s Jan. 25 announcement that he plans to eventually make the federal fleet of vehicles electric. Biden had campaigned on a promise to steer the federal government toward buying more electric vehicles.
Sources: Clerk of the House of Representatives

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden planned a winter storm as "warfare, an attack on Texas by altering the jet stream."
Justification: The storm resulted from a polar vortex.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says death reports in federal database show the fatal risk of COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: •  The post copies information from a federal database of reports on adverse events that happen after vaccination. The agencies that maintain the database warn that the reports do not indicate whether an adverse event is linked to or caused by the vaccine.•  Vaccine experts describe the database as an early warning system to flag issues that may need further study. To establish causation, researchers examine if an adverse event is significantly more common in a population of vaccinated people than in non-vaccinated ones.• Safety data involving tens of thousands of people have shown the approved COVID-19 vaccines to be safe and effective. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden said, “I don’t know what I’m signing,” while signing a document.
Justification: It is not clear from a video clip that accompanies the post what Biden, who wore a mask, briefly muttered while signing official documents on his first day as president. No credible news organizations reported what the Facebook post claims he said during the ceremony, which was broadcast live. Experts who enhanced the audio from the video told PolitiFact it is not clear what Biden said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden said, “Buy a man eat fish, he day, teach fish man, to a lifetime."
Justification: The jumbled version of the famous adage about teaching a man to fish is fake. PolitiFact found no record of President Joe Biden saying it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden “will redirect the $30 billion” that Donald Trump “left for U.S. farmers to ‘climate change.’”
Justification: There was not $30 billion that Trump "left for farmers." A $30 billion fund created in 1933 can be used broadly for supporting agriculture. Biden’s nominee for agriculture secretary has said the administration would use the fund, in part, to pursue climate change goals by paying incentives to farmers for sustainable farming practices.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The Biden family is so heavily invested in oil and energy in other countries."
Justification: The latest financial disclosure form for Biden and his wife, Jill, show no direct investments in foreign energy or oil. Other Biden family members have had ties to foreign energy companies, but those family members are not required to file disclosures that would reveal their investments.
Sources: U.S. Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Doctor proves masks don’t work” by vaping through them.
Justification: A video showing how the vapor generated by using an electronic cigarette can pass through masks is not evidence that masks don’t prevent the spread of COVID-19. Masks are meant to protect against the passing of larger respiratory droplets that can carry the coronavirus. The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other experts continue to recommend mask wearing as a key way to prevent spread of the virus.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden’s Air Force One is not the same as Trump’s Air Force One,” which indicates Biden is not the real president.
Justification: • Any Air Force plane carrying the president is technically Air Force One.• Two planes are typically designated with the Air Force One call sign: an iconic military plane and a smaller one used for domestic flights. On a trip to Delaware on Feb. 5, Biden took the smaller plane.• Joe Biden is the president of the United States. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Democratic protesters who “stormed the U.S. Capitol in 2018.”
Justification: A popular Facebook photo shows protesters gathered in the Wisconsin Capitol in February 2011 — not the U.S. Capitol in 2018.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pfizer and Moderna could share their design with dozens of other pharma companies who stand ready to produce their vaccines and end the pandemic.”
Justification: Industry experts say it’s highly unlikely that "dozens" of other pharmaceutical companies that aren’t already producing the vaccines stand ready to do so. Supplies, ingredients, storage capacity, training and facility compliance are a handful of aspects that make the process complex and lengthy. The tweet also doesn’t mention that Pfizer and Moderna have partnerships with various contract manufacturers to help speed up vaccine production.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Not one court has looked at the evidence and said that Biden legally won” the presidential election.
Justification: President Joe Biden was sworn into office Jan. 20. All 50 states and the District of Columbia certified the results affirming his win, some following recounts and audits. Trump and his allies filed dozens of lawsuits in state and federal courts to challenge the election results. Not one of them proved that voter fraud affected the election outcome.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A Miracle! Only 23 Americans Tested Positive for Flu Last Week Compared to 14,657 Cases Reported Last Year at Same Time.”
Justification: The number of people testing positive for influenza this season is down dramatically from last season. Experts cite shutdowns, social distancing and other measures being taken in response to COVID-19.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Myanmar used Dominion Voting Systems.”
Justification: Dominion Voting Systems technology has never been used in Myanmar, according to the company. Voters in Myanmar used paper ballots. We found no evidence to support this claim.
Sources: 2020 General Election in Myanmar — Fact Sheet

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Under the 2017 tax law, “people who make under $75,000 will have their taxes raised in 2021 and every 2 years after that until 2027.”
Justification: • The post distorts the conclusions of an analysis by the Joint Committee on Taxation, which concluded that some income groups will see their after-tax incomes decline in 2021 and beyond.• Other analyses by independent groups show that every income group will benefit from the law to some degree each year until 2027.• The difference in the analyses is the complicated way the Joint Committee on Taxation treated the elimination of the penalty for not having health insurance.
Sources: Urban Institute-Brookings Institution Tax Policy Center

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Facebook recently logged users out to track their “off Facebook activity” involving bank accounts, emails and other apps.
Justification: Some Facebook users were unexpectedly logged out of their accounts due to a system change. It wasn’t an update to a tool that tracks users off-Facebook activity. The company’s "Off-Facebook Tracker," a tool that enables users to have more control over how Facebook traces them on the internet, has been on the website since January 2020 and is unrelated to the logout glitch. The tool does not give Facebook the ability to track users’ bank account or email activity.
Sources: Emailed statement from a Facebook company spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a video shows Joe Biden boasted in 2006 “about voting for ‘700 miles of fence’” and “talking about immigration in some entirely different ways than he does today.”
Justification: In the 2006 video clip, Biden boasted about voting for a 700-mile fence, a vote he said he made mainly to fight drug trafficking, not illegal immigration. But the 2006 Secure Fence Act was squarely aimed at stemming illegal immigration along the southern border. Biden in 2006 supported a variety of measures to fight illegal immigration much as he does today, including addressing root causes that lead people to flee their homes to the United States.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Exotic was pardoned.
Justification: Joe Exotic wasn’t pardoned by President Donald Trump.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden is “following through with a fracking ban.”
Justification: President Joe Biden has not "followed through" on a fracking ban. He signed two executive orders, one that pauses the permitting of oil and natural gas operations in northeastern Alaska and one that pauses leases for drilling on all federal land. Biden’s climate change plan never called for banning fracking. Instead, it proposed banning new fracking on federal lands.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Military tribunals start Jan. 20, 2021.”
Justification: There were no military tribunals at the Capitol on Jan. 20. President Joe Biden was inaugurated that day.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: On Inauguration Day, Vice President Kamala Harris “put her clutch on top of the Bible so her hand is not touching it.”
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris took the oath of office on two Bibles. One belongs to a close family friend, and the other belonged to former Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall.
Sources: Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Biden had to take a private plane to D.C. instead of a government plane “because they know he’s not a legitimate president” and "the military is now responsible for restoring legitimate civilian government.”
Justification: Biden’s form of travel has nothing to do with the legitimacy of his presidency. The post simply repeats variations of elaborate claims that have no credible evidence or basis in truth.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Go to antifa.com and it takes you to Biden’s White House! … Just a slap in the face.”
Justification: Joe Biden has been the target of the redirected URL since he secured the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020. Anyone can buy an available domain and set it to forward to another website, without the permission or coordination from the owners of that site. Computer experts told us that redirecting a domain name is no different from forwarding a telephone number or mailing address. The person on the receiving end can’t do much to stop it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Donald Trump offered his hotel “to our troops to sleep in after they were put in a car garage.”
Justification: The National Guard said it is not aware of any offer by Trump to provide hotel rooms to Guard members when some were temporarily forced to rest in parking garages after providing security at the U.S. Capitol. No Guard members stayed at the Trump hotel, according to the Guard.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “CNN-NPR photojournalist Jade Sacker was embedded with antifa leader" during the U.S. Capitol attack.
Justification: Sacker is a freelance photojournalist. CNN said she has never worked for the network. NPR said she once took photos for its network. Both said she was not working for them during the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. Sacker was with controversial Utah activist John Sullivan inside the Capitol during the attack. She said she was there to work on a documentary about him. Sullivan has denied being an anti-fascist activist and there is no evidence that antifa was behind the attack. He was arrested in connection with the attack nine days after it happened.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Democrats forced our GREAT troops to sleep on the ground of a PARKING garage after dragging them to DC for photo ops!"
Justification: National Guard members stationed in Washington to secure Joe Biden’s inauguration were forced to relocate from the U.S. Capitol. Some ended up resting in a cramped parking garage. There are conflicting statements about who requested the relocation, but there is no evidence or indication that Democratic lawmakers or the Biden administration played a role. The National Guard told PolitiFact that members of Congress had no knowledge of the relocations. Many offered their personal offices and conference rooms to the troops after they were alerted to the situation.
Sources: Joint Statement from National Guard Bureau and US Capitol Police

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Coronavirus vaccinations seem to be causing 50 times the adverse events of flu vaccinations after just the first of two shots.”
Justification: Raw data indicate that the rate of reported "adverse events" — ranging from mild side effects to serious health problems or death — following COVID-19 vaccinations is many times higher than for flu shots. Reports of adverse events to the federal tracking system are not verified, and the CDC and experts say the data cannot be used to draw conclusions about vaccinations causing the adverse events. Experts say the data about the new COVID-19 vaccinations are too new to make meaningful comparisons with flu shots.
Sources: Ron Paul Institute for Peace and Prosperity
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Rep. Lauren Boebert with Capitol rioters before she gave them a tour of the building "one day before the insurrection."
Justification: The photo was taken in December 2019, outside of the Colorado State Capitol.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Soybeans dropped 70 cents and corn 50 cents per bushel in two days, causing farmers to lose big money, “thanks to Biden’s executive orders.”
Justification: A post claims that unspecified executive orders issued by Biden during his first two days as president caused a sudden drop in soybean and corn prices, and big financial losses for farmers. Experts said prices for both commodities have been high and were due for a correction. The experts saw no connection between any executive orders and the price decreases.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hank Aaron’s death was caused by a COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: • A spokesperson at the Fulton County Medical Examiner’s office confirmed that Aaron died of natural causes and that his death was not linked to the COVID-19 vaccine.• Just because Aaron died after receiving a vaccine doesn’t prove that the vaccine caused his death. To establish causation, experts look beyond isolated data points to studies of large groups of people to see if a negative symptom is more prominent in vaccinated people than in non-vaccinated ones.• Safety data involving tens of thousands of people have proven the COVID-19 vaccines to be safe and effective. ​
Sources: Interview with Fulton County Medical Examiner’s office

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The COVID-19 vaccine is dangerous because 23 people died in Norway "within hours” of receiving it.
Justification: • Thirty-three elderly people in Norway died after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine.• Those who died were very frail nursing home residents with serious underlying illnesses. The inoculation was not determined to be the cause of death.• Norwegian health authorities say that in some of the cases, relatively mild side effects from the vaccine such as fever and nausea could have contributed to the deaths of the most frail patients.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "By revoking the Keystone pipeline permit, Biden is destroying 11,000 jobs.”
Justification: On his first day in office, President Joe Biden signed an executive order revoking the permit for the Keystone XL pipeline, halting its construction in the U.S. TC Energy Corp. said it will lay off "thousands" of union workers because of the order. The company’s president said the layoffs would number more than 1,000. TC Energy estimated in October that the pipeline would employ 11,000 Americans in 2021, generating more than $1.6 billion in wages. The pipeline provided far fewer permanent jobs.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "In March 2020 the United States deployed 30,000 troops to Europe to ... free child-trafficked children and arrest deep state cabal members."
Justification: • The U.S. had been scheduled to send 20,000 troops to Europe at the start of 2020 in preparation for a multinational strategic exercise with European allies. The exercise was scaled back due to COVID-19 concerns.• There is no evidence the troops deployed to Europe were excavating secret military bases, freeing children or arresting members of the "deep state."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says President Trump has ordered the military to take over “major corrupt cities” to stay in office and that U.S. citizens will receive emergency alerts on their devices.
Justification: The rumor, which tells people to stock up on food and water and warns against traveling to large cities, was initially promoted by known conspiracy theorists and has no basis in truth. Military and federal communications officials both rejected the claims, and President Donald Trump has signaled he would support a peaceful transition to a new administration.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Rep. Pramila Jayapal was not wearing a mask in Congress during the U.S. Capitol mob.
Justification: A screenshot from a video captured inside the House chambers during the U.S. Capitol mob shows Rep. Pramila Jayapal without a mask. The screenshot is missing critical context: Capitol police had instructed Jayapal and other lawmakers to take off their masks in order to prepare to put on gas masks. Jayapal tested positive for COVID-19 days after the Capitol riot. She blamed Republican lawmakers who had refused to wear masks in a secured indoor location that day.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Barack Obama was arrested.”
Justification: Barack Obama has not been arrested. The false claim is connected to the baseless QAnon conspiracy theory. The video cited in the post shows Obama visiting the cell where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned in South Africa.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Inauguration Cancelled, Trump Remains in Office.”
Justification: President-elect Joe Biden’s Jan. 20 inauguration is proceeding as planned. On Jan. 7, Trump said that a new administration will be inaugurated. Vice President Mike Pence will be attend the ceremony, though Trump said he will not.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden invested the entire family fortune in Ukraine gas and oil. Then shuts down Keystone pipeline. Starting to get the picture.”
Justification: • There is no evidence that Joe Biden invested any family money in Ukrainian gas or oil.• Hunter Biden, his son, held a directorship for a Ukrainian gas company, Burisma Holdings, while Joe Biden was serving as vice president. And as president, Joe Biden signed an order effectively canceling the proposed Keystone XL pipeline.• Biden’s cancellation of the pipeline is consistent with his stated policy to phase out fossil fuels.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden was sworn in on a "Masonic/Illuminati Bible."
Justification: President Joe Biden has used a family Bible dating to 1893 throughout his career in public office. There is no credible evidence that it’s related to a secret society.
Sources: Christopher Hodapp and Alice Von Kannon

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The U.S. Department of State … released a statement on their website stating that Donald J. Trump's term ended” on Jan. 11, 2021.
Justification: • The State Department on Jan. 11 took down Donald Trump’s biography page from its website after the page was updated to read that Trump’s term had ended on Jan. 11, 2021. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has ordered an internal investigation into the incident.• Sources with inside knowledge of the incident told news outlets that a rogue staffer made the change.• Donald Trump is still president. Though many are calling for his removal, his term is not scheduled to end until Jan. 20 when President-elect Joe Biden is sworn in.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Maxine Waters said Trump supporters are “not welcome here” and “we must welcome everyone who crosses our borders.”
Justification: Neither quote is accurate. Waters in 2018 criticized the Trump administration’s zero-tolerance immigration policy that led to the separation of children from their parents at the Mexico border, saying that members of Trump’s Cabinet were "not welcome anymore, anywhere." Her comments were not about Trump supporters generally.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A second impeachment means Donald Trump loses his lifetime pension, travel allowance, Secret Service detail, and his ability to run for public office.
Justification: The source of the viral post said it "isn’t completely true." If the House votes to impeach Trump, he would not automatically lose his post-presidency perks. Two-thirds of the Senate would have to vote to convict Trump while he’s still in office, and his Secret Service detail would be unaffected. The Senate could bar Trump from holding public office again.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a photo shows armed soldiers protecting Joe Biden’s inauguration.
Justification: Thousands of troops are expected in D.C. to protect Joe Biden’s presidential inauguration; an increase in security is due to threats of potential violence, especially after a mob rioted the Capitol earlier this month. But the photo shared on Facebook shows National Guard troops at the Lincoln Memorial in June, during protests for racial justice.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Nancy Pelosi is no longer the Speaker of the House
Justification: This is wrong. The clip showed the opening of a brief session when the presiding officer, in this case Nancy Pelosi, was absent and appointed a "Speaker pro tempore." This is standard House procedure and doesn’t indicate that Pelosi has resigned as speaker.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Biden's Rolex belonged to his late son Beau.
Justification: The watch didn’t belong to Beau Biden. It was gifted to the president by first lady Jill Biden, the White House said in a statement.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A facial recognition firm “confirmed antifa infiltrated the Trump rally in D.C.”
Justification: The Washington Times reported on Jan. 6 that XRVision, a facial recognition firm, had analyzed footage and claimed antifa had infiltrated Donald Trump supporters who stormed the U.S. Capitol. XRVision has denied that and said that the individuals it identified were not associated with antifa. Rather, the company said, two of the individuals were associated with "two known Nazi organizations." The Washington Times has since corrected its story.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Nashville bombing was an attempt to stop an AT&T audit into Dominion software and cover up election corruption.
Justification: There is no evidence to suggest that the Dec. 25 explosion was election-related. Both companies have denied the posts’ claims, saying that there was no such audit and that Dominion’s machines were not recently transported to Nashville, Tenn.
Sources: Dominion Voting Systems Acquired by its Management Team and Staple Street Capital

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the new coronavirus vaccines contain toxic ingredients and are more dangerous than getting COVID-19.
Justification: The ingredient list for the vaccines does not include any of the "toxic" contents listed in the post. The leading vaccines — which have been tested for several months in thousands of people — can cause mild or moderate short-term reactions that resolve without complication. They are not more dangerous than the virus, which has killed over 300,000 Americans and more than 1.6 million people worldwide.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: News outlets reported that the Nashville bomber died of COVID-19.
Justification: Anthony Warner, the man behind the Dec. 25 bombing in downtown Nashville, Tenn., was killed in the blast, according to investigators. The screengrab of a doctored CNN chyron containing this claim comes from a satirical news website.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Quotes show Democrats supported riots “when BLM was BURNING down cities and killing people in the streets!”
Justification: This is misleading. Some of the quotes are legitimate, and were made during or around the height of the Black Lives Matter protests over the summer. Some statements received backlash, but none specifically indicated that they meant anything besides peaceful protest. Other comments were made years ago and were not referring to any looting or violent civil unrest that occurred in 2020.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says City Blue Imaging Services in Rochester, N.Y. “printed ballots there. If you search them you’ll see they’re the ones who had ballots misprint errors for the ballots sent to NYC.”
Justification: City Blue Imaging Services says it does not do ballot printing. Another Rochester, N.Y., company, Phoenix Graphics, is the one that was contracted by New York City election officials to print and distribute ballots; thousands of those ballots were defective.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Nurse passes out on live TV after taking vaccine.”
Justification: A nurse in Tennessee did become dizzy and was assisted to the ground after taking a COVID-19 vaccine. The nurse recovered and later said that her dizziness is something that regularly happens to her after experiencing any kind of pain, even after stubbing a toe. Becoming dizzy after a vaccine is not unusual for some people, a doctor said. The doctor dismissed the notion that the episode was indicative of something dangerous in the vaccine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Chief Justice John Roberts visited Jeffrey Epstein's private island.
Justification: There’s no evidence Chief Justice John Roberts is in the viral picture. The photo was taken in the Dominican Republic, not on Jeffrey Epstein’s private island. There’s no credible evidence that a "John Roberts" listed in Epstein’s flight logs is the chief justice, or that the chief justice had a personal relationship with Epstein.
Sources: Various searches on Google and Nexis

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Google and Apple maps won’t give directions to Washington, D.C. because “they don’t want you going to a certain big rally.”
Justification: Google Maps is providing directions to Washington D.C. Apple Maps did not provide car directions to D.C. from some locations due to "current road conditions." The app does provide public transportation directions to D.C. Dozens of streets were closed to vehicular traffic in D.C. on Jan. 5 and 6.
Sources: Government of the District of Columbia

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Wisconsin Legislature “Will Likely Decertify State and Award to President Trump.”
Justification: This claim is complete nonsense and disproves itself within the story. The bill cited as proof says nothing about decertifying or awarding Wisconsin votes to Trump. It simply says the Legislature will prioritize legislation addressing election laws.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Georgia and Kansas Capitol buildings have been stormed by protesters.”
Justification: Protesters were legally inside both statehouses.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Voting machines didn’t work in heavily GOP areas for the Georgia runoff elections, leaving some voters unable to cast ballots.
Justification: An article widely shared on Facebook suggested that voting machines weren’t working in heavily Republican areas of Georgia for the Jan. 5 runoff elections, leaving people unable to cast their votes. Officials reported only isolated, temporary problems with scanning ballots.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows man upset because he was added to the no-fly list for storming the Capitol.
Justification: The TikTok user who posted the video said that the man was upset because he was kicked off his flight for not wearing a mask. If the man had been added to the No Fly List, he wouldn’t have made it to the boarding area, where this video was taken. If someone is on the No Fly List, they can’t get a boarding pass, which means he wouldn’t have made it to the gate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Cornell University professor Robert Oswald said “COVID-19 was imaginary and fictitious.”
Justification: Robert Oswald debunked the post on his Cornell faculty page. COVID-19 is not a hoax. The virus has killed more than 332,000 Americans.
Sources: Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Judge Rules Over 200,000 Biden Votes Are Illegitimate In Wisconsin.”
