Justification: There is no evidence all the ballots in question here all backed Biden. That data simply isn’t available. And the court ruling in question said votes were only invalid if the individual casting them falsely claimed to be indefinitely confined — a determination that has to be made on a case-by-case basis. The court expressly ruled against a lawsuit from Trump seeking to invalidate those votes en masse.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "‘Simple math’ shows Biden claims 13 million more votes than there were eligible voters who voted in 2020 election.”
Justification: Biden received about 81 million votes while Trump received 74 million. That translated to Biden’s Electoral College win of 306 to 232, which electors made official Dec. 14. Federal security officials have said there was no evidence of widespread voter fraud in the Nov. 3 election.
Sources: United States Election Project turnout rates

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: 32,000 votes for David Perdue “disappeared” during the Georgia Senate runoff election.
Justification: The Georgia secretary of state’s office told PolitiFact its data did not reflect a drop in votes for Sen. David Perdue at any point. Votes for Perdue appeared to change during CNN’s broadcast because the firm that the network gets its data from corrected an error.
Sources: Email from the Georgia secretary of state’s office

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Christmas Day explosion in Nashville, Tenn., was the result of a “missile strike.”
Justification: Law enforcement officials have said a man named Anthony Warner was responsible for the bombing and died in the blast. The bomb was located in a recreational vehicle. The video in the Facebook post shows smoke from the explosion over the Nashville skyline. It does not show a missile hitting the city.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger “faces espionage charges.”
Justification: It was not illegal for anyone on the call to record it, or to disseminate the recording, according to legal experts. Since the conversation was not about sensitive defense information, disclosing it would not violate the Espionage Act, the experts said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An image shows National Guard at the Capitol during the Black Lives Matter protests in D.C.
Justification: • A photo shows members of the D.C. National Guard at the Lincoln Memorial, not the Capitol.• The central claim of the post is valid. During the June 2020 Black Lives Matter Protests, police used riot control tactics meant to dominate the crowd. During the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol, law enforcement was filmed treating the pro-Trump mob with relative restraint. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Mike Pence was arrested.
Justification: Mike Pence wasn’t arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A man who stormed the U.S. Capitol in a horned fur cap is an “Antifa thug.”
Justification: A man who stormed the U.S. Capitol in a horned fur cap is not an antifa activist. He is a known QAnon supporter who has backed President Donald Trump.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says COVID-19 relief bill “provides more funding to foreign governments and to American arts centers, than to the American people.”
Justification: The post conflates provisions of the $900 billion COVID-19 relief bill with provisions of a separate, $1.4 trillion omnibus spending bill. Both were part of a broader $2.3 trillion package approved by Congress. The overall spending bill included funding for American arts centers and foreign aid, but that funding was not included in the COVID-19 relief bill. It was part of the $1.4 trillion omnibus spending bill.
Sources: Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a recent study found no asymptomatic or presymptomatic spread of COVID.
Justification: • The journal article in question found people with symptoms were more contagious than those without, but asymptomatic people did transmit the virus.• The paper looks only at household transmission, not community spread. An asymptomatic individual who went out in the community could still infect a sizable number of people.• The paper itself warns that the number of studies looking at asymptomatic transmission is small, making it hard to draw sweeping conclusions.
Sources: Email interview with Tara C. Smith

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Simpsons predicted the Capitol riots
Justification: A photo shows Simpsons character Groundskeeper Willie dressed in the exact same horned garb as a costume donned by one of the Pro-Trump rioters who breached the building. The photo is doctored.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There are “absolutely no patients” at Los Angeles hospital considered the center of region's COVID-19 surge.
Justification: A Facebookvideoclaimed L.A. hospitals were not overrun with patients after the rapid increase of COVID-19 cases. It said there were "absolutely no patients" at Martin Luther King, Jr. Community Hospital in south Los Angeles. The video was filmed at the hospital’s outpatient center, which is not where COVID-19 patients arrive. They come in through separate emergency department and ambulance entrances. News reports, patient data and statements from the hospital all show MLK Jr. Community Hospital, like many in the region, was flooded with patients last month as COVID-19 cases soared. A hospital spokesperson described the claim as baseless.
Sources: L.A. County issues most dire coronavirus warnings yet: Hospitals in crisis as death toll surges toward 10
Los Angeles County Public Health Department

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says left-wing activist John Sullivan “incited (the) insurgence of (the) US Capitol.”
Justification: John Sullivan, an activist from Utah, joined supporters of President Donald Trump who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. He said he was trying to document what happened. There’s no evidence that Sullivan "incited (the) insurgence" alone amid a crowd of thousands. Video he uploaded online shows his perspective as he filmed. Sullivan denied any affiliation to the broad antifa coalition, although he has posted related hashtags on his Twitter accounts. There remains no legitimate evidence that the mob at the Capitol was infiltrated or led by antifa activists in disguise.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: New York “is trying to pass a bill that would allow them to round up non mask wearers and people who don’t want to take the vaccine into concentration camps. Then with a court order they can force vaccinate you.”
Justification: The bill in question, A416, is not new. It was first introduced in 2015 during the Ebola outbreak and has not gained any traction in the New York State Assembly. It has no co-sponsors and has never once been heard by committee despite being introduced in the 2015-16, 2017-18, 2019-20 sessions, and the current session.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris is planning to use the 25th Amendment against Joe Biden and appoint Mike Pence as her vice president.
Justification: There is no evidence to substantiate this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says shredded ballots were found in Dell boxes in Georgia
Justification: There is no truth to this. Shredding ballots is a federal crime and election officials in the state rejected the claim. Representatives from Fulton County, which was identified as the location where the photo was taken, said the scraps of paper are from the envelopes that absentee ballots come in.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An optional microchip for COVID-19 vaccines “would give officials information on who has and has not been vaccinated” and “tracks the location of the patient.”
Justification: COVID-19 vaccines do not include microchips for tracking patients. A medical technology company has been producing prefilled syringes for coronavirus vaccines. The syringes can include an optional chip on the label — not inside the injected dose itself — that would show if a particular dose is expired or counterfeit. The chips would not be injected with the vaccine, nor would they gather information on patients or allow their locations to be tracked.
Sources: Statement from the Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "If all goes 'well' it'll become federal law to get the (COVID-19) vaccine."
Justification: Moderna has applied for emergency use authorization from the FDA for its vaccine against COVID-19. Neither the Trump administration nor the incoming Biden administration has announced plans to make the vaccine mandatory, if the vaccine is authorized. States, not the federal government, have the general authority over vaccination laws.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The probability of Biden winning in Wisconsin, Georgia, Michigan and Pennsylvania “given President Trump’s early lead ... is less than one in a quadrillion” in each state.
Justification: This purported statistical analysis assumes votes in the November election were uniformly distributed across every county. Building on that assumption, it says the late swings to Biden in four key states were statistically virtually impossible. But the last votes to be counted weren’t a random sample — they were absentee ballots and from large cities, both groups that swing very heavily to Democrats. Given which votes were uncounted in the wee hours of Nov. 4, the swing to Biden was expected, logical and legitimate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “CNN is now saying that Trump will win!”
Justification: CNN has projected Joe Biden as the winner of the presidential election. The Facebook post features a clip from CNN that shows Fareed Zakaria talking about Donald Trump’s path to victory, but it’s from September, before the election.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "THOUSANDS of fake votes found at Wisconsin Recount in Dane County."
Justification: Article claims MLW initials repeated on many ballots are evidence of "fake votes." But those are just the the initials of the Madison clerk who issued absentee ballots.
Sources: Email exchange with Dane County Clerk Scott McDonell
Email exchange with Gateway Pundit Editor Jim Hoft

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The USPS backdated 100K ballots so they could be counted illegally.
Justification: We can’t say yet if the back-dating claims are true, but we know they didn’t affect the Wisconsin vote totals. Absentee ballots had to be received by the time polls closed on Election Day to be counted. The date doesn’t matter if the ballots weren’t submitted by then All Wisconsin election results were reported by 4 a.m. Nov. 4, before the alleged backdating referenced by this purported whistleblower.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden killed a Kelly Loeffler campaign staffer.
Justification: Harrison Deal, a campaign staffer for Sen. Kelly Loeffler, died after a three-vehicle collision, according to news and police reports. A spokesperson for the police department in the town where Deal died said a flatbed truck struck Deal’s vehicle from behind, causing him to hit another vehicle. There is no evidence that Joe Biden was involved.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The number of people who have died in the U.S. in 2020 is on par with years prior to COVID-19.
Justification: A chart that compares annual U.S. death tolls using CDC data is incomplete. It doesn’t accurately represent the number of deaths in the country in 2020. The health agency has reported that an estimated 198,081 excess deaths between late January and early October 2020 in the U.S. are attributable to the virus.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Images that show a 90-year-old UK woman receiving the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine appeared online in a CNN news story in October.
Justification: Images of Margaret Keenan receiving the first Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine in the UK were not published in earlier articles by CNN, or any other news organization. The photos were taken the day of the event, on Dec. 8, and do not appear on the internet before then. Those who spread the post misunderstood that some news websites, including CNN’s, will sometimes feature videos of other, unrelated stories on various article pages.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Voting machines found in bus in Arizona.”
Justification: Voting machines weren’t found in a bus in Arizona. "The bus was full of office equipment purchased at a surplus sale, complete with invoices and receipts," the local police department said in a Facebook post.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A 2018 executive order gives Trump the ability to impose martial law
Justification: • According to six scholars of constitutional law and presidential power, a 2018 executive order gives the president the ability to impose economic sanctions on foreign entities who interfere in a U.S. election. It does not give the president the ability to impose martial law.• Under the Constitution, the president can’t unilaterally impose martial law. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “One of the first nurses to receive the vaccine in AL is now dead.”
Justification: The Alabama Department of Public Health said in a Dec. 16 statement that no recipients of the Pfizer coronavirus vaccine had died.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Supreme Court “has decided to take up the Texas case.”
Justification: The Supreme Court hasn’t agreed to hear a lawsuit filed by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton against four states on grounds their election procedures violated the law.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Masks will kill quite a few people, it’s well known that they reduce blood oxygen levels and those with respiratory and cardiac disorders will die.”
Justification: We found no credible reports of people dying because they used masks to stop the spread of the coronavirus. Public health experts say it is not true that masks reduce blood oxygen levels. The CDC says that people with underlying medical conditions should still wear masks.
Sources: The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “40 years of research, and no vaccine for HIV. At least 100 years of research and no vaccine for cancer. Ongoing research and no vaccine for the common cold. Now in less than a year, there's a vaccine for COVID-19?”
Justification: Despite decades of research, there is no vaccine against HIV given unique challenges the virus poses, such as rapid mutations that are difficult for the immune system to adapt to. There are some vaccines to prevent and even treat some cancers, but not all cancers are caused by a virus. There are many different rhinoviruses that can cause the common cold. That makes it difficult for researchers to create a vaccine that can address them all. Governments around the world have invested in companies to help speed up a COVID-19 vaccine. COVID-19 vaccines up for FDA evaluation have characteristics that allow them to be produced faster than other commonly known vaccines.
Sources: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Dominion representative in Gwinnett County improperly downloaded election data to “manipulate the data.”
Justification: Georgia elections official Gabriel Sterling said the allegation that a Dominion worker manipulated elections data was wrong. Sterling said that election workers have faced violent threats, and he called on President Donald Trump and Sens. Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue to condemn such rhetoric.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A Georgia Bureau of Investigation agent was killed for investigating the election.
Justification: A Georgia Bureau of Investigation agent died at his home on Dec. 14. The bureau has refuted rumors that he was killed because of the election.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Donald Trump will hold his inauguration for a second term at Mar-a-Lago
Justification: President Donald Trump lost his bid for a second term. He has not said what he will do during Joe Biden’s inauguration Jan. 20.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden plagiarized Donald Trump in his Democratic National Convention speech.
Justification: Joe Biden and Donald Trump have both talked about the pandemic, medical supplies, and more, but Biden’s speech accepting the Democratic presidential nomination did not plagiarize Trump.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: People in Germany saw this electoral map that shows Trump beating Biden with 410 electoral votes before Dominion’s servers were seized.
Justification: There’s no evidence any servers related to the U.S. election were seized in Germany. The company at the heart of the conspiracy theory says it has no offices in the country, and the U.S. Army denied such an event took place. The map is not legitimate or related to Germany. It was aired by One America News Network, a pro-Trump cable network based in the U.S., and doesn’t reflect the 2020 election results.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video footage from Georgia shows suitcases filled with ballots pulled from under a table and illegally counted after election observers were told to leave.
Justification: A video presented by Rudy Giuliani and promoted by the Trump campaign purports to show Georgia election workers illegally counting suitcases full of ballots after election observers had been told to leave. The video itself doesn’t prove this claim. Georgia election officials, including Republican voting system implementation manager Gabriel Sterling, publicly disputed claims that the video shows fraudulent activity. Officials said that there was never an instruction for observers to leave, and that there were no suitcases full of ballots. The bins in the video were standard ballot containers, and the footage shows what officials described as the normal tabulation process.
Sources: Statement from One America News Network

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The COVID-19 pandemic has caused four of the eight “deadliest days in American history.”
Justification: • The tally only includes daily deaths directly linked to a specific event resulting in mass fatality. It leaves out the number of deaths from all causes.• The image omits some historical events that claimed more lives. ​• The COVID-19 pandemic has seen daily death totals that have surpassed those of events memorialized as national tragedies, including Pearl Harbor and 9/11.
Sources: Emergency Management: Concepts and Strategies for Effective Programs
National Commission of Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States
The US Caribbean & Ethnic Florida Digital Newspaper Project

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Dominion and Smartmatic “have closed up shop” and executives are “on the run.”
Justification: • Dominion Voting Systems and Smartmatic haven’t shut down. Employees have been working from home, partly due to the pandemic.• Dominion Voting Systems said its workers have been encouraged to work remotely and protect their social media accounts due to persistent threats and harassment after conspiracy theories circulated.• There is no evidence that executives are suspected of crimes or are "on the run."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says “Hugo Chavez’s family still owns” Dominion Voting Systems.
Justification: • The company is majority-owned by a New York-based private equity firm.• The claim echoes elements of baseless conspiracy theories that we have debunked in the past. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden did not win legally.”
Justification: Joe Biden won the presidential election. Though misinformation about Biden’s victory continues to spread, there is no evidence of widespread voter fraud. Dozens of lawsuits filed by Donald Trump and his allies to overturn the election have failed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Say North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper was arrested for driving while intoxicated in Stanly County.
Justification: Multiple Facebook posts claim that North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper was arrested in Stanly County for driving while under the influence of alcohol. The rumor may have originated from a video where a woman asked her smart home device if Cooper had been arrested. PolitiFact found no record of Cooper being arrested, and local law enforcement officials say they're not aware of any incident involving Cooper.
Sources: Email and telephone interviews with Stanly County Sheriff Jeffrey Crisco.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden is wearing a foot boot to hide an ankle monitor.
Justification: Joe Biden injured his foot while playing with his dog. There’s no evidence to support the claim that he has an ankle monitor.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Texas Rep. Terry Meza said changing the castle doctrine is meant to create a “peaceful” transfer of property from victims to thieves
Justification: • Texas state Rep. Terry Meza introduced HB 196 that would modify, but not repeal, the state’s "castle doctrine," which allows the use of deadly force to protect property.• Comments about the legislation attributed to Meza appear to have been taken from a story that was labeled "semi-satire" and written by a political satirist.• Meza has said that her legislation is intended to "require a homeowner to exhaust the potential of safely retreating into their habitation before using deadly force in defense of themselves or their property."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “This whole COVID thing? It’s a SIMULATION.”
Justification: The COVID-19 pandemic is not a simulation. The virus has infected more than 74 million people around the world and caused more than 1.65 million deaths.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Pope Francis says covid vaccine will now be required to enter heaven.”
Justification: The words attributed to Pope Francis actually come from a satire website, The Babylon Bee.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Officials in Fairfax, Va., gave 100,000 Trump votes to Biden.
Justification: • Fairfax County in Virginia mistakenly reported 100,000 more votes for Biden than existed shortly after midnight on Nov. 4.• Officials noticed an error in the spreadsheet and corrected the number within 10 minutes of posting.• Reported votes for Trump didn’t change.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Facebook removed the title of ‘President’ from Donald Trump and designated him as ‘Political Candidate.’”
Justification: • Archived versions of President Donald Trump’s Facebook page show the "political candidate" designation has been used for months.• Facebook did not change the designation after Trump lost the election.• The page still says Trump is the "45th President of the United States."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Arizona trooper found 50,000 ballots in dumpster all for President Trump!!”
Justification: The Arizona Department of Public Safety said this isn’t true.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “These are real to date pictures taken during the Million (MAGA) March 2020.”
Justification: The post is wrong to say that more than 1 million people attended rallies for Donald Trump in Washington, D.C., on Nov. 14. News outlets estimate that attendance was in the thousands. Some of the images in the Facebook post are from a parade and rally for the Cleveland Cavaliers, who won the NBA championship in June 2016. Another photo shows an aerial view of the 2017 Women’s March in Washington.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A screenshot shows Tucker Carlson announcing he’ll “be starting at NewsMax next month.”
Justification: The Parler post is fake. Carlson is not leaving Fox News to join NewsMax, a conservative television network.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a poll worker committing voter fraud in Delaware County, Pa.
Justification: County officials say the video shows a poll worker copying information from a damaged ballot onto a blank ballot so that it could be counted. The video is cropped so that bipartisan poll watchers who were not more than six feet away are no longer in the frame, a spokesperson for the county said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The real electoral map" shows Donald Trump leading Joe Biden in electoral votes.
Justification: Joe Biden is the clear winner of the presidential race, having won more votes than Donald Trump in battleground states like Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania and enough electoral votes overall. It’s unlikely that legal challenges from the Trump campaign will affect the outcome of the election.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “AARP endorsed Biden” and “says if you are past 75 you should just die and go away.”
Justification: AARP does not endorse political candidates. AARP has actively advocated against rationing care for elderly Americans during the coronavirus pandemic.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The MOB in PA was HIRED by the Biden team to create fake ballots by the thousands!!”
Justification: The source of the allegation is the Buffalo Chronicle, a website that has published false claims about Canadian politics and prospective members of Joe Biden’s administration. The site’s article relies on anonymous sources. There is no evidence the Biden campaign hired a mob boss named "Skinny Joey" Merlino to fabricate hundreds of thousands of ballots in Philadelphia. Officials have said the election was "the most transparent and secure" in the city’s history. Merlino’s lawyer denied that his client had anything to do with a purported voter fraud scheme. The reputed Philadelphia mob veteran has been on supervised release in South Florida since 2018.
Sources: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper’s “daughter is having a big wedding today. 500 people. Then going to lock you down on Monday.”
Justification: A spokesperson for North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper said that his daughter, who is engaged, didn’t have a wedding. The state isn’t in lockdown but there are COVID-19 restrictions, including limiting the number of people who can gather indoors outside.
Sources: North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An election worker in Georgia threw away a ballot.
Justification: The worker threw away a piece of paper containing voter instructions.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “118-year-old William Bradley voted via an absentee ballot in Wayne County, Michigan this year. William died in 1984. They’re trying to steal this election.”
Justification: A Detroit voter named William Bradley told us he voted by mail. He said a ballot was also sent for his dead father with the same name, but he threw out that ballot. A city elections official said that a ballot was not cast on behalf of the elder Bradley, but when the alive Bradley voted officials made a clerical error in recording the ballot. Elections officials take steps including signature verification to prevent people from impersonating dead voters.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Video shows trashed ballots for Donald Trump.
Justification: A video of two men discovering ballots for President Donald Trump in the trash can at a former polling location leaves the impression that valid ballots were dumped, but these ballots were "spoiled," meaning a voter accidentally marked two people in one race and needed a new ballot.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Time magazine cover with Barack Obama that says “Treason.”
Justification: This video includes several doctored photos of President Barack Obama, a fake Time magazine cover and unfounded conspiracy theories.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Dominion Voting System flipped votes to Joe Biden in states where Trump is bringing legal challenges.
Justification: There is no credible evidence that the voting system affected any vote tallies. Dominion Voting Systems was only used in a few counties that experienced minor problems that were quickly resolved, and were either the result of human error or temporary malfunctions. These claims are a misunderstanding of how election administration works, experts said. The process involves several protocols and rigorous testing that would make it exceedingly difficult for mass fraud to happen at this level undetected.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A judge has ordered a "HAND RECOUNT by an INDEPENDENT COMMISSION in the state of Michigan, following hard evidence of voting fraud by Detroit City Election Commission."
Justification: A hand recount has not been ordered in Michigan. The secretary of state’s office said the post is "made up."
Sources: Michigan Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Voter FRAUD exposed in Georgia. Over 2600 votes 'FOUND.'"
Justification: Election officials found more than 2,600 uncounted votes in Floyd County, Ga., northwest of Atlanta. Most of the votes favor President Donald Trump. Those uncounted ballots are not evidence of voter fraud in Georgia. State election officials said the mistake was due to human error. Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, a Republican, has repeatedly said there is no evidence of fraud affecting the state’s presidential election results.
Sources: Email from Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden lead disappears in NV, AZ, GA, PA.”
Justification: Major media organizations have projected Joe Biden as the winner of the 2020 presidential election. The media makes these calls every election year. Biden’s leads have not "disappear(ed)" in Nevada, Arizona, Georgia or Pennsylvania. When the ballots were counted, Biden received more votes than Trump.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Trump administration put secret watermarks on official ballots to trick cheating Democrats.
Justification: This is a bogus conspiracy theory. The federal government has no role in printing ballots or in the on-the-ground mechanics of elections. The responsibility lies with state and local governments. Some states may require a watermark on ballots, but there is no evidence of a secret Trump-issued watermark on "official ballots."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Sen. Kelly Loeffler said on Parler that “Black people shouldn’t be allowed to vote.”
Justification: A Parler message about Black voters that was attributed to Loeffler and depicted in a Facebook post is from a fake account, not the senator’s.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: More poll workers caught filling out ballots in Delaware County Pennsylvania.
Justification: Videos show poll workers filling out blank ballots. County officials say the poll workers were copying information from damaged ballots onto blank ballots so they could be counted. Bipartisan poll watchers monitored the process, a spokesperson for the county said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The media called the 2016 election for Hillary Clinton.
Justification: Polls projected that Hillary Clinton would win but media organizations didn’t call the race for her. Early in the morning after Election Day, the Associated Press called the race for Donald Trump.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Active crime scene in Spalding County, Ga., where ballots for President Donald Trump were discovered in a dumpster.”
Justification: No ballots for President Donald Trump (or any candidate) were discovered in a Spalding County dumpster, according to the county’s Republican sheriff. Empty envelopes marked "ballot" were discovered in the dumpster.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Siri gave “CONFIRMATION of the Democrats' sinister plan to REMOVE Sleepy Joe immediately using the 25th Amendment and instate Kamala Harris as President!”
Justification: The Siri responses were part of a bug involving election data from Wolfram Alpha, a website that feeds into the assistant’s responses. There is no evidence that Democrats are working to invoke the 25th Amendment.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The NAACP has received credible information that some of the white nationalist groups … will be looking to snatch black men and boys and hang them, shoot them, torture them and kill them.”
Justification: The NAACP has said this information is false and not credible.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Church bells rang in Paris and fireworks were set off in London to celebrate Joe Biden’s presidential win.
Justification: The church bells were not related to the U.S. presidential race. Fireworks had been going off in London for several days in celebration of the British holiday Guy Fawkes Day on Nov. 5.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Republican election challengers were unfairly barred from observing absentee ballot processing and counting in Detroit.
Justification: At one point, more than 500 Republican, Democratic and nonpartisan challengers were inside Detroit’s ballot counting center to observe, including over 200 Republican challengers. Others were not allowed in because the number of challengers in the room had reached the limit allowed under state law.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Milwaukee Elections Chief Lost Elections Flash Drive in Morning Hours of November 4th When Democrats Miraculously Found 120,000 Votes for Joe Biden.”
Justification: There was nothing nefarious about the flash drive issue. It was unintentionally left behind, but was in an observed, supervised area the whole time. We know the data wasn't altered since the timestamp on the data copied to the drive matched the original transfer, and the vote totals on it matched those recorded by the machine. And it's ridiculous to connect the drive to the votes reported overnight. Those were Milwaukee absentee ballots that were long projected to take a long time to count and strongly favor Biden.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Overnight, election workers “found” 140,000 mail in ballots in Wisconsin; 200,000 in Michigan and 1 million in Pennsylvania. “All for Biden. None for Trump.”
Justification: This is a misinterpretation of how counting mail in ballots works. Some of the numbers are simply wrong, while others represent exaggerated versions of  misinformation that PolitiFact has debunked.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: There is “aborted male fetus” in the Oxford-AstraZeneca “Covid 19 vaccine.”
Justification: • The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine is created from a virus grown in a cell line derived from aborted fetal tissue. However, the cell line is purified away from the vaccine before the vaccine is used.•  The video incorrectly identifies the cell line used to grow the vaccine.
Sources: Kennedy Institute of Ethics at Georgetown University

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “This is the California model spreading across the country. When you need to flip things blue there’s always some mysterious mail-in ballots lying around that’ll do the trick. Shameful!”
Justification: A popular Facebook post claimed "mysterious mail-in ballots lying around" helped flip key states for Democrat Joe Biden. It also suggested California’s mail-in voting system is fraudulent. There’s no evidence that officials discovered new or illegal ballots "lying around" after Election Day. Several battleground states where early results from Tuesday’s in-person vote favored President Trump continued counting legally-voted mail-in ballots Tuesday night and Wednesday. Those ballots can take longer to count and some states were prohibited from starting to tally them until Tuesday. Election experts reject the idea that mail-in ballots in California or any other state lead to widespread fraud.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the toddler shown in a photo clinging to a police officer was found wandering, alone and barefoot, looking for his mother amid protests in Philadelphia.
Justification: The photo is legitimate, but posts sharing it mischaracterize what happened. The boy wasn’t found wandering around alone and barefoot by police. He was pulled from an SUV after police officers swarmed and smashed the vehicle’s windows.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Thousands of military ballots were found in the trash in Wisconsin.
Justification: We found no reports that "thousands" of mostly pro-Trump military ballots were found in the trash in Wisconsin. Election officials in the state called the claim inaccurate, and said they’ve seen no evidence of this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump supporters are blocking access to polling sites at Clifton City Hall, New Jersey.”
Justification: On Nov. 1, a woman called Clifton, N.J., police to report a man near an outdoor ballot box holding a Trump banner. Surveillance video of the 40-second incident showed that no voter intimidation occurred. Police forwarded the information to the New Jersey attorney general, which is a standard practice.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Wisconsin found 112k votes at 3am.”
Justification: The suggestion that ballots were randomly "found" is wrong. Election officials in Wisconsin said they didn’t know what the post specifically meant by the 112,000 reference. The City of Milwaukee was still counting absentee ballots around 3 a.m., but that doesn’t mean that those ballots were "found" or appeared at that time.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden was called for Michigan even though Donald Trump won more votes.
Justification: When news organizations called Michigan for Joe Biden, the secretary of state’s website showed Donald Trump with more votes. But the secretary of state’s website is slow to update, and Biden actually had a 70,000-vote lead when the Associated Press declared him the winner.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Seven Milwaukee wards report more 2020 presidential votes than registered voters.”
Justification: The website is one of several purported local news sites run by a conservative businessman who’s been criticized for companies that produce what some call "pink-slime journalism." In fact, the seven Milwaukee wards cited in the article had more registered voters than ballots cast. And the state Elections Commission has emphasized that it’s not possible for more ballots to exist than registered voters.
Sources: Milwaukee Journal Sentinel interview with Claire Woodall-Vogg

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Pennsylvania officials are “attempting to silence voters” by sending them letters that say they’ve been exposed to COVID-19 and “must remain quarantined and not vote in person on Election Day.”
Justification: During the pandemic the Pennsylvania Department of Health has sent letters to close contacts of people who have tested positive for COVID-19, directing them to quarantine to try to prevent the spread of the disease. The letters say that residents under quarantine are not supposed to leave their homes. They do not mention voting. Pennsylvania residents under quarantine can request and cast an emergency absentee ballot on Election Day. If no one is available to cast a ballot on the voter’s behalf, a county official will provide the ballot and return it for them.
Sources: Letter from the Pennsylvania Department of Health re: "Close contacts of person with Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)"
Pennsylvania Department of Health press release

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi’s son served on the Burisma board with Hunter Biden.
Justification: Nancy Pelosi’s son, Paul Pelosi Jr., didn’t serve on the Burisma board.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Say Joe Biden told a crowd in Florida, "Hello Minnesota!"
Justification: • The video that was used to back up this claim was manipulated. The event took place in Minnesota, and the banner and sign in the video had Minnesota-specific touches that were doctored out of the widely shared version of the clip.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Now that it’s even, Nevada decides to stop counting and is now not going to count anything until TOMORROW! What?!”
Justification: The Nevada Elections office tweeted early in the morning of Nov. 4 that it would post its next updated results on Nov. 5. But counting of ballots continued in the counties. By state law, Nevada counts ballots postmarked Nov. 3 but received up until seven days later. Voters have until Nov. 12 to "cure" their mail ballots if they forgot to sign them or have signature mismatches.
Sources: Nevada Secretary of State Barbara Cegavske

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Six states can't get the votes counted. Six states in which @realDonaldTrump is leading. Six states where Dems are in charge."
Justification: When this post was shared, there was no winner in the U.S. presidential election. A few key states that determine the path to the White House remain uncalled. Some states in which Donald Trump was leading on election night experienced delays in the ballot-counting process due to an influx of mail-in ballots. There is no evidence that states are deliberately stalling vote tabulation to favor Joe Biden.
Sources: North Carolina State Board of Election

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Bricks are being “randomly placed all over Detroit.”
Justification: Bricks photographed in Detroit are for construction projects, according to police.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Dems have removed any mention of ‘God’ from their Platform.”
Justification: • The 2020 Democratic Party platform includes a reference to "God-given potential." It also includes numerous references to faith and religious freedom.• The party attracted national attention in 2012 when all references to God initially were omitted from its platform. The platform was amended one day after its introduction to include a reference to "God-given potential."• The party’s platform has had fewer references to God in recent years: three in 2016 and one reference each in 2008, 2012 and 2020, compared with seven in 2004.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Kohl's confirmed that they will be selling BLM merchandise” but are not selling  “back the blue” at this time.
Justification: The department store Kohl’s partnered with a Black-owned business from Milwaukee to produce a T-shirt collection that features anti-racism slogans and symbols that overlap with ones used by the Black Lives Matter movement. The collection is not officially affiliated with Black Lives Matter, and Kohl’s does sell at least one item that features symbols affiliated with the pro-police Blue Lives Matter movement.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “How many of you still don't know that Michelle Obama was born Michael Lavaughn Robinson and is a man?”
Justification: There is no evidence for this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Six states "decided to stop counting" votes as Donald Trump was "headed for a win” on election night.
Justification: None of the states cited in the post stopped counting votes altogether on Nov. 3. Election officials in Fulton County, Ga., briefly paused counting ballots after a pipe burst at a facility in Atlanta. North Carolina stopped counting in-person votes once 100% of precincts were reported, but the state is still counting absentee ballots. Delays in election results are due to an influx of mail-in ballots, spurred by the coronavirus pandemic.
Sources: North Carolina State Board of Election

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows massive wall in front of White House on Election Day.
Justification: The image is doctored. The original photo was taken in 2009 and includes no wall.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “There are people trying to make legal age of consent 4 years old.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that people are trying to lower the age of consent to 4.
Sources: Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If Biden wins the election, there are people out there planning on mass murdering poc and lbgtq+ people. Please stay inside during the election and a few days after.”
Justification: Social media posts went viral on Election Day warning people of color and LGBTQ people to stay home. The posts claim that if Joe Biden wins the election, supporters of President Donald Trump plan mass murders of people in those groups. Experts doubted the authenticity of any such plot and said the aim of the posts could be intimidation.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An image shows “what appears to be an official ballot box being taken away from a polling location by an unidentified civilian.”
Justification: The person in the image is an election worker transporting the ballots in Philadelphia as part of their official duties.
Sources: Text messages exchanged with Jane Roh

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If you were forced to use a Sharpie” to fill out your ballot, “that is voter fraud.”
Justification: Some in-person voters complained that election officials gave them Sharpie pens at their polling place and that the ink spoiled and invalidated their ballots. In some cases, Sharpies are actually recommended as the best type of pen to use on ballots, and election officials have taken steps to guard against ink "bleed-through" on ballots. There is no evidence that elections officials used Sharpies to invalidate ballots.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Kamala’s husband, a lawyer, represents the Communist Chinese Party in America!! Think about that!!”
Justification: • To avoid the appearance of conflict of interest as his wife ran for vice president, attorney Douglas Emhoff in August took leave from his firm, DLA Piper, where he has been a partner since 2017.• An article on a conservative news website alleged that several DLA Piper employees have ties to the Chinese Communist Party. But it never claimed that Emhoff himself represented the CCP and we found no evidence that he has.• DLA Piper hasnearly 4,000lawyersin more than40 countries.• Foreign policy experts told us that the CCP has over 90 million members and that it’s difficult for a firm in the country to avoid doing business with anybody with party ties.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Wisconsin took a break, and when they returned, Biden coincidentally came back ahead by 100k.”
Justification: Election officials worked all night and into the early morning to count over 3.2 million ballots in Wisconsin. Any delay in results being reported stemmed from an influx of mail-in ballots — not because officials "took a break."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Voters in Maricopa County, Ariz., were forced to vote using Sharpie pens that aren’t read by voting machines.
Justification: Voters could use ink pens to fill out their ballots, but the county gave Sharpie markers to voters because ballots filled in with Sharpie pens are processed more precisely by voting machines.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump has won the election with 294 electoral votes.”
Justification: According to several news organizations, President Donald Trump had 213 electoral votes by 11:30 a.m. Eastern Time on Nov. 4. Though he has falsely declared victory, millions of votes in crucial states are still uncounted, and the election is undecided.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says President Trump’s Oct. 31 rally in Butler, Pa., drew over 57,000 people.
Justification: We could find no official tally, but estimates from police, local news outlets and bus operators put the number of attendees between 10,000 and about 15,000.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Say a video shows “staffers stuffing ballots in flint mi”
Justification: • A video purportedly showing ballot-stuffing in Flint, Mich., is not from any Flint polling place. It was shot in Russia.• The video was published in a Washington Post news article in 2018.• The polling place has prominently posted logos that look like the Russian Federation’s coat of arms.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Miami-Dade reporting 23% of early ballots being rejected for missing signatures.”
Justification: Slightly less than 1% of mail in ballots had been rejected in Miami-Dade County as of the morning of Oct. 30. The most common reason that a ballot was rejected was due to having no signature on the envelope. The county contacts voters to give them a chance to "cure" or fix their ballot if the signature was missing or didn’t match.
Sources: Michael Herron and Daniel A Smith op-ed Tampa Bay Times

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Detroit has “2,503 dead people registered” including “one voter born in 1823.”
Justification: The Public Interest Legal Foundation filed a lawsuit in December 2019 against Detroit elections officials alleging that they failed to maintain accurate and current voter rolls. The foundation dropped their lawsuit in June after they were satisfied that Detroit officials took action. The fact that dead people are on the voter rolls does not mean that anyone has tried to cast a fraudulent ballot in their name.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says “Hunter Biden had 25,000 pics of him torturing and raping children under age 10 in China on his laptop.”
Justification: There is no evidence that a laptop previously belonging to Hunter Biden contains child pornography. The allegation originated on an anonymous internet forum that’s a known source of online disinformation.
Sources: U.S. Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Because our family couldn’t afford health insurance, Obama/Biden penalized us about $10,000, then took that $10,000 and used it to pay for others’ free Obamacare. Trump ended that theft.”
Justification: Experts said a penalty of $10,000 in one year would have been extremely unlikely because it would have meant the family’s income would have been in the $400,000 range. In that income bracket, the family would likely have been able to afford health insurance. President Donald Trump and congressional Republicans in 2017 zeroed out the penalty for not having health insurance, known as the individual mandate. Before the individual mandate was undone, this penalty was collected like any other tax, so it went directly into the federal Treasury. Therefore, it may or may not have been directly used to fund health insurance subsidies. Subsidies reduce the cost of insurance; they do not make it free.
Sources: 5th Circuit Court of Appeals’ technical revisions

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Anthony Fauci was indicted “for crimes including treason, conspiring with the enemy and fraud.”
Justification: Anthony Fauci has not been indicted.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "World renowned experts" declare that we should “live normally, practice simple hygiene,” stay home when sick and use protective measures only with “the most vulnerable populations.”
Justification: A trio of scientists drafted the "Great Barrington Declaration," which says that people without underlying medical conditions should immediately be allowed to resume life as normal, while the vulnerable should remain protected. The document was swiftly denounced by top health officials and thousands of researchers and scientists around the world, who called the approach unethical and nearly impossible.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The “3 red stripes” in Joe Biden’s campaign logo refer to a Chinese socialist slogan.
Justification: "Three red banners" has nothing to do with the Biden campaign. The phrase is a socialist slogan that was used in China during the late 1950s. The Biden campaign logo was inspired by red stripes on the American flag.
Sources: " Two Republics in China: How Imperial China Became the PRC
Interview with a Biden campaign spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Hunter Biden “died of a crack overdose.”
Justification: There is no evidence that Hunter Biden died after an overdose. The claim originated on a fringe internet platform that’s a known source of disinformation.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Biden said, "The day after I’m elected I will let you know what I stand for, bc if I tell you now it will be all over the news."
Justification: • Joe Biden did not say this.• Biden initially said he would give his opinion on court packing — the idea of adding justices to the Supreme Court — when the election is over.• He has outlined his positions on other issues.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden told a factory worker, “I don’t work for you!” while pointing a finger in the worker’s face.
Justification: • In March, Joe Biden got into a verbal spat with a factory worker, telling him he was "full of s---" when the worker accused Biden of trying to take away Second Amendment rights and repeatedly challenged Biden’s responses.• Later during the same exchange, the worker told Biden, "You’re working for me, man" and Biden either replied, "I’m not working for you," or stopped short of that, according to differing media accounts.• Biden pointed at the worker through much of the exchange.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kamala Harris said looters are just feeding their hungry kids.
Justification: Sen. Kamala Harris has condemned looting in the wake of police shootings. Most recently, in the wake of the death of Walter Wallace Jr. in Philadelphia, she and Joe Biden said in a joint statement: "Looting is not a protest, it is a crime."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Dr. Anthony Fauci wrote a paper blaming 1918-19 flu deaths on masks.
Justification: There is no historical or scientific evidence for the claim that masks cause pneumonia, experts said. A 2008 study, co-authored by Dr. Fauci, found that bacterial pneumonia caused a majority of deaths in the 1918 influenza pandemic. The study made no mention of masks.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Jeff Foxworthy wrote a ‘fence test’ for Republicans and Democrats.
Justification: "I would just like to clear the air and say it was not created by me," Jeff Foxworthy said about the statement attributed to him. "It is nothing close to my beliefs, and someone just slapped my name on it."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An “anti-Black Lives Matter” flag replaced the American flag behind President Trump during a Waukesha campaign rally.
Justification: A Thin Blue Line flag was used as a backdrop for President Trump’s Oct. 24, 2020 rally in Wisconsin. A Facebook post labeled it an "anti-Black Lives Matter flag." The flag has been associated with the pro-police Blue Lives Matter movement, which arose to counter the Black Lives Matter effort. It is possible to support police and the Black Lives Matter movement, but Trump has condemned protests tied to the latter.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "The daughter of Sen. Coons (D-DE), along with 7 other underaged girls are featured on Hunter's laptop! - Breitbart News"
Justification: There is no evidence that a computer hard drive previously belonging to Hunter Biden contains illicit images of the teenage daughter of Sen. Chris Coons, D-Del. The claim comes from Lauren Witzke, a Republican running against Coons to represent Delaware in the Senate. She has not offered proof.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Sen. Kamala Harris “may have broken laws” when she visited a voting site in Ohio
Justification: Ohio laws say no one can campaign within 100 feet from a polling place or within 10 feet of any voter in line. Sen. Kamala Harris briefly spoke outside of the Cuyahoga County early voting center in Cleveland. She made no mention of candidates and gave a brief pep talk to people in line about the power of voting. County elections officials said she did not violate electioneering laws.
Sources: National Association of Secretaries of State
Ohio Secretary of State Frank LaRose
Press pool report by Henry Gomez of Buzzfeed

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Pennsylvania rejected 372,000 mail-in ballots
Justification: Conservative reports wrongly conflated applications for mail-in ballots with actual ballots in Pennsylvania. As of mid October, Pennsylvania rejected about 372,000 applications for mail ballots, primarily because the voters had previously requested one.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Biden slipped up and came out saying he’s going to tax your 401k. Are any of you EVEN paying attention?"
Justification: • The Biden campaign platform doesn’t propose taxing 401(k) accounts. He never said he’s going to tax your 401(k).• Tax policy experts said that a Biden proposal to replace the current deduction with a 26% refundable tax credit wouldn’t constitute a tax on 401(k) accounts because everyone would still receive a tax subsidy for contributing to these accounts.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says NBC News’ Kristen Welker “gave thousands of dollars to Obama, Clinton and Biden, is registered as a Democrat & her family spent Christmas with the Obamas at the White House.”
Justification: NBC News correspondent Kristen Welker, the moderator for the third presidential debate, has not donated money to Democrats, according to contribution data. Welker is currently registered to vote in Washington, D.C., with no party affiliation, according to the District of Columbia Board of Elections. A photo of Welker with Barack and Michelle Obama is from a 2012 White House reception for the press.
Sources: Phone and text interviews with Nick Jacobs
Various searches in the Federal Election Commission’s databases

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Donald Trump said “good” during the final presidential debate in reference to families being separated at the border.
Justification: President Donald Trump said "go ahead" to moderator Kristen Welker, who was trying to change the subject.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden said, “I lived in Section 8 housing as a little boy.”
Justification: Joe Biden didn’t say he lived in Section 8 housing as a boy. During the ABC News town hall on Oct. 15, he said that as a child, his family lived in apartments that "much later" became Section 8 housing.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Donald Trump and Thom Tillis opposed legislation that would lower the price of insulin and other prescription drugs.”
Justification: The progressive Change Now PAC launched a campaign ad, which also circulated on Facebook, criticizing President Donald Trump and Sen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., for not "fighting" for people with diabetes who struggle with the high cost of insulin. Trump and Tillis have voiced opposition to prominent bills that experts say could decrease the cost of insulin for a broad group of Americans. But both have also proposed alternative policies to lower the price of insulin and other prescription drugs. Most of these proposals have not taken effect and are largely targeted at seniors, unlike the young woman who is featured in the ad.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Donald Trump “voted twice” in the Nov. 3, 2020 election
Justification: Trump voted in person at a library in Palm Beach County Oct. 24. The Supervisor of Elections said he did not vote twice in the general election. Trump voted by mail for the presidential preference primary in March and the state primary in August. For the primaries, Trump had a representative pick up the ballot for him, which is allowed under Florida law.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris’ husband said, “I am married to the next president of the United States.”
Justification: Kamala Harris’ husband said he was married to "the next president of the United States" in June 2019, when Harris was still running for president.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden had an iPad at his podium during the debate.
Justification: Identical notepads were removed from both President Donald Trump’s podium and Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden’s podium after the final presidential debate on Oct. 22. There is nothing to suggest that Biden had an iPad at his podium during the debate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says “Joe & Jill Biden’s income went from $396,456 in 2016, to $16,596,979 in 2017-2019. Anyone else want to know where that money is coming from?”
Justification: • Joe Biden and his wife reported $396,456 in adjusted gross income in 2016, the last full year he served as vice president.• In the years since he left office, the couple reported adjusted gross income of $11,031,309 in 2017, $4,580,437 in 2018 and $985,233 in 2019, for a total of $16,596,979.• The Bidens’ income sources are reported on tax returns and financial disclosures that they have made public, and most of their income in recent years has come from speaking fees and book deals.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says photo from Hunter Biden's laptop shows Paul Pelosi Jr. abusing a girl and doing drugs.
Justification: The image isn’t from the purported Hunter Biden laptop. It was published online in late 2019 in a story about an alleged relationship between Paul Pelosi Jr. and a woman named Karena Feng. The photo doesn’t show abuse or drugs. The girl appears to be Feng’s daughter, who isn’t tied up and is cutting a cake.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Joe Biden next to a man seen in a sex sting video.
Justification: • The post misidentifies the man in the photo with Biden. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden “wants to get rid of something called ‘stepped up basis’” that reduces inheritance taxes.
Justification: • Biden has proposed eliminating the "stepped-up basis," a tax policy that reduces inheritance taxes.• If the policy were abolished, Biden’s plan calls for using the extra federal taxes collected to provide two years of free community college to students.• If Biden is elected, he can propose changes to tax law, but only Congress can enact tax laws.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “WHO now says your child’s presence in school counts as ‘informed consent’ for vaccination - parental presence not required.”
Justification: • The WHO told us that a child’s presence at school would only count as consent if a parent had already received advance notice of a planned immunization and been given the opportunity to opt out or take appropriate steps to express their desire to do so.• The World Health Organization doesn’t have any legal ability to determine vaccine policy in the United States. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A video shows ballots being changed in Maryland.
Justification: Maryland elections officials say the worker seen writing on a ballot in a viral video was darkening an oval that was filled in too lightly so that the ballot scanner would recognize it.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says YouTube removed Tucker Carlson’s interview with Tony Bobulinski.
Justification: Fox News posted a segment of the interview on YouTube and then linked to its own website for viewers to watch the rest.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Rock has lost 48 million followers on his IG and YouTube after coming out for Biden.”
Justification: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson on Sept. 27 endorsed Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden and his running mate Sen. Kamala Harris. Johnson gained about 196,000 Instagram followers the day he posted his announcement and 3 million Instagram followers in September. His YouTube subscribers increased A review of news stories and websites that track social media analytics found Johnson didn’t lose anywhere near 48 million followers following his announcement.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “BREAKING NEWS: All Charges Dropped for Kyle Rittenhouse.”
Justification: After shootings left two dead and one injured in Kenosha, Wis., 17-year-old Kyle Rittenhouse surrendered to authorities in Illinois He is being held in an Illinois juvenile facility awaiting extradition to Wisconsin to face charges. Illinois authorities said they will not file charges against him based on how he obtained a gun used in the shootings. But Rittenhouse still faces several charges in Wisconsin, including first-degree intentional homicide
Sources: Facebook "All charges for Kyle Rittenhouse dropped
Milwaukee Journal Sentinel " Illinois prosecutor says there’s no evidence Kyle Rittenhouse took the gun used in Kenosha shootings out of Wisconsin
Milwaukee Journal Sentinel " Kyle Rittenhouse’s lawyers say extraditing teen to Wisconsin would be ‘turning him over to the mob

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Federal law requires people to speak English to be naturalized as American citizens.”
Justification: •  Foreigners seeking American citizenship must pass an English language test.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A photo shows a massive crowd at a recent Florida rally for Donald Trump.
Justification: • The photo does not show a Trump rally in Florida. It shows Street Parade Zurich, a music festival in Switzerland.• The photo dates back to 2018.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "If Biden becomes president and cannot complete his term, Harris will become president, and Pelosi will become vice president."
Justification: • If the president leaves office, the vice president becomes the president. That person nominates a new vice president.• So if Joe Biden becomes president and leaves office early, Kamala Harris will become president and nominate a vice president. Nancy Pelosi will not become vice president.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jeffrey Epstein found living in New Mexico!”
Justification: Multiple official sources have confirmed that Jeffrey Epstein is dead. This Facebook post offers no evidence to support the claim that he is alive in New Mexico.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Amy Coney Barrett said that breastfeeding babies is child molestation.
Justification: There’s no evidence that Amy Coney Barrett made such a statement. The words appear to have originated from an anonymous post on Reddit.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kamala Harris said there will be “a federal tax on your home for reparations.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that the Democratic vice presidential nominee supports a tax to pay for slavery reparations, or even direct payments as reparations.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Wisconsin Republicans have not passed a single bill in 6 months.”
Justification: The Wisconsin Legislature last passed a bill in April, almost 6 months ago This is normally a period in an election year where the Legislature is in recess, but this year is anything but normal. Only three state legislatures have passed fewer COVID-related bills since March than Wisconsin’s one. Every other full-time Legislature has met vastly more often.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden’s “capital gains tax means that when you sell your home you’ll owe taxes of 40% of your profit!”
Justification: Joe Biden would increase capital gains taxes for Americans who make more than $1 million per year. Homeowners must pay capital gains taxes if they sell their homes for a $250,000 profit, if single, or a $500,000 profit, if married and filing jointly.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “AARP endorses Biden and gives financial support to Planned Parenthood.”
Justification: AARP is a nonpartisan organization that lobbies on behalf of its members, who are 50 or older. It does not endorse political candidates. The organization says it has never funded Planned Parenthood, and we found no evidence to contradict that.
Sources: AARP state director letter to volunteer

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “South Dakota, Idaho, Florida, Tennessee & Georgia are now mask FREE!”
Justification: None of these states have a statewide mask mandate, but cities and counties in each have orders requiring face coverings.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jaime Harrison is being left off of South Carolina ballots”
Justification: South Carolina is one of a handful of states that give voters the option to use straight party ticket voting. When voting straight ticket, a voter who selects the Democratic Party would see Harrison’s name appear automatically on the Senate screen. However, if the voter then touches Harrison’s name, that would deselect his name. Voters are given warnings on the screen if they skip a race, and they can confirm their choices when the machine prints out a paper card showing the names of the candidates they voted for.
Sources: Email exchange between Whitmire and Scott

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Kamala Harris Tried to Put Pro-Lifers in Jail Who Exposed Planned Parenthood Selling Baby Parts”
Justification: Popular Facebook posts claimed Kamala Harris tried to put "pro-lifers" in jail who "exposed Planned Parenthood selling baby parts." Planned Parenthood denied the accusations. Staffers in unedited videos discussed covering costs for the legal donation of fetal tissue for medical research. A dozen states investigated Planned Parenthood after edited videos released by anti-abortion activists accused it of illegally selling fetal tissue. No criminal findings were ever made for that activity. While Harris was California attorney general, her agency investigated the anti-abortion activists. They were charged with violating state privacy laws after Harris left for the U.S. Senate.
Sources: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi was photographed with the Manson Family.
Justification: • A meme circulating on Facebook misidentifies a prominent member of the Charles Manson Family as House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.• The woman circled in the meme is Mary Brunner, Manson’s first recruit and mother of his child.• Pelosi lived in San Francisco with five children at the time the photo was taken.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Image shows Nancy Pelosi drunk and being kissed by President Barack Obama.
Justification: This photo is a cropped version of aphototaken Sept. 30, 2016, at Joint Andrews Base as Pelosi, Obama and other dignitaries debarked Air Force One after attending funeral services for former Israeli president Shimon Peres. Other photos show the scene from a different angle. There is no indication Pelosi was inebriated. Pelosi doesn't drink alcohol.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “HOUSE PASSES BILL TO PAY U.N. TO RUN LOCAL POLICE BOARDS IN 46 U.S. CITIES.”
Justification: HR 7120, the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act of 2020, is a sweeping police reform bill that passed the U.S. House in June. It does not mention the United Nations, nor does it empower the United Nations to run local police boards in dozens of U.S. cities.
Sources: H.R. 7120 - George Floyd Justice in Policing Act of 2020

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hillsboro school district has already placed Antifa, BLM in their curriculum as Justice Fighters. Fourth grade.”
Justification: This isn’t true. In fourth grade, Hillsboro students are taught about civic engagement and there’s a series of lessons called Justice Fighters that teach the kids about leaders who fight for justice. It includes Black leaders like Martin Luther King, but it doesn’t call out groups or movements like Antifa or Black Lives Matter.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A CDC report found that “people who wear masks, are actually ‘collecting’ the virus in their masks.”
Justification: • The post inaccurately summarizes a CDC report. In reality, the report found a correlation between regular mask wearing and lower COVID-19 transmission.• Scientific studies have consistently found that face-mask use is one of the most effective means of preventing the transmission of COVID-19. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden said, “You know, we have to come together. That’s why I’m running. I’m running as a proud Democrat for the Senate. So vote! Vote!”
Justification: A Facebook video edited Joe Biden’s remarks, pulling words out of context and omitting a key portion of his remarks. Biden said, "You know, we have to come together. That’s why I’m running. I’m running as a proud Democrat for the Senate, when I had run as a proud Democrat for vice president, and I’m running as a proud Democrat for president. But I promise you this. I will govern as an American president … So vote! Vote!" The video was edited to show Biden saying, "You know, we have to come together. That’s why I’m running. I’m running as a proud Democrat for the Senate. So vote! Vote!"

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Amy Coney Barrett said "calling a Black employee the N-word does not make for a hostile work environment."
Justification: In 2019, Barrett wrote for a unanimous three-judge panel that a plaintiff named Terry Smith being called a racial slur by a former supervisor was not sufficient to support his claim of a racially motivated hostile work environment. Barrett called the comment an "egregious racial epithet" but said the single incident wasn’t enough to constitute a hostile work environment for multiple reasons, including that Smith’s relationship with supervisors had long been problematic. Barrett did not say that being called the racial slur does not ever constitute a hostile work environment.
Sources: U.S. Court of Appeals For the Seventh Circuit

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “ABC News has confirmed that attendees to Trump WH Rally were paid. $150. ea and had to sign an NDA.”
Justification: BLEXIT, a group founded by conservative activist Candace Owens, covered the travel costs for some people to attend the event at the White House on Oct. 10, according to an ABC News report. The story doesn’t mention $150 or a nondisclosure agreement. We couldn’t find other news coverage to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden took a knee during the national anthem.
Justification: • Joe Biden was photographed kneeling during an Oct. 5 campaign stop in Miami.• The national anthem was not playing at the time, two journalists present at the event confirmed.• The photo was taken at the Little Haiti Cultural Center, where Biden posed with dancers standing behind him.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kamala Harris said, “American churches are PROPAGANDA CENTERS for intolerant homophobic, xenophobic vitriol."
Justification: There is no evidence Kamala Harris said this. Harris identifies as a Christian who attends a Baptist church.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Hacked emails “revealed that Hillary Clinton & pals are involved in sex trafficking children.”
Justification: There is no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Chris Christie told Donald Trump to interrupt Joe Biden during the debate because “people who overcome stuttering have a harder time maintaining their train of thought when interrupted. Keep interrupting him and he’ll stumble when he tries to speak. This will enforce the ‘senile’ narrative.”
Justification: • Christie said this claim is "completely false."• We found no evidence to support that the governor said this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: No one showed up for this Joe Biden and Kamala Harris joint campaign event in Arizona.
Justification: The screenshot shows a still image from a local news segment about a campaign stop that Joe Biden and Kamala Harris made in Phoenix on Oct. 8. The stop wasn’t a rally. Biden’s campaign told local news reporters that it didn’t release details about the times and locations of the day’s events to avoid crowding amid the COVID-19 pandemic. A clip of the segment on YouTube was deceptively edited and spliced together so viewers didn’t know that Biden’s campaign chose not to advertise the event.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden said 14,000 people died from H1N1. “Fact checking it is 574,000.”
Justification: • The post cites the number of H1N1 deaths worldwide. The context makes clear that Biden was citing the number of H1N1 deaths in the U.S. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “NYT is correcting their lies..Trump paid $1M in 2016 & $3.8M in 2017-18..THEY LIED..AGAIN. INFO ON TWITTER THIS AM.”
Justification: • The New York Times reported onSept. 27that President Trump paid no federal income tax in 11 of 18 years for which the newspaper had obtained records, and in 2016 and 2017, he paid $750 each year.• The Times has not issuedany correctionson its reporting about Trump’s taxes.• Trump hasnot provided evidenceto counter the Times’ reporting and says he cannot release his tax returns because of an ongoing audit.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: During the debate, Kamala Harris said, “that’s a great segway to the next question,” suggesting she knew the next question.
Justification: Susan Page, the debate’s moderator and Washington bureau chief of USA Today, said "that’s a good segue into our third question" after Vice President Mike Pence finished making a point. Sen. Kamala Harris then said, "That’s a great segue," but it’s unclear what she meant. At the beginning of the debate, Page said no one had been told in advance what topics she would raise or what questions she would ask.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “PHIL MURPHY ONLY ALLOWING IN PERSON VOTING ON Election Day AT PRUDENTIAL CENTER IN NEWARK NJ - Calling it a #SuperPollingStation”
Justification: • New Jersey will send mail-in ballots to all registered voters in the general election.• All counties will be required to provide at least half their usual polling locations on Election Day, when residents can vote in person with a paper provisional ballot.• Drop boxes for ballots will also be available in locations throughout the state.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A U-Haul operated by antifa activists distributed “shields, weapons & black bloc” to protesters in Louisville, Ky., and is linked to “a George Soros-funded initiative.”
Justification: A video shows protesters taking shields, signs and other supplies from the back of a U-Haul truck in Louisville, Ky. Some of the signs bear a symbol associated with antifa activists and the truck’s driver has done anti-fascist organizing in the past. An eyewitness said he didn’t see any weapons in the truck. We could find no evidence that antifa activists passed out weapons at the protests. The claim that the U-Haul is linked to an organization funded by George Soros appears to have originated on forums known for spreading disinformation. There is no connection between the billionaire philanthropist and the truck.
Sources: David E. Barclay and Eric D. Weitz

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden and Obama allowed grown men in restrooms with little girls. Trump has rescued over 300 missing children from (pedophiles) and perverts.”
Justification: •  The post wrongly conflates accommodations for transgender students with child molestation.• During the Obama administration, federal agencies issued guidance instructing schools to allow transgender students to use the facilities that correspond with their gender identity. The guidance was related to students and did not address adults.• There is no evidence President Donald Trump, or any part of his administration, have rescued 300 missing children.
Sources: U.S. Department of Education and U.S. Department of Justice

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Donald Trump boarded Marine One "with a portable oxygen concentrator in his pocket with the nasal cannula going up his back, hidden in his hair and tucked under his mask."
Justification: There is a lot of confusion surrounding Trump’s use of supplemental oxygen to treat his COVID-19 symptoms. But he did not have a portable oxygen concentrator when he left the White House for the hospital. The source of the viral claim appears to be a now-suspended Twitter account. Other angles of Trump’s walk from the White House to Marine One don’t support the conspiracy theory.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says over 1,000 mail in ballots were found in a dumpster in California.
