Justification: The images show old, empty envelopes — not ballots — that were legally disposed of from the November 2018 election.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Merrick Garland is investigating Donald Trump’s “tax evasion case.”
Justification: Merrick Garland is a judge whose 2016 nomination to the Supreme Court was blocked by the Republican-led Senate. The appeals court where Garland served as the chief judge until February has reviewed efforts by Donald Trump to block the House oversight committee from subpoenaing his financial records, but Garland was not involved in the ruling.
Sources: House Committee on Oversight and Reform
U.S. Court of Appeals District of Columbia

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Biden wants to end Shareholder Capitalism.. that's your 401k..your pensions.. your retirement.. are you voting for that???"
Justification: • Biden called for corporations to stop maximizing short-term profits for shareholders at the expense of their workers and communities. He wasn’t calling for the end of shareholding or capitalism altogether.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Jared Kushner “deleted all of his tweets after the tax story broke.”
Justification: • Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump’s son-in-law and adviser, has not posted tweets on his account since 2016.• Kushner did not delete tweets after the news broke about Trump’s tax history.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden has a medical device implanted in his skull so he can hear someone give him answers to questions.
Justification: Envoy Medical said that the claims about its hearing implant were inaccurate and that its device "cannot secretly and wirelessly transmit conversations." Biden’s medical and surgical history summary does not mention any skull implant. The summary says his hearing is normal.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says “Ruth Bader Ginsburg was nominated and confirmed 43 days before an election.”
Justification: Ruth Bader Ginsburg was formally nominated and confirmed as a Supreme Court justice in about 42 days in 1993. The presidential election took place the year before, in 1992.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Facebook is creating these #firstborn and #secondborn challenges so the IRS can confirm who y’all claiming on them taxes as dependents.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that this social media challenge is connected to the IRS or pedophiles.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Judge Amy Coney Barrett said that “gays have a right to be discriminated against because they are against God’s wishes” and that “white people are God’s chosen ones.”
Justification: • Social media posts saying that Barrett has made homophobic and racist statements are fabricated. She never said or wrote the statements. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden “wants American farmers to put their farmland into Gvt ‘land banks.’ Gvt would then tell farmers what ‘sustainable’ plants they could grow.”
Justification: • Biden said during atelevised town hallmeeting that his proposed policies would pay farmers to put land in land banks and to plant certain carbon-absorbing crops. U.S. government programs already exist that pay farmers not to plant crops on their land, or to plant certain crops, including the Conservation Reserve Program and the Conservation Stewardship Program.• Biden vowed to "dramaticallyexpand and fortify" the existingConservation Stewardship Programto include payments based on environmentally friendly practices such as carbon sequestration. He specified during the town hall meeting that his policies would pay farmers "for planting certain crops that in fact absorb carbon from the air."• The programs are voluntary.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Two “Doomsday Planes” took flight because of President Donald Trump’s COVID-19 diagnosis.
Justification: Military officials have said that the flights were pre-planned and unrelated to President Donald Trump’s COVID-19 diagnosis.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden said today, if he loses, his people will keep burning, looting and killing.”
Justification: In a campaign speech on Aug. 31, Biden condemned Donald Trump’s handling of racial justice demonstrations in the United States, saying the president only added fuel to the fire. He didn’t say "his people" would burn, loot and kill if he loses. He denounced looting, arson and violence.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says President Trump tweeted that it’s “not fair for a president to leave office because of BAD votes!” and that the Supreme Court “should decide the presidency at every election.”
Justification: Donald Trump didn’t tweet that the Supreme Court should decide every election.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "This Is Real: Biden Waves To An Empty Field."
Justification: • Biden was waving to firefighters and ground personnel out of frame. ​• Two videos more clearly show Biden waving toward a firetruck at the other end of the field.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A graphic on U.S. abortion rates shows larger declines during recent Democratic presidential administrations, and says its due to the party’s approach of making abortions unnecessary, rather than the Republican Party’s approach of making the procedure illegal.
Justification: The graphic cites CDC data, but health department reporting on abortions has fluctuated so much over the years that making broad comparisons can prove challenging. Experts said tying the abortion rate to the occupant of the White House alone is an oversimplification of a variety of factors at play, including easier access to affordable contraception and fewer women getting pregnant.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kentucky Attorney General Daniel Cameron “married his mentor Mitch McConnell's granddaughter."
Justification: • A spokesperson for McConnell confirmed that Cameron’s wife was not the senator’s granddaughter.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The man in a mugshot is “responsible for lighting 32 of the wildfires” on the West Coast.
Justification: The man in the photo, Brandon McGlover, did not light 32 wildfires, in 2020 or any other year. McGlover was arrested in July 2018 and is currently in prison for lighting nine fires in southwest California, including the Cranston Fire, which forced thousands of evacuations and burned over 13,000 acres. Experts say that climate change has modified environments in the West Coast, making them more conducive to wildfires. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Facebook “is banning Trump from advertising for president.”
Justification: Facebook has removed some Trump campaign ads for violating the company’s policies, but it has not banned the president from advertising. As of Sept. 22, about 880 Trump campaign ads were active on the social media platform.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “9,871,525 is the number of registered voters in AZ according to FB. AZ population is 7,270,000.”
Justification: Facebook confirmed that it hasn’t shared voter registration information by region or state. As part of its 2020 voter information initiative, Facebook displays a tally of users around the country who’ve shared that they registered to vote. It isn’t state specific. But the post gets Arizona’s population right.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An episode of “The Simpsons” showed Donald Trump in a coffin.
Justification: That image of Trump purportedly in a coffin in an episode of "The Simpsons has been circulating for years and has been debunked. The image did not appear in "The Simpsons" and while its origins are unclear, it appears to have been promoted on the fringe forum website 4chan.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden was “wearing a wire” during the first presidential debate.
Justification: A widely shared video on Facebook claims to show former Vice President Joe Biden wearing a wire during the first presidential debate. In fact, it shows a crease in his shirt. The post was widely shared in conspiratorial groups and is the latest example of misinformation about presidential candidates getting help during debates.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Bikers show up to The Walter Reed Hospital to pray for President Trump.”
Justification: A video clip being described as showing bikers praying for Trump outside of Walter Reed National Military Medical Center actually shows protesters in South Africa demonstrating against the killings of farmers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Don’t buy the new Pepsi can coming out with pics of the Empire State building and the Pledge of Allegiance on them. Pepsi left out 2 little words in the pledge ‘Under God.’”
Justification: • Pepsi did not release cans with a design that featured the Empire State Building and a portion of the Pledge of Allegiance that omitted the words "under God."• Dr Pepper released a can with the Statue of Liberty and the words "One nation… indivisible" in 2001, following the 9/11 terrorist attacks.• As early as 2002, these claims against Pepsi were debunked.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Amy Coney Barrett has said that a woman should not be able to own property, buy or sell without the permission of her husband or a male relative.”
Justification: There’s no evidence President Donald Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court made such a statement.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden “made it clear..No More Coal Fired Power Plants!! So, No More Coal!! Wake Up WV, PA,OH, KY”
Justification: • Joe Biden said "nobody’s going to build another coal-fired plant in America" during the first presidential debate.• He said under the Obama administration, he brought the cost of renewable energy down to "cheaper than or as cheap as" coal, gas and oil, and his energy plan states that "marketplace competition has continued to shift this country away from coal-fired electricity."• His climate action plan does not include a ban on coal.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Donald Trump is not at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, “he is on AF1.”
Justification: The post was published by a supporter of QAnon, a baseless conspiracy theory that says Trump is secretly fighting a cabal of pedophiles. It’s inaccurate to say that Trump is on Air Force One instead of staying at Walter Reed. Photo and video evidence place the president at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. There is no evidence that Trump is faking his illness.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A federal judge just ordered Wisconsin must have all ballots counted by 8 p.m. on the day of the election.”
Justification: This Facebook post gets it completely wrong. First, voters in line at 8 p.m. on Election Day can legally cast their vote. So it’s impossible for all votes to be counted by 8 p.m. No judge made this ruling. It is fabricated. A ruling from a federal judge -- upheld by an appeals panel -- actually does the opposite. It allows any absentee ballots returned by Nov. 9 to be counted, as long as they were postmarked by Election Day.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Olive Garden employees are allowed to wear Black Lives Matter masks “but NOT the American flag.”
Justification: Servers must wear protective masks. Olive Garden says employees can wear whatever masks they want.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Anti-poaching organizations dye elephant tusks and rhino horns with “the same pink dye that is used to mark stolen banknotes.”
Justification: • Images showing rhinos and elephants with pink horns are doctored from stock photos.• Some organizations have infused rhino horns with a mixture of poison and dye to deter poaching. However, this process only produces a slight discoloration on the outside of the horn.• Conservationists say that superficially staining tusks and horns is impractical.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Kenosha car dealer kills himself after insurance won’t cover … damages caused by the riots.”
Justification: The headline shown here was manipulated — no such story was published by Fox Business Network. The headline is poorly worded and misspelled, and the supposed screenshot lacks a date, byline and other elements a legitimate story would have included. The family that owns the Car Source lot confirms no one involved in the ownership had taken their own life. However, it is correct that insurance has so far refused to cover the damage.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “James Comey has 50 counts of TREASON. And John Brennan has 48 counts of TREASON.”
Justification: Former FBI Director James Comey and former CIA Director John Brennan have not been charged with treason.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “So far, out of 175 arrested in Kenosha, 102 were not from Kenosha. Rioting has become its own industry.”
Justification: The numbers are correct, but the "industry" claim is not. 90% of those arrested were from Wisconsin or nearby Illinois, the people one would expect to naturally gather for a local protest. A dozen West Coast residents were arrested, but most were from a nonprofit that says it detoured to Kenosha to feed the protesters.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “In 1983, Joe Biden voted in favor of taxing 50% of Social Security” and in 1993, Biden “was the deciding vote in raising the percentage taxed on Social Security from 50% to 85%.”
Justification: In 1983, then-Sen. Biden voted in favor of legislation to allow up to 50% of Social Security benefits to be added to taxable income if the taxpayer’s total income exceeded certain thresholds. The legislation, intended to shore up Social Security, had bipartisan support and was signed by President Ronald Reagan. In 1993, the Senate along with Biden passed President Bill Clinton’s deficit reduction plan, which required recipients with certain incomes to pay taxes on 85% of their Social Security benefits. In 1993, Vice President Al Gore cast the deciding vote after the Senate split 50-50.
Sources: Center for Budget and Policy Priorities

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Quotes Kamala Harris as saying “Take the guns first. Go through due process second, I like taking the guns early.”
Justification: Sen. Kamala Harris didn’t say this. The comment was made by President Trump in 2018.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Kroger Corporate says employees can not wear flag masks but they can wear BLM masks!”
Justification: The uniform policy at Kroger grocery stores prohibits employees from wearing anything with visible pictures, logos, words or abbreviations.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “McDonald’s removes their American flags in support of Antifa & BLM nationwide.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The CDC has removed the ‘Covid-19 Pandemic’ and replaced it with ‘Covid-19 Outbreak’ on their website. It was never a pandemic.”
Justification: • The World Health Organization declared COVID-19 a pandemic in March.• There is no evidence the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention removed the term "pandemic" and replaced it with "outbreak" on its website homepage; "outbreak" has been used on the homepage for months.• On many pages, the CDC website refers to "the COVID-19 pandemic."
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Most of the wildfires on the West Coast are “all being started by antifa.”
Justification: A combination of drought, historic heat, lightning storms and heavy winds are thought to have contributed to more than 90 wildfires that have burned thousands of square miles across the West Coast. Antifa stands for "anti-fascist." It’s a loose, broad coalition of left-wing activists. There is no evidence that antifa supporters set wildfires in California, Oregon and Washington. Police and fire officials have dispelled rumors about antifa, and while investigations are still ongoing, many of the wildfires appear to have been sparked accidentally.
Sources: National Interagency Coordination Center Incident Management Situation Report

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "ANTIFA is now carrying chain saws, and cutting down utility poles, and starting more fires."
Justification: The post may stem from comments made by a sheriff’s captain during a Clackamas County, Ore., commission meeting. He said the office had received reports of "suspected antifa" activists and people trying to down telephone poles and start more fires. But the sheriff’s captain said those reports are unconfirmed. And multiple police departments, fire officials and the FBI’s Portland field office have debunked rumors that antifa has anything to do with wildfires on the West Coast. While the cause of many fires is under investigation, all evidence points to a mix of weather, downed power lines and fires set by people trying to enjoy the outdoors.
Sources: National Interagency Coordination Center Incident Management Situation Report

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows “some of the firefighters in California fighting fires 24/7 to save people's lives and property.”
Justification: The photo is from 2016 in Tennessee.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “CBS stole a photo from Latinos for Trump in Phoenix and tagged it as a Biden event.”
Justification: "CBS Evening News" ran a segment Sept. 15 about a Joe Biden campaign trip to Florida and his efforts to court Latino voters. At one point, while CBS News correspondent Ed O’Keefe spoke in a voiceover about President Donald Trump’s standing with Latino voters, an image of a Latinos for Trump event in Phoenix was displayed on screen. The full segment makes it clear that "CBS Evening News" was not trying to pass off the photo of Trump’s Latino supporters as the crowd from a Biden event.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “4 republican senators now on board...no vote until January on (Supreme Court): Murkowski, Romney, Collins, Grassley.”
Justification: Two of the senators cited, Lisa Murkowski and Susan Collins, have stated their position since Ginsburg’s death. They both said they opposed a vote before the election, but they did not explicitly rule out a vote after the election during the lame-duck period before a new Congress is sworn in. The other two senators, Romney and Grassley, have not commented about how to proceed with the current vacancy.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Donald Trump funded a Veterans Day parade 26 years ago in New York City after the city refused to pay.
Justification: When he was a real estate developer, Donald Trump helped raise funds and donated at least $200,000 to organizers of the 1995 Veterans Day parade in New York City. While he didn’t finance the parade on his own, he is credited by organizers for saving the event, which had drawn zero contributions from corporations at the time of his donation.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a Twitter account for "Scarsdale NY Antifa" tweeted that "chapters of Antifa around Oregon have collaborated to ignite fires around the state."
Justification: Antifa stands for "anti-fascist" and refers to a broad coalition of activists — including communists, anarchists and socialists — that has been around for decades. There is no evidence that antifa activists ignited the wildfires that have burned recently in Oregon and throughout the West Coast. The Twitter account allegedly belonging to an antifa group in Scarsdale, N.Y., has been suspended from Twitter, a company spokesperson confirmed.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a photo shows an ambushed Los Angeles police officer and that the NFL intends to “honor and praise the organization” that stood outside of the hospital chanting, “We hope she dies.”
Justification: The Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department has released neither the names nor photos of the ambushed officers. The photo does not show one of the victims. The NFL did not honor any protester or movement that called for the death of the ambushed police.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Entire port in Delaware on lockdown? 60 plus kids in shipping containers.”
Justification: This didn’t happen.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “CDC announces that ordinary (non-N95) masks (which most people are wearing) will do nothing to protect you against wildfire smoke … Fun fact: smoke particles are far larger than SARS-CoV-2 particles.”
Justification: The CDC said cloth masks provide little protection against wildfire smoke because they don’t catch microscopic smoke particles that can get into the lungs. For COVID-19, cloth masks are used as a form of source control to help stop the spread of the virus and are meant to protect others by blocking the wearer’s coughs or sneezes, which are considered larger respiratory droplets, not to protect the wearer from tiny viral particles. Wildfire smoke particles have a range of sizes, experts said, and some are comparable to COVID-19 particles.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Nobody is found dead of corona in their homes.. They all die at the hospital.”
Justification: Most people who died of COVID-19 in the United States died in medical facilities, but nearly 10,000 as of Sept. 17 had died at home, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says President Trump posted a combative tweet to EA Sports about Colin Kaepernick.
Justification: The tweet is fake. It was fabricated by a satirical sports account.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: West Coast wildfires are due to “bad forest maintenance,” not climate change.
Justification: • Climate change has modified environments in the West Coast, making them more conducive to wildfires. ​• Forest maintenance does play a role in mitigating forest fires, but that doesn't negate the role of climate change in making environments more flammable.• Experts say forest management should be thought of as one among many tools to cushion the effects of climate change, including the increased risk of wildfires.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: If Joe Biden steps down, Nancy Pelosi will become vice president.
Justification: The House speaker does not automatically become vice president if the president steps down. If Joe Biden were elected president and then stepped down, his vice president, Kamala Harris, would assume the office. She could then nominate Nancy Pelosi to become vice president, or someone else. Whoever she nominates would have to face confirmation by the House and Senate.
Sources: 3 U.S. Code § 19. Vacancy in offices of both President and Vice President; officers eligible to act

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “A portion of everything you pay A.A.R.P goes directly to the Democratic Party.”
Justification: • AARP is a nonpartisan nonprofit organization.• AARP has a policy against endorsing or appearing to endorse political parties, government officials or candidates for office.• This claim has been debunked numerous times by other fact-checking organizations.
Sources: Email interview with AARP spokesperson Jason Young

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “This is what Kamala Harris thinks about young Americans … ‘They are stupid!’”
Justification: In a 2014 speech about how the criminal justice system shouldn’t penalize young adults for making certain mistakes, Sen. Kamala Harris, then California’s attorney general, described young people ages 18 to 24 as "stupid." The quote being shared online lacks that context.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Houston Texans coming out for the Black National Anthem then going into the locker room for THE REAL NATIONAL ANTHEM is DISGRACEFUL.”
Justification: The Texans stayed in their locker room for both anthems.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Canada has just criminalized all CV19 measures requiring masks, distancing, quarantining & vaccines.”
Justification: • The Canadian government has not enacted a law that criminalizes COVID-19 restrictions or prevents enforcement of those guidelines.• There are places in Canada where you can be fined for disobeying COVID-19 public health orders.• The post appears to be referring to a proclamation issued by a "council of citizens’ assemblies."
Sources: Email interview with Canadian House of Commons spokesperson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “KXL Radio in Portland reported today that Firefighters are now being shot at by suspected Antifa and BLM members.”
Justification: There's no evidence that activists attacked firefighters, and KXL did not report that.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “You people hate on Trump but he put on a child protective force that found over 300 missing kids in less than 30 days.”
Justification: • There is no evidence that President Donald Trump established a child protective force that searches for missing children.• The U.S. Marshals Service has helped recover missing children, but not more than 300 in less than 30 days, as the post claims.• The Marshals’ Missing Child Unit was created during the Obama administration.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: More than 500,000 mail in ballots in Virginia and 200,000 in Nevada were sent to dead people or pets
Justification: A voter registration group sent 500,000 applications for absentee ballots — not actual ballots — to Virginia voters. The applications had the wrong elections office return address. Around 226,000 ballots sent to voters in Clark County, Nev., were returned as undeliverable because the voters no longer lived at the addresses. In neither case was there evidence of thousands of ballots being sent to dead people and pets.
Sources: Center for Voter Information CEO and President

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi passed a bill awarding a $9 billion contract to her husband’s company.
Justification: • Nancy Pelosi hasn’t held a seat on the House Appropriations Committee for 18 years.• No such bill exists.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Two mail in ballots in PA (were) sent to the same person with their names on both a week and a half apart.”
Justification: A photo shared online appears to show duplicate mail-in ballots addressed to one Pittsburgh resident. It’s very unlikely that the person, or anyone else who erroneously receives more than one ballot could vote more than once. The system uses one unique barcode, or number, for each voter. If a duplicate is scanned, election officials would mark the ballot as rejected.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “At 17 years old Kyle (Rittenhouse) was perfectly legal to be able to possess that rifle without parental supervision.”
Justification: N/A

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “... in 2013 Obama determined Social Security would not send checks through the USPS, because it was not secure”
Justification: • A law shifted Social Security benefits and statements to primarily paperless, electronic delivery by March 2013, but some recipients can choose mailed checks.• The shift to a paperless system was promoted as cost-saving and eco-friendly.• Hundreds of thousands of Americans still receive their Social Security checks by mail.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says “Kamala Harris is not able to be VP. Because she's a felon. She lied on her application to buy a gun here in CA.”
Justification: • There is no evidence that Sen. Kamala Harris was ever convicted of a felony.• A person convicted of a felony could still serve as vice president.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Says authorities found 39 children in a double wide trailer in Georgia and it's not the biggest news story in America.”
Justification: Authorities found 39 missing children in Georgia, but not all in one location and not in a "double wide trailer." Many news outlets covered the story.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “PELOSI says if President TRUMP wins, she will resign!!”
Justification: Nancy Pelosi didn’t say this. This claim originated on a website that describes its content as satire.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If I mail in my ballot on Sunday and show up to the polling station on Tuesday, they won’t know if I’ve already voted or not. That, my friends, is a serious concern for all of us.”
Justification: All states have different procedures in place to prevent double voting, and mail-in ballots are verified before they are counted. Voting or trying to vote twice is illegal. Experts said signing a mail-in ballot and casting an in-person ballot would be a surefire way to get caught committing voter fraud. Experts advise sending in vote-by-mail ballots early to be sure they are counted.
Sources: Email interview with Charles Stewart III
Maryland Office of the Attorney General

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Jill Biden said, “all Americans will be required to learn Spanish when we win”
Justification: Jill Biden is studying Spanish on the Babbel app. She has not called for requiring everyone to learn Spanish.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden was asleep and snoring during a TV interview.
Justification: That didn’t happen. The video was edited to create a deceiving and inaccurate narrative. The original video from 2011 involved an interview with Harry Belafonte. The fabricated video used a clip of Biden from an April town hall. Biden did not fall asleep then, either.
Sources: Archive of Facebook post with manipulated video

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Melania Trump is the “first FLOTUS to visit troops in a combat zone since 1969.”
Justification: This is false. At least two former first ladies — Michelle Obama and Laura Bush —  have visited U.S. troops in designated combat zones since first lady Pat Nixon went to South Vietnam in 1969. Michelle Obama visited troops in 2015 in Qatar, and Laura Bush made trips to Afghanistan in 2005 and 2008.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Jacob Blake, shot by police in Kenosha, had a warrant for sexual assault and prior convictions for gun use
Justification: Blake did have an active warrant from a May 2020 incident where he is accused of sexually assaulting a woman and stealing her debit card and car keys. That case has not yet gone to trial. A police dispatcher alerted responding officers to the warrant, according to scanner audio. Prior charges stemming from a bar confrontation in 2015 were dismissed by prosecutors.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Elderly people were “beat up by a BLM hate group” for being white.
Justification: Multiple photos in the collage show elderly people who were attacked in South Africa, some several years ago. There’s no evidence the images were taken in the U.S. or have any connection to the Black Lives Matter movement.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Countries were exporting COVID-19 “diagnostic test instruments” in 2018.
Justification: The World Bank created a list of exports of COVID-19 testing equipment, drawing from an older list of existing diagnostic testing equipment. Some equipment now used for COVID-19 testing existed prior to 2019 and was marked as being available before that year.  But COVID-19 tests did not exist in 2018.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The CDC “adjusted the US Covid deaths from 153,504 to 9,210.”
Justification: President Donald Trump retweeted multiple posts that falsely claimed the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention decreased the number of U.S. coronavirus deaths to 9,210. Those posts misconstrue data from the CDC, which shows that the vast majority of coronavirus-related deaths occur in patients who have comorbidities like influenza or pneumonia. As of Aug. 31, the CDC reported that 182,622 Americans have died since the start of the pandemic. Some estimates put the death toll even higher.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “NIKE has stated, ‘We’re a $76 billion dollar company that can afford to let go of all ‘Make America Great Again’ customers.”
Justification: Nike didn’t say this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "PEDOPHILIA is now LEGAL in CALIFORNIA. Now a 21 year old can have sex with an 11 year old, and not be listed on the sex registry as a sex offender."
Justification: A flood of social media posts claimed California had "legalized" pedophilia. Some said offenders who had sex with minors as young as 11 would not be placed on the state’s sex offender registry. Those claims are both false. In reality, the California Legislature passed a bill that aims to eliminate automatic sex offender registration mainly for LGBTQ young adults. Instead, a judge would decide whether to register for life those convicted of having voluntary anal or oral sex with a minor and are within 10 years of age of the victim. The bill does not reduce the standards for statutory rape. Existing law allows judges to decide whether to place offenders on the registry in cases involving vaginal intercourse. The bill in question only applies to young people ages 14, 15, 16 or 17 and any offender within a 10 year age range.
Sources: California Senate Floor Analyses on SB 145
State Sen. Scott Wiener and Asm. Sydney Kamlager

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Feds Seize 19,888 Fake State Driver Licenses (Made in China) in Chicago O'Hare Airport - ALL Registered to Vote -- ALL Demorats!”
Justification: • About 20,000 fake driver’s licenses were seized at Chicago O'Hare International Airport between January and June 2020.• There is no evidence that the confiscated fake licenses could be used to commit voter fraud, or that they were all headed to registered Democratic voters.• There are fail-safes in place to prevent voters from using fake IDs to vote or register to vote.
Sources: Email interview with Michigan Secretary of State Spokesperson Tracy Wimmer
National Association of Secretaries of State

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Video showed police thank (Kyle Rittenhouse) & give him water prior to the killings”
Justification: A two-hour livestream of the Kenosha protests from Aug. 25, 2020, shows Rittenhouse interacting with police. About 15 minutes before the shooting, officers throw a water bottle in response to Rittenhouse’s request. An officer then said to Rittenhouse’s group, "We appreciate you guys, we really do."
Sources: Facebook messenger exchange with Kristan T. Harris

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “It cost taxpayers $120,000 to fly Nancy (Pelosi) to get her hair done.”
Justification: Security footage shows House Speaker Nancy Pelosi in a San Francisco hair salon on Aug. 31, when it was against city rules for salons to operate. There is no evidence that Pelosi’s hair appointment cost taxpayers tens of thousands of dollars. The speaker did not fly to San Francisco specifically to get her hair done, and she has routinely flown commercial airlines since 2011.
Sources: San Francisco Office of the Mayor

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “South Korea sprays rioters with dye so they can be identified & arrested later.”
Justification: South Korea stopped using dye to mark protesters in 2015. Human rights groups have criticized the practice as an invasive form of surveillance. Hong Kong police used dye cannons on protesters demonstrating last year against the Chinese government. ​

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden “wants to put a 3% annual federal tax on your home.”
Justification: Joe Biden has not proposed a nationwide property tax, nor has he advocated raising taxes on Americans making less than $400,000 per year.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Trump denies fire assistance to California because they didn't vote for him, but helped Russia with their wildfires in Siberia.”
Justification: A widely-shared Facebook post claims President Trump denied fire aid to California but helped Russia fight wildfires in Siberia. Trump has repeatedly threatened to withhold federal wildfire assistance from California, including last week. But the White House approved assistance days later. Last year, Trump said he offered Russia help with its fires in Siberia. We found no evidence he followed through. Two months after we published this fact check, the Trump administration rejected subsequent California fire aid requests.
Sources: Office of California Gov. Gavin Newsom

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Police training in Wisconsin is 21 weeks. A cosmetology license takes 40 weeks.”
Justification: In Wisconsin, cosmetologists are required to put in more time for training than police. But aspiring officers must have an associate’s degree (at hiring, or finished within their first five years) for a position, something not required for a cosmetology license. Officers must also undergo a medical assessment, background check and drug test.
Sources: Wisconsin Department of Safety and Professional Services

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Jacob Blake “declared he had a gun in the car and was going to go get it” and was “brandishing” a knife
Justification: There was no gun involved. State investigators said there was none found at the scene. Police did find a knife in the SUV, but authorities haven’t said if it was there throughout the confrontation or if Blake held it at some point. Grainy video shows an object in Blake’s hand, but he didn’t "brandish" it, and it’s not clear if it’s a knife, sunglasses or something else.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Jacob S. Blake is a Child (16 YO Girl) Rapist.”
Justification: Jacob Blake, a 29-year-old Black man, was shot in the back by a white police officer in Kenosha, Wis., on Aug. 23. There is no evidence that Blake is a "child rapist." Court records show that Blake has been charged with one felony count of third-degree sexual assault related to an alleged incident of domestic abuse. Under Wisconsin law, sex with a minor is not one of the offenses included in that charge.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “BLM rioters just burned down a black church in a black community with a BLM sign out front.”
Justification: A fire that was set at a used-car dealership adjacent to Bradford Community Church in Kenosha, Wis., burned the church’s sign, which said "Black Lives Matter." The church did not burn down, and the church’s minister said he does not think the church was a target. The church is in the city’s historic downtown and "relatively close" to what would be considered a Black neighborhood, the minister said, but the congregation is largely white.
Sources: Interview with the Rev. Erik David Carlson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a photo shows accused shooter Kyle Rittenhouse’s mother, armed with a long gun, in Kenosha, Wisconsin, on the night two protesters were killed and one injured.
Justification: A photo purports to show the mother of Kyle Rittenhouse, who is charged owth shooting and killing two at a protest in Kenosha. But the photo, which depicts a white woman with a long gun strapped to her chest, is a cropped image from a photo taken on Aug. 24, 2020 in Madison, two days before Rittenhouse arrived in Kenosha It is unknown whether the teen’s mother drove him to the protest that day — but this photo is from a different scene, in a different city.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If you go to Antifa.com, it takes you directly to Joe Biden’s webpage...what’s that tell ya…try it yourself.”
Justification: Anyone can buy and redirect a domain to another website without the permission or coordination from the person that it’s being redirected to. Computer experts told us that redirecting a domain name is no different than forwarding a telephone number or mailing address. The person on the receiving end can’t do much to stop you.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a picture of stacked mailboxes is proof of voter suppression in Wisconsin
Justification: The picture was taken at Hartford Finishing, which has a contract with USPS to refinish or destroy old mailboxes. The picture has nothing to do with voter suppression. The boxes were either removed from little-used locations or replaced with new boxes due to their condition, USPS says.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Biden supports a school choice ban that would impact 74,000 Wisconsin students.
Justification: Biden does oppose one stripe of school choice programs, ones that apply public tax dollars to parents’ private school tuition bills. But the term "school choice" also covers an array of other programs that Biden supports. And the president doesn't have the power to "ban" voucher programs — they are authorized and funded by the state.
Sources: Interview and email exchange with Frederick Hess
Interview and email exchange with Jim Bender

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says "Pelosi blackmails Congress! She demands mail-in voting or no 2nd stimulus for you and your family.”
Justification: Pelosi does not have the power to "demand" mail-in voting for November; that is being decided by each state governor The HEROES Act includes election funding for states to conduct safe elections in any form during COVID-19
Sources: Email exchange with Frances R. Hill

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Clicking on this link in a text message lets sex traffickers track you.
Justification: These text messages appear to be scams, but not tools for sex traffickers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Contractors hired by government officials to frame Donald Trump are “behind the fake news in mainstream media” and recent protests.
Justification: This viral video makes unfounded claims about the deep state, the president, the media and protests in the wake of George Floyd’s death.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Michelle Obama said, “Vote Democrat or the riots and violence will continue.”
Justification: Michelle Obama didn’t say this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kamala Harris inaccurately “claimed to be bussed in the 60’s due to segregation type issues.”
Justification: In 1970, when Kamala Harris was in first grade, she was part of an effort to desegregate Berkeley, Calif., schools using busing.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: If Joe Biden can’t serve his full term, Kamala Harris “cannot by constitutional law become president.”
Justification: Kamala Harris’ father and mother were born in Jamaica and India, respectively, but she is a natural-born citizen and eligible to be president of the United States.
Sources: The Truths We Hold: An American Journey
United States v. Wong Kim Ark

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “As of the last 24 hours this is the protocol regarding masks: Masks should only be used by healthcare workers, caretakers or by people who are sick with symptoms like fever and cough.”
Justification: The photo is outdated. The giveaway is the Nasdaq composite index listed in the bottom right-hand corner. The Nasdaq hasn’t sat at 9,415.23 since mid-June; the post claims the photo was taken in mid-August. The quote depicted in the image is from at least as early of March, a Google search shows. The World Health Organization currently says governments should encourage the general public to wear a fabric mask if "there is widespread community transmission, and especially in settings where physical distancing cannot be maintained."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Mike Pence “said he won’t debate Kamala Harris.”
Justification: We found no evidence that Mike Pence said he won’t debate Kamala Harris. He has said that he "can’t wait" to debate her.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "In 3 months, Melania took 21 trips to NY, to get her hair done, at taxpayer cost of $675,000 or $32,143/trip."
Justification: • Military flight records show that Melania Trump incurred $675,000 in taxpayer-funded travel expenses in the first three months of the Trump presidency.​• She traveled frequently to New York to spend time with her son, Barron, not "to get her hair done."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Let me splain how ‘no payroll taxes’ helps you, it doesn’t. It helps employers.”
Justification: • Many observers say the payroll tax break makes life harder for employers, because it’s unclear where things will stand next year after the election.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kamala Harris said, “If elected & you don’t surrender your guns, I will sign an executive order & the police will show up at your door.”
Justification: • There is no evidence Sen. Kamala Harris ever said this.• When she was a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, Harris pledged to act on gun control within 100 days of being in office, but she did not say she would sign an executive order if elected that would force people to surrender their guns.• Other fact-checking organizations have debunked this claim.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: President Donald Trump “put a hold on ALL EVICTIONS through December.”
Justification: • An eviction moratorium for properties linked to federal housing financing was included in the CARES Act, a major coronavirus relief bill. The moratorium expired in late July.• Trump’s executive order doesn’t extend the moratorium. Instead, it takes a softer approach by telling executive branch officials to think about possible solutions to evictions during the coronavirus pandemic and its related economic downturn. The executive order also says nothing about any December deadline.
Sources: Center on Budget and Policy Priorities

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Condoleezza Rice said, “If you are taught bitterness and anger, then you will believe you are a victim. You will feel aggrieved and the twin brother of aggrievement is entitlement. So now you think you are owed something and you don’t have to work for it and now you’re on a really bad road to nowhere because there are people who will play to that sense of victimhood, aggrievement and entitlement, and you still won’t have a job.”
Justification: Condoleezza Rice has spoken about aggrievement and entitlement but this post appears to paraphrase and embellish her words, which were not pointed at the Democratic Party.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says series of 11 photos are “from the 1918 flu pandemic.”
Justification: • Five of the 11 photos are from the 1918 flu pandemic. Six are not.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
National Library of Medicine’s Circulating Now
The Seattle Times’ Pacific NW Magazine

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden owns a private island next to Jeffrey Epstein’s.
Justification: There’s no evidence that Joe Biden owns a private island near Little St. James, Jeffrey Epstein’s island in the U.S. Virgin Islands.
Sources: Property records searches for Sussex County
Various searches on Google and Nexis
Various searches on the U.S. Virgin Islands recorder of deeds database

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden and Kamala Harris would raise the federal income tax rate for a person with a bi-weekly gross salary of $3,000 to 39.6%, costing “nearly half your paycheck.”
Justification: Biden has vowed not to raise taxes on people making less than $400,000 per year. An individual taxpayer making $3,000 every two weeks, or roughly $78,000 per year, would not have his or her income taxed at 39.6% under Joe Biden’s plan. Biden wants to raise the top individual federal income tax rate to 39.6% from 37%. That would apply to Americans making far more annually than $78,000.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kamala Harris said, “I don’t like Joe Biden and do not like his history with certain people or who he’s aligned with, he’s trash to me.”
Justification: This quote comes from a blog post about Kamala Harris and Joe Biden, but it was the post’s author — not Harris — who called Biden "trash."

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Biden’s tax rate on a family making 75,000 dollars would go from 12% to 25%.”
Justification: Biden has promised not to raise taxes for anyone making less than $400,000 a year. So he has no plan to increase federal tax rates on a family earning $75,000 annually. Biden’s tax plan seeks to raise up to $4 trillion in tax revenues over a decade. His proposed changes, which include raising the top individual income tax rate to 39.6%, would largely target wealthy Americans.
Sources: Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Kamala Harris refused to be sworn in using the Bible.”
Justification: U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris was sworn in using a Bible.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Killing the payroll tax means killing Social Security.”
Justification: Donald Trump’s payroll tax holiday pauses payroll taxes but does not end them permanently. This executive action by itself doesn’t cripple either Social Security or Medicare, but it does increase the pressure on huge programs already under financial stress.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Trump’s plan “would suspend the 7.65% your employer matches. See? You will NOT get that, nor will your wage or salary increase by 7.65%”
Justification: N/A

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Kamala Harris wants to eliminate beef.
Justification: Kamala Harris co-sponsored a bill to protect workers at meatpacking plants from the spread of COVID-19. Harris said the government should offer incentives and dietary guidelines to reduce the consumption of meat, but she didn’t say she wants to eliminate beef altogether.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: An Illinois couple who received five vote-by-mail applications can vote five times.
Justification: In Illinois, election officials will mail a ballot to a voter only after they verify that the signature on the application matches the signature on file for the voter. Each person has a unique voter ID that’s tied to a single ballot, election officials say. Once a voter’s application is received and verified, any subsequent applications will be rejected.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Post Office advises never send cash in the mail. It’s not secure. Vote by mail?”
Justification: The Postal Service doesn’t say to never send cash in the mail, and it offers insurance for cash sent in the mail. But it "is advisable to send money via a personal or certified check or money order." "The U.S. Mail remains a secure, efficient and effective means for citizens to participate in the electoral process," a spokesperson said.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Say Joe Biden is a pedophile.
Justification: There is no credible evidence that supports this claim. In Joe Biden’s more than 40 years of public life, we could find no news reports, formal accusations, complaints, arrests or investigations that implicate him in any sort of sex crimes involving kids.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The FBI raided a “Cleveland office linked to Ukraine. Biden, Pelosi, Kerry and Romney all had sons getting tens of millions of dollars from no-show jobs in Ukraine.”
Justification: On Aug. 4, agents with the FBI and the Internal Revenue Service raided offices in Miami and Cleveland that belong to Optima Management Group LLC. Optima is partially owned by principals of the Privat Group, a large business group based in Ukraine. One of those principals is Ukrainian oligarch Igor Kolomoisky, who has been the subject of an FBI investigation for more than a year. The Justice Department has accused him of an international money laundering scheme. The sons of Nancy Pelosi, John Kerry, Joe Biden and Mitt Romney are unrelated to the investigation.
Sources: Email from FBI Special Agent Vicki Anderson

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Melania dug up the WH Rose Garden, removing roses from every First Lady since 1913.”
Justification: Over the years, roses have both died and been replaced as different administrations have left their mark on the White House Rose Garden. "Most of these were long gone by the time the Trumps moved in," a landscape historian said.
Sources: The White House Rose Garden Landscape Report

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Anthony Fauci, Bill Gates, George Soros and Jeffrey Epstein are connected with Moderna, Inc., and its efforts to create the coronavirus vaccine.
Justification: The connections the post claims are wrong. Fauci is more than 14 years older than Gates and had already graduated from Cornell and was working at the NIH when Gates was in college. Gates did not attend Cornell and did not room with Fauci. IG Farben is not connected to Moderna. Fauci was never CEO of Moderna. Epstein was not the primary stockholder of Moderna when he died.
Sources: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “At John Lewis funeral Obama told a room full of people that rooms full of people is too dangerous so we must mail in vote.”
Justification: Barack Obama spoke about voting rights and voter suppression during his eulogy at John Lewis’s funeral, but he didn’t say that rooms full of people are so dangerous that mail-in voting is necessary.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says actor Kurt Russell said this about the police.
Justification: There’s no evidence Kurt Russell wrote this, and other iterations say the author is unknown.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “America was the ONLY country that ended” slavery
Justification: Mexico, Britain, France, and Denmark had all abolished slavery before the United States adopted the 13th Amendment in 1865. Other claims in the post are inaccurate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Herd immunity has been reached.”
Justification: We have not reached herd immunity against the coronavirus, and scientists say we aren’t close to achieving it in the United States.Scientists estimate herd immunity will probably be reached when 60% to 70% of the population has been infected.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The Beirut explosion was linked to “human trafficking by HRC."
Justification: Posts linking the Beirut explosion to Hillary Clinton and a human trafficking operation have been widely shared in Facebook groups dedicated to the Pizzagate and QAnon conspiracy theories. Lebanese officials have attributed the blast to the ignition of more than 2,700 tons of ammonium nitrate, although they haven’t ruled out a "rocket or bomb" as a possible cause of the fire. There is no evidence that Clinton or a sex trafficking operation had anything to do with the tragedy.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The NFL agreed to give the domestic terror group, BLM, 250 million dollars.”
Justification: The NFL has pledged $250 million over 10 years to combat systemic racism. The league will work with players to identify programs to donate the money to.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “American coronavirus vaccine killed five Ukrainians.”
Justification: The alleged testing and deaths have not been reported on by any mainstream news organizations. The claim is by a website known for producing pro-Russian disinformation. Two global databases show no testing in Ukraine for a coronavirus vaccine.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “If you have worked during the COVID-19 pandemic, the Department of Labor has finally authorized up to $4,800 in hazard pay for qualified essential workers.”
Justification: This is a hoax.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Bubba Watson wrote a viral Facebook post about Black Lives Matter.
Justification: Bubba Watson didn’t write this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Black Lives Matter is a terrorist organization."
Justification: The State Department keeps a list of foreign groups that have been formally designated terrorist organizations. Black Lives Matter, a domestic organization, is not on it. There is no legal process for designating domestic groups as terrorist organizations. Black Lives Matter is not listed as a perpetrator group in a global database of nearly 200,000 terrorism incidents.
Sources: University of Maryland Global Terrorism Database

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Mark Zuckerberg's real name is Jacob Greenberg and he’s the grandson of billionaire David Rockefeller.
Justification: The conspiracy theory appeared in 2012 after some thought a mugshot of a man with that name looked like Mark Zuckerberg, but a simple comparison shows they’re not the same person. There is no one with the name Jacob Greenberg related to the Rockefeller family.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Say that according to the Los Angeles Times, “95% of warrants for murder in Los Angeles are for illegal aliens,” more than two-thirds of all births in Los Angeles County “are to illegal alien Mexicans” on Medicaid, “nearly 60% of all occupants of HUD properties are illegal,” and Nancy Pelosi “wants to put a windfall tax” on retirement fund profits.
Justification: • The assertions in this post range from unsupported to incorrect, even though they have been circulating consistently for almost a decade and a half despite repeated debunkings by fact-checkers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Tom Hanks’ name is on Jeffrey Epstein’s flight logs.
Justification: Tom Hanks’ name does not appear on the flight logs and there is no other evidence to indicate he flew on Epstein’s plane.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Florida is doing over five times better” than New Jersey and New York in COVID-19 deaths per million people.
Justification: The claim is accurate on one measure — the number of COVID-19 deaths per capita for the duration of the outbreak. But the claim is that Florida is doing well now, when in fact deaths are on the rise.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Scores of politicians and others are on a “list” of sex cases from newly unsealed Ghislaine Maxwell court documents.
Justification: Maxwell was the companion of Jeffrey Epstein. She is charged with luring girls to be sexually abused by the late financier. Newly unsealed documents, from a civil suit involving Maxwell, contain more details about the allegations against the pair. A list shared on Facebook of scores of people who were convicted of sex crimes or were allegedly involved in other sex-related acts does not come from the unsealed documents. Cases on the list were made publicyears ago.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Social media posts claim the U.S. Postal Service “says you should give mail in ballots at least 14 days roundtrip. So, if you plan to vote by mail, election day isn’t November 3. It’s October 20th.”
Justification: Social media posts claimed Election Day is really Oct. 20, and not Nov. 3, for those who want to vote-by-mail. They also said the U.S. Postal Service recommends allowing two weeks between the time you request your mail-in ballot and placing it in the mail so that it arrives on time. We found that part about the postal service is correct. But we also found that some states allow far more time to receive a mail-in ballot than others. And some states have ways to speed up the process, including drop off ballot boxes or allowing voters to drop off mail ballots at polling places. We also found it’s best to check with your local election officials about deadlines.
Sources: The National Conference of State Legislatures

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A patch on law enforcement officers in Portland is for “ZTI solutions, a PRIVATE contractor.”
Justification: The patch in the post reads "ZT1" — a unique identifier aimed at keeping the pictured U.S. Marshal anonymous. The acting commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection said federal agents in Portland don’t have names on their uniforms because some organizers have posted their personal information on the internet.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Walmart has just pledged $100 million to Black Lives Matter.”
Justification: Walmart pledged $100 million to create a racial equity center that "will support philanthropic initiatives" on the nation’s financial, healthcare, education and criminal justice systems." The money isn’t pledged to Black Lives Matter.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says the NIH “15 years ago published a study on chloroquine. It is effective against COVID-(1).”
Justification: The 2005 study wasn’t published by the NIH and didn’t prove chloroquine was effective against "COVID-1" because that’s not a real disease. The study found that chloroquine could inhibit the spread of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome in animal cell culture, and the authors said more research was needed. There are currently no approved medications or treatments for COVID-19.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Milwaukee police were protecting a sex offender's house and snuck children out of it after a mother tracked her missing daughter to that address.
Justification: Milwaukee police say they were protecting the residents of a home a crowd of people burned down believing it was a sex trafficking hub The house does not belong to a registered sex offender The two missing girls believed by the crowd to be at the house were found three miles away and denied ever being at the house

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “California has six extra” congressional representatives “because illegals are counted” in the census.
Justification: Experts estimate that California has two to four more seats in the U.S. House than it would if immigrants who are in the country illegally were excluded from census counts that are used to apportion seats. The Constitution mandates that all residents of the United States be counted in the census.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Mississippi got 10,145 warrants for unemployment fraud!!”
Justification: Mississippi Gov. Tate Reeves has warned of unemployment fraud related to COVID-19 in the state. Federal authorities have said such fraud has spiked. We found no evidence that Mississippi has secured or executed 10,145 warrants of any kind related to that unemployment fraud.
Sources: Statement from the U.S. Secret Service
Various searches on Google and Nexis

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Beirut bombing today was directly next to the Lebanon Central Bank, which is also owned by the most evil deep state family, the Rothschilds. There are no coincidences.”
Justification: An explosion at the port of Beirut was said to have occurred at a warehouse. Lebanese authorities have attributed it to the detonation of ammonium nitrate. There is no evidence as of this writing that the blast was premeditated. The Central Bank of Lebanon is located a few miles away from the site of the explosion. It has financial autonomy and gets its capital from the state, according to its website. The Rothschilds, the influential European banking family, have been a target of anti-Semitic conspiracies for centuries, including recently by QAnon groups. There is no evidence that they had anything to do with the Beirut explosion.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The longest filibuster in U.S. history was 75 days and “took place in 1964, when Democrats tried to block the Civil Rights Act.”
Justification: Southern Democrats held the longest filibuster in Senate history over the Civil Rights Act of 1964. But it wasn’t led by all Democrats, and the debate lasted 60 days, not 75. Many Democrats from non-Southern states supported the bill and helped end the debate.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Portland goon squads were Blackwater contractors not federal officers.”
Justification: We found no publicly available evidence that employees from Academi, a private military firm formerly known as Blackwater, or related companies have been deployed to quell protests in Portland instead of federal officers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Black Lives Matter "injures 1000 police officers kills 36 people and does $8 billion in damage."
Justification: We found no evidence that the toll from protests against police brutality is as high as the numbers in the post. The U.S. Justice Department told us it does not have numbers on officer injuries or property damage resulting from civil disturbances. Black Lives Matter protests attract not only BLM members but supporters and opponents, making it difficult to assign blame to BLM for particular incidents.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Target ended its “Heroes & Helpers” program that pairs children with police officers for holiday shopping trips.
Justification: A Target spokesperson said the company plans to continue the "Shop with a Cop" program, officially known as "Heroes & Helpers," an annual event pairing underserved children with officers to shop for holiday gifts.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Herman Cain died of cancer, not COVID-19.
Justification: Herman Cain died of complications from COVID-19 on July 30. In 2006, he was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer, which spread to his liver, but he recovered and went on to run for president in 2012.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The White House doctored a photo of a Donald Trump event “to make the crowd look bigger.”
Justification: A doctored image of an airport crowd greeting Trump in Tampa was posted by a Twitter user, who said he thought it was an obvious joke.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: A study from the CDC and the WHO “proves face masks do not prevent the spread of a virus.”
Justification: The study was done on influenza, which spreads in ways similar to COVID-19, but it makes no mention of COVID-19. The study was published by the CDC and supported by WHO, but it was done by the University of Hong Kong. One of the study’s authors told us the claim is incorrect.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s Emerging Infectious Diseases

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Bank of America just pledged $1 billion dollars to Black Lives Matter.
Justification: Bank of America announced it would donate $1 billion over four years to communities of color and minority-owned businesses affected by COVID-19. The bank did not pledge to contribute any money directly to the Black Lives Matter organization.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “No other country” is having a “second wave” of COVID-19 “because they are not trying to unseat a President in November.”
Justification: Some say the United States is in a second wave of the COVID-19 outbreak, but many experts believe it is still in the first. The United States is not alone in seeing a resurgence of coronavirus infections.
Sources: Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The Supreme Court ruled today NO VOTING BY MAIL !!!”
Justification: A popular Facebook post claimed that "the Supreme Court ruled today NO VOTING BY MAIL !!!" That's not what happened. In reality, the high court rejected an expansion of mail-in voting in Texas in late June. It also voted down an effort to make the practice easier in three counties in Alabama in early July. Those rulings don't take away existing rights to vote-by-mail in dozens of states across the nation.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The New York Times “published Tucker Carlson’s home address and location.”
Justification: The New York Times hasn’t published Tucker Carlson’s home address. Carlson accused the newspaper of revealing his address in an upcoming story but the Times says it never planned to and that Carlson knew that when he made the allegation on air.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Betsy Devos said "only" 0.02% of kids are likely to die when they go back to school.
Justification: DeVos’ office denied the claim and called the quote "a total lie." DeVos made several public appearances recently touting the safety of reopening schools in the fall, but there is no record of her ever saying this.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Quotes President Donald Trump as saying, “Everybody says I’ve done a tremendous job with COVID… I think a little gratitude would be nice. Maybe a big ‘Thank you Mr. President’ is called for.”
Justification: This quote can only be found in two opinion pieces that were originally published by the News-Times in Connecticut. Trump didn’t say this quote on the two dates the opinion pieces claimed he did, and there is no evidence he’s ever said it. The newspaper has clarified its post to say it cannot confirm the quote.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says COVID-19 testing could be done with mouth swabs, so maybe deeper swabbing is “implanting something.”
Justification: Nasal swabs are preferred over mouth swabs as a more accurate way of testing for COVID-19. There’s no evidence nasal swabs are used for "implanting something."
Sources: University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Michigan House “passes bill to ‘voluntarily’ begin placing human implantable microchips into the bodies of all state government employees”
Justification: • The Michigan House of Representatives recently passed a bill that would prevent companies from making implanted microchips mandatory for employees. It still needs to pass the Senate and be signed into law.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden has said 150 million Americans died from guns and another 120 million from COVID-19
Justification: A Facebook post said presidential candidate Joe Biden said 150 million people died from gun violence and 120 million people died from COVID-19 In February, Biden incorrectly said in the final Democratic primary debate that 150 million Americans have been killed with guns. Biden’s campaign admitted this was a mistake after the debate and the number was supposed to be 150,000 people. Presidential candidate Joe Biden incorrectly said on June 25 at a campaign event that 120 million people died from COVID-19. As of June 25, more than 119,000 died according to the Johns Hopkins Coronavirus Resource Center’s U.S. map. After making the ‘120 million’ claim, Biden immediately corrected himself. The Facebook ad was correct in that Biden made these claims. The numbers in these claims are incorrect.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says FEMA is giving essential workers $1,000.
Justification: This is a hoax.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Weis Food stores will no longer sell anything with the American flag and their employees can no longer wear anything with the flag.”
Justification: Employees of the Northeast chain Weis Markets must follow the company’s dress code, which means not decorating their uniforms with anything, including the American flag. This is not a new policy. The company says there is no flag ban.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Hillary Clinton is on trial, she (supposed) to have killed” a 10-year-old girl.
Justification: This claim is fabricated. Clinton is not on trial for any crime.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Amber Alerts are issued for white kids "but not Black kids in Milwaukee."
Justification: Nearly half of the 41 alerts issued since 2003 in Wisconsin were for Black children. Milwaukee police initiated more than one-fourth of all alerts, far more than any other agency. Every one of their 11 alerts was for a Black child.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Lists eight wealthy politicians and public figures who “got millions (or close to it) in PPP loans.”
Justification: The Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) is a loan that’s aimed at incentivizing businesses to keep workers on their payroll during the coronavirus pandemic. The Facebook post correctly characterizes how Kanye West, Jared Kushner’s family and Rep. Roger Williams are connected to companies that received money from that program. However, the post oversimplifies how Elaine Chao, Brad Parscale, Betsy DeVos and Devin Nunes benefited.
Sources: Clerk of the House of Representatives

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Businesses that refuse any legal tender can be fined and sued.
Justification: There is no federal requirement that businesses accept cash or coins as payment for goods and services. Several states and cities, however, require most businesses to accept cash.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Quotes Dr. Denis Mukwege as saying he resigned from the Congolese coronavirus response team because he was ordered to fabricate COVID-19 case and death numbers.
Justification: The quote is fabricated. Dr. Denis Mukwege said he resigned from Congo’s COVID-19 response team over inefficient testing and lax preventive measures, not because he was asked to falsify numbers.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Two stamps needed for mail-in ballots.”
Justification: When it comes to voting by mail, some states provide postage-paid ballots, but most don’t. Technically, voters are required to pay for postage if they don’t have a postage-paid ballot. But the U.S. Postal Service says its policy is to deliver mail ballots to election offices even if the ballots lack postage.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Quotes Joe Biden as saying “We need to teach our children the ISLAMIC FAITH in our schools!”
Justification: At a voter outreach event aimed at Muslims, Biden said, "I wish we taught more in our schools about the Islamic faith… about all the great confessional faiths." Conservative commentators said Biden was anti-Christian and against prayer in schools, leaving out the context of him talking about theology in general. Biden is Roman Catholic and has talked about how faith led him to run for public office. He has said he supports the separation of church and state.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says a leader of the Blackfeet Nation tribe designed the current Washington Redskins logo and once said it “made us all proud to have an Indian on a big-time team."
Justification: Former Blackfeet tribal chairman Walter Wetzel is credited as the driving force behind the creation of the team’s current logo, and the quote attributed to him is genuine. Since the team’s announcement, members of Wetzel’s family have said they’re sad to see the logo go but acknowledged the name change is "long overdue." While they don’t all agree, numerous Native American tribes, organizations and advocacy groups have called on the team to change its name and imagery.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Only 56 coronavirus deaths a day was enough to collapse the world economy, even though thousands of people die daily from tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and other diseases.
Justification: The post used March 9 as its date for coronavirus deaths, which was right before deaths soared. Subsequent daily totals show that coronavirus deaths have become larger than any other disease on the list. The coronavirus spreads through the air, there is no vaccine or treatment, and by now it’s established itself in most countries. So in many cases, limiting casual contact between people, including by economic shutdowns, may be the only effective way of stopping the virus’ spread.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says President Donald Trump tweeted that South Dakota needs to keep its border with California closed.
Justification: The tweet is fake. It doesn’t appear on his Twitter timeline, in Twitter searches or in a database of deleted tweets.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: The FBI uncovered "256 texts between Adam Schiff and Jeffrey Epstein"
Justification: The claim originated on a satirical website that carries a disclaimer that says all of its content is fiction.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “Teachers are the number one occupation of the antifa terrorist organization according to the FBI.”
Justification: The FBI has made no such public statement. Antifa is not a designated terrorist organization.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “You must apply to get your second stimulus check! I’ve already filed for mine and will be receiving $2,000 a month for the rest of the year.”
Justification: This is a hoax.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Quotes Anthony Fauci as writing, “I reject the notion that it’s ‘just a virus’ and we’ll all get it eventually. What a careless, lazy, heartless stance.”
Justification: Anthony Fauci didn’t write this. A Facebook user named Amy Wright has taken credit for the words.
Sources: Statement from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The CDC may have to stop calling COVID-19 an ‘epidemic’ due to a remarkably low death rate.”
Justification: Despite a dip in death rates, which are expected to rise again, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention still considers COVID-19 an epidemic. Death rates alone don’t determine whether an outbreak is an epidemic.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "New study: The flu vaccine is 'significantly associated' with an increased risk of coronavirus"
Justification: The study featured in the article is from 2019 and the data for it was collected in 2017-18, so it doesn’t include COVID-19 information. In past fact-checks, experts said this connection between the flu vaccine and other viruses is still speculative.
Sources: Email exchange with Richard M. Watanabe
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Tom Hanks was “arrested in Australia for pedophilia.”
Justification: Tom Hanks wasn’t arrested.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "Wrong" COVID-19 case count by Orlando Health "explains the 'outbreak' in Florida."
Justification: A Florida Department of Health website showed that one of Orlando Health’s 13 testing sites reported a 98% positive rate on 522 tests for COVID-19. Orlando Health said the positive rate for its system was about 10%. Some small labs have been reporting only positive results to the department, which says it is working with those labs to report all results. The rate of positive tests alone is not reflective of the size of the outbreak in Florida, which had 301,810 total cases and on July 12 set a national record for cases in one day.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “TEA is allowing online learning with attendance stipulations but will not fund school districts if they do not open their schools...If schools do not open and are not funded there will be no more teachers or school at all.”
Justification: N/A
Sources: Texas Education Agency " SY 20-21 Attendance and Enrollment FAQ
Texas Education Agency " SY 20-21 Public Health Planning Guidance

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: "China has been stealing our manufacturing, costing Wisconsin almost 90,000 jobs."
Justification: Wisconsin has lost more than 90,000 manufacturing jobs since 2001 The trade deficit with China did influence the loss of manufacturing jobs One study blamed nearly all U.S. manufacturing job loss on China, but several others say factors such as productivity played an equal or greater role.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: Says Melania Trump’s dress at Mount Rushmore speech was designed from “drawings of several young victims of sex trafficking.”
Justification: People on social media, not "the media," mocked the dress the first lady wore at President Donald Trump’s rally near Mount Rushmore. The dress was not designed based on the drawings of young people who had been sex trafficked.

Speaker: facebook-posts
Main Claim: “The spot where they are ‘getting a sample’ for the COVID-19 test is called your Blood-Brain Barrier.”
Justification: • The swabs used for COVID-19 tests collect samples from the nasopharynx.• Doctors say the swabs do not go anywhere near the blood-brain barrier.• There is also no evidence that getting a COVID-19 test could cause anything more serious than temporary irritation.
Sources: Interview with University of Michigan professor Dr. Sandro Cinti who specializes in infectious diseases
The National Center for Biotechnology Information
University of Queensland Queensland Brain Institute
